English: BCP Psalter, 1605
The i. day.
Manx: THE FIRST DAY

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Beatus vir qui non abijt. Psal.1.
Manx: Psal. 1. Beatus vir, qui non abiit.

English: Blessed is the man that hath not walked in the counsaile of the ungodly, nor stand in the way of sinners : and hath not sit in the seat of the scornefull.
Manx: 1 Bannit ta’n dooinney nagh vel er n’immeeaght ayns coyrle ny mee‐chrauee, ny er hassoo ayns raad peccee: as nagh vel er hoie ayns stoyl ny craidoilee;

English: stand] 1636 stood; sit] 1636 sate
2 But his delight is in the Law of the Lord : and in his Law will he exercise himselfe day and night.
Manx: 2 Agh ta e haitnys ayns leigh yn Chiarn: as ayns y leigh echeysyn nee eh eh hene y chliaghtey laa as oie.

English: 3 And hee shall bee like a tree planted by the water side : that wil bring foorth his fruit in due season.
Manx: 3 As bee eh myr billey soit rish oirr yn ushtey: ver magh e vess ayns imbagh cooie.

English: 4 His leafe also shall not wither : and looke whatsoever he doeth, it shall prosper.
Manx: 4 E ghuillag neesht cha jean fioghey: as jeeagh, cre‐erbee t’eh dy yannoo, te cheet lesh.

English: 5 As for the ungodly it is not so with them : but they are like the chaffe which the wind scattereth away from the face of the earth.
Manx: 5 Er son ny mee-chrauee, cha vel eh myr shen mâroosyn: agh t’ad goll‐rish y choau ta’n gheay dy heebey veih eddin y thallooin.

English: 6 Therefore the ungodly shall not be able to stand in the judgement : neither the sinners in the Congregation of the righteous.
Manx: 6 Shen‐y‐fa cha vod ny mee‐chrauee shassoo ayns y vriwnys: cha-moo ny peccee ayns chaglym y sleih ynrick.

English: 7 But the Lord knoweth the way of the righteous : and the way of the ungodly shall perish.
Manx: 7 Son shione da’n Chiarn raad y sleih cairal: as nee raad ny mee‐chrauee cherraghtyn.

English: Quare fremuerunt gentes? Psal. 2.
Manx: Psal. 2. Quare fremuerunt gentes?

English: Why doe the heathen so furiously rage together : and why doe the people imagine a vaine thing?
Manx: 1 Cre’n‐fa ta ny ashoonyn cha eulyssagh [sonnaasagh] girree-magh lesh-y-chielley: as cre hon ta’n sleih goaill red ommijagh ayns nyn gione.
[sonnaasagh] omitted in 1769, 1777; gione] 1765, 1769 ghione

English: 2 The Kings of the earth stand up, and the rulers take counsaile together : against the Lorde, and against his Anoynted:
Manx: 2 Ta reeaghyn y thallooin troggal seose, as ta ny fir‐reill goaill coyrle cooidjagh: noi’n Chiarn, as noi’n Fer‐ooilit echey.

English: 3 Let us breake their bonds asunder : and cast away their cordes from us.
Manx: 3 Lhig dooin brishey ny kainlaghyn oc veih my‐chielley: as y whing oc y cheau ersooyl j’in.

English: 4 He that dwelleth in heaven shall laugh them to scorne : the Lord shall have them in derision.
Manx: 4 Eshyn ta vaghey ayns niau gharys orroo lesh craid: bee ad ec y Chiarn ayns faghid.

English: 5 Then shal he speake unto them in his wrath : and vexe them in his sore displeasure:
Manx: 5 Eisht nee eh loayrt roo ayns e chorree: as ver eh sneih orroo ayns trimmid e yymmoose.

English: 6 Yet have I set my King : upon my holy hill of Sion.
Manx: 6 Agh ta mish er hoiaghey seose my Ree: er Sion my chronk casherick.

English: 7 I wil preach the Law whereof the Lord hath said unto me: thou art my Sonne, this day have I begotten thee.
Manx: 7 Nee’ms y leigh y phreacheil, my‐y‐chione ta’n Chiarn er ghra rhym: Uss my Vac, jiu yn laa ta mee er dty gheddyn.

English: 8 Desire of mee, and I shall give thee the Heathen for thine inheritance, : and the uttermost parts of the earth for thy possession.
Manx: 8 Shirr orrym, as ver‐ym dhyt ny ashoonyn son dty eiraght: as ny ayrnyn sodjey magh jeh’n theihll fo dty rere.

English: uttermost] 1662 utmost
9 Thou shalt bruise them with a rod of yron : and breake them in pieces like a potters vessell.
Manx: 9 Nee uss ad y vroo lesh lorg-reill dy yiarn: as brishey ad ayns peeshyn myr saagh craie.

English: 10 Be wise now therefore, O yee Kings : be learned yee that are Judges of the earth.
Manx: 10 Gow‐jee keeal nish er‐y‐fa shen, O shiuish reeaghyn: gow‐jee raaue, shiuish ta briwnyn y thallooin.

English: 11 Serve the Lord in feare : and rejoyce unto him with reverence.
Manx: 11 Shirveish‐jee yn Chiarn lesh aggle: as gow‐jee boggey ayn lesh arrym.

English: 12 Kisse the Sonne lest he be angry, and so ye perish from the right way : if his wrath be kindled (yea but a little) blessed are all they that put their trust in him.
Manx: 12 Cur‐jee ooashley da’n Mac, nagh bee eh jymmoosagh, as myr shen shiu dy herraghtyn veih’n raad cair: my vees e chorree er ny vrasnaghey, (agh ny veggan;) bannit t’adsyn ooilley ta coyrt nyn dreishteil aynsyn.
herraghtyn] 1765, 1769 cherraghtyn

English: Domine quid? Psal. 3.
Manx: Psal. 3. Domine, quid multiplicati?

English: Lord how are they encreased that trouble mee : many are they that rise against me.
Manx: 1 Hiarn, kys t’adsyn er nyn mishaghey ta dy my voirey: shimmey ad ta girree m’oï.
shimmey ad] 1819 shimmey t’ad

English: 2 Many one there be that say of my soule : there is no helpe for him in his God.
Manx: 2 Shimmey t’ayn ta gra jeh m’annym: Cha vel veg y chooney ny chour ayns e Yee.

English: 3 But thou, O Lord, art my defender : thou art my worship, and the lifter up of my head.
Manx: 3 Agh uss, O Hiarn, m’endeilagh: uss my ooashley, as y fer ta cummal seose my chione.

English: 4 I did call upon the Lord with my voice : and he heard me out of his holy hill.
Manx: 4 Deïe mee er y Chiarn lesh my choraa: as cheayll eh mee ass e chronk casherick.

English: 5 I laid me downe and slept, and rose up againe : for the Lord sustained me.
Manx: 5 Lhie mee sheese as chaddil mee, as dirree mee seose reesht: son ren y Chiarn m’y niartaghey.

English: 6 I will not bee afraid for ten thousands of the people : that have set themselves against me round about.
Manx: 6 Cha goyms aggle roish jeih millaghyn jeh’n sleih: ta er n’irree-magh m’oï er dy-chooilley cheu.[6]
cheu] 1819 heu

English: 7 Up Lorde, and helpe me, O my God : for thou smitest all mine enemies upon the cheeke bone; thou hast broken the teeth of the ungodly.
Manx: 7 Seose, Hiarn, as cooin lhiam, O my Yee: son t’ow bwoalley ooilley my noidyn er craue-ny-keeill; t’ow er vrishey feeacklyn ny mee‐chrauee.

English: 8 Salvation belongeth unto the Lord : and thy blessing is upon the people.
Manx: 8 Ta Saualtys bentyn gys y Chiarn: as ta dty vannaght er dty phobble.

English: the people] 1660 thy people (as 1539)
Cum inuocarem. Psal. 4.
Manx: Psal.4. Cum invocarem.

English: Heare me when I call, O God of my righteousnesse : for thou hast set me at libertie when I was in trouble; have mercie upon me, and hearken unto my prayer.
Manx: 1 Clasht rhym tra ta mee geamagh, O Yee my chairys: t’ow er choyrt feaysley dooys tra va mee ayns seaghyn; jean myghin orrym, as eaisht rish my phadjer.

English: for thou hast set] 1662 thou hast set
2 O ye sonnes of men, how long will ye blaspheme mine honour : and have such pleasure in vanitie, and seeke after leasing?
Manx: 2 O shiuish vec gheiney, caid nee shiu goltooan my ooashley: as goaill lheid y taitnys ayns coyrlyn fardalagh, as geiyrt da breagyn?

English: 3 Know this also, that the Lord hath chosen to himselfe the man that is godly : when I call upon the Lord, hee will hear me.
Manx: 3 Toigg‐jee shoh neesht, dy vel y Chiarn er reih da hene yn dooinney ta crauee: tra nee’m geamagh er y Chiarn, nee eh clashtyn rhym.

English: 4 Stand in awe and sinne not : commune with your owne heart, and in your chamber, and be still.
Manx: 4 Shass‐jee ayns aggle, as ny jean‐jee peccah: smooinee‐jee dy-dowin ayns nyn gree hene, as ayns nyn shamyr, as bee‐jee ec shee.

English: 5 Offer the sacrifice of righteousnesse : and put your trust in the Lord.
Manx: 5 Cheb‐jee yn oural dy chairys: as cur‐jee nyn dreishteil ayns y Chiarn.

English: 6 There be many that say : who wil shew us any good?
Manx: 6 Shimmey t’ayn ta gra: Quoi yeeaghys dooin veg y vie?

English: 7 Lord lift thou up : the light of thy Countenance upon us.
Manx: 7 Hiarn, trogg uss seose: soilshey dt’eddin orrin.

English: 8 Thou hast put gladnesse in my heart : since the time that their corne and wine and oyle increased.
Manx: 8 T’ow er choyrt gennallys ayns my chree: er dyn traa dy ren yn arroo, as y feeyn, as yn ooïll ocsyn bishaghey.

English: 9 I wil lay me downe in peace, and take my rest : for it is thou Lord onely, that makest me dwell in safetie.
Manx: 9 Nee’ms lhie sheese ayns shee, as goaill my ea: son she uss, Hiarn, dty lomarcan, ta coyrt orrym vaghey ayns sauchys.

English: Verba mea auribus. Psal. 5.
Manx: Psal. 5. Verba mea auribus.

English: Ponder my words, O Lord : consider my meditation.
Manx: 1 Cur geill da my ghoan, O Hiarn: gow tastey jeh smooinaghtyn dowin my chree.

English: 2 O hearken thou unto the voyce of my calling, my King and my God : for unto thee will I make my prayer.
Manx: 2 O eaisht rish coraa my eam, my Ree, as my Yee: son hoods nee’m my phadjer.

English: 3 My voice shalt thou heare betimes, O Lord : earely in the morning will I direct my prayer unto thee, and will looke up.
Manx: 3 My choraa clynnee uss dy-leah, O Hiarn: dy-moghey nee’ms my phadjer y hebbal hoods, as jeeaghyn seose.

English: 4 For thou art the God that hast no pleasure in wickednesse : neither shall any evill dwell with thee.
Manx: 4 Son she uss y Jee nagh vel veg y taitnys ayd ayns mee‐chraueeaght: cha‐moo nee olk erbee vaghey mârt.

English: 5 Such as be foolish shall not stand in thy sight : for thou hatest all them that worke vanitie.
Manx: 5 Cha jean nyn lheid as ta ommijagh shassoo ayns dty enish: son ta dwoaie ayd orroosyn ooilley ta jannoo mee‐chairys.

English: 6 Thou shalt destroy them that speake leasing : the Lord will abhore both the bloodthirstie and deceitfull man.
Manx: 6 Nee uss adsyn y stroie ta loayrt breagyn: ver y Chiarn feoh chammah da’n dooinney foalley as da’n er molteyragh.

English: 7 But as for mee, I will come into thy house, even upon the multitude of thy mercie : and in thy feare wil I worship toward thy holy Temple.
Manx: 7 Agh er my hon’s, hig‐ym gys dty hie, er eer ymmodee dty vyghin: as ayns dty aggle ver‐yms ooashley kiongoyrt rish dty hiamble casherick.

English: 8 Leade me, O Lord, in thy righteousnesse, because of mine enemies : make thy way plaine before my face.
Manx: 8 Leeid mee, O Hiarn, ayns dty chairys, kyndagh rish my noidyn: jean dty raad rea roish m’eddin.

English: 9 For there is no faithfulnesse in his mouth : their inward parts are very wickednesse.
Manx: 9 Son cha vel veg y firrinys ayns e veeal: ta ny ayrnyn cheu‐sthie oc eer olkys.

English: 10 Their throat is an open sepulchre : they flatter with their tongue.
Manx: 10 Ta’n scoarnagh oc oaie foshlit: t’ad brynnyraght lesh nyn jengey.

English: 11 Destroy thou them, O God; let them perish through their owne imaginations : cast them out in the multitude of their ungodlinesse, for they have rebelled against thee.
Manx: 11 Stroie uss adsyn O Yee; lhig daue cherraghtyn liorish nyn goyrlyn hene: tilg ad magh ayns ymmodee nyn mee‐chraueeaght; son t’ad er n’irree‐magh dt’oï.

English: 12 And let all them that put their trust in thee, rejoyce : they shall ever be giving of thankes, because thou defendest them, they that love thy Name shall be joyfull in thee;
Manx: 12 As lhig dauesyn ooilley ta coyrt nyn dreishteil ayn-yds, boggey ’ghoaill: bee adsyn dy-kinjagh coyrt booise, son dy vel oo fendeil ad; adsyn ta graihagh er dt’Ennym, vees laane dy voggey ayn-yds.

English: 13 For thou Lord wilt give thy blessing unto the righteous : and with thy favourable kindnes wilt thou defend him, as with a shield.
Manx: 13 Son ver uss, Hiarn, dty vannaght da’n fer‐cairal: as lesh dty chenjallys foayroil nee oo eshyn y endeil myr lesh eïlley‐caggee.

English: The i. day.
Manx: The 1. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Domine ne in furore. Psal. 6.
Manx: Psal. 6. Domine, ne.

English: O Lorde, rebuke me not in thine indignation : neither chasten me in thy displeasure.
Manx: 1 O Hiarn, ny cur oghsan dooys ayns dty chorree: cha-moo smaghtee mee ayns dty yymmoose.

English: 2 Have mercie upon me, O Lord, for I am weake : O Lord heale me, for my bones are vexed.
Manx: 2 Jean myghin orrym, O Hiarn, son ta mee annoon: O Hiarn, slaanee mee, son ta my chraueyn seaghnit.

English: 3 My soule is also sore troubled : but Lord, how long wilt thou punish mee?
Manx: 3 Ta sou‐aigney trome myrgeddin orrym: agh, Hiarn, caid nee oo mish y cherraghey?

English: is also] 1662 also is
4 Turne thee, O Lord, and deliver my soule : Oh save me for thy mercies sake.
Manx: 4 Chyndaa uss, O Hian, as livrey m’annym: O saue mee er graih dty vyghinyn.

English: 5 For in death no man remembreth thee : and who will give thee thankes in the pit?
Manx: 5 Son ayns baase cha vel dooinney erbee cooinaghtyn orts: as quoi ver moylley dhyts ayns yn oaie?

English: 6 I am wearie of my groning; every night wash I my bed : and water my couch with my teares.
Manx: 6 Ta mee deïnagh lesh gaccan; dy-chooilley oie ta mee gushtaghey my lhiabbee: as fluighey my lhiaght lesh my yeïr.

English: 7 My beautie is gone for very trouble : and worne away because of all mine enemies.
Manx: 7 Ta my aalid er n’immeeaght lesh eer seaghyn: as er ny lheïe ersooyl kyndagh rish ooilley my noidyn.

English: 8 Away from me all ye that worke vanitie : for the Lord hath heard the voice of my weeping.
Manx: 8 Ersooyl voym shiuish ooilley ta gobbraghey molteyrys: son ta’n Chiarn er chlashtyn coraa my ghobberan.

English: 9 The Lord hath heard my petition : the Lord will receive my prayer.
Manx: 9 Ta’n Chiarn er chlashtyn my accan: nee’n Chiarn soiaghey jeh my phadjer.

English: 10 All mine enemies shall be confounded and sore vexed : they shal be turned backe and put to shame suddenly.
Manx: 10 Bee ooilley my noidyn er nyn stroie as dy-trome seaghnit: chyndaa‐ee ad nyn gooyl, as hig ad gys nearey doaltattym.
gooyl] 1765, 1769 gool

English: Domine Deus meus. Psal. 7
Manx: Psal. 7. Domine, Deus meus.

English: O Lorde my God, in thee have I put my trust : save mee from all them that persecute me, and deliver me;
Manx: 1 O Hiarn my Yee, ayn-yds ta mee er choyrt my hreishteil: saue mee vowesyn ooilley ta jannoo tranlaase orrym, as livrey mee;

English: 2 Lest he devoure my soule like a Lion, and teare it in pieces : while there is none to helpe.
Manx: 2 Er aggle dy stroie eh my vioys myr lion, as eh y raipey dy peeshyn: choud as nagh vel unnane dy chooney lhiam.

English: 3 O Lord my God, if I have done any such thing : or if there be any wickednesse in my hands;
Manx: 3 O Hiarn my Yee, my ta mee er n’yannoo veg dy lheid y red: ny my ta olkys erbee ayns my laueyn;

English: 4 If I have rewarded evill unto him that dealt friendly with mee : yea, I have delivered him that without any cause is mine enemie;
Manx: 4 My ta mee er chooilleeney olk dasyn ren dellal dy-dooie rhym: (ta mee eer er livrey eshyn ta my noid fegooish oyr;)

English: 5 Then let mine enemy persecute my soule, and take me : yea, let him tread my life downe upon the earth, and lay mine honour in the dust.
Manx: 5 Eisht lhig da my noid eiyrtys y yannoo er m’annym, as m’y ghoaill: dy-jarroo lhig da my vioys y stampey sheese er y thalloo, as cur my onnor ny lhie ’sy joan.

English: 6 Stand up, O Lord, in thy wrath, and lift up thy selfe : because of the indignation of mine enemies, arise up for me in the Judgement that thou hast commanded.
Manx: 6 Irree, O Hiarn, ayns dty chorree, as trogg oo hene seose, kyndagh rish farg my noidyn: shass er my hon ayns y vriwnys t’ow er haarey.

English: 7 And so shall the congregation of the people come about thee : for their sakes therefore lift up thy selfe againe.
Manx: 7 As myr shen hig chaglym y phobble mygeayrt‐y‐mood: er y ghraih ocsyn eisht trogg seose oo hene reesht.

English: 8 The Lord shall judge the people; give sentence with me, O Lord : according to my righteousnesse, and according to the innocencie that is in me.
Manx: 8 Nee’n Chiarn yn pobble y vriwnys; cur briwnys lhiam, O Hiarn: lurg my ynrickys, as cordail rish y neu-loghtynid t’ayn-ym.

English: 9 O let the wickednesse of the ungodly come to an ende : but guide thou the just.
Manx: 9 O lhig da olkys ny mee‐chrauee cheet gys jerrey: agh jean uss yn sleih ynrick y leeideil.

English: 10 For the righteous God : trieth the very hearts & reines.
Manx: 10 Son ta’n Jee cairal: prowal ny creeaghyn, as ny meeaghyn.

English: 11 My help commeth of God : which preserveth them that are true of heart.
Manx: 11 Ta my chooney cheet veih Jee: ta coadey adsyn ta ynrick ayns cree.

English: which] 1662 who
12 God is a righteous Judge, strong and patient : and God is provoked every day.
Manx: 12 Ta Jee briw cairagh, niartal as surransagh: as ta Jee er ny vrasnaghey dy-chooilley laa.

English: 13 If a man will not turne, he will whet his sword : hee hath bent his bow, and made it ready.
Manx: 13 Mannagh jean dooinney chyndaa, nee eh shleeu e chliwe: t’eh er lhoobey e vhow, as er n’yannoo eh aarloo.

English: 14 He hath prepared for him the instruments of death : he ordeineth his arrowes against the persecuters.
Manx: 14 T’eh er chiarail ny chour ny greinyn baaish: t’eh coyrt magh e hideyn noi ny tranlaasee.

English: 15 Behold, he travaileth with mischiefe : hee hath conceived sorrow, and brought foorth ungodlinesse.
Manx: 15 Cur‐my‐ner, t’eh er‐troailt er olkys: t’eh er yiennaghtyn trimshey, as er n’ymmyrkey mee‐chairys.

English: 16 He hath graven and digged up a pit : and is fallen himselfe into the destruction that he made for other.
Manx: 16 T’eh er vosley as er chleï ooig: as t’eh hene er duittym ayns y ribbeh v’eh kiarail da fer elley.
v’eh kiarail] 1765, 1769 ve kiarail

English: 17 For his travaile shall come upon his owne head : and his wickednesse shall fall on his owne pate.
Manx: 17 Son hig e obbyr er e chione hene: as tuittee yn olkys echey er e vollag hene.

English: 18 I will give thankes unto the Lord, according to his righteousnesse : and will prayse the Name of the Lord the most High.
Manx: 18 Ver‐yms booise da’n Chiarn, cordail rish e chairys: as nee’ms moylley Ennym y Chiarn smoo Ard.

English: Domine Dominus. Psal. 8.
Manx: Psal. 8. Domine, Dominus noster.

English: O Lord our governour, how excellent is thy Name in all the world : thou that hast set thy glory above the heavens.
Manx: 1 O Hiarn, nyn Giannoort, cre cha ooasle ta dt’Ennym trooid ooilley yn theihll: uss ta er hoiaghey dty ghloyr er-skyn ny niaughyn!
Giannoort] 1765, 1769 Ghiannoort

English: 2 Out of the mouth of very babes and sucklings hast thou ordeined strength, because of thine enemies : that thou mightest still the enemie and the avenger.
Manx: 2 Magh ass eer beïll oikanyn as cloan er y cheeagh t’ow er n’oardaghey niart, kyndagh rish dty noidyn: dy voddagh oo yn noid, as yn eulyssagh y chastey.

English: 3 For I will consider the heavens, even the works of thy fingers : the Moone and the Starres which thou hast ordeined.
Manx: 3 Son goym tastey jeh dty niaughyn, eer obbraghyn dty veïr: yn eayst as ny rollaagyn t’ow er n’oardaghey.

English: the heavens] 1662 thy heavens (as 1562)
4 What is man that thou art mindefull of him : and the sonne of man, that thou visitest him?
Manx: 4 Cre ta dooinney, dy vel oo aggindagh er: as mac y dooinney dy vel oo jeeaghyn er?
aggindagh] 1765 aigindagh

English: 5 Thou madest him lower then the Angels : to crowne him with glory and worship.
Manx: 5 Ren oo eh ny s’inshley na ny ainlyn: dy chomm’rey eh lesh gloyr as ooashley.

English: 6 Thou makest him to have dominion of the workes of thy handes : and thou hast put all things in subjection under his feete;
Manx: 6 T’ow coyrt dasyn yn reill harrish obbraghyn dty laueyn: as er choyrt dy-chooilley nhee ayns biallys fo e chassyn;

English: 7 All sheepe and oxen : yea and the beasts of the field;
Manx: 7 Dy-chooilley cheyrrey as dow: as myrgeddin beïyn y vagher;

English: 8 The foules of the aire, and the fishes of the sea : and whatsoever walketh through the paths of the Seas.
Manx: 8 Eeanlee yn aer, as eeastyn ny marrey: as cre‐erbee ta snaaue trooid raaidyn ny faarkaghyn.

English: 9 O Lord our governour : how excellent is thy Name in all the world!
Manx: 9 O Hiarn nyn Giannoort: cre cha ooasle ta dt’Ennym ayns ooilley yn seihll!
Ghiannoort] 1765, 1769 Ghiannoort

English: The ii. day.
Manx: The 2. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Confitebor tibi. Psal. 9.
Manx: Psal. 9. Confitebor tibi.

English: I will give thankes unto thee, O Lord, with my whole heart : I will speake of all thy marveilous workes.
Manx: 1 Ver‐yms booise dhyts, O Hiarn, lesh ooilley my chree: loayr‐ym jeh ooilley dty obbraghyn mirrillagh.

English: 2 I will bee glad and rejoyce in thee : yea, my songs will I make of thy Name, O thou most Highest.
Manx: 2 Bee’ms gennal as goym boggey ayn-yds: dy-jarroo, my arraneyn nee’m y yannoo jeh dt’Ennym, O Uss smoo Ard.

English: 3 While mine enemies are driven backe : they shall fall and perish at thy presence.
Manx: 3 Choud as ta my noidyn er nyn imman ersooyl: nee ad tuittym as cherraghtyn ec dt’enish.

English: 4 For thou hast maintained my right, & my cause : thou art set in the Throne that judgest right.
Manx: 4 Son t’ow er vendeil my chairys as my chooish: t’ow dty hoie er stoyl‐reeoil dy vriwnys cairagh.
dty hoie] 1765, 1769 dy hoie

English: 5 Thou hast rebuked the Heathen, and destroyed the ungodly : thou hast put out their Name for ever and ever.
Manx: 5 T’ow er choyrt oghsan da ny ashoonyn, as er stroie ny mee‐chrauee: t’ow er choyrt ass yn ennym oc son dy-bragh as dy-bragh.

English: 6 O thou enemie, destructions are come to a perpetuall ende : even as the cities which thou hast destroyed, their memoriall is perished with them.
Manx: 6 O uss noid, ta traartyssyn er jeet gys slane jerrey: eer myr ny ard‐valjyn t’ow er stroie; ta’n imraa oc er gholl naardey mâroo.

English: 7 But the Lord shall endure for ever : hee hath also prepared his seat for Judgement.
Manx: 7 Agh ta’n Chiarn farraghtyn son dy-bragh: t’eh myrgeddin er chiarail e stoyl‐reeoil son briwnys.

English: 8 For he shall judge the world in righteousnesse : and minister true Judgement unto the people.
Manx: 8 Son nee eh yn seihll y vriwnys ayns cairys: as shirveish briwnys firrinagh er y pobble.

English: 9 The Lord also will be a defence for the oppressed : even a refuge in due time of trouble.
Manx: 9 Bee yn Chiarn neesht fendeilys dauesyn ta tranlaasit: dy-jarroo kemmyrk ayns y traa cooie dy heaghyn.

English: 10 And they that know thy Name, will put their trust in thee : for thou, Lord, hast never failed them that seeke thee.
Manx: 10 As adsyn shione daue dt’Ennym, ver nyn dreishteil ayn-yds: son cha vel uss, Hiarn, rieau er hreigeil adsyn ta dy dty hirrey.

English: 11 O praise the Lord which dwelleth in Sion : shew the people of his doings.
Manx: 11 O moylley‐jee yn Chiarn ta vaghey ayns Sion: soilshee‐jee da’n pobble cre t’eh er n’yannoo.

English: 12 For when he maketh inquisition for blood, hee remembreth them : and forgetteth not the complaint of the poore.
Manx: 12 Son tra t’eh jannoo briaght son deayrtey fuill dyn loght, t’eh cooinaghtyn orroo: as cha vel eh jarrood accan ny ymmyrchee.

English: 13 Have mercy upon mee, O Lord; consider the trouble which I suffer of them that hate me : thou that liftest me up from the gates of death.
Manx: 13 Jean myghin orrym, O Hiarn; smooinee er y seaghyn ta mee dy hurranse lioroosyn ta dwoaie oc orrym: uss ta dy my hroggal seose veih giattyn y vaaish;
dy hurranse] 1819 er hurranse

English: 14 That I may shew all thy praises within the ports of the daughter of Sion : I will rejoyce in thy salvation.
Manx: 14 Dy voddym soilshaghey ooilley dty voylley cheu‐sthie jeh giattyn inneen Sion: nee’ms boggey ’ghoaill ayns dty haualtys.

English: 15 The heathen are sunke down in the pit that they made : in the same net which they hid privily, is their foote taken.
Manx: 15 Ta ny ashoonyn er duittym sheese ayns yn ooig t’ad hene er n’yannoo: ayns y ribbeh cheddin dollee ad dy-follit, ta’n chass oc hene er ny ghoaill.

English: 16 The Lord is knowen to execute Judgement : the ungodly is trapped in the worke of his owne hands.
Manx: 16 Ta fys ain dy vel y Chiarn cooilleeney briwnys: ta’n mee‐chrauee er ny chassey ayns obbyr e laueyn hene.

English: 17 The wicked shall bee turned into hell : and all the people that forget God.
Manx: 17 Bee ny drogh‐yantee er nyn jyndaa gys niurin: as ooilley yn sleih ta jarrood Jee.

English: 18 For the poore shall not alway be forgotten : the patient abiding of the meeke shall not perish for ever.
Manx: 18 Son cha bee’n boght dy-kinjagh er ny yarrood: cha jean farkiaght surransagh ny imlee cherraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 19 Up Lord, and let not man have the upper hand : let the Heathen be judged in thy sight.
Manx: 19 Trogg ort, Hiarn, as ny lhig da dooinney laue yn eaghtyr y gheddyn: lhig da ny ashoonyn v’er nyn mriwnys ayns dty hilley.

English: 20 Put them in feare (O Lord) : that the heathen may know themselves to be but men.
Manx: 20 Cur ad ayns aggle, O Hiarn: dy vod fys ’ve ec ny ashoonyn nagh vel ad hene agh deiney.

English: Vt quid Domine. Psal. 10.
Manx: Psal. 10. Ut quid, Domine.

English: Why standest thou so farre off (O Lord) : and hidest thy face in the needfull time of trouble?
Manx: 1 Cre hon t’ow shassoo choud jeh, O Hiarn: as follaghey dt’eddin ayns y traa fêmoil dy heaghyn?

English: 2 The ungodly for his owne lust doeth persecute the poore : let them bee taken in the craftie wilinesse that they have imagined.
Manx: 2 Ta’n mee‐chrauee dy chooilleeney e aigney hene jannoo tranlaase er y voght: lhig daue hene ve goit ayns ny kialgyn croutagh t’ad er ghoaill ayns nyn smooinaghtyn.

English: 3 For the ungodly hath made boast of his owne hearts desire : and speaketh good of the covetous whom God abhorreth.
Manx: 3 Son ta’n dooinney mee‐chrauee er voggyssagh jeh yeearree e chree hene: as loayrt dy-mie jeh’n er sayntoilagh ta feoh ec Jee er.

English: 4 The ungodly is so proud, that hee careth not for God : neither is God in all his thoughts.
Manx: 4 Ta’n mee‐chrauee cha mooaralagh, nagh vel geill echey da Jee: cha-moo ta Jee ayns ooilley e smooinaghtyn.

English: 5 His wayes are alway grievous : thy Judgements are farre above out of his sight, and therefore defieth he all his enemies.
Manx: 5 Ta ny raaidyn echey kinjagh seaghnagh: ta dty vriwnyssyn foddey er-skyn roshtyn e hilley, as er yn oyr shen t’eh cur‐y‐laan fo ooilley e noidyn.

English: 6 For he hath said in his heart, Tush, I shall never bee cast downe : there shall no harme happen unto me.
Manx: 6 Son t’eh er ghra ayns e chree, Cha n’aggle dou, cha bee’m dy-bragh er my hilgey sheese: cha daghyr skielley erbee my raad.

English: 7 His mouth is full of cursing, deceit, and fraud : under his tongue is ungodlinesse and vanitie.
Manx: 7 Ta’n beeal echey laane dy ghweeaghyn, dy oalsaght as molteyrys: fo e hengey ta mee‐chraueeaght as fardail.

English: 8 He sitteth lurking in the theevish corners of the streets : and privily in his lurking dennes doeth he murther the innocent; his eyes are set against the poore.
Manx: 8 T’eh soie fo‐chlea myr maarliagh ayns corneilyn fadaan ny straaidyn: as dy-follit ayns e oayldyn dorraghey t’eh dunverys yn dooinney gyn loght; ta e hooillyn soit noi’n voght.

English: 9 For hee lyeth waiting secretly, even as a Lion lurketh he in his denne : that he may ravish the poore.
Manx: 9 Son t’eh lhie farkiaght dy-follit, dy-jarroo myr lion t’eh ny lhie kellit ayns e ooig: dy vod eh spooilley yn boght.

English: 10 He doeth ravish the poore : when hee getteth him into his net.
Manx: 10 T’eh jannoo niart er y voght: tra t’eh tayrtyn eh ayns e ribbeh.

English: 11 He falleth downe, and humbleth himselfe : that the congregation of the poore may fall into the handes of his Captaines.
Manx: 11 T’eh tuittym sheese, as crommey eh hene: dy vod sheshaght ny boghtyn tuittym ayns laueyn e leeideilee.

English: 12 He hath said in his heart, Tush, God hath forgotten : he hideth away his face, and he will never see it.
Manx: 12 T’eh er ghra ayns e chree, Cha vel aggle orrym, ta Jee er yarrood: t’eh follaghey e eddin, as cha der eh dy-bragh geill da.

English: 13 Arise (O Lord God) and lift up thine hand : forget not the poore.
Manx: 13 Irree, O Hiarn Yee, as trogg seose dty laue: ny jarrood yn boght.

English: 14 Wherefore should the wicked blaspheme God : while he doeth say in his heart, Tush, thou God carest not for it?
Manx: 14 Cre’n‐fa yinnagh y dooinney olkyssagh loayrt dy-mollaghtagh noi Jee: choud as t’eh gra ayns e chree, Cha vel aggle orrym, s’cummey lhiats, O Yee, er y hon.

English: 15 Surely thou hast seene it : for thou beholdest ungodlinesse and wrong.
Manx: 15 Shickyr t’ow er vakin eh: son t’ow goaill tastey jeh mee‐chraueeaght as aggair.

English: 16 That thou mayest take the matter into thine hand : the poore committeth himselfe unto thee; for thou art the helper of the friendlesse.
Manx: 16 Dy vod oo goaill y chooish ayns dty laue hene: ta’n boght coyrt e varrant hoods; son uss yn fer‐coonee ocsyn ta gyn caarjyn.

English: 17 Breake thou the power of the ungodly and malicious : take away his ungodlinesse and thou shalt finde none.
Manx: 17 Brish uss pooar yn mee‐chrauee as goanlyssagh: gow ersooyl yn vee‐chraueeaght echey, nagh bee veg jeh ry-gheddyn.

English: 18 The Lord is King for ever and ever : and the heathen are perished out of the land.
Manx: 18 Ta’n Chiarn ny Ree son dy-bragh as dy-bragh: as ta ny ashoonyn er cherraghtyn ass y cheer.
cherraghtyn] 1777 herraghtyn; 1819 jerraghtyn

English: 19 Lord, thou hast heard the desire of the poore : thou preparest their heart, and thine eare hearkeneth thereto;
Manx: 19 Hiarn, t’ow er chlashtyn yeearree ny boghtyn: t’ow niartaghey ny creeaghyn oc, as ta dty chleaysh geaishtagh roo;

English: 20 To helpe the fatherlesse and poore unto their right : that the man of the earth be no more exalted against them.
Manx: 20 Dy chooney lesh y chloan gyn ayr as y boght gys nyn gair: nagh bee yn dooinney seihltagh ny sodjey er ny hoiaghey seose nyn ’oï.

English: In Domino confido. Psal. 11.
Manx: Psal. 11. In Domino confido.

English: In the Lord put I my trust : how say yee then to my soule, that she should flee as a bird unto the hill?
Manx: 1 Ayns y Chiarn ta mish cur my hreishteil, kys dy vel shiu gra eisht rish m’annym, ee dy chosney ersooyl myr eean gys y chronk?

English: flee] flie 1660, flee 1662 (as also 1599)
2 For loe, the ungodly bend their bow, and make readie their arrowes within the quiver : that they may privily shoot at them which are true of heart.
Manx: 2 Son cur‐my‐ner, ta ny mee‐chrauee loobey nyn mhow, as jannoo aarloo nyn sideyn ayns y whiver: dy vod ad lhiggey gyn-yss orroosyn ta ynrick ayns cree.

English: 3 For the foundations wil be cast downe : and what hath the righteous done?
Manx: 3 Son bee ny undinyn er nyn dilgey sheese: as cre oddys y vooinjer chairagh y yannoo?

English: 4 The Lord is in his holy Temple : the Lords seate is in heaven.
Manx: 4 Ta’n Chiarn ayns e hiamble casherick: ta stoyl‐reeoil y Chiarn ayns niau;

English: 5 His eyes consider the poore : and his eye lids tryeth the children of men.
Manx: 5 Ta ny sooillyn echey goaill tastey jeh’n voght: as ferroogh e hooillyn prowal cloan gheiney.

English: 6 The Lord alloweth the righteous : but the ungodly, and him that delighteth in wickednes, doth his soule abhorre.
Manx: 6 Ta’n Chiarn lowal jeh’n sleih cairagh: agh ta dwoaie ec e annym er y vee‐chrauee, as ersyn ta sleeuit er olkys.

English: 7 Upon the ungodly he shall raine snares, fire and brimstone, storme and tempest : this shal be their portion to drinke.
Manx: 7 Er ny mee‐chrauee deayrtee eh ribbaghyn, aile as brimstone, sterrym as dorrin: shoh vees y cronney ocsyn dy iu.

English: 8 For the righteous Lorde loveth righteousnesse : his countenance will behold the thing that is just.
Manx: 8 Son ta’n Chiarn cairal graihagh er cairys: as ver e eddin my‐ner shen ny ta kiart.

English: The ii. day.
Manx: The 2. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Saluum me fac. Psal. 12.
Manx: Psal. 12. Salvum me fac.

English: Help me Lorde, for there is not one godly man left : for the faithfull are minished from among the children of men.
Manx: 1 Cooin lhiam, Hiarn, son cha vel un dooinney crauee faagit: son cha vel y vooinjer ynrick agh beggan mastey cloan gheiney.
beggan] 1769, 1777 goaun

English: 2 They talke of vanitie every one with his neighbour : they doe but flatter with their lips, and dissemble in their double heart.
Manx: 2 T’ad taggloo jeh fardail dagh unnane rish e naboo: cha vel ad agh brynnyraght lesh nyn meillyn, as jannoo molteyrys ayns nyn gree dooble.

English: 3 The Lord shall roote out all deceitfull lips : and the tongue that speaketh proud things;
Manx: 3 Ver y Chiarn mow ooilley ny meillyn molteyragh: as y chengey ta loayrt goan mooaralagh;

English: 4 Which have said, With our tongues wee wil prevaile : we are they that ought to speake, who is lord over us?
Manx: 4 Adsyn ta er ghra, Lesh nyn jengey yiow mayd barriaght: shin hene lhisagh loayrt; quoi ta ny Hiarn harrin?

English: wee wil] 1662 will we
5 Nowe for the comfortlesse troubles sake of the needie : and because of the deepe sighing of the poore,
Manx: 5Nish er graih seaghyn vee‐gherjoil ny ymmyrchee: as er son osnaghyn trommey ny boghtyn;

English: 6 I will up (sayth the Lord) : and will helpe every one from him that swelleth against him, and will set them at rest.
Manx: 6 Trogg‐ym orrym, ta’n Chiarn dy ghra: as ver‐ym feaysley da dagh unnane veihsyn ta gatt n’oï, as ver‐ym eh gys fea.

English: them] 1662 him
7 The wordes of the Lord are pure words : even as the silver, which from the earth is tried, and purified seven times in the fire.
Manx: 7 Ta goan y Chiarn goan glen: dy-jarroo myr yn argid, ta er ny ghlenney veih’n ooir, as er ny lheïe shiaght keayrtyn ayns yn aile.

English: 8 Thou shalt keepe them, O Lord : thou shalt preserve him from this generation for ever.
Manx: 8 Nee oo ad y reaylley, O Hiarn: nee oo adsyn y choadey veih’n sheeloghe shoh son dy-bragh.

English: 9 The ungodly walke on every side : when they are exalted, the children of men are put to rebuke.
Manx: 9 Ta ny mee‐chrauee gimmeeaght er dy-chooilley cheu: tra t’adsyn er nyn soiaghey seose, ta cloan gheiney er nyn goyrt fo.
cheu] 1819 heu; fo] 1769, 1777 fo chosh.

English: Vsquequo Domine. Psal. 13.
Manx: Psal. 13. Usque quo, Domine.

English: How long wilt thou forget mee (O Lord) for ever : how long wilt thou hide thy face from me?
Manx: 1 Caid nee oo m’y yarrood, O Hiarn, nee son dy-bragh? caid nee oo follaghey dt’eddin voym?

English: 2 How long shall I seeke counsell in my soule, and be so vexed in my heart : how long shall mine enemies triumph over me?
Manx: 2 Caid nee’m coyrle y hirrey ayns m’annym, as ve cha seaghnit ayns my chree: caid vees my noidyn boggyssagh harrym?

English: 3 Consider, and heare me, O Lord my God : lighten mine eyes, that I sleepe not in death.
Manx: 3 Smooinee orrym, as eaisht rhym, O Hiarn my Yee: soilshee my hooillyn, nagh gadlym ayns baase;

English: 4 Lest mine enemie say, I have prevailed against him : for if I be cast downe, they that trouble me, will rejoyce at it.
Manx: 4 Er aggle dy jir my noid, Ta mee er gheddyn y varriaght er: son my vee’m er my hilgey sheese, nee adsyn ta dy my heaghney boggey ’ghoaill jeh.

English: 5 But my trust is in thy mercie : and my heart is joyfull in thy salvation.
Manx: 5 Agh ta my hreishteil ayns dty vyghin: as nee my chree boggey ’ghoaill ayns dty haualtys.

English: 6 I wil sing of the Lord, because hee hath delt so lovingly with me : yea, I will praise the Name of the Lord most Highest.
Manx: 6 Nee’ms arrane y ghoaill jeh’n Chiarn, son dy vel eh er ghellal rhym er aght cha graihagh: dy-jarroo ver‐ym moylley da Ennym y Chiarn smoo Ard.

English: Dixit insipiens. Psal. 14.
Manx: Psal. 14. Dixit insipiens.

English: The foole hath said in his heart : there is no God.
Manx: 1 Ta’n ommydan er ghra ayns e chree: Cha vel Jee erbee.

English: 2 They are corrupt and become abominable in their doings : there is not one that doeth good (no not one).
Manx: 2 T’ad er jeet dy ve feer vee‐chrauee, as dwoaiagh ayns nyn yannoo: cha vel unnane erbee ta jannoo dy-mie, cha vel unnane.

English: there is not one] 1662 there is none
3 The Lord looked downe from heaven upon the children of men : to see if there were any that would understand and seeke after God.
Manx: 3 Yeeagh y Chiarn neose veih niau er cloan gheiney: dy akin row veg jeu yinnagh toiggal, as shirrey lurg Jee.

English: 4 But they are all gone out of the way, they are altogether become abominable : there is none that doeth good, no not one.
Manx: 4 Agh t’ad ooilley er gholl magh ass y raad, t’ad ooilley‐cooidjagh er jeet dy ve feohdoil: cha vel unnane ta jannoo dy mie, cha vel eer unnane.
magh] missing in 1769, 1777

English: 5 Their throat is an open sepulchre, with their tongues have they deceived : the poison of aspes is under their lips.
Manx: 5 Ta’n scoarnagh oc oaie foshlit; lesh nyn jengey t’ad er volley: ta pyshoon ard-nieughyn fo nyn meillyn.

English: 6 Their mouth is full of cursing and bitternesse : their feet are swift to shed blood.
Manx: 6 Ta’n beeal oc laane dy ghweeaghyn as dy herriuid: ta ny cassyn oc tappee dy gheayrtey fuill.

English: 7 Destruction and unhappinesse is in their wayes, and the way of peace have they not knowen : there is no feare of God before their eyes.
Manx: 7 Ta toyrt‐mow as mee‐vaynrys ayns nyn raaidyn, as raad y chee cha bione daue: cha vel aggle erbee dy Yee roish nyn sooillyn.

English: 8 Have they no knowledge, that they are all such workers of mischief : eating up my people as it were bread?
Manx: 8 Vel veg y tushtey oc, dy vel ad ooilley myr shoh cur rish olkys: gee seose my phobble myr arran, as cha vel ad geamagh er y Chiarn?

English: 9 And call not upon the Lord, there were they brought in great feare, (even where no feare was) : for God is in the generation of the righteous.
Manx: 9 Shen y raad v’ad er nyn goyrt lhieu ayns aggle vooar, dy-jarroo raad nagh row veg yn aggle: son ta Jee ayns sheeloghe y sleih cairal.

English: And call not upon the Lord] 1662 this clause is restored to the end of v. 8, where it belongs, and was in the 1539 Great Bible.
10 As for you, ye have made a mocke at the counsaile of the poore : because he putteth his trust in the Lord.
Manx: 10 Er nyn son euish, ta shiu er n’yannoo craid er coyrle y voght: er‐yn‐oyr dy vel eh coyrt e hreishteil ayns y Chiarn.

English: 11 Who shal give salvation unto Israel out of Sion? when the Lord turneth the captivitie of his people : then shall Jacob rejoyce, and Israel shall be glad.
Manx: 11 Quoi ver Saualtys da Israel magh ass Sion? Tra ta’n Chiarn chyndaa cappeeys e phobble: eisht gowee Jacob boggey, as bee Israel gennal.

English: The iii. day.
Manx: The 3. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Domine quis habitabit. Psal. 15.
Manx: Psal. 15. Domine, quis habitabit?

English: Lord, who shal dwell in thy tabernacle : or who shall rest upon thy holy hill?
Manx: 1 Hiarn, quoi nee vaghey ayns dty chabbane‐agglish: ny quoi vees ec fea er dty chronk chasherick?
vees ec fea] 1769, 1777 nee cummal

English: 2 Even he that leadeth an uncorrupt life : and doeth the thing which is right, and speaketh the trueth from his heart.
Manx: 2 Eshyn dy-jarroo ta leeideil bea ôney: as ta jannoo yn red ta jeeragh, as ta loayrt yn irriney veih e chree.

English: 3 Hee that hath used no deceit in his tongue, nor done evill to his neighbour : and hath not slandered his neighbours.
Manx: 3 Eshyn nagh vel er chliaghtey molteyraght erbee ayns e hengey, ny er n’yannoo olk da e naboo: as nagh vel er chooyl‐chassid e naboo.

English: neighbours] 1660 neighbor
Manx: chooyl-] 1765, 1769 cooyl-

English: 4 He that setteth not by himselfe, but is lowly in his owne eyes : and maketh much of them that feare the Lord.
Manx: 4 Eshyn nagh vel soiaghey jeh hene, agh ta imlee ayns e hooillyn hene: as jannoo mooar jeusyn ta goaill aggle roish y Chiarn.

English: 5 He that sweareth unto his neighbour, and disappointeth him not : though it were to his owne hinderance.
Manx: 5 Eshyn ta lhoo da e naboo, as nagh vel dy volley eh: ga dy beagh eh gys e choayl hene.

English: 6 He that hath not given his money upon usurie : nor taken reward against the innocent.
Manx: 6 Eshyn nagh vel er choyrt magh e argid er use: ny er ghoaill leagh noi’n persoon gyn loght.

English: 7 Who so doeth these things : shall never fall.
Manx: 7 Eh ta jannoo myr shoh: cha jean eh dy-bragh tuittym.

English: Conserua me. Psal. 16.
Manx: Psal. 16. Conserva me, Domine.

English: Preserve me, O God : for in thee have I put my trust.
Manx: 1 Jean m’y choadey, O Yee: son ayn-yds ta mee er choyrt my hreishteil.

English: 2 O my soule, thou hast said unto the Lord : thou art my God, my goods are nothing unto thee.
Manx: 2 O m’annym, t’ow er ghra rish y Chiarn: Uss my Yee; cha vel my chooid-seihlt dy ve soyllit hoods.

English: 3 All my delight is upon the saints that are in the earth : and upon such as excell in vertue.
Manx: 3 Ta ooilley my haitnys er ny nooghyn t’er y thalloo: as er nyn lheid as ta dy-firrinagh crauee.

English: 4 But they that run after another god : shall have great trouble.
Manx: 4 Agh adsyn ta geiyrt er Jee elley: yiow seaghyn mooar.

English: 5 Their drinke offerings of blood will I not offer : neither make mention of their names within my lips.
Manx: 5 Nyn ourallyn-jough foalley cha jean‐yms y hebbal: cha-moo nee’m imraa jeh’n ennym oc cheu‐sthie jeh my veillyn.
ourallyn-jough foalley] 1769, 1777 ourallyn-iu folley

English: 6 The Lord himselfe is the portion of mine inheritance, and of my cup : thou shalt maintaine my lot.
Manx: 6 Yn Chiarn hene ayrn my eiraght, as my chabban: nee uss my chronney y yannoo mie.
ayrn] 1769, 1777 toghyr; chabban] 1777 chappan

English: 7 My lot is fallen unto me in a faire ground : yea, I have a goodly heritage.
Manx: 7 Ta my chronney er duittym ayns cheer aalin: dy-feer, ta aym eiraght ooasle.

English: My lot] 1599, 1660, 1662 The lot
8 I will thanke the Lorde for giving me warning : my reines also chasten me in the night season.
Manx: 8 Ver‐yms booise da’n Chiarn son raaue y choyrt dou: ta my veeaghyn neesht dy my choyrlaghey er imbagh ny hoie.

English: 9 I have set God alwayes before mee : for hee is on my right hand, therefore I shall not fall.
Manx: 9 Ta mee er hoiaghey Jee kinjagh kiongoyrt rhym: son t’eh er my laue yesh, shen-y‐fa cha jean‐ym tuittym.

English: 10 Wherefore my heart was glad, and my glory rejoyced : my flesh also shall rest in hope.
Manx: 10 Shen‐y‐fa va my chree gennal, as my ghloyr laane dy voggey: Nee my challin myrgeddin goaill fea ayns treishteil.[29]
ghloyr] 1769 gloyr

English: 11 For why? thou shalt not leave my soule in hell : neither shalt thou suffer thine holy One to see corruption.
Manx: 11 Son cre’n‐fa? cha vaag uss m’annym ayns stayd ny merriu: cha-moo lhiggys oo da dt’Er‐casherick hene dy akin loauys.

English: 12 Thou shalt shewe me the path of life; in thy presence is the fulnesse of joy : and at thy right hand there is pleasure for evermore.
Manx: 12 Nee uss soilshaghey dou raad y vea; ayns dt’enish ta laanid dy voggey: as er dty laue yesh ta eunys er son dy-bragh.

English: Exaudi Domine iustitiam. Psal. 17.
Manx: Psal. 17 Exaudi, Domine.

English: Heare the right, O Lord, consider my complaint : & hearken unto my prayer, that goeth not out of fained lips.
Manx: 1 Eaisht rish cairys my chooish, O Hiarn, smooinee er my accan: as clasht rish my phadjer, nagh vel goll magh ass meillyn molteyragh.

English: 2 Let my sentence come forth from thy presence : and let thine eyes looke upon the thing that is equall.
Manx: 2 Lhig da’n vriwnys ayms cheet magh veih dt’enish: as lhig da dty hooillyn jeeaghyn er shen ny ta cairal.

English: 3 Thou hast prooved and visited mine heart in the night season; thou hast tried me, and shalt finde no wickednesse in mee : for I am utterly purposed that my mouth shall not offend.
Manx: 3 T’ow er phrowal as er ronsaghey my chree ayns imbagh ny hoie; t’ow er my hirrey magh as cha vow veg yn olkys ayn-ym: son ta mee dy-slane kiarit nagh jean-ym foill lesh my hengey.

English: 4 Because of mens workes that are done against the wordes of my lippes : I have kept me from the wayes of the destroyer.
Manx: 4 Kyndagh rish obbraghyn deiney ta jeant noi goan dty veillyn: ta mee er reayll mee hene veih raaidyn y stroider.

English: my lippes] 1662 (as 1539) thy lips
5 O hold thou up my goings in thy paths : that my footsteps slip not.
Manx: 5 Cumm uss seose my immeeaght ayns dty raaidyn: nagh jean my chesmadyn skyrraghtyn.

English: 6 I have called upon thee, O God, for thou shalt heare me : encline thine eare to me, and hearken unto my words.
Manx: 6 Ta mee er n’eamagh ort, O Yee, son nee oo m’y chlashtyn: cromm dty chleaysh hym, as eaisht rish my ghoan.

English: 7 Shew thy marveilous loving kindnesse, thou that art the Saviour of them which put their trust in thee : from such as resist thy right hand.
Manx: 7 Soilshee dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh er-skyn‐insh, uss yn Saualtagh ocsyn ta coyrt nyn dreishteil ayn-yd: veih nyn lheid ocsyn as ta shassoo noi dty laue yesh.

English: 8 Keepe mee as the apple of an eye : hide mee under the shadow of thy wings,
Manx: 8 Jean m’y reayll myr clagh ny sooilley: follee mee fo scaa dty skainyn.

English: 9 From the ungodly that trouble me : mine enemies compass me round about to take away my soule.
Manx: 9 Veih’n vee‐chrauee ta dy my voirey: ta my noidyn chionney orrym er dy-chooilley cheu dy ghoaill ersooyl my vioys.
cheu] 1819 heu

English: 10 They are inclosed in their owne fat : and their mouth speaketh proud things.
Manx: 10 T’ad dooint ayns y reuïd oc hene: as ta’n beeal oc loayrt reddyn mooaralagh.

English: 11 They lye waiting in our way on every side : turning their eyes downe to the ground;
Manx: 11 T’ad lhie farkiaght ayns y raad ain er dy-chooilley cheu: chyndaa nyn sooillyn sheese gys y thalloo.
cheu] 1819 heu

English: 12 Like as a Lion that is greedie of his pray : and as it were a Lions whelpe lurking in secret places.
Manx: 12 Myr y lion ta jollyssagh er e heilg: as myr y lion aeg ta lhie gyn‐yss ayns ynnydyn follit.

English: 13 Up Lord, disappoint him, and cast him downe : deliver my soule from the ungodly, which is a sword of thine;
Manx: 13 Seose, Hiarn, cur e haaseyn mow, as ceau sheese eh: livrey m’annym veih’n vee‐chrauee, ta myr cliwe ayns dty laue;

English: 14 From the men of thy hand, O Lord, from the men, I say, and from the evill world : which have their portion in this life, whose bellies thou fillest with thy hid treasure.
Manx: 14 Veih deiney dty laue, O Hiarn, veih ny deiney, ta mee gra, as veih’n drogh heihll: ta’n toghyr oc ’sy vea shoh, ny builg oc t’ow dy lhieeney lesh dty verchys follit.

English: 15 They have children at their desire : and leave the rest of their substance for their babes.
Manx: 15 Ta cloan oc lurg nyn aigney: as t’ad faagail ny ta er-mayrn jeh nyn merchys da nyn lhuight.

English: 16 But as for me, I will behold thy presence in righteousnesse : and when I awake up after thy likenesse, I shal be satisfied with it.
Manx: 16 Agh er my hon’s, nee’m fakin dt’eddin ayns cairys: as tra nee’m doostey seose lurg dty chaslys, yioym yn slane soylley jeh.

English: The iii. day.
Manx: The 3. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Diligam te. Psal. 18.
Manx: Psal. 18. Diligam te, Domine.

English: I will love thee (O Lord) my strength; the Lord is my stony rocke, and my defence : my Saviour, my God, and my might, in whom I will trust, my buckler, the horne also of my salvation, and my refuge.
Manx: 1 Ver‐yms graih dhyt, O Hiarn, my niart; she yn Chiarn my chregg lajer, as m’endeilys: my Haualtagh, my Yee, as my hroshid, huggey ver‐ym barrant; my eïlley‐caggee, ynnyd-lajer myrgeddin my hauchys, as my chemmyrk.
ynnyd-lajer] 1769, 1777 troshid

English: 2 I will call upon the Lord, which is worthy to bee praised : so shall I bee safe from mine enemies.
Manx: 2 Nee’ms geamagh er y Chiarn, ta feeu dy ve er ny voylley: myr shen bee’m sauchey veih my noidyn.

English: 3 The sorowes of death compassed me : and the overflowings of ungodlines made me afraid.
Manx: 3 Haink angaishyn y vaaish mygeayrt‐y‐moom: as ren ny thooillaghyn dy vee‐chraueeaght m’y agglaghey.

English: 4 The paines of hell came about me : the snares of death overtooke me.
Manx: 4 Haink pianyn niurin mygeayrt‐y‐moom: ren ribbaghyn y vaaish berraghtyn orrym.

English: 5 In my trouble I will call upon the Lorde : and complaine unto my God.
Manx: 5 Ayns my heaghyn nee’m geamagh er y Chiarn: as jannoo accan gys my Yee.

English: 6 So shall hee heare my voice out of his holy Temple: and my complaint shall come before him, it shall enter even into his eares.
Manx: 6 Myr shen clynnee eh my choraa veih e hiamble chasherick: as hig my phlaynt kiongoyrt rish, hed eh stiagh dy-jarroo gys e chleayshyn.

English: 7 The earth trembled and quaked : the very foundations also of the hilles shooke and were remooved, because hee was wroth.
Manx: 7 Va’n thalloo er ny ghleashagh, as ren eh craa: va eer undinyn ny sleïtyn neesht er‐creau, as v’ad er ny scughey, ec e yymmoose.

English: 8 There went a smoke out in his presence : and a consuming fire out of his mouth, so that coales were kindled at it.
Manx: 8 Hie jaagh veih e enish: as aile va cur mow ass e veeal, myr shen dy row smarageyn er nyn voadey lesh.

English: 9 Hee bowed the heavens also, and came downe : and it was darke under his feete.
Manx: 9 Chromm eh ny niaughyn neesht, as haink eh neose: as ve dorraghey fo e chassyn.

English: 10 He rode upon the Cherubims and did flie : he came flying upon the wings of the winde.
Manx: 10 Varkee eh er ny Cherubimyn, as ren eh getlagh: haink eh getlagh er skainyn ny geayee.
Cherubimyn] 1819 Cherubim

English: 11 He made darknesse his secret place : his pavilion round about him, with darke water and thicke clouds to cover him.
Manx: 11 Ren eh dorraghys e ynnyd follit: e chabbane‐reeoil mygeayrt‐y‐mysh lesh ushtey dorraghey, as bodjallyn chiu dy choodaghey eh.

English: 12 At the brightnesse of his presence his clouds removed : hailestones and coales of fire.
Manx: 12 Ec sollyssid e enish ren e vodjallyn scughey: claghyn‐sniaghtee, as smarageyn d’aile.

English: 13 The Lord also thundered out of heaven, and the Highest gave his thunder : hailestones, and coales of fire.
Manx: 13 Hug y Chiarn neesht taarnagh veih niau, as ren y Fer‐syrjey coyrt e haarnagh: claghyn‐sniaghtee, as smarageyn d’aile.

English: 14 Hee sent out his arrowes, and scattered them : hee cast foorth lightnings, and destroyed them.
Manx: 14 Lhig eh magh e hideyn, as skeayll eh ad: hug eh magh e hendeilyn, as ren eh ad [y] stroie.
hendeilyn, as ren eh ad [y] stroie] 1769, 1777 hendreilyn, as ren eh stroie ad.

English: 15 The springs of waters were seene, and the foundations of the round world were discovered at thy chiding, O Lord : at the blasting of the breath of thy displeasure.
Manx: 15 Va ny farraneyn ushtey er nyn vakin, as haink undinyn y theihll rish, lesh dty oghsan, O Hiarn: ec sheidey ennal dty yymmoose.
farraneyn] 1765, 1769 faraneyn; sheidey] 1769, 1777 blest

English: 16 He shal send downe from the high to fetch me : and shal take me out of many waters.
Manx: 16 Ver eh fyss veih’n yrjid dy my hauail: as nee eh m’y ghoaill ass ymmodee ushtaghyn.
fyss] 1769, 1777 cooney

English: 17 He shal deliver me from my strongest enemy, and from them which hate me : for they are too mighty for me.
Manx: 17 Nee eh m’y livrey veih my noidyn stroshey, as vowesyn ta dwoaie oc orrym: son t’ad ro lajer er my hon.

English: 18 They prevented mee in the day of my trouble : but the Lord was my upholder.
Manx: 18 Haink ad orrym gyn‐yss ayns my heaghyn: agh y Chiarn ren m’y chummal seose.

English: 19 He brought mee foorth also into a place of libertie: hee brought me forth, even because he had a favour unto me.
Manx: 19 Hug eh lesh mee magh neesht gys boayl dy reamys: hug eh lesh mee magh, dy-jarroo son dy row foayr echey dou.

English: 20 The Lord shall reward mee after my righteous dealing : according to the cleannesse of my handes shall he recompense me.
Manx: 20 Nee’n Chiarn m’y chooilleeney lurg my ghellal cairagh: cordail rish glennid my laueyn nee eh lhiasaghey dou;

English: 21 Because I have kept the wayes of the Lord : and have not forsaken my God as the wicked doeth.
Manx: 21 Er son dy vel mee er vreayll raaidyn y Chiarn: as nagh vel mee er hreigeil my Yee, myr ta ny mee‐chrauee dy yannoo.
Er son] 1769, 1777 Son

English: 22 For I have an eye unto all his Lawes : and will not cast out his Commandements from me.
Manx: 22 Son ta sooill aym gys ooilley e leighyn: as cha dilg-ym e annaghyn voym.

English: 23 I was also uncorrupt before him : and eschewed mine owne wickednesse.
Manx: 23 Va mish kinjagh gyn loght kiongoyrt rishyn: as hug mee cooyl rish m’olkys hene.

English: 24 Therefore shall the Lord reward mee after my righteous dealing : & according unto the cleannesse of my hands in his eye sight.
Manx: 24 Shen‐y‐fa nee’n Chiarn m’y chooilleeney lurg my ghellal cairagh: as cordail rish glennid my laueyn ayns shilley e hooillyn.

English: 25 With the holy, thou shalt be holy : and with a perfect man, thou shalt be perfect.
Manx: 25 Da’n dooinney casherick nee oo soilshaghey oo hene dy ve [dty Yee] casherick: as da’n dooinney ynrick vees oo ynrick.

English: 26 With the cleane, thou shalt be cleane : and with the froward, thou shalt learne frowardnesse.
Manx: 26 Dasyn ta glen nee oo soilshaghey oo hene glen: as noi’n roonagh soilshee oo dty roon.

English: 27 For thou shalt save the people that are in adversitie : and shalt bring downe the high lookes of the proud.
Manx: 27 Nee oo sauail y sleih ta ayns seaghyn: as ver oo sheese shillaghyn ard ny mooaralee.

English: 28 Thou also shalt light my candle : the Lord my God shall make my darkenes to be light.
Manx: 28 Nee oo myrgeddin my chainle y oaddey: ver y Chiarn my Yee er my ghorraghys dy ve soilshey.
oaddey] 1765, 1769 oadey

English: 29 For in thee I shall discomfit an hoste of men : and with the helpe of my God I shall leape over the wall.
Manx: 29 Son liorts ver-ym fo-chosh sheshaght‐caggee dy gheiney: as lesh cooney my Yee lheim‐ym harrish y voall.
voall] 1769, 1777 voalley

English: 30 The way of God is an undefiled way : the word of the Lord also is tried in the fire; hee is the defender of all them that put their trust in him.
Manx: 30 Ta raad Yee raad rea: ta goo yn Chiarn neesht er ny phrowal ’syn aile; eh yn fendeilagh ocsyn ooilley ta coyrt nyn dreishteil aynsyn.

English: 31 For who is God, but the Lord : or who hath any strength except our God?
Manx: 31 Son quoi ta Jee, agh y Chiarn! ny quoi echey ta niart erbee, agh ec y Jee ain?

English: 32 It is God that girdeth mee with strength of warre: and maketh my way perfect.
Manx: 32 She Jee ta dy my eïllaghey lesh niart caggee: as ta jannoo my raad jeeragh.
eïllaghey] 1769, 1777 choamrey

English: 33 Hee maketh my feete like harts feete : and setteth mee up on high.
Manx: 33 T’eh jannoo my chassyn myr cassyn feeaïh: as soiaghey mee seose dy-ard.

English: 34 He teacheth mine hands to fight : and mine armes shall breake even a bow of steel.
Manx: 34 T’eh gynsaghey my laueyn dy chaggey: nee my roihaghyn brishey eer bow steïllyn.

English: 35 Thou hast given me the defence of thy salvation : thy right hand also shall holde mee up, and thy loving correction shall make me great.
Manx: 35 T’ow er choyrt dooys fendeilys dy haualtys: nee dty laue yesh neesht m’y chummal seose, as nee dty smaght graihagh mish y yannoo mooar.

English: 36 Thou shalt make roume ynough under me for to goe : that my footesteps shall not slide.
Manx: 36 Nee oo raad liane dy-liooar foym dy immeeaght: nagh skyrr my chesmadyn.

English: 37 I wil follow upon mine enemies, and overtake them : neither wil I turne againe till I have destroyed them.
Manx: 37 Eiyr‐ym er my noidyn as berr‐ym orroo: cha-moo nee’m chyndaa reesht derrey vee’m er stroie ad.

English: 38 I will smite them, that they shall not be able to stand : but fall under my feete.
Manx: 38 Bwoail‐ym ad, derrey nagh vod ad shassoo: agh tuittym fo my chassyn.

English: 39 Thou hast girded mee with strength unto the battell : thou shalt throw downe mine enemies under me.
Manx: 39 T’ow er my chomm’rey lesh niart son y chaggey: nee uss my noidyn y lhieggal sheese foym.

English: 40 Thou hast made mine enemies also to turne their backs upon me : and I shall destroy them that hate me.
Manx: 40 T’ow er choyrt er my noidyn neesht dy chur cooyl rhym: as nee’ms adsyn y stroie ta dwoaie oc orrym.

English: 41 They shal cry, but there shal be none to help them : yea, even unto the Lord shal they cry, but he shal not heare them.
Manx: 41 Nee ad geamagh, agh cha bee unnane dy chooney lhieu: dy-jarroo gys y Chiarn, nee ad geamagh, agh cha der eh clashtyn daue.

English: 42 I wil beat them as smal as the dust before the winde : I will cast them out as the clay in the streets.
Manx: 42 Bwoail‐yms ad cha meen as y joan roish y gheay: as tilg‐ym ad magh myr y laagh ayns ny straaidyn.

English: 43 Thou shalt deliver mee from the strivings of the people : and thou shalt make me the head of the heathen.
Manx: 43 Nee uss m’y livrey veih anvea yn pobble: as ver oo orrym dy ve kione ny ashoonyn.

English: 44 A people whom I have not knowen : shall serve me.
Manx: 44 Pobble nagh nione dooys: nee m’y hirveish.

English: 45 Assoone as they heare of me, they shall obey mee: but the strange children shall dissemble with me.
Manx: 45 Cha leah as chlynnys ad jee’m, ver ad biallys dou: agh nee’n chloan yoarree foalsaght rhym.

English: 46 The strange children shall faile : and bee afraid out of their prisons.
Manx: 46 Nee’n chloan yoarree failleil: as bee ad agglagh ayns ny ynnydyn follit oc.

English: 47 The Lord liveth, and blessed bee my strong helper : and praised be the God of my salvation;
Manx: 47 Ta’n Chiarn bio, as bannit dy row m’er‐coonee niartal: as moylley dy row gys Jee my haualtys;

English: 48 Even the God that seeth that I be avenged : and subdueth the people unto me.
Manx: 48 Yn Jee hene ta fakin dy goym cooilleeney: as ta coyrt yn pobble fo my smaght.

English: 49 It is he that delivereth me from my (cruel) enemies, and setteth me up above mine adversaries : thou shalt rid me from the wicked man.
Manx: 49 Eshyn eh ta dy my livrey veih my noidyn dewil, as ta dy my hoiaghey seose er nyn skyn ocsyn ta shassoo m’oï: nee oo m’y livrey veih’n dooinney olkyssagh.

English: 50 For this cause wil I give thanks unto thee (O Lord) among the Gentiles : and sing praises unto thy Name.
Manx: 50 Son yn oyr shoh ver‐yms booise dhyt, O Hiarn, mastey ny Ashoonyn: as goym arraneyn-moyllee gys dt’Ennym.

English: 51 Great prosperitie giveth he unto his King : and sheweth loving kindness unto David his anoynted, and unto his seed for evermore.
Manx: 51 Barriaght vooar t’eh coyrt da e Ree: as soilshaghey kenjallys-ghraihagh da David e Er‐ooïllit, as gys e lhuight er son dy-bragh.

English: The iiii. day.
Manx: The 4. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Cœli enarrant. Psal. 19.
Manx: Psal.19. Cœli enarrant.

English: The heavens declare the glory of God : and the firmament sheweth his handy worke.
Manx: 1 Ta ny niaughyn fockley magh gloyr Yee: as ta’n aer soilshaghey obbyr e laueyn.

English: 2 One day telleth another : and one night certifieth another.
Manx: 2 Laa lurg laa te er ny hoilshaghey: as ta oie lurg oie cur toiggal jeh.

English: 3 There is neither speech nor language : but their voyces are heard among them.
Manx: 3 Cha vel eddyr goan ny glaare: raad nagh vel ny coraaghyn oc er nyn glashtyn.

English: 4 Their sound is gone out into all landes : and their wordes into the endes of the world.
Manx: 4 Ta’n sheean oc er gholl magh gys dy-chooilley heer: as ny goan oc gys ny ardjyn sodjey magh jeh’n theihll.
heer] 1765, 1769 cheer

English: 5 In them hath he set a tabernacle for the Sunne : which commeth foorth as a bridegrome out of his chamber, and rejoyceth as a Giant to runne his course.
Manx: 5 Ayndoo t’eh er hoiaghey cabbane son y ghrian: ta cheet magh myr dooinney‐poosee ass e hiamyr, as goaill boggey myr dooinney lajer dy roih e choorse.

English: 6 It goeth foorth from the uttermost part of the heaven, and runneth about unto the end of it againe : and there is nothing hid from the heat thereof.
Manx: 6 T’eh goll magh veih’n ayrn sodjey jeh’n aer, as roih mygeayrt gys y chione echey reesht; as cha vel nhee erbee follit veih’n chiass echey.
roih mygeayrt gys y chione] 1769, 1777 goaill combaase mygeayrt ny ardjyn [1769 ardjin]

English: 7 The Law of the Lord is an undefiled law, converting the soule : the testimonie of the Lord is sure, and giveth wisedome unto the simple.
Manx: 7 Ta leigh yn Chiarn ny leigh gyn-foill, niartaghey yn annym: ta recortyssyn y Chiarn shickyr, as coyrt creenaght da’n vee-hushtagh.

English: 8 The Statutes of the Lord are right, and rejoyce the heart : the Commandement of the Lord is pure, and giveth light unto the eyes.
Manx: 8 Ta slattyssyn y Chiarn jeeragh, as coyrt boggey da’n chree: ta saarey yn Chiarn ynrick, as coyrt soilshey da ny sooillyn.

English: 9 The feare of the Lord is cleane, and endureth for ever : the Judgements of the Lord are true and righteous altogether.
Manx: 9 Ta aggle y Chiarn glen, as farraghtyn son dy-bragh: ta briwnyssyn y Chiarn firrinagh as cairagh ooilley dy-cheïley.

English: 10 More to be desired are they then golde, yea, then much fine gold : sweeter also then honie, and the honie combe.
Manx: 10 Ny smoo t’ad dy v’er nyn yeearree na airh, dy-jarroo, na mooarane airh ghlen: ny s’miljey neesht na mill, as y khere‐volley.

English: 11 Moreover, by them is thy servant taught : and in keeping of them there is great reward.
Manx: 11 Lioroosyn myrgeddin ta dty harvaant ynsit: as ayns freaylley ad ta leagh vooar.

English: 12 Who can tell how oft he offendeth : O cleanse thou me from my secret faults.
Manx: 12 Quoi oddys ginsh earroo e loghtyn? O glen mee veih my pheccaghyn follit.

English: 13 Keepe thy servant also from presumptuous sinnes, lest they get the dominion over mee : so shall I be undefiled, and innocent from the great offence.
Manx: 13 Freill dty harvaant myrgeddin veih peccaghyn dy ghaanys, nagh vowe ad barriaght harrym: myr shen bee’m seyr, as gyn loght veih’n peccah trome.

English: 14 Let the words of my mouth, and the meditation of my heart : be alway acceptable in thy sight,
Manx: 14 Lhig da goan my veeal, as smooinaghtyn my chree: ve dy-kinjagh booisal ayns dty hilley,

English: 15 O Lord : my strength, and my Redeemer.
Manx: 15 O Hiarn: my niart as my Er‐kionnee.

English: Exaudiat te Dominus. Psal. 20.
Manx: Psal. 20. Exaudiat te, Dominus.

English: The Lord heare thee in the day of trouble : the Name of the God of Jacob defend thee;
Manx: 1 Dy jean y Chiarn dty chlashtyn ayns y laa dy heaghyn: dy jean Ennym Jee Yacob dt’endeil.

English: 2 Send thee helpe from the Sanctuary : and strength thee out of Sion;
Manx: 2 Dy der eh cooney hood veih’n ynnyd casherick: as dy jean eh dty niartaghey magh ass Sion.

English: strength] 1660 strengthen
3 Remember all thy offerings : and accept thy burnt sacrifice;
Manx: 3 Dy gooinee eh er ooilley dty hebballyn: as soiaghey jeh dty ourallyn losht.

English: 4 Grant thee thy hearts desire : and fulfill all thy minde.
Manx: 4 Dy der eh dhyt yeearree dty chree: as ooilley dt’aigney ’chooilleeney.

English: 5 Wee will rejoyce in thy salvation, and triumph in the Name of the Lord our God : the Lord performe all thy petitions.
Manx: 5 Gow mayd boggey ayns dty haualtys, as barriaght y gheddyn ayns Ennym y Chiarn y Jee ain: dy gooilleen y Chiarn ooilley dty aghinyn.

English: 6 Now know I that the Lord helpeth his anointed, and will heare him from his holy heaven : even with the wholesome strength of his right hand.
Manx: 6 Nish ta fys aym, dy vel y Chiarn cooney lesh e Er‐ooïllit, as dy der eh clashtyn da veih e niau chasherick: dy-jarroo lesh troshid slayntoil e laue yesh.

English: 7 Some put their trust in charets, and some in horses : but we will remember the Name of the Lord our God.
Manx: 7 Ta paart coyrt nyn marrant gys fainaghyn, as paart gys cabbil: agh nee shinyn cooinaghtyn er Ennym y Chiarn y Jee ain.

English: 8 They are brought downe and fallen : but we are risen, and stand upright.
Manx: 8 T’adsyn er nyn goyrt fo‐chosh, as er duittym: agh ta shinyn er droggal, as shassoo dy-shickyr.

English: 9 Save Lord, and heare us, O King of heaven : when we call upon thee.
Manx: 9 Saue shin, Hiarn, as clasht rooin, O Ree flaunys: tra ta shin geamagh ort.

English: Domine in virtute. Psal. 21.
Manx: Psal. 21. Domine, in virtute tua.

English: The King shall rejoyce in thy strength, O Lord : exceeding glad shall he be of thy salvation.
Manx: 1 Nee’n Ree boggey ’ghoaill ayns dty niart, O Hiarn: feer yennal vees eh jeh dty haualtys.

English: 2 Thou hast given him his hearts desire : and hast not denied him the request of his lips.
Manx: 2 T’ow er choyrt da yeearree e chree: as cha vel oo er n’obbal da aghin e veillyn.

English: 3 For thou shalt prevent him with the blessings of goodnesse : and shalt set a Crowne of pure golde upon his head.
Manx: 3 Son ver oo dasyn ro‐laue bannaghtyn dy vieys: as soiaghey attey dy airh ghlen er e chione.

English: 4 Hee asked life of thee, and thou gavest him a long life : even for ever and ever.
Manx: 4 Hirr eh bea orts, as hug oo da bea liauyr: dy-jarroo son dy-bragh as dy-bragh.

English: 5 His honour is great in thy Salvation : glorie and great worship shalt thou lay upon him.
Manx: 5 Ta’n onnor echey mooar liorish dty haualtys: gloyr as ooashley vooar ver oo ersyn.

English: 6 For thou shalt give him everlasting felicitie : and make him glad with the joy of thy countenance.
Manx: 6 Son ver uss dasyn maynrys dy-bragh farraghtyn: as nee oo eh gennal lesh boggey dt’eddin.

English: 7 And why? because the King putteth his trust in the Lord : and in the mercie of the most Highest he shall not miscarie.
Manx: 7 As cre’n‐fa? son dy vel y Ree coyrt e hreishteil ayns y Chiarn: as ayns myghin yn Er smoo syrjey cha bee eh er ny scughey.

English: 8 All thine enemies shall feele thine hand : thy right hand shall finde out them that hate thee.
Manx: 8 Nee ooilley dty noidyn gennaghtyn dty laue: yiow dty laue yesh adsyn magh ta dwoaie oc ort.

English: 9 Thou shalt make them like a fiery oven in time of thy wrath : the Lord shall destroy them in his displeasure, and the fire shall consume them.
Manx: 9 Nee oo ad y yannoo myr oghe ailagh ayns traa dty chorree: nee yn Chiarn ad y stroie ayns e yymmoose, as nee yn aile ad y choyrt mow.

English: 10 Their fruit shalt thou root out of the earth : and their seed from among the children of men.
Manx: 10 Yn rass oc ver oo ass ny fraueyn jeh’n thalloo: as yn sluight oc veih mastey cloan gheiney.

English: 11 For they intended mischiefe against thee : and imagined such a device as they are not able to performe.
Manx: 11 Son chiare ad olkys dt’oï: as ghow ad ayns laue lheid y saase as nagh jarg ad y chooilleeney.

English: 12 Therefore shalt thou put them to flight : & the strings of thy bow shalt thou make ready against the face of them.
Manx: 12 Shen‐y‐fa ver oo orroosyn cooyl y choyrt: as strengyn dty vhow nee oo aarloo noi’n eddin oc.

English: 13 Be thou exalted Lord in thine owne strength : so will we sing and praise thy power.
Manx: 13 Bee uss, Hiarn, er dty hoiaghey seose ayns dty niart hene: myr shen nee mayd goaill arrane, as moylley ’choyrt da dty phooar.

English: The iiii. day.
Manx: The 4. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Deus, Deus meus. Psal. 22.
Manx: Psal. 22. Deus, Deus meus.

English: My God, my God (look upon mee) why hast thou forsaken mee : and art so farre from my health, and from the words of my complaint?
Manx: 1 My Yee, my Yee, jeeagh orrym; cre’n‐fa t’ow er my hreigeil: as t’ow choud veih my lhaynt, as veih goan my accan?

English: 2 O my God, I cry in the day time, but thou hearest not : and in the night season also I take no rest.
Manx: 2O my Yee, ta mee geam fey laa, agh cha vel oo cur clashtyn: as ooilley’n oie neesht cha vel mee goaill veg y fea.
fey laa] 1769, 1777 fey ny-laa; ooilley’n oie neesht] 1769, 1777 ayns imbagh ny hoie myrgeddin; goaill] 1777 geddyn

English: 3 And thou continuest holy : O thou worship of Israel.
Manx: 3 As t’ow uss tannaghtyn casherick: O uss ooashley Israel.

English: 4 Our fathers hoped in thee : they trusted in thee, and thou diddest deliver them.
Manx: 4 Ren ny ayraghyn ain treishteil ayn-yds: hug ad nyn marrant ort, as ren oo ad y livrey.

English: 5 They called upon thee, and were holpen : they put their trust in thee, and were not confounded.
Manx: 5 Deïe ad orts, as hooar ad cooney: hug ad nyn marrant ort, as cha row ad er nyn goyrt mow.
goyrt] 1765, 1769, 1777 ghoyrt

English: 6 But as for me, I am a worme, & no man : a very scorne of men, and the outcast of the people.
Manx: 6 Agh er my hon’s, she beishteig mee, as cha nee dooinney: eer craid gheiney, as oltooan y pobble.

English: 7 All they that see me, laugh me to scorne : they shoot out their lips, and shake their heads, saying,
Manx: 7 Ta ooilley ny ta dy m’akin, gannidys orrym: t’ad sheeyney magh nyn meillyn, as craa nyn ghing, gra,

English: 8 He trusted in God, that hee would deliver him : let him deliver him, if he will have him.
Manx: 8 Hreisht eh ayns Jee, dy jinnagh eh eshyn y livrey: lhig da eh y livrey, my ta taitnys echey ayn.[46]

English: 9 But thou art hee that tooke mee out of my mothers wombe : thou wast my hope, when I hanged yet upon my mothers breasts.
Manx: 9 Agh uss eh ren m’y ghoaill ass breïn my vayrey: v’ow my hreishteil tra va mee foast er keeagh my voïr.

English: 10 I have bene left unto thee ever since I was borne: thou art my God, even from my mothers wombe.
Manx: 10 Ta mee er ve fo dty chiarail er dyn traa ruggyr mee: uss my Yee eer veih breïn my vayrey.

English: 11 O go not fro me, for trouble is hard at hand : and there is none to helpe me.
Manx: 11 O ny treig mee, son ta seaghyn er‐gerrey: as cha vel unnane dy chooney lhiam.

English: 12 Many oxen are come about mee : fat Bulles of Basan close me in on every side.
Manx: 12 Ta ymmodee dew er jeet mygeayrt‐y‐moom: ta terriu lajer Vasan er hoiaghey orrym er dagh cheu.

English: 13 They gape upon me with their mouthes : as it were a ramping and a roaring Lion.
Manx: 13 T’ad fosley nyn meeal orrym: myr lion jollyssagh buirroogh son spooilley.

English: 14 I am powred out like water, and all my bones are out of joynt : my heart also in the middest of my body is even like melting waxe.
Manx: 14 Ta mee deayrtit magh myr ushtey, as ta ooilley my chraueyn ass ynnyd: ta my chree neesht ayns mean my chorp eer myr kere ta lheïe.

English: 15 My strength is dried up like a potsheard, & my tongue cleaveth to my gummes : and thou shalt bring mee into the dust of death.
Manx: 15 Ta my niart chyrmit seose myr peesh dy haagh-craie, as ta my hengey lhiantyn gys my ghruntyn: as ver uss lhiat mee gys joan y vaaish.

English: 16 For (many) dogs are come about me : and the counsell of the wicked layeth siege against me.
Manx: 16 Son ta ymmodee moddee er jeet mygeayrt‐y‐moom: as ta coonceïl ny olkyssee cur nyn goyrle dy-cheïley m’oï.

English: 17 They pearced my hands, and my feete; I may tell all my bones : they stand staring and looking upon me.
Manx: 17 Hoyll ad my laueyn as my chassyn; foddym ooilley my chraueyn y choontey: t’ad shassoo gindys as jeeaghyn orrym.

English: 18 They part my garments among them : and cast lots upon my vesture.
Manx: 18 Rheinn ad my gharmadyn ny mast’ oc: as er my chooat hilg ad lottyn.

English: 19 But be not thou farre from me, O Lord : thou art my succour, haste thee to helpe me.
Manx: 19 Agh ny bee uss foddey voym, O Hiarn: she uss my chemmyrk; jean siyr dy chooney lhiam.

English: 20 Deliver my soule from the sword : my darling from the power of the dogge.
Manx: 20 Livrey m’annym veih’n chliwe: as my ynrycan bioys veih pooar y voddey.
ynrycan bioys] 1769, 1777 vioys deyr

English: 21 Save me from the Lions mouth : thou hast heard me also from among the hornes of the Unicornes.
Manx: 21 Saue mee veih beeall y lion: t’ow er my chlashtyn myrgeddin veih mastey eairkyn ny unicornyn.
eairkyn] 1765, 1769, 1777 earkyn

English: 22 I will declare thy Name unto my brethren : in the middest of the Congregation will I praise thee.
Manx: 22 Nee’ms dt’Ennym y hoilshaghey da my vraaraghyn: ayns mean ny hagglish nee’m uss y voylley.

English: 23 O praise the Lord ye that feare him : magnifie him all ye of the seed of Jacob, and feare him all ye seed of Israel;
Manx: 23 O moylley‐jee yn Chiarn, shiuish ta goaill aggle roïsh: cur‐jee ard‐voylley da, ooilley shiuish jeh sluight Yacob, as gow‐jee aggle roïsh, ooilley shiuish sluight Israel.

English: 24 For he hath not despised nor abhorred the low estate of the poore; he hath not hid his face from him : but when he called unto him, he heard him.
Manx: 24 Son cha vel eh er hoiaghey beg jeh, ny er hreigeil stayd inshil y voght: cha vel eh er ollaghey e eddin veih, agh tra deïe eh er, hug eh clashtyn da.

English: 25 My praise is of thee in the great Congregation : my vowes will I performe in the sight of them that feare him.
Manx: 25 Hoods nee’m chebbal my voylley ayns sheshaght vooar ny nooghyn: my vreearraghyn nee’ms y chooilleeney ayns yn enish ocsyn ta goaill aggle roishyn.

English: 26 The poore shall eate and be satisfied : they that seeke after the Lord, shall praise him; your heart shall live for ever.
Manx: 26 Nee ny boghtyn gee, as bee ad er nyn yannoo magh: adsyn ta shirrey lurg y Chiarn, moyllee ad eh; bee’n cree eu bio son dy-bragh,

English: 27 All the ends of the world shall remember themselves, and be turned unto the Lord : and all the kinreds of the nations shall worship before him.
Manx: 27 Nee ooilley ardjyn y thallooin cooinaghtyn orroo hene, as bee ad er nyn jyndaa gys y Chiarn: as ver ooilley kynneeyn ny ashoonyn ooashley kiongoyrt rish.

English: 28 For the kingdome is the Lords : and hee is the governour among the people.
Manx: 28 Son lesh y Chiarn yn reeriaght: as she eshyn yn Kiannoort mastey yn pobble.

English: 29 All such as be fat upon earth : have eaten & worshipped.
Manx: 29 Nee nyn lheid ocsyn ooilley ta berchagh er y thalloo: gee as ooashley ’choyrt.

English: 30 All they that go downe into the dust shall kneele before him : and no man hath quickened his owne soule.
Manx: 30 Nee adsyn ooilley ta er nyn injillaghey gys y joan [gys boghtynid] gliooney kiongoyrt rish: as cha vel dooinney erbee er vioghey e annym hene.
[gys boghtynid] not in 1819.

English: 31 My seed shall serve him : they shall be counted unto the Lord for a generation.
Manx: 31 Nee my lhuight’s eshyn y hirveish: bee ad goit stiagh son sheeloghe da’n Chiarn.

English: 32 They shall come, and the heavens shall declare his righteousnesse : unto a people that shall be borne, whom the Lord hath made.
Manx: 32 Hig adsyn, as nee ny niaughyn soilshaghey magh e chairys: da pobble hig er y theihll, adsyn ta’n Chiarn er chroo.

English: Dominus regit me. Psal. 23.
Manx: Psal. 23. Dominus regit me.

English: The Lord is my Shepheard : therefore can I lacke nothing.
Manx: 1 She’n Chiarn my vochilley: shen‐y‐fa cha bee’m feme nhee erbee.

English: 2 He shall feed me in a greene pasture : and lead me forth beside the waters of comfort.
Manx: 2 Nee eh fassaghey mee ayns pastyr glass: as m’y leeideil magh rish ny hushtaghyn dy ooraghey.
fassaghey] 1765, 1769, 1777 faassaghey

English: 3 He shall convert my soule : and bring mee foorth in the paths of righteousnesse for his Names sake.
Manx: 3 Nee eh m’annym y hyndaa: as m’y choyrt lesh magh ayns ny cassanyn dy chairys er graih e Ennym.

English: 4 Yea though I walke thorow the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evill : for thou art with mee; thy rod and thy staffe comfort me.
Manx: 4 Dy-jarroo, ga dy vel mee shooyll ayns coan scadoo yn vaaish, cha goym aggle roish olk erbee: son t’ow uss mârym; ta dty lhatt as dty lorg dy my gherjaghey.

English: 5 Thou shalt prepare a Table before mee against them that trouble mee : thou hast anointed my head with oile, and my cup shal be full.
Manx: 5 Nee oo boayrd y yannoo aarloo roym ayns yn enish ocsyn ta er my heaghney: t’ow er ooïllaghey my chione, as bee my chappan laane.

English: 6 But thy loving kindenesse and mercy shall follow mee all the dayes of my life : and I will dwell in the house of the Lord for ever.
Manx: 6 Agh eiyree dty chenjallys-ghraihagh as dty vyghin orrym ooilley laghyn my vea: as nee’ms taaghey thie’n Chiarn son dy-bragh.
son dy-bragh] 1769 choud as bio vee’m, 1777 choud as vee’m bio.

English: The v. day.
Manx: The 5. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Domini est terra. Psal. 24.
Manx: Psal.24. Domini est terra.

English: The earth is the Lords, and all that therein is : the compasse of the world, and they that dwell therein.
Manx: 1 Lesh y Chiarn y thalloo, as ooilley ny t’ayn: cumbaase y theihll, as adsyn ta vaghey ayn.

English: 2 For he hath founded it upon the Seas : and prepared it upon the floods.
Manx: 2 Son t’eh er hoiaghey eh er ny faarkaghyn: as er hickyraghey eh er ny thooillaghyn.

English: 3 Who shall ascend into the hill of the Lord : or who shal rise up in his holy place?
Manx: 3 Quoi eh hed seose er cronk y Chiarn: ny quoi vees cooie dy hassoo ayns e ynnyd casherick?

English: 4 Even he that hath cleane hands, and a pure heart : and that hath not lift up his minde unto vanitie, nor sworne to deceive his neighbour.
Manx: 4 Eshyn eh ta laueyn glen echey, as cree gyn loght: as nagh vel er hoiaghey e aigney er foalsaght, as nagh vel er ghoaill lhoo dy volley e naboo.

English: 5 Hee shall receive the blessing from the Lord: and righteousnesse from the God of his salvation.
Manx: 5 Yiow eshyn yn bannaght veih’n Chiarn: as cairys veih Jee e haualtys.

English: 6 This is the generation of them that seeke him : even of them that seeke thy face, O Jacob.
Manx: 6 Shoh’n sheeloghe ocsyn ta dy hirrey eh: jeusyn dy-jarroo ta shirrey dt’eddin, O Yacob.

English: 7 Lift up your heads, O yee gates, and bee ye lift up yee everlasting doores : and the King of glory shall come in.
Manx: 7 Trogg‐jee seose nyn ghing, O shiuish yiattyn, as bee‐jee er nyn droggal seose, shiuish ghorryssyn dy-bragh farraghtyn: as hig Ree ny ghloyr stiagh.

English: 8 Who is the King of glory : it is the Lord strong and mightie, even the Lord mighty in battell.
Manx: 8 Quoi ta Ree ny ghloyr: yn Chiarn eh ta lajer as niartal, yn Chiarn hene niartal ayns caggey.

English: 9 Lift up your heads, O yee gates, and be ye lift up yee everlasting doores : and the King of glory shall come in.
Manx: 9 Trogg‐jee seose nyn ghing, O shiuish yiattyn, as bee‐jee er nyn droggal seose, shiuish ghorryssyn dy-bragh farraghtyn: as hig Ree ny ghloyr stiagh.

English: 10 Who is the King of glory : even the Lord of hostes, he is the King of glory.
Manx: 10 Quoi ta Ree ny ghloyr: dy-jarroo yn Chiarn dy heshaght‐chaggee, eshyn Ree ny ghloyr.

English: Ad te Domine. Psal. 25.
Manx: Psal. 25. Ad te, Domine, levavi.

English: Unto thee, O Lord, will I lift up my soule; my God, I have put my trust in thee : O let mee not be confounded, neither let mine enemies triumph over me.
Manx: 1 Hoods, O Hiarn, trogg-ym seose m’annym; my Yee, ta mee er choyrt my hreishteil ayn-yd: O ny lhig dooys ’ve er my choyrt gys nearey, cha-moo lhig da my noidyn ve boggyssagh harrym.

English: 2 For all they that hope in thee shal not be ashamed : but such as transgresse without a cause, shall be put to confusion.
