Manx: 2 Son cha bee veg jeusyn ooilley ta treishteil ayn-yds er nyn naaraghey: agh bee nyn lheid as ta girree-magh gyn oyr er nyn goyrt bun‐ry‐skyn.
goyrt] 1765, 1769 ghoyrt

English: 3 Shew mee thy wayes, O Lord : and teach mee thy paths.
Manx: 3 Jeeagh dou dty raad, O Hiarn: as ynsee dou dty chassanyn.

English: 4 Leade me forth in thy trueth, and learne me : for thou art the God of my salvation; in thee hath bene my hope all the day long.
Manx: 4 Leeid mish ayns dt’irriney, as ynsee mee: son uss Jee my haualtys; ayn-yd va my hreishteil fey‐ny‐laa.

English: 5 Call to remembrance, O Lord, thy tender mercies : and thy loving-kindnesse which hath been ever of old.
Manx: 5 Tayrn gys cooinaghtyn, O Hiarn, dty vyghinyn meigh: as dty chenjallys-ghraihagh, t’er ny ve er dy-rieau.

English: kindenesse which hath] 1662 kindnesses which have
6 Oh remember not the sinnes and offences of my youth : but according to thy mercie thinke thou upon mee, O Lord, for thy goodnesse.
Manx: 6 O ny cooinee er peccaghyn as loghtyn my aegid: agh cordail rish dty vyghin smooinee orrym, O Hiarn, er graih dty vieys.

English: 7 Gracious and righteous is the Lord : therefore wil he teach sinners in the way.
Manx: 7 Graysoil as cairal ta’n Chiarn: shen‐y‐fa ynsee eh da peccee yn raad cair.

English: 8 Them that be meeke shal he guide in Judgement : and such as be gentle, them shall he learne his way.
Manx: 8 Adsyn ta imlee nee eh leeideil ayns briwnys: as dauesyn ta meen, ynsee eh e raad.

English: be meeke] 1662 are meek; be gentle] 1662 are gentle
9 All the pathes of the Lord are mercie and trueth : unto such as keepe his covenant and his testimonies.
Manx: 9 Ta ooilley raaidyn y Chiarn myghin as firrinys: da lheid as ta freaylley e chonaant as e leighyn.

English: 10 For thy Names sake, O Lord : bee mercifull unto my sinne, for it is great.
Manx: 10 Er graih dt’Ennym, O Hiarn: bee myghinagh da my pheccah, son te mooar.
te mooar] 1769, 1777 s’mooar te.

English: 11 What man is hee that feareth the Lord : him shall hee teach in the way that he shall choose.
Manx: 11 Cre’n dooinney ta goaill aggle roish y Chiarn: eshyn nee eh leeideil ayns y raad lhisagh eh ’reih.

English: 12 His soule shal dwel at ease : & his seed shall inherit the land.
Manx: 12 Bee’n annym echey ec aash: as yiow e lhuight yn cheer ayns eiraght.

English: 13 The secret of the Lord is among them that feare him : and he will shew them his Covenant.
Manx: 13 Ta folliaght y Chiarn nyn mast’ ocsyn ta goaill aggle roïsh: as nee eh soilshaghey daue e chonaant.

English: 14 Mine eyes are ever looking unto the Lord : for he shall plucke my feet out of the net.
Manx: 14 Ta my hooillyn dy-bragh jeeaghyn gys y Chiarn: son tayrnee eh my chassyn ass y ribbeh.

English: 15 Turne thee unto me, and have mercie upon me : for I am desolate and in miserie.
Manx: 15 Chyndaa oo hene hym’s, as jean myghin orrym: son ta mee treigit as ayns treihys.

English: 16 The sorrowes of my heart are enlarged : O bring thou me out of my troubles.
Manx: 16 Ta trimshey my chree er ny vishaghey: O cur uss lhiat mee ass my heaghyn.

English: 17 Looke upon mine adversitie and miserie : and forgive me all my sinne.
Manx: 17J eeagh er my arkys as my hreihys: as leih dou ooilley my pheccah.

English: 18 Consider mine enemies how many they are : and they beare a tyrannous hate against me.
Manx: 18 Jeeagh er my noidyn kys t’ad er mishaghey: as t’ad gymmyrkey goanlys tranlaasagh m’oï.
er mishaghey] 1819 er nyn mishaghey

English: 19 O keepe my soul, and deliver me : let mee not bee confounded, for I have put my trust in thee.
Manx: 19 O freill m’annym, as livrey mee: ny lhig dou v’er my choyrt gys nearey, son ayn-yds ta mee er choyrt my hreishteil.

English: 20 Let perfectness and righteous dealing waite upon me : for my hope hath bene in thee.
Manx: 20 Lhig da ônid as dellal yeeragh goll mârym: son ta my hreishteil er ny ve ayn-yds.

English: 21 Deliver Israel, O God : out of all his troubles.
Manx: 21 Livrey Israel, O Yee: veih ooilley e heaghyn.

English: Iudica me Domine. Psal. 26.
Manx: Psal. 26. Judica me, Domine.

English: Be thou my Judge, O Lord, for I have walked innocently : my trust hath bene also in the Lord, therfore shal I not fall.
Manx: 1 Bee uss my vriw, O Hiarn, son ta mee er n’ymmyrkey mee hene gyn loght: ta my varrant neesht er ny ve er y Chiarn, er‐y‐fa shen cha duittym.

English: 2 Examine me, O Lord, and proove mee : try out my reines and my heart.
Manx: 2 Feysht mee, O Hiarn, as prow mee: ronsee my veeaghyn as my chree.

English: 3 For thy loving kindnesse is ever before mine eyes : and I wil walke in thy trueth.
Manx: 3 Son ta dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh kinjagh roish my hooillyn: as nee’m gimmeeaght ayns dty irrinys.

English: 4 I have not dwelt with vaine persons : neither wil I have fellowship with the deceitfull.
Manx: 4 Cha vel mee er vaghey marish sleih foalsey: cha-moo nee’m sheshaght rish y vooinjer volteyragh.

English: 5 I have hated the congregation of the wicked : and will not sit among the ungodly.
Manx: 5 Ta feoh er ve aym er chymsagh cooidjagh yn drogh ’leih: as cha soie‐ym mastey ny mee‐chrauee.

English: 6 I wil wash mine hands in innocencie, O Lord : and so will I goe to thine Altar;
Manx: 6 Niee‐ym my laueyn ayns ônid, O Hiarn: as myr shen hem gys dty altar;

English: 7 That I may shew the voyce of thankesgiving : and tell of all thy wonderous workes.
Manx: 7 Dy voddym fockley magh yn coraa dy wooise: as soilshaghey ooilley dty obbraghyn yindyssagh.

English: 8 Lord, I have loved the habitation of thy house : and the place where thine honour dwelleth.
Manx: 8 Hiarn, ta mee er ve graihagh er coortyn dty hie: as ynnyd cabbane‐agglish dty ooashley.

English: 9 O shut not up my soule with the sinners : nor my life with the bloodthirstie;
Manx: 9 O ny jeigh seose m’annym marish ny peccee: ny my vioys marish y vooinjer foalley;

English: 10 In whose hands is wickednes : and their right hands are full of gifts.
Manx: 10 Ayns ny laueyn oc ta mee‐chairys: as ta nyn laue yesh laane dy yiootyn.

English: 11 But as for mee, I will walke innocently : O Lord deliver me and be mercifull unto me.
Manx: 11 Agh er my hon’s, nee’m gimmeeaght gyn loght: O livrey mee, as bee myghinagh dou.

English: 12 My foote standeth right : I wil praise the Lord in the Congregations.
Manx: 12 Ta my chass shassoo dy kiart: ver‐ym moylley da’n Chiarn ayns chaglym cooidjagh y phobble.

English: The v. day.
Manx: The 5. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Dominus illuminatio. Psal. 27.
Manx: Psal. 27. Dominus illuminatio.

English: The Lord is my light & my salvation; whom then shal I feare : the Lord is the strength of my life; of whom then shall I be afraid?
Manx: 1Yn Chiarn my hoilshey as my haualtys; quoi roish eisht ghoym aggle: yn Chiarn niart my vea; quoi roish eisht vee’m agglagh?

English: 2 When the wicked (even mine enemies and my foes) came upon mee to eat up my flesh : they stumbled and fell.
Manx: 2 Tra haink ny olkyssee, dy-jarroo my noidyn as my hranlaasee orrym dy my stroie: ren ad snapperal as tuittym.

English: 3 Though an hoste of men were layd against me, yet shal not my heart bee afraide : and though there rose up war against me, yet wil I put my trust in him.
Manx: 3 Ga dy beagh sheshaght‐caggee dy gheiney soit m’oï, foast cha bee my chree agglagh: as ga dy jinnagh caggey girree seose m’oï, foast ver‐ym my varrant ersyn.

English: 4 One thing have I desired of the Lord, which I will require : even that I may dwell in the house of the Lord all the dayes of my life, to beholde the faire beautie of the Lord, and to visit his Temple.
Manx: 4 Un red ta mish er hirrey er y Chiarn, shen nee’m y yeearree: dy-jarroo dy voddym vaghey ayns thie yn Chiarn ooilley laghyn my vea, dy akin aalid eunyssagh y Chiarn, as dy haaghey e hiamble.

English: 5 For in the time of trouble he shal hide me in his Tabernacle : yea, in the secret place of his dwelling shall he hide me, and set me up upon a rocke of stone.
Manx: 5 Son ayns traa my heaghyn follee eh mee ayns e chabbane: dy-jarroo ayns boayl kellit e ynnyd‐vaghee nee eh m’y ollaghey, as m’y hoiaghey seose er cregg chloie.
cregg chloie] 1777 creg chloaie

English: 6 And now shall hee lift up mine head : above mine enemies round about me.
Manx: 6 As nish troggee eh seose my chione: er-skyn my noidyn mygeayrt‐y‐moom.
my chione] 1765 ny chione

English: 7 Therefore wil I offer in his dwelling an oblation with great gladnes : I wil sing and speake praises unto the Lord.
Manx: 7 Shen‐y‐fa nee’ms oural y hebbal ayns e ynnyd casherick lesh ard ghennallys: nee’m arrane y ghoaill, as soilshaghey magh moylley yn Chiarn.

English: 8 Hearken unto my voyce, O Lord, when I cry unto thee : have mercy upon me, and heare me.
Manx: 8 Eaisht rish my choraa, O Hiarn, tra ta mee geamagh hoods: jean myghin orrym, as clasht rhym.

English: 9 My heart hath talked of thee, seeke ye my face : thy face Lord will I seeke.
Manx: 9 Ta my chree er yannoo imraa jeed’s; Shirr‐jee my eddin: Dt’eddin, Hiarn, nee’ms y hirrey.

English: 10 O hide not thou thy face from me : nor cast thy servant away in displeasure.
Manx: 10 O ny follee dty eddin voym: cha-moo jean dty harvaant y hyndaa ersooyl ayns jymmoose.

English: 11 Thou hast bene my succour : leave mee not, neither forsake me, O God of my salvation.
Manx: 11 T’ow er ny ve my chemmyrk: ny faag mee, cha-moo jean m’y hreigeil, O Yee my haualtys.

English: 12 When my father and my mother forsake me : the Lord taketh me up.
Manx: 12 Tra ta my ayr as my voir dy my hreigeil: ta’n Chiarn dy my ghoaill seose.

English: 13 Teach me thy way, O Lord : and leade me in the right way, because of mine enemies.
Manx: 13 Ynsee dooys dty raad, O Hiarn: as leeid mee ayns y raad cair, kyndagh rish my noidyn.

English: 14 Deliver me not over into the wil of mine adversaries : for there are false witnesses risen up against mee, and such as speake wrong.
Manx: 14 Ny livrey mee seose gys aigney my noidyn: son ta feanishyn foalsey er n’irree seose m’oï, as lheid as ta loayrt aggair.

English: 15 I should utterly have fainted : but that I beleeve verely to see the goodnesse of the Lord in the land of the living.
Manx: 15 Va mee dy-bollagh er choayll my chree: agh dy vel mee dy-shickyr credjal dy akin kenjallys y Chiarn ayns cheer ny bio.
ny bio] 1769, 1777 ny bioee

English: 16 O tary thou the Lords leasure : be strong, and he shall comfort thine heart; and put thou thy trust in the Lord.
Manx: 16 O jean uss farkiaght er caa yn Chiarn: bee dunnal, as nee eh gerjaghey dty chree, as cur uss dty hreishteil ayns y Chiarn.

English: Ad te Domine. Psal. 28.
Manx: Psal. 28. Ad te, Domine.

English: Unto thee will I cry, O Lord, my strength : thinke no scorne of mee; lest if thou make as though thou hearest not, I become like them that goe downe into the pit.
Manx: 1 Hoods nee’m geamagh, O Hiarn my niart: ny jean beg y hoiaghey jee’m, er aggle mannagh jean oo m’y chlashtyn, dy bee’m casley roosyn ta goll sheese gys yn oaie.

English: 2 Heare the voyce of my humble petitions when I cry unto thee : when I holde up my handes toward the Mercie seat of thy holy Temple.
Manx: 2 Eaisht rish coraa my aghinyn imlee, tra ta mee geamagh ort: tra ta mee troggal seose my laueyn gys stoyl‐y‐vyghin dty hiamble casherick.

English: 3 O plucke mee not away (neither destroy mee) with the ungodly and wicked doers : which speake friendly to their neighbours, but imagine mischiefe in their hearts.
Manx: 3 O ny tayrn mee ersooyl, cha-moo jean m’y stroie marish ny mee‐chrauee as drogh yantee: ta loayrt dy-dooie rish nyn naboo, agh t’ad smooinaghtyn er olkys ayns nyn gree.

English: 4 Reward them according to their deeds : and according to the wickednesse of their owne inventions.
Manx: 4 Cur daue nyn leagh cordail rish nyn yannoo: as cordail rish olkys ny croutyn oc hene.

English: 5 Recompense them after the worke of their hands : pay them that they have deserved.
Manx: 5 Cooilleen ad cordail rish obbyr nyn laueyn: eeck daue shen ny t’ad er hoilchin.

English: 6 For they regard not in their minde the workes of the Lord, nor the operation of his handes : therefore shall hee breake them downe, and not build them up.
Manx: 6 Son cha vel ad ayns nyn aigney cur geill da obbraghyn y Chiarn, cha-moo da jannoo e laueyn: shen‐y‐fa nee eh ad y lieggal sheese, as cha jean eh ad y hroggal.

English: 7 Praised be the Lord : for he hath heard the voice of my humble petitions.
Manx: 7 Moylley dy row da’n Chiarn: son t’eh er chlashtyn coraa my aghinyn imlee.

English: 8 The Lord is my strength and my shield; my heart hath trusted in him, and I am helped : therefore my heart danceth for joy, and in my song will I praise him.
Manx: 8 Yn Chiarn my niart as my eïlley‐caggee; ta my chree er dreishteil aynsyn, as ta mee er gheddyn cooney: shen‐y‐fa ta my chree lheïm dyn voggey, as ayns my arrane nee’m eshyn y voylley.

English: 9 The Lord is my strength : and he is the wholesome defence of his Anointed.
Manx: 9 Yn Chiarn my niart: as eshyn fendeilys slayntoil e Er‐ooïllit.

English: 10 O save thy people, and give thy blessing unto thine inheritance : feed them, and set them up for ever.
Manx: 10 O saue dty phobble, as cur dty vannaght da dty eiraght: cur beaghey daue, as soie ad seose er son dy-bragh.

English: Afferte Domino. Psal. 29.
Manx: Psal. 29. Afferte Domino.

English: Bring unto the Lord (O ye mightie) bring yong rammes unto the Lord : ascribe unto the Lord worship and strength.
Manx: 1 Cur‐jee lhieu gys y Chiarn, O shiuish ard‐gheiney, cur‐jee lhieu reaghyn aegey gys y Chiarn: cur‐jee lieh’n Chiarn ooashley as niart.

English: 2 Give the Lord the honour due unto his Name : worship the Lord with holy worship.
Manx: 2 Cur‐jee da’n Chiarn yn onnor cooie da’n Ennym echey: cur‐jee ooashley da’n Chiarn lesh ammys crauee.
onnor] 1769, 1777 gloyr ta

English: 3 It is the Lord that commandeth the waters : it is the glorious God that maketh the thunder.
Manx: 3 She’n Chiarn ta saarey ny ushtaghyn: yn Jee gloyroil ta jannoo yn taarnagh.

English: 4 It is the Lord that ruleth the sea; the voice of the Lord is mightie in operation : the voice of the Lord is a glorious voice.
Manx: 4 She’n Chiarn ta reill y faarkey; ta coraa’n Chiarn niartal ayns bree: ta coraa yn Chiarn coraa gloyroil.

English: 5 The voice of the Lord breaketh the Cedar trees : yea, the Lord breaketh the Cedars of Libanus.
Manx: 5 Ta coraa yn Chiarn brishey ny biljyn‐cedar: yn Chiarn, dy-feer, ta brishey cedaryn Libanus.

English: 6 Hee made them also to skip like a calfe : Libanus also, and Syrion, like a yong Unicorne.
Manx: 6 T’eh cur orroo myrgeddin dy lheïmeragh myr lheiy: Libanus neesht as Sirion myr unicorn aeg.

English: made] 1662 maketh
7 The voice of the Lord divideth the flames of fire; the voice of the Lord shaketh the wildernesse: yea, the Lord shaketh the wildernesse of Cades.
Manx: 7 Ta coraa yn Chiarn scoltey ny tendeïlyn dy aile; ta coraa yn Chiarn craa yn aasagh: yn Chiarn, dy-feer, ta craa faasagh Chades.

English: 8 The voice of the Lord maketh the Hindes to bring forth yong, and discovereth the thicke bushes : in his Temple doeth every man speake of his honour.
Manx: 8 Ta coraa yn Chiarn cur er ny feaïee nyn lheiyee y hilgey, as roostey tammagyn chiu yn aasagh: as ayns e hiamble ta dy-chooilley ghooinney loayrt jeh e ooashley.

English: 9 The Lord sitteth above the water flood : and the Lord remaineth a King for ever.
Manx: 9 Ta’n Chiarn soie er-skyn ny thooillaghyn: as ta’n Chiarn tannaghtyn ny Ree son dy-bragh.

English: 10 The Lord shal give strength unto his people : the Lord shall give his people the blessing of peace.
Manx: 10 Ver y Chiarn niart da e phobble: ver y Chiarn da e phobble yn bannaght dy hee.

English: The vi. day.
Manx: The 6. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Exaltabo te Domine. Psal. 30.
Manx: Psal. 30. Exaltabo te, Domine.

English: I will magnifie thee, O Lord, for thou hast set mee up : and not made my foes to triumph over me.
Manx: 1 Ver‐yms ard‐voylley dhyts, O Hiarn, son t’ow er my hoiaghey seose: as cha vel oo er lhiggey da my noidyn dy ve mooaralagh harrym.

English: 2 O Lord my God, I cried unto thee : and thou hast healed me.
Manx: 2 O Hiarn my Yee, deïe mee hood: as t’ow er my lheihys.

English: 3 Thou Lord hast brought my soule out of hell : thou hast kept my life from them that goe downe to the pit.
Manx: 3 T’ow uss, Hiarn, er livrey m’annym veih’n oaie: t’ow er vreayll my vioys veih goll sheese gys ooig y vaaish.

English: 4 Sing praises unto the Lord (O ye saints of his) : and give thankes unto him for a remembrance of his holinesse.
Manx: 4 Gow‐jee arraneyn‐moyllee gys y Chiarn, O shiuish e nooghyn: as cur‐jee booise da ayns cooinaghtyn jeh e chasherickys.

English: 5 For his wrath endureth but the twinckling of an eye, and in his pleasure is life : heavinesse may endure for a night, but joy commeth in the morning.
Manx: 5 Son cha vel e chorree farraghtyn agh meekey sooilley, as ayns y foayr echey ta bea: foddee trimshey farraghtyn son oie, agh ta boggey cheet ’sy voghrey.

English: 6 And in my prosperitie I said, I shal never be removed : thou Lord of thy goodnesse hadst made my hill so strong.
Manx: 6 Ayns my staydoilys dooyrt mee, Cha bee’m dy-bragh er my scughey: t’ow uss, Hiarn, jeh dty vieys, er n’yannoo my chronk cha lajer.

English: 7 Thou didst turne thy face (fro me) : & I was troubled.
Manx: 7 Hyndaa oo dt’eddin voym: as va mee seaghnit.

English: 8 Then cried I unto thee, O Lord : and gate mee unto my Lord right humbly.
Manx: 8 Eisht deïe mish hood’s, O Hiarn: as chosne mee gys my Hiarn dy feer imlee.

English: 9 What profit is there in my blood : when I goe downe to the pit?
Manx: 9 Cre’n vondeish t’ayns my uill: tra hem sheese gys yn oaie?

English: 10 Shall the dust give thanks unto thee : or shall it declare thy trueth?
Manx: 10 Der y joan booise dhyt: ny jean eh soilshaghey dt’ynrickys?

English: 11 Heare, O Lord, and have mercie upon mee : Lord be thou my helper.
Manx: 11 Clasht, O Hiarn, as jean myghin orrym: Hiarn, bee uss my er‐coonee.

English: 12 Thou hast turned my heavinesse into joy : thou hast put off my sackcloth, and girded me with gladnesse.
Manx: 12 T’ow er hyndaa my hrimshey gys boggey: t’ow er choyrt jee’m my aanrit-sack, as er my chomm’rey lesh gennallys.

English: 13 Therefore shal every good man sing of thy praise without ceasing : O my God, I wil give thanks unto thee for ever.
Manx: 13 Shen‐y‐fa nee dy-chooilley ghooinney mie goaill arrane jeh dty voylley fegooish skeeys: O my Yee, ver‐yms booise dhyt son dy-bragh.

English: In te Domine speraui. Psal. 31.
Manx: Psal. 31. In te, Domine, speravi.

English: In thee, O Lord, have I put my trust : let me never bee put to confusion, deliver me in thy righteousnesse.
Manx: 1 Ayn-yds, O Hiarn, ta mee er choyrt my hreishteil: ny lhig dou dy-bragh v’er my choyrt gys nearey; livrey mee ayns dty chairys.

English: 2 Bow down thine eare to me : make haste to deliver me.
Manx: 2 Cromm sheese dty chleaysh hym: jean siyr dy my livrey.

English: 3 And be thou my strong rocke, and the house of defence : that thou mayest save me.
Manx: 3 As bee uss my chregg lajer, as thie my endeilys: dy vod oo m’y hauail.

English: and the house] 1662 and house
4 For thou art my strong rocke, and my castle : be thou also my guide, and leade me for thy Names sake.
Manx: 4 Son uss my chregg lajer, as my chashtal: bee uss neesht my leeideilagh, as cur mee er y raad er graih dt’Ennym.

English: 5 Draw mee out of the net that they have layd privily for me : for thou art my strength.
Manx: 5 Tayrn mee ass y ribbeh t’ad er hoiaghey dy-follit er my hon: son uss my niart.

English: 6 Into thy handes I commend my spirit : for thou hast redeemed me, O Lord, thou God of trueth.
Manx: 6 Gys dty laueyn ta mee treishteil m’annym: son t’ow er my livrey, O Hiarn, uss Jee yn ynrickys.
dty laueyn] 1765 dy laueyn

English: 7 I have hated them that hold of superstitious vanities : and my trust hath bene in the Lord.
Manx: 7 Ta dwoaie er ve aym orroosyn ta geiyrt er ny cliaghtaghyn faase‐chredjuagh [dy obbeeys]: as ta my hreishteil er ny ve ayns y Chiarn.

English: 8 I wil be glad, & rejoyce in thy mercy : for thou hast considered my trouble, and hast knowen my soule in adversities.
Manx: 8 Bee’m gennal, as nee’m boggey ’ghoaill ayns dty vyghin: son t’ow er choyrt tastey da my heaghyn, as er chooinaghtyn er my annym ayns treihys.

English: 9 Thou hast not shut me up into the hand of the enemie : but hast set my feet in a large roume.
Manx: 9 Cha vel oo er my yeigh seose ayns laue my noid: agh er hoiaghey my chassyn ayns boayl dy reamys.

English: 10 Have mercie upon mee, O Lord, for I am in trouble : and mine eye is consumed for very heavinesse; yea, my soule and my body.
Manx: 10 Jean myghin orrym, O Hiarn, son ta mee ayns seaghyn: as ta my hoilshey er n’aase moal lesh eer trimshey; dy-jarroo my annym as my challin.

English: 11 For my life is waxen olde with heavinesse : and my yeeres with mourning.
Manx: 11 Son ta my vea er n’aase shenn lesh trimshey: as my vleeantyn lesh dobberan.

English: 12 My strength faileth me, because of mine iniquitie : and my bones are consumed.
Manx: 12 Ta my niart dy m’ailleil, kyndagh rish my vee‐chraueeaght: as ta my chraueyn er choayll nyn mree.
mree] 1769, 1777 mioyr

English: 13 I became a reproofe among all mine enemies, but specially among my neighbors : and they of mine acquaintance were afraid of me; and they that did see mee without conveyed themselves from me.
Manx: 13 Haink mee dy ve son oltooan mastey ooilley my noidyn, agh er‐lheh mastey my naboonyn: as ren adsyn jeh m’ainjys roih er-chea voym, as adsyn honnick mee er y raad, ren ad m’y haghney.

English: 14 I am cleane forgotten, as a dead man out of minde : I am become like a broken vessell.
Manx: 14 Ta mee dy-bollagh er my yarrood, myr dooinney marroo ass cooinaghtyn: ta mee coontit myr saagh brisht.

English: 15 For I have heard the blasphemie of the multitude : and feare is on every side, while they conspire together against me, and take their counsell to take away my life.
Manx: 15 Ta mee er chlashtyn jeh cooyl‐chassid y sleih: as ta aggle er dy-chooilley cheu, choud as t’ad cur nyn ghing cooidjagh, as goaill coyrle dy ghoaill ersooyl my vioys.
cheu] 1819 heu

English: 16 But my hope hath bene in thee, O Lord : I have said, Thou art my God.
Manx: 16 Agh ta my hreishteil er ny ve ayn-yds, O Hiarn: ta mish er ghra, She uss my Yee.

English: 17 My time is in thy hand; deliver mee from the hand of mine enemies : and from them that persecute me.
Manx: 17 Ta my hraa ayns dty laue; livrey mee veih laue my noidyn: as vowesyn ta jannoo tranlaase orrym.

English: 18 Shew thy servant the light of thy countenance: and save me for thy mercies sake.
Manx: 18J eeagh da dty harvaant soilshey dty eddin: as saue mee er graih dty vyghinyn.

English: 19 Let mee not be confounded, O Lord, for I have called upon thee : let the ungodly be put to confusion, and bee put to silence in the grave.
Manx: 19 Ny lhig dou tuittym giare jeh my hreishteil, O Hiarn, son ta mee er n’eamagh ort: lhig da ny mee‐chrauee ve er nyn goyrt gys nearey, as er nyn goyrt nyn‐dost ayns yn oaie.
goyrt] 1765, 1769 ghoyrt ´2

English: 20 Let the lying lips be put to silence : which cruelly, disdainefully, and despitefully speake against the righteous.
Manx: 20 Lhig da ny meillyn breagagh ve er nyn ghoyrt nyn‐dost: ta dy-dewil, dy-mooaralagh, as dy-olkyssagh loayrt noi’n vooinjer chairagh.
goyrt] 1765, 1769 ghoyrt

English: 21 O how plentifull is thy goodnesse which thou hast laid up for them that feare thee : and that thou hast prepared for them that put their trust in thee, even before the sonnes of men.
Manx: 21 O cre cha palchey ta dty vieys, t’ow er chiarail nyn gour ocsyn ta goaill aggle royd: as shen t’ow er n’yannoo aarloo dauesyn ta coyrt nyn dreishteil ayn-yd, dy-jarroo kiongoyrt rish mec gheiney!

English: 22 Thou shalt hide them privily by thine owne presence, from the provoking of all men : thou shalt keepe them secretly in thy Tabernacle from the strife of tongues.
Manx: 22 Nee oo ad y choadey ayns boayl follit dty enish veih brasnaghey dy-chooilley ghooinney: nee oo ad y cheiltyn ayns dty chabbane veih argane chengaghyn.
ghooinney] 1765 ghoinney

English: 23 Thankes be to the Lord : for he hath shewed me marveilous great kindnesse in a strong Citie.
Manx: 23 Dy row booise gys y Chiarn: son t’eh er yeeaghyn dooys kenjallys yindyssagh ayns ard‐valley lajer.

English: 24 And when I made haste, I said : I am cast out of the sight of thine eyes.
Manx: 24 As tra va mee ayns my hiyr, dooyrt mee: Ta mish er my hilgey magh veih shilley dty hooillyn.

English: 25 Neverthelesse thou heardest the voice of my prayer : when I cried unto thee.
Manx: 25 Ny‐yeih, hug oo clashtyn da coraa my phadjer: tra ren mee geamagh ort.

English: 26 O love the Lord all yee his Saints : for the Lord preserveth them that are faithfull, and plenteously rewardeth the proud doer.
Manx: 26 O cur‐jee graih da’n Chiarn, ooilley shiuish e nooghyn: son ta’n Chiarn coadey adsyn ta ynrick, as dy-palchey cooilleeney eshyn ta gymmyrkey eh hene dy mooaralagh.

English: 27 Be strong, and he shall stablish your heart : all yee that put your trust in the Lord.
Manx: 27 Bee‐jee dunnal, as nee eshyn niartaghey nyn gree: shiuish ooilley ta coyrt nyn dreishteil ayns y Chiarn.

English: The vi. day.
Manx: The 6. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Beati quorum. Psal. 32.
Manx: Psal. 32. Beati, quorum.

English: Blessed is hee whose unrighteousnesse is forgiven : and whose sinne is covered.
Manx: 1 Bannit t’eshyn ta e neu‐chairys er ny leih da: as e pheccah er ny choodaghey.

English: 2 Blessed is the man unto whom the Lord imputeth no sinne : and in whose spirit there is no guile.
Manx: 2 Bannit yn dooinney nagh vel y Chiarn cur peccah erbee ny lieh: as ayns e chree nagh vel kialg erbee.
kialg] 1765 kalg

English: 3 For while I held my tongue : my bones consumed away through my dayly complaining.
Manx: 3 Son choud as chumm mee my hengey: ren my chraueyn shymley ersooyl trooid my accan gagh‐laa.

English: 4 For thy hand is heavie upon mee day and night : and my moisture is like the drought in Summer.
Manx: 4 Son ta dty laue trome orrym laa as oie: as ta soo my chorp myr chirmagh‐loshtee yn towrey.

English: 5 I will acknowledge my sinne unto thee : and mine unrighteousnesse have I not hid.
Manx: 5 Goym rish my pheccah hoods: as my neu‐chairys cha vel mee er cheiltyn.

English: 6 I said, I will confesse my sinnes unto the Lord : and so thou forgavest the wickedneses of my sinne.
Manx: 6 Dooyrt mee, Nee’m goaill‐rish my pheccaghyn gys y Chiarn: as myr shen ren uss olkys my pheccah y leih dou.

English: 7 For this shall every one that is godly, make his prayer unto thee in a time when thou mayest bee found : but in the great water-floods they shall not come nigh him.
Manx: 7 Son shoh nee dagh dooinney ta crauee, jannoo e phadjer hood, ayns traa oddys oo v’er dty gheddyn: agh ayns ny thooillaghyn mooarey dy ushtey cha jig ad ny-choar.

English: 8 Thou art a place to hide me in, thou shalt preserve mee from trouble : thou shalt compasse mee about with songs of deliverance.
Manx: 8 T’ow uss ynnyd dy m’ollaghey ayn, nee uss m’y choadey veih seaghyn: nee oo m’y chumbaasal er dy-chooilley cheu lesh arraneyn‐moyllee dy livrey‐ys.
cheu] 1819 heu

English: 9 I will enforme thee, and teach thee in the way wherein thou shalt goe : and I will guide thee with mine eye.
Manx: 9 Ver‐yms tushtey dhyt, as ynsee‐ym dhyt yn raad t’ow dy ghoaill: as nee’m dty leeideil lesh my hooill.

English: 10 Be ye not like to horse and mule, which have no understanding : whose mouthes must be holden with bit and bridle, lest they fall upon thee.
Manx: 10 Ny bee‐jee shiuish goll‐rish cabbyl ny mule, ta fegooish tushtey: yn beeall oc shegin y ve smaghtit lesh beealraghyn as streean, er aggle dy roih ad ort.

English: holden] 1662 held
11 Great plagues remaine for the ungodly : but who so putteth his trust in the Lord, mercy imbraceth him on every side.
Manx: 11 Ta kerraghey trome gour ny mee‐chrauee: agh eshyn ta coyrt e varrant er y Chiarn, ta myghin lhiantyn huggey er dagh cheu.

English: 12 Be glad, O ye righteous, and rejoyce in the Lord : and be joyfull, all ye that are true of heart.
Manx: 12 Bee‐jee gennal, O shiuish sleih ynrick, as gow‐jee boggey ayns y Chiarn: as bee‐jee gerjoil, ooilley shiuish ta firrinagh ayns cree.

English: Exultate iusti. Psal. 33.
Manx: Psal. 33. Exultate, justi.

English: Rejoyce in the Lord, O yee righteous : for it becometh well the just to be thankefull.
Manx: 1Gow‐jee boggey ayns y Chiarn, O shiuish sleih cairagh: son te feer chooie da’n sleih ynrick dy ve booisal.
chooie] 1769, 1777 jesh

English: 2 Praise the Lord with harpe : sing Psalmes unto him with the Lute and instrument of ten strings.
Manx: 2 Moylley‐jee yn Chiarn lesh y chlaasagh: gow‐jee arraneyn‐moyllee da lesh y lute, as y ghreïe-chiaull dy yheih strengyn.

English: Psalmes] 1662 praises
Manx: ghreïe-chiaull] 1765 ghreïe-chai

English: 3 Sing unto the Lord a newe Song : sing praises lustily (unto him) with a good courage.
Manx: 3 Gow‐jee arrane noa gys y Chiarn: trogg‐jee seose nyn goraa huggeysyn ayns bingys dy-jeean as lesh cree gennal.
goraa] 1765, 1769 ghoraa

English: 4 For the word of the Lord is true : and all his workes are faithfull.
Manx: 4 Son ta goo yn Chiarn firrinagh: as ooilley e obbraghyn ynrick.

English: 5 He loveth righteousnesse and Judgement : the earth is full of the goodnesse of the Lord.
Manx: 5 T’eh graihagh er cairys as briwnys: ta’n seihll laane jeh mieys y Chiarn.

English: 6 By the word of the Lord were the heavens made: and all the hostes of them by the breath of his mouth.
Manx: 6 Liorish goo yn Chiarn va ny niaughyn er nyn groo: as ooilley ny pooaraghyn oc liorish ennal e veeal.

English: 7 He gathereth the waters of the sea together, as it were upon an heape : and layeth up the deep as in a treasure house.
Manx: 7 T’eh chaglym ushtaghyn ny marrey cooidjagh, myr carnane: as freayll fo yn diunid vooar myr ayns thie‐tashtee.

English: 8 Let all the earth feare the Lord : stand in awe of him, all ye that dwell in the world.
Manx: 8 Lhig da’n seihll ooilley aggle ’ghoaill roish y Chiarn: bee‐jee er-creau roïshyn, ooilley shiuish cummaltee yn thallooin.

English: 9 For he spake, and it was done : hee commanded, and it stood fast.
Manx: 9 Son loayr eh, as ve jeant: hug eh saarey, as hass eh shickyr.

English: 10 The Lord bringeth the counsell of the heathen to nought : and maketh the devises of the people to be of none effect, and casteth out the counsailes of Princes.
Manx: 10 Ta’n Chiarn coyrt bun-ry‐skyn coyrle ny ashoonyn: as cur er saaseyn croutagh y phobble dy ve gyn‐ymmyd, as cur shaghrynys er coyrleyn ny prinsyn.

English: 11 The counsaile of the Lord shall endure for ever : and the thoughts of his heart from generation to generation.
Manx: 11 Nee coyrle y Chiarn farraghtyn son dy-bragh: as smooinaghtyn e chree veih sheeloghe gys sheeloghe.

English: 12 Blessed are the people, whose God is the Lord Jehova : and blessed are the folke that he hath chosen to him to be his inheritance.
Manx: 12 Bannit yn pobble ta’n Jee oc yn Chiarn Jehovah: as bannit ta’n sleih t’eh er reih son e eiraght.

English: 13 The Lord looked downe from heaven, and beheld all the children of men : from the habitation of his dwelling hee considereth all them that dwell on the earth.
Manx: 13 Yeeagh y Chiarn neose veih niau, as chur eh my‐ner ooilley cloan gheiney: veih stoyl‐reeoil e ynnyd‐vaghee ta sooill echey er cummaltee yn theihll.

English: 14 He fashioneth all the hearts of them : and understandeth all their workes.
Manx: 14 T’eh cummey ooilley ny creeaghyn oc: as toiggal ooilley nyn obbraghyn.

English: 15 There is no king that can be saved by the multitude of an host : neither is any mighty man delivered by much strength.
Manx: 15 Cha vel Ree erbee oddys v’er ny hauail liorish niart e heshaght‐chaggee: cha-moo ta dooinney lajer erbee er ny livrey liorish mooarane niart.

English: 16 A horse is counted but a vaine thing to save a man : neither shall he deliver any man by his great strength.
Manx: 16 Cha vel cabbyl coontit agh red fardalagh dy hauail dooinney: cha-moo oddys eh livrey dooinney erbee liorish mooad’s e niart.

English: 17 Beholde, the eye of the Lord is upon them that feare him : and upon them that put their trust in his mercy;
Manx: 17 Cur‐my‐ner ta sooill y Chiarn orroosyn ta goaill aggle roïsh: as orroosyn ta coyrt nyn dreishteil ayns e vyghin;

English: 18 To deliver their soules from death : and to feede them in the time of dearth.
Manx: 18 Dy livrey yn annym oc veih baase: as dy veaghey ad ayns earish dy ghenney.

English: 19 Our soule hath patiently taried for the Lord : for he is our helpe, and our shield.
Manx: 19 Ta’n annym ain dy-meen er ny ve farkiaght er y Chiarn: she eshyn nyn gooney as nyn vendeilagh.

English: 20 For our heart shall rejoyce in him : because wee have hoped in his holy Name.
Manx: 20 Son gowee nyn gree boggey aynsyn: er‐yn‐oyr dy vel shin er hreishteil ayns e Ennym casherick.

English: 21 Let thy mercifull kindenesse (O Lord) bee upon us : like as we doe put our trust in thee.
Manx: 21 Lhig da dty chenjallys vyghinagh, O Hiarn, ve orrin: ’naght myr ta shin cur nyn dreishteil ayn-yd.

English: Benedicam Domino. Psal. 34.
Manx: Psal. 34. Benedicam Domino.

English: I will alway give thankes unto the Lord : his praise shall ever be in my mouth.
Manx: 1 Ver‐yms dy-kinjagh booise da’n Chiarn: bee e voylley dy-bragh ayns my veeall.

English: 2 My soule shall make her boast of the Lord : the humble shall heare thereof, and be glad.
Manx: 2 Bee m’annym boggyssagh ayns y Chiarn: nee’n sleih imlee clashtyn jeh shen, as bee ad gennal.

English: boast of] 1662 boast in
3 O praise the Lord with mee : and let us magnifie his Name together.
Manx: 3 O moylley‐jee yn Chiarn mârym: as lhig dooin ard‐voylley ’choyrt da’n Ennym echey ry‐cheïley.

English: 4 I sought the Lord, and he heard me : yea, he delivered me out of all my feare.
Manx: 4 Hirr mee yn Chiarn ayns padjer, as cheayll eh mee: as ren eh m’y livrey veih ooilley my aggle.

English: 5 They had an eye unto him, and were lightened: and their faces were not ashamed.
Manx: 5 Yeeagh ad seose huggey, as hooar ad soilshey: as cha row ny eddinyn oc naaragh.

English: 6 Lo, the poore crieth, and the Lord heareth him : yea, and saveth him out of all his troubles.
Manx: 6 Cur‐my‐ner, ta’n boght geamagh, as ta’n Chiarn clashtyn eh: dy-jarroo, as t’eh sauail eh ass ooilley e heaghyn.

English: 7 The Angel of the Lord tarieth round about them that feare him : and delivereth them.
Manx: 7 Ta ainle y Chiarn freayll arrey mygeayrt‐y‐moosyn ta goaill aggle roïsh: as dy livrey ad.

English: 8 O taste and see how gracious the Lord is : blessed is the man that trusteth in him.
Manx: 8 O blasht‐jee, as jeeagh‐jee, cre cha graysoil ta’n Chiarn: bannit yn dooinney ta coyrt e varrant ersyn.

English: 9 O feare the Lord yee that are his Saints : for they that feare him, lacke nothing.
Manx: 9 O gow‐jee aggle roish y Chiarn, shiuish e nooghyn: son adsyn ta goaill aggle roïsh cha bee nhee dy laccal orroo.

English: 10 The lions do lack, and suffer hunger : but they which seeke the Lord, shall want no maner of thing that is good.
Manx: 10 Ta ny lionyn ayns feme, as gennaghtyn accyrys: agh adsyn ta shirrey yn Chiarn, cha bee ad laccal nhee erbee dy vel mie.

English: which] 1662 who
11 Come ye children, and hearken unto mee : I will teach you the feare of the Lord.
Manx: 11 Tarr‐jee, shiuish chloan, as eaisht‐jee rhym: ynsee‐yms diu aggle y Chiarn.

English: 12 What man is hee that lusteth to live, and would faine see good dayes : keepe thy tongue from evil, and thy lips that they speake no guile.
Manx: 12 Quoi’n dooinney eh ta aignagh dy ve beayn: as ballish laghyn mie y akin?

English: keepe, etc.] in 1662 becomes v. 13, with consequent numbering of the remaining verses moved on by one.
Manx: 13 Smaght dty hengey veih olk: as dty veillyn, nagh loayr ad foalsaght erbee.

English: 13 Eschew evil, and doe good : seeke peace, and ensue it.
Manx: 14 Shaghyn dagh olk, as jean dy-mie: shirr lurg shee, as cur eh er y hoshiaght.

English: 14 The eyes of the Lord are over the righteous : and his eares are open unto their prayers.
Manx: 15 Ta sooillyn y Chiarn harrish y sleih cairal: as ta ny cleayshyn echey foshlit gys nyn badjeryn.

English: 15 The countenance of the Lord is against them that doe evil : to root out the remembrance of them from the earth.
Manx: 16 Ta eddin y Chiarn noi ocsyn ta jannoo olk: dy chur ass ny fraueyn yn chooinaghtyn oc veih eaghtyr y thallooin.

English: 16 The righteous cry, and the Lord heareth them: and delivereth them out of all their troubles.
Manx: 17 Ta’n sleih cairagh jannoo aghin, as ta’n Chiarn cur clashtyn daue: as dy livrey ad ass ooilley nyn seaghyn.

English: 17 The Lord is nigh unto them that are of a contrite heart : and wil save such as be of an humble spirit.
Manx: 18 Ta’n Chiarn er‐gerrey dauesyn ta jeh cree brisht: as sauee eh nyn lheid as ta jeh spyrryd imlee.

English: 18 Great are the troubles of the righteous : but the Lord delivereth him out of all.
Manx: 19 S’mooar ta seaghyn y fer‐cairal: agh ta’n Chiarn cur feaysley da assdoo ooilley.

English: 19 Hee keepeth all his bones : so that not one of them is broken.
Manx: 20 T’eh coadey ooilley e chraueyn: myr shen cha vel unnane jeu er ny vrishey.

English: 20 But misfortune shall slay the ungodly : and they that hate the righteous, shall be desolate.
Manx: 21 Agh nee lag‐haghyrt stroie ny mee‐chrauee: as adsyn ta cur dwoaie da’n sleih ynrick, hig y chraagh orroo.

English: 21 The Lord delivereth the soules of his servants : and all they that put their trust in him, shall not be destitute.
Manx: 22 Ta’n Chiarn cur feaysley da anmeenyn e harvaantyn: as adsyn ooilley ta cur nyn marrant ersyn, cha bee ad er nyn dreigeil.

English: The vii. day.
Manx: The 7. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Iudica me Domine. Psal. 35.
Manx: Psal. 35. Judica me, Domine.

English: Pleade thou my cause, O Lord, with them that strive with mee : and fight thou against them that fight against me.
Manx: 1 Gow my chooish ayns laue, O Hiarn, roosyn ta streeu rhym: as jean uss caggey noi ocsyn ta caggey m’oï.

English: 2 Lay hand upon the shield and buckler : and stand up to helpe me.
Manx: 2 Cur dty laue gys y scape as yn eïlley‐caggee: as shass seose dy chooney lhiam.

English: 3 Bring foorth the speare, and stop the way against them that persecute mee : say unto my soule, I am thy salvation.
Manx: 3 Tayrn magh y shleiy, as cur chyndaa dauesyn ta jannoo tranlaase orrym: abbyr rish m’annym, Mish dty haualtys.

English: 4 Let them be confounded and put to shame that seeke after my soule : let them bee turned backe, & brought to confusion, that imagine mischiefe for me.
Manx: 4 Bee ad er nyn gastey, as er nyn goyrt gys nearey, ta shelg lurg m’annym: ver ad cooyl, as bee ad er nyn goyrt mow, ta kiarail olk m’oï.

English: 5 Let them be as the dust before the winde : and the Angel of the Lord scattering them.
Manx: 5 Bee ad myr y joan roish y gheay: as Ainle y Chiarn dyn skeaylley ad.

English: 6 Let their way be darke and slipperie : and let the Angel of the Lord persecute them.
Manx: 6 Bee’n raad oc dorraghey as sliawin: as nee Ainle y Chiarn ad y imman.

English: 7 For they have privily layd their net to destroy me without a cause : yea, even without a cause have they made a pit for my soule.
Manx: 7 Son ren ad dy-follit soiaghey nyn ribbeh dy my stroie gyn oyr: dy-jarroo fegooish oyr ren ad ooig son m’annym.

English: 8 Let a sudden destruction come upon him unawares, and his net that he hath layd privily catch himselfe : that hee may fall into his owne mischiefe.
Manx: 8 Hig toyrt‐mow doaltattym ersyn gyn‐yss, as nee’n ribbeh t’eh er hoiaghey dy-follit eh hene y hayrtyn: dy vod eh tuittym ayns yn olkys echey hene.

English: 9 And my soule, bee joyfull in the Lord : it shall rejoyce in his salvation.
Manx: 9 As m’annym, bee gerjoilagh ayns y Chiarn: nee eh boggey ’ghoaill ayns e haualtys.

English: 10 All my bones shall say, Lord, who is like unto thee, which deliverest the poore from him that is too strong for him : yea, the poore and him that is in miserie, from him that spoileth him?
Manx: 10 Nee ooilley my chraueyn gra, Hiarn, quoi ta casley rhyts, ta livrey yn boght veihsyn ta ro hrean da: dy-jarroo yn boght, as eshyn ta ayns treihys, veihsyn ta dy spooilley eh?

English: which] 1662 who
11 False witnesses did rise up : they laid to my charge things that I knew not.
Manx: 11 Dirree feanishyn foalsey seose: hug ad reddyn gys my lieh nagh row mee kyndagh jeu.

English: witnesses] 1605 witnesse
12 They rewarded me evil for good : to the great discomfort of my soule.
Manx: 12 Deeck ad dooys olk son mie: gys mee-gherjagh mooar m’annym.

English: 13 Neverthelesse, when they were sicke, I put on sacke-cloth, and humbled my soule with fasting : and my prayer shall turne into mine owne bosome.
Manx: 13 Ny-yeih, tra v’adsyn ching, hug mee orrym aanrit-sack, as ren mee m’annym y injillaghey lesh trostey: as chyndaa‐ee my phadjer ayns m’oghrish hene.
ayns m’oghrish] 1769, 1777 gys m’oghrish

English: 14 I behaved my selfe as though it had bene my friend, or my brother : I went heavily, as one that mourneth for his mother.
Manx: 14 Ren mee gymmyrkey mee hene myr gys my charrey, ny my vraar: hie mee dy-trimshagh, myr fer ta dobberan son e voir.

English: 15 But in mine adversitie they rejoyced, & gathered them together : yea, the very abjects came together against me unawares, making mowes at me, and ceased not.
Manx: 15 Agh ayns my arkys ghow ad boggey, as haggil ad cooidjagh: dy-jarroo, haink ny eer ghonnanyn cooidjagh m’oï nagh bione dou, jannoo craid jee’m, as cha scuirr ad.

English: them] 1662 themselves; mowes] 1662 mouthes
Manx: haggil] 1765, 1769 chaggyl

English: 16 With the flatterers were busie mockers : which gnashed upon me with their teeth.
Manx: 16 Marish ny brynnyree va grindeyryn connyssagh: ren snaggeraght orrym lesh nyn veeacklyn.

English: which] 1662 who
17 Lord, how long wilt thou looke upon this : O deliver my soule from the calamities which they bring on me, and my darling from the Lions.
Manx: 17 Hiarn, caid yeeaghys oo er shoh: O livrey m’annym veih ny seaghyn t’ad cur lhieu orrym, as m’annym veih ny lionyn.

English: 18 So will I give thee thankes in the great Congregation : I will praise thee among much people.
Manx: 18 Myr shen ver‐yms booise dhyt ayns y chaglym mooar dy ’leih: nee’m dty voylley mastey mooarane pobble.

English: 19 O let not them that are mine enemies triumph over mee ungodly : neither let them winke with their eyes that hate me without a cause.
Manx: 19 O ny lhig dauesyn ta my noidyn boggyssagh harrym dy-aggairagh: cha-moo lhig daue meekey lesh nyn sooillyn ta dwoaie oc orrym gyn oyr.

English: 20 And why? their communing is not for peace : but they imagine deceitfull words against them that are quiet in the land.
Manx: 20 As cre’n-oyr? cha vel y ghlare oc son shee: agh t’ad soit er goan scammyltagh noi ocsyn ta sheeoil ayns y cheer.

English: 21 They gaped on me with their mouthes, and said: Fie on thee, fie on thee, we saw it with our eyes.
Manx: 21 Doshil ad nyn meeall orrym, as dooyrt ad: Gow nearey, gow nearey, honnick shin eh lesh nyn sooillyn.

English: gaped on] 1662 gaped upon
22 This thou hast seene, O Lord : holde not thy tongue then, goe not farre from me, O Lord.
Manx: 22 Shoh t’ow er vakin, O Hiarn, ny bee dty-host eisht, ny gow foddey voym, O Hiarn.
dty-host] 1765, 1769 dy-host

English: 23 Awake and stand up to judge my quarrel : avenge thou my cause, my God, and my Lord.
Manx: 23 Dooisht, as shass seose dy vriwnys my phlaynt: jean cairys ayns my chooish, my Yee, as my Hiarn.

English: 24 Judge mee, O Lord my God, according to thy righteousnes : and let them not triumph over mee.
Manx: 24 Jean mish y vriwnys, O Hiarn my Yee, cordail rish dty chairys: as ny lhig daue boggyssagh harrym.

English: 25 Let them not say in their hearts, There, there, so would we have it : neither let them say, Wee have devoured him.
Manx: 25 Ny lhig daue gra ayns nyn greeaghyn, Shen, shen, shoh myr baïllin eh: cha-moo lhig daue gra, Ta shin er choyrt mow eh.

English: 26 Let them be put to confusion and shame together that rejoyce at my trouble : let them bee clothed with rebuke and dishonour that boast themselves against me.
Manx: 26 Bee ad er nyn goyrt bun‐ry‐skyn as gys nearey cooidjagh ta goaill boggey jeh my heaghyn: bee ad er nyn goodaghey lesh oghsan as mee‐ooashley ta boggyssagh m’oï.
goyrt] 1765, 1769 ghoyrt

English: 27 Let them be glad and rejoyce that favour my righteous dealing : yea let them say alway, Blessed bee the Lord, which hath pleasure in the prosperitie of his servant.
Manx: 2 7Lhig dauesyn ve gennal as goaill boggey ta er cheu my ghellal yeeragh: dy-jarroo lhig daue dy-kinjagh gra, Bannit dy row yn Chiarn, ta goaill taitnys ayns maynrys e harvaant.

English: which] 1662 who
28 And as for my tongue, it shall be talking of thy righteousnes : and of thy praise all the day long.
Manx: 28 As er son my hengey’s, bee eh loayrt jeh dty chairys: as jeh dty voylley fey‐ny-laa.

English: Dixit iniustus. Psal. 36.
Manx: Psal. 36. Dixit injustus.

English: My heart sheweth me the wickednes of the ungodly : that there is no feare of God before his eyes.
Manx: 1 Ta my chree ginsh dou olkys y vee‐chrauee: nagh vel veg yn aggle dy Yee roish e hooillyn.

English: 2 For he flattereth himselfe in his owne sight : untill his abominable sinne be found out.
Manx: 2 Son t’eh brynnyraght rish hene ayns e hilley hene: derrey vees e pheccah eajee er ny gheddyn magh.

English: 3 The wordes of his mouth are unrighteous, and full of deceit : he hath left off to behave himselfe wisely, & to do good.
Manx: 3 Ta goan e veeall neu‐ynrick as laane dy oalsaght: t’eh er vaagail jeh dy ymmyrkey eh hene dy-creeney, as jeh jannoo dy-mie.

English: 4 He imagineth mischiefe upon his bed, and hath set himselfe in no good way : neither doth he abhorre any thing that is evill.
Manx: 4 T’eh smooinaghtyn er olk er e lhiabbee, as cha vel eh er hoiaghey eh hene ayns raad mie erbee: cha-moo t’eh cur dwoaie da’n red ta olk.

English: 5 Thy mercy, O Lord, reacheth unto the heavens : and thy faithfulnesse unto the clouds.
Manx: 5 Ta dty vyghin, O Hiarn, roshtyn gys ny niaughyn: as dty ynrickys gys ny bodjallyn.

English: 6 Thy Righteousnesse standeth like the strong mountaines : thy Judgements are like the great deepe.
Manx: 6 Ta dty chairys shassoo myr ny sleïtyn ard: ta dty vriwnyssyn goll-rish y diunid vooar.

English: 7 Thou Lord shalt save both man and beast; How excellent is thy mercie, O God : and the children of men shall put their trust under the shadow of thy wings.
Manx: 7 Coadee uss, Hiarn, chammah dooinney as baagh; Cre cha ooasle ta dty vyghin, O Yee: as ver cloan gheiney nyn marrant fo scaa dty skainyn.
baagh] 1765, 1769 beagh

English: 8 They shall bee satisfied with the plenteousnesse of thy house : and thou shalt give them drinke of thy pleasures, as out of the river.
Manx: 8 Bee ad er nyn yannoo magh lesh palchey dty hie: as ver uss daue jough dty eunyssyn myr ass yn awin.

English: 9 For with thee is the well of life : and in thy Light shall we see light.
Manx: 9 Son mârts ta chibbyr y vea: as ayns dty hoilshey nee mayd fakin soilshey.
chibbyr] 1769, 1777 farrane

English: 10 O continue foorth thy loving kindnesse unto them that know thee : and thy righteousnesse unto them that are true of heart.
Manx: 10 O sheeyn magh dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh hucsyn ta coyrt enney ort: as dty chairys dauesyn ta firrinagh ayns cree.

English: 11 O let not the foote of pride come against me : and let not the hand of the ungodly cast me downe.
Manx: 11 O ny lhig da’n chass dy voyrn cheet m’oï: as ny lhig da laue ny mee‐chrauee m’y hilgey sheese.

English: 12 There are they fallen (all) that worke wickednes: they are cast downe, and shall not be able to stand.
Manx: 12 Shen y raad t’ad er duittym, ooilley ny ta gobbraghey mee‐chairys: t’ad er nyn dilgey sheese, as cha bee bree ayndoo dy hassoo.

English: The vii. day.
Manx: The 7. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Noli æmulari. Psal. 37.
Manx: Psal. 37. Noli æmulari.

English: Fret not thy selfe, because of the ungodly : neither bee thou envious against the evill doers.
Manx: 1 Ny jean oo hene y heaghney er coontey ny mee‐chrauee: cha-moo jean uss troo mysh ny drogh‐yantee.
jean oo hene y heaghney] 1819 bee oo fargagh

English: 2 For they shall soone bee cut downe like the grasse : and bee withered even as the greene herbe.
Manx: 2 Son bee adsyn dy-gerrit giarit sheese myr y faiyr: as er nyn vioghey myr y lhuss glass.
as er nyn vioghey myr y lhuss glass] 1769, 1777 as fiojit myr glassyragh y vagher [1769 vaghyr]

English: 3 Put thou thy trust in the Lord, and be doing good : dwell in the land, & verily thou shalt be fed.
Manx: 3 Cur uss dty varrant er y Chiarn, as jean dy-mie: jean cummal ayns y cheer, as bee oo dy-firrinagh er dty yannoo magh.
er dty yannoo] 1765, 1769 er dy yannoo

English: 4 Delight thou in the Lorde : and he shall give thee thy hearts desire.
Manx: 4 Gow taitnys ayns y Chiarn: as ver eh dhyt yeearree dty chree.

English: 5 Commit thy way unto the Lorde, and put thy trust in him : and he shall bring it to passe.
Manx: 5 Treisht gys y Chiarn dty raad, as cur dty varrant er: as ver eshyn lesh eh gy kione.

English: 6 He shall make thy righteousnesse as cleare as the light : and thy just dealing as the noone day.
Manx: 6 Nee eh dty chairys y yannoo cha sollys as y soilshey: as dty ghellal yeeragh myr y vun-laa.

English: 7 Holde thee still in the Lord, and abide patiently upon him : but grieve not thy selfe at him whose way doth prosper, against the man that doeth after evill counsailes.
Manx: 7 Cumm shickyr gys y Chiarn, as farkee dy-surransagh ersyn: as ny lhig da sneih ve ort kyndagh rishyn ta’n seihll cheet lesh, noi’n dooinney ta jannoo lurg drogh choyrlyn.

English: 8 Leave off from wrath, and let goe displeasure : fret not thy selfe, else shalt thou be mooved to doe evill.
Manx: 8 Scuirr veih corree, as faag voïd jymmoose: ny bee er dty vrasnaghey, er aggle dy bee oo er dty ghreinaghey dy yannoo olk.
er dty ghreinaghey] 1765, 1769 er dy ghreinaghey

English: 9 Wicked doers shall bee rooted out : and they that patiently abide the Lord, those shall inherit the land.
Manx: 9 Bee drogh‐yantee er nyn astyrt ass ny fraueyn: as adsyn ta dy-surransagh farkiaght er y Chiarn, yiow ad shoh eiraght ’sy cheer.

English: 10 Yet a little while, and the ungodly shal be cleane gone : thou shalt looke after his place, and he shall be away.
Manx: 10 Foast maghey tammylt beg, as bee’n mee‐chrauee dy-bollagh ersooyl: nee uss jeeaghyn son yn ynnyd echey, as bee eh er n’immeeaght.

English: 11 But the meeke spirited shal possesse the earth : and shal be refreshed in the multitude of peace.
Manx: 11 Agh yiow adsyn ta jeh spyrryd meen eiraght ayns y cheer: as bee ad er nyn ooraghey ayns palchey dy hee.
palchey dy hee] 1769, 1777 mooarane shee

English: 12 The ungodly seeketh counsaile against the just: and gnasheth upon him with his teeth.
Manx: 12 Ta’n vee‐chrauee goaill coyrle noi’n dooinney ynrick: as snaggeraght er lesh e eeacklyn.

English: 13 The Lord shall laugh him to scorne : for he hath seene that his day is comming.
Manx: 13 Cha jean y Chiarn agh craid jeh: son t’eh er vakin dy vel y laa echey er‐gerrey.

English: 14 The ungodly have drawen out the sword, and have bent their bow : to cast downe the poore and needy, and to slay such as be of a right conversation.
Manx: 14 Ta’n vee‐chrauee er dayrn y cliwe, as er lhoobey nyn mhow: dy lieggal sheese y boght as yn ymmyrchagh, as dy stroie ny lheid ocsyn ta jeh ymmyrkey yeeragh.

English: such as be] 1662 such as are
15 Their sword shall goe through their owne heart: and their bow shall be broken.
Manx: 15 Hed y cliwe oc trooid y chree oc hene: as bee’n bow ocsyn er ny vrishey.

English: 16 A small thing that the righteous hath : is better then great riches of the ungodly.
Manx: 16 Ta’n red fardalagh t’ec y dooinney cairagh: ny share na berchys vooar ny mee‐chrauee.

English: 17 For the armes of the ungodly shall be broken : and the Lord upholdeth the righteous.
Manx: 17 Son bee roihaghyn ny mee‐chrauee er nyn mrishey: as ta’n Chiarn cummal seose yn sleih cairagh.

English: 18 The Lord knoweth the dayes of the godly : and their inheritance shall endure for ever.
Manx: 18 Ta fys ec y Chiarn er laghyn y vooinjer chrauee: as farree yn eiraght oc son dy-bragh.

English: 19 They shal not be confounded in the perilous time : and in the dayes of dearth they shall have ynough.
Manx: 19 Cha bee ad seaghnit ayns yn earish ghaueagh: as ayns ny laghyn dy ghenney bee dy-liooar oc.

English: 20 As for the ungodly they shall perish; and the enemies of the Lord shall consume as the fat of lambes : yea, even as the smoke shall they consume away.
Manx: 20 Er son ny mee‐chrauee, nee ad cherraghtyn, as nee noidyn y Chiarn lheïe ersooyl myr meeaylys eayin: dy-feer, myr y jaagh bee ad eebrit ersooyl.

English: 21 The ungodly borroweth, and payeth not againe : but the righteous is mercifull and liberall.
Manx: 21 Ta’n mee‐chrauee goaill er eeasaght, as cha vel eh geeck: agh ta’n dooinney cairagh erreeishagh as feoyltagh.

English: 22 Such as be blessed of God, shall possesse the land : and they that be cursed of him shal be rooted out.
Manx: 22 Nee adsyn ta bannit dy Yee, vaghey ’sy cheer: as adsyn t’eh er gheyrey vees astyrit ass ny fraueyn.

English: Such as be] 1662 Such as are; they that be] 1662 they that are
23 The Lord ordereth a good mans going : and maketh his way acceptable to himselfe.
Manx: 23Ta’n Chiarn goardrail kesmadyn y dooinney mie: as jannoo e raad booisal da hene.

English: 24 Though he fall, he shal not be cast away : for the Lord upholdeth him with his hand.
Manx: 24 Ga dy duitt eh, cha bee eh treigit: son ta’n Chiarn dy chummal eh seose lesh e laue.

English: 25 I have bene yong, and now am olde : and yet saw I never the righteous forsaken, nor his seede begging their bread.
Manx: 25 Va mee aeg, as nish ta mee shenn: as foast cha vaik mee rieau yn dooinney cairagh treigit, cha-moo e lhuight shooyl ny-dhieyn.

English: 26 The righteous is ever merciful, and lendeth : and his seede is blessed.
Manx: 26 Ta’n fer‐cairagh dy-bragh myghinagh, as geeasaght: as ta e lhuight er ny vannaghey.

English: 27 Flee from evill, and doe the thing that is good : and dwell for evermore.
Manx: 27 Chea veih olk, as jean shen ny ta mie: as bee dty chummal foddey beayn.

English: 28 For the Lord loveth the thing that is right : hee forsaketh not his that be godly, but they are preserved for ever.
Manx: 28 Son shynney lesh y Chiarn shen ny ta cairagh: cha vel eh treigeil e vooinjer chrauee hene, agh t’ad er nyn goadey er son dy‑bragh.

English: 29 The righteous shall be punished : as for the seed of the ungodly, it shall be rooted out.
Manx: 29 Bee’n sleih neu‐chairagh er nyn gerraghey: er son sluight ny mee‐chrauee, bee eh astyrit ass ny fraueyn.

English: The righteous (sic)] 1662 The unrighteous
30 The righteous shall inherit the land : and dwel therein for ever.
Manx: 30 Nee’n vooinjer chairagh eiraght ’gheddyn ’sy cheer: as vaghey ayn son dy-bragh.

English: 31 The mouth of the righteous is exercised in wisedome : and his tongue will be talking of judgement.
Manx: 31 Ta beeall y fer‐cairagh loayrt jeh creenaght: as bee e hengey taggloo jeh briwnys.

English: 32 The Law of his God is in his heart : and his goings shall not slide.
Manx: 32 Ta leigh e Yee ayns e chree: as cha jean e chesmadyn skyrraghtyn.

English: 33 The ungodly seeth the righteous : and seeketh occasion to slay him.
Manx: 33 Ta sooill ec y vee‐chrauee er y fer-ynrick: as t’eh shirrey oyr dy stroie eh.

English: 34 The Lord will not leave him in his hand : nor condemne him when he is judged.
Manx: 34 Cha vaag y Chiarn eh ayns e laue: ny eh y gheyrey tra t’eh er ny vriwnys.

English: 35 Hope thou in the Lord, and keepe his way, and he shal promote thee, that thou shalt possesse the land : when the ungodly shall perish, thou shalt see it.
Manx: 35 Treisht uss ayns y Chiarn, as freill yn raad echey, as nee eh uss y vishaghey dy bee eiraght ayd ’sy cheer: tra ta ny mee‐chrauee cherraghtyn, nee oo shen y akin.

English: 36 I my selfe have seene the ungodly in great power: and flourishing like a greene Bay tree.
Manx: 36 Ta mish mee hene er vakin ny mee‐chrauee ayns ard phooar: as blaaghey myr billey glass bay.

English: 37 I went by, and loe he was gone : I sought him, but his place could no where be found.
Manx: 37 Hie mee shiaghey, as cur‐my‐ner, v’eh ersooyl: vrie mee er y hon, agh cha row yn ynnyd echey raad erbee er ny gheddyn.

English: 38 Keepe innocencie, and take heed unto the thing that is right : for that shall bring a man peace at the last.
Manx: 38 Freill oo hene gyn loght, as cur tastey da’n red ta jeeragh: son shen ver lesh shee gys dooinney ec y jerrey.

English: 39 As for the transgressors, they shall perish together : and the end of the ungodly is, They shal be rooted out at the last.
Manx: 39 Er son ny drogh‐yantee, nee ad cherraghtyn cooidjagh: as cronney ny mee‐chrauee te, dy bee ad astyrit magh ec y jerrey.

English: 40 But the salvation of the righteous commeth of the Lord : which is also their strength in the time of trouble.
Manx: 40 Agh ta saualtys y sleih cairagh cheet veih’n Chiarn: ta myrgeddin yn niart oc ayns y traa dy heaghyn.

English: which is] 1662 who is
41 And the Lord shall stand by them, and save them : hee shall deliver them from the ungodly, and shall save them, because they put their trust in him.
Manx: 41 As shassee yn Chiarn lioroo, as sauee eh ad: nee eh ad y livrey veih ny mee‐chrauee, as sauail ad, er yn oyr dy vel ad coyrt nyn dreishteil aynsyn.

English: The viii. day.
Manx: The 8. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Domine ne in furore. Psal. 38.
Manx: Psal. 38. Domine, ne in furore.

English: Put me not to rebuke (O Lord) in thine anger : neither chasten me in thy heavie displeasure.
Manx: 1 Ny cur oghsan dooys, O Hiarn, ayns dty chorree: cha-moo jean m’y smaghtaghey ayns dty yymmoose hrome.
yymmoose] 1765, 1769 ymmoose

English: 2 For thine arrows sticke fast in me : & thy hand presseth me sore.
Manx: 2 Son ta dty hideyn soit dy-shickyr ayn-ym: as ta dty laue lhie orrym dy-trome.

English: 3 There is no health in my flesh, because of thy displeasure : neither is there any rest in my bones, by reason of my sinne.
Manx: 3 Cha vel veg y slaynt ayns m’eill kyndagh rish dty yymmoose: cha-moo ta fea erbee ayns my chraueyn, kyndagh rish my pheccah.
ayns] 1765 ayms

English: 4 For my wickednesses are gone over my head : and are like a sore burden too heavy for me to beare.
Manx: 4 Son ta my pheccaghyn er n’gholl harrish my chione: as t’ad myr errey seaghnagh, ro hrome er my hon dy ymmyrkey.

English: 5 My wounds stink, & are corrupt : through my foolishnes.
Manx: 5 Ta soar trome jeh my lottyn, as t’ad breïn: trooid my ommijys.

English: 6 I am brought into so great trouble and miserie : that I goe mourning all the day long.
Manx: 6 Ta mee er jeet gys lheid y seaghyn mooar as treihys: dy vel mee goll dobberan fey‐ny‐laa.

English: 7 For my loynes are filled with a sore disease : and there is no whole part in my body.
Manx: 7 Son ta my veeaghyn lhieent lesh doghan brogh: as cha vel ayrn erbee slane ayns my chorp.
brogh] 1769, 1777 trome

English: 8 I am feeble and sore smitten : I have roared for the very disquietnesse of my heart.
Manx: 8 Ta mee moal, as gooint dy-trome: ta mee er ullaghey son eer angaaish my chree.

English: 9 Lord, thou knowest all my desire : and my groning is not hid from thee.
Manx: 9 Hiarn, ta fys ayd er ooilley my yeearree: as cha vel m’accan kellit voïd’s.

English: 10 My heart panteth, my strength hath failed mee : and the sight of mine eyes is gone from me.
Manx: 10 Ta my chree pandooagh, ta my niart er my ailleil: as ta soilshey my hooillyn er gholl voym.

English: 11 My lovers and my neighbours did stand looking upon my trouble : and my kinsemen stood afarre off.
Manx: 11 Hass my chaarjyn as my naboonyn jeeaghyn er my heaghyn: as hass my gheiney-mooinjerey foddey jeh.

English: 12 They also that sought after my life, layd snares for me : and they that went about to doe mee evill talked of wickednesse, and imagined deceit all the day long.
Manx: 12 Adsyn neesht va sleeuit er my vioys, ren ribbaghyn y hoiaghey er my hon: as ren adsyn va shirrey dy yannoo aggair dou, taggloo jeh olkys, as smooinaghtyn er molteyraght fey‐ny‐laa.

English: 13 As for me, I was like a deafe man, and heard not: and as one that is dumbe, which doeth not open his mouth.
Manx: 13 Er my hon’s, va mee myr dooinney bouyr nagh row clashtyn: as myr fer ta balloo, nagh vel fosley e veeall.

English: which doeth] 1662 who doth
14 I became even as a man that heareth not : and in whose mouth are no reproofes.
Manx: 14 Va mee dy-jarroo myr dooinney nagh vel clashtyn: as nagh vel fockle echey dy ghra er e hon hene.

English: 15 For in thee, O Lord, have I put my trust : thou shalt answere for me, O Lord my God.
Manx: 15 Son orts, O Hiarn, ta mee er choyrt my varrant: nee uss m’y reggyrt, O Hiarn my Yee.

English: 16 I have required that they, even mine enemies, should not triumph over mee : for when my foot slipt, they rejoyced greatly against me.
Manx: 16 Ta mee er yeearree nagh jinnagh adsyn, dy-jarroo my noidyn, boggyssagh harrym: son tra ren my chass skyrraghtyn, ghow ad mooarane boggey m’oï.

English: 17 And I truely am set in the plague : and my heaviness is ever in my sight.
Manx: 17 As ta mish, dy-firrinagh, soit ayns y cherraghey trome: as ta my hrimshey kinjagh kiongoyrt rhym.

English: 18 For I wil confesse my wickednes : & be sory for my sinne.
Manx: 18 Son nee’m goaill‐rish my olkys: as bee’m trimshagh son my pheccah.

English: 19 But mine enemies live, and are mighty : and they that hate me wrongfully are many in number.
Manx: 19 Agh ta my noidyn bio as niartal: as t’adsyn ta dwoaie oc orrym gyn-oyr, ymmodee ayns earroo.

English: 20 They also that reward evill for good, are against me : because I follow the thing that good is.
Manx: 20 Adsyn neesht ta cooilleeney olk son mie, t’ad m’oï: er‐yn‐oyr dy vel mee geiyrt er shen ny ta mie.

English: 21 Forsake me not, O Lord my God : be not thou far from me.
Manx: 21 Ny treig mee, O Hiarn my Yee: ny bee uss foddey voym.

English: 22 Haste thee to helpe mee : O Lord God my salvation.
Manx: 22 Jean siyr dy chooney lhiam: O Hiarn Yee my haualtys.

English: God my salvation, 1599] 1636, 1660 God of my salvation
Dixi, custodiam. Psal. 39.
Manx: Psal. 39. Dixi, Custodiam.

English: I said, I will take heed to my wayes : that I offend not in my tongue.
Manx: 1 Dooyrt mee, Goym tastey jeh my raaidyn: nagh jean‐ym peccah lesh my hengey.

English: 2 I will keepe my mouth, as it were with a bridle : while the ungodly is in my sight.
Manx: 2 Smaght-ym my veeall myr lesh streean: choud as ta’n vee‐chrauee ayns my hilley.

English: 3 I helde my tongue, and spake nothing : I kept silence, yea, even from good words; but it was paine & griefe to me.
Manx: 3Chumm mee my hengey, as cha loayr mee veg: va mee my-host, dy-jarroo, veih goan mie; agh va shoh pian as trimshey dou.

English: 4 My heart was hotte within mee, and while I was thus musing, the fire kindled : and at the last I spake with my tongue;
Manx: 4 Va my chree cheh cheu‐sthie jee’m; as choud va mee myr shoh ayns smooinaghtyn dowin, ren yn aile greesaghey: as ec y jerrey loayr mee lesh my hengey.

English: 5 Lord, let me know mine ende, and the number of my dayes : that I may be certified how long I have to live.
Manx: 5 Hiarn, cur toiggal dou jeh my yerrey, as earroo my laghyn: dy vod shickyrys ’ve aym caid t’aym dy ve bio.
shickyrys ’ve aym caid t’aym dy ve bio] 1769, 1777 fys ve aym cre cha giare ta my vea

English: 6 Behold, thou hast made my dayes as it were a spanne long : and mine age is even as nothing in respect of thee; and verily every man living is altogether vanity.
Manx: 6 Cur‐my‐ner, t’ow uss er n’yannoo my laghyn myr liurid reaish: as cha vel my eash agh myr red gyn veg dy ve soyllit hoods; as dy-firrinagh ta dy-chooilley ghooinney bio ooilley-cooidjagh fardail.

English: 7 For man walketh in a vaine shadowe, and disquieteth himselfe in vaine : he heapeth up riches, and cannot tell who shall gather them.
Manx: 7 Son ta dooinney gimmeeaght ayns scadoo fardalagh, as dy voïrey eh hene ayns fardail: t’eh stoyral seose berchys, as cha vel fys echey quoi yiow soylley jeu.

English: 8 And now, Lord, what is my hope : truely my hope is even in thee.
Manx: 8 As nish, Hiarn, cre ta my hreishteil? ta my hreishteil dy-jarroo ayn-yds.

English: 9 Deliver mee from all mine offences : and make mee not a rebuke unto the foolish.
Manx: 9 Livrey mee veih ooilley my loghtyn: as ny lhig dou ’ve son craid da’n vooinjer vee‐chrauee.

English: 10 I became dumbe, and opened not my mouth : for it was thy doing.
Manx: 10 Va mee my-host, as cha doshil mee my veeal: son dty yannoo’s ve.

English: 11 Take thy plague away from me : I am even consumed by the meanes of thy heavie hand.
Manx: 11 Scugh dty cherraghey voym: ta mee dy-jarroo ceaut fo errey hrome dty laue.

English: 12 When thou with rebukes doest chasten man for sinne, thou makest his beauty to consume away like as it were a moth fretting a garment : every man therefore is but vanitie.
Manx: 12 Tra t’ow uss ayns dty chorree smaghtaghey dooinney son peccah, t’ow coyrt er yn aalid echey goll mow, myr dy beagh eh garmad eeit lesh lhemeen: cha vel dy-chooilley ghooinney er‐y‐fa shen agh fardail.

English: 13 Heare my prayer, O Lord, and with thine eares consider my calling : hold not thy peace at my teares.
Manx: 13 Eaisht rish my phadjer, O Hiarn, as lesh dty chleayshyn cur geill da my accan: ny bee uss dty-host ec my yheïr.
dty-host] 1765, 1769 dy-host

English: 14 For I am a stranger with thee, and a sojourner : as all my fathers were.
Manx: 14 Son ta mish my yoarree mârts, as my hroailtagh: myr va ooilley m’ayraghyn.

English: 15 O spare mee a little, that I may recover my strength : before I goe hence, and be no more seene.
Manx: 15 O ymmyrk lhiam son tammylt beg, dy voddym my niart y gheddyn reesht: roish my vaag-ym yn seihll shoh, as nagh bee’m arragh er my akin.

English: Expectans expectaui. Psal. 40.
Manx: Psal. 40. Expectans expectavi.

English: I waited patiently for the Lord : and hee enclined unto mee, and heard my calling.
Manx: 1 Ren mee farkiaght dy-surransagh er y Chiarn: as deaisht eh rhym, as cheayll eh my eam.

English: 2 He brought me also out of the horrible pit, out of the myre and clay : and set my feete upon the rocke, and ordered my goings.
Manx: 2 Hug eh lesh mee neesht magh ass y lhag atchimagh, magh ass y lhaagh as y chray: as hoie eh my chassyn er y chregg, as ren eh my immeeaght y oardrail.

English: 3 And hee hath put a newe song in my mouth : even a thankesgiving unto our God.
Manx: 3 As t’eh er choyrt arrane noa ayns my veeall: dy-jarroo, toyrt‐booise gys y Jee ain.

English: 4 Many shall see it, and feare : and shall put their trust in the Lord.
Manx: 4 Nee ymmodee fakin shoh, as aggle y ghoaill: as ver ad nyn dreishteil ayns y Chiarn.

English: 5 Blessed is the man that hath set his hope in the Lord : and turned not unto the proud, and to such as goe about with lies.
Manx: 5 Bannit ta’n dooinney ta er hoiaghey e hreishteil ayns y Chiarn: as nagh vel er hyndaa gys y vooinjer voyrnagh, as gys nyn lheid as ta goll mygeayrt lesh breagyn.

English: 6 O Lord my God, great are thy wonderous workes which thou hast done : like as be also thy thoughts which are to us ward, and yet there is no man that ordereth them unto thee.
Manx: 6 O Hiarn my Yee, smooar ta ny obbraghyn yindyssagh t’ow uss er n’yannoo, myr ta neesht dty smooinaghtyn hooinyn: as foast cha vel y dooinney shen oddys yn earroo oc y hoiaghey royd dy-kiart.

English: 7 If I would declare them and speake of them : they should be mo then I am able to expresse.
Manx: 7 Dy jinnin’s goaill orrym dy hoilshaghey ad, as dy loayrt jeu: veagh ad ny smoo na ta mee fondagh dy hoiaghey magh.

English: If I would] 1662 If I should; mo] 1660 more
Manx: jinnin’s] 1765, 1769 jinninsh

English: 8 Sacrifice and meate offering thou wouldest not have: but mine eares hast thou opened.
Manx: 8 Toyrtys casherick as bee‐oural cha baïlts: agh my chleayshyn t’ow er vosley.

English: wouldest not have] 1662 wouldest not
9 Burnt offerings and sacrifice for sinne hast thou not required : then said I, Loe, I come,
Manx: 9 Chebballyn-losht, as oural son peccah cha vel oo er hirrey: eisht dooyrt mish, Jeeagh, ta mee cheet.

English: 10 In the volume of the booke it is written of me, that I should fulfill thy will, O my God : I am content to do it; yea, thy Law is within my heart.
Manx: 10 Ayns corp y lioar te er ny scrieu jee’ms, dy lhisins dt’aigney ’chooilleeney, O my Yee: ta mee booiagh y yannoo eh; dy-jarroo ta’n leigh ayds er cheu‐sthie dy my chree.
dy my chree] 1777 jeh my chree

English: 11 I have declared thy righteousnes in the great Congregation : loe, I will not refrane my lips, O Lord, and that thou knowest.
Manx: 11 Ta mee er hoilshaghey dty chairys ayns y chaglym mooar: cur‐my‐ner, cha gum-ym my veillyn, O Hiarn, as shen ta fys ayd er.

English: 12 I have not hid thy righteousnes within my heart : my talking hath beene of thy trueth and of thy salvation.
Manx: 12 Cha vel mee er cheiltyn dty chairys cheu‐sthie jeh my chree: ta my haggloo er ny ve jeh dty ynrickys, as jeh dty haualtys.

English: my talking] 1662 my talk
13 I have not kept backe thy loving mercie and trueth : from the great Congregation.
Manx: 13 Cha vel mee er vreayll ergooyl dty vyghin as firrinys: veih’n chaglym mooar.

English: 14 Withdraw not thou thy mercie from mee, O Lorde: let thy loving kindenesse and thy trueth alway preserve mee.
Manx: 14 Ny tayrn dty vyghin ersooyl voym, O Hiarn: lhig da dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh as dty irriney dy-kinjagh mish y choadey.

English: 15 For innumerable troubles are come about mee; my sinnes have taken such hold upon mee, that I am not able to looke up : yea, they are mo in number then the haires of mine head, and mine heart hath failed me.
Manx: 15 Son ta seaghyn er-skyn‐earroo er jeet mygeayrt‐y‐moom; ta my pheccaghyn er ghoaill lheid y ghreme orrym, nagh vel mee abyl jeeaghyn seose: sfeer eh, t’ad ny smoo ayns earroo na renaigyn my khing, as ta my chree dy m’ailleil.
renaigyn] 1765, 1769 renaighyn

English: 16 O Lord, let it be thy pleasure to deliver me : make haste (O Lord) to helpe me.
Manx: 16 O Hiarn, lhig da ve dty aigney dy my livrey: jean siyr, O Hiarn, dy chooney lhiam.

English: 17 Let them bee ashamed and confounded together that seeke after my soule to destroy it : let them bee driven backward and put to rebuke that wish me evill.
Manx: 17 Lhig dauesyn ve er nyn goyrt gys nearey, as er nyn gastey cooidjagh, ta shirrey lurg m’annym dy stroie eh: lhig daue v’er nyn imman gour nyn drommey dy-scammyltagh, ta wooishal olk dou.
goyrt] 1765, 1769 ghoyrt

English: 18 Let them be desolate and rewarded with shame, that say unto me: Fie upon thee, fie upon thee.
Manx: 18 Lhig daue ve treigit, as er nyn gooilleeney lesh nearey: ta gra rhym, Fie ort, fie ort.

English: 19 Let all those that seeke thee, be joyful, and glad in thee : and let such as love thy Salvation, say alway, The Lord be praised.
Manx: 19 Lhig dauesyn ooilley ta dy dty hirrey, ve gennal as boggoil ayn-yds: as lhig dauesyn ta graihagh er dty haualtys, dy-kinjagh gra, Dy row moylley gys y Chiarn.

English: 20 As for me, I am poore and needy : but the Lord careth for me.
Manx: 20 Er my hon’s, ta mee boght as ymmyrchagh: agh ta’n Chiarn kiarail er my hon.

English: 21 Thou art my helper and Redeemer : make no long tarying, O my God.
Manx: 21 Uss my er‐coonee as my er‐kionnee: ny lhig shiaghey foddey, O my Yee.

English: The viii. day.
Manx: The 8. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Beatus qui intelligit. Psal. 41.
Manx: Psal. 41. Beatus qui intelligit.

English: Blessed is he that considereth the poore (and needy) : the Lord shall deliver him in the time of trouble.
Manx: 1 Bannit t’eshyn ta smooinaghtyn er y voght as yn ymmyrchagh: nee’n Chiarn eshyn y livrey ayns traa e heaghyn.

English: 2 The Lord preserve him and keep him alive, that hee may be blessed upon earth : and deliver not thou him into the will of his enemies.
Manx: 2 Dy jean y Chiarn eshyn y choadey as y reayll bio, dy vod eh ve bannit er y thalloo: as ny livrey uss eh gys aigney e noidyn.

English: 3 The Lorde comfort him, when hee lyeth sicke upon his bedde : make thou all his bed in his sickenesse.
Manx: 3 Dy jean y Chiarn eh y gherjaghey tra t’eh ny lhie dy-ching er e lhiabbee: jean uss ooilley e lhiabbee ayns e hingys.

English: 4 I said, Lord be mercifull unto me : heale my soule, for I have sinned against thee.
Manx: 4 Dooyrt mee, Hiarn, bee myghinagh dou: slaanee m’annym, son ta mee er n’yannoo peccah dt’oï.

English: 5 Mine enemies speake evill of me : when shall he die, and his name perish?
Manx: 5 Ta my noidyn loayrt dy-olk jee’m: Cooinn yiow eh baase, as cooinn nee e ennym cherraghtyn?

English: 6 And if he come to see me, he speaketh vanitie: and his heart conceiveth falshood within himselfe, and when he commeth, forth he telleth it.
Manx: 6 As my t’eh cheet dy my yeeaghyn, t’eh loayrt dy-foalsey: as ta e chree giennaghtyn molteyrys cheu‐sthie jeh; as tra t’eh goll roish t’eh d’insh eh.

English: 7 All mine enemies whisper together against me: even against me doe they imagine this evill.
Manx: 7 Ta ooilley my noidyn sonsheraght cooidjagh m’oï: dy-jarroo m’oï t’ad smooinaghtyn er yn olk shoh.

English: 8 Let the sentence of guiltinesse proceed against him : and now that he lyeth, let him rise up no more.
Manx: 8 Lhig da’n vriwnys ta cair da fer-kyndagh goll magh n’oï: as nish dy vel eh ny lhie; ny lhig da girree seose arragh.
da’n vriwnys ta cair da fer-kyndagh goll] 1769, 1777 da briwnys baaish goll, 1819 da briwnys baaish cheet

English: 9 Yea, even mine owne familiar friend whom I trusted : which did also eat of my bread, hath laid great wait for me.
Manx: 9 Dy-jarroo, my charrey ainjyssagh hene, er hug mee my hreisht: eshyn ren neesht gee jeh m’arran, t’eh dy-mooar farkiaght dy-follit er my hon.

English: which] 1662 who
Manx: ren neesht] 1819 neesht ren

English: 10 But be thou merciful unto me, O Lord : raise thou me up againe, and I shall reward them.
Manx: 10 Agh bee uss myghinagh dou, O Hiarn: jean uss m’y hroggal seose reesht, as nee’m ad y chooilleeney,

English: 11 By this I know thou favourest me : that mine enemy doeth not triumph against me.
Manx: 11 Liorish shoh ta fys aym dy vel oo foayroil dou: nagh vel my noid geddyn barriaght m’oï.

English: 12 And when I am in my health, thou upholdest me : and shalt set me before thy face for ever.
Manx: 12 As tra ta mee ec my lhaynt, t’ow dy my chummal seose: as nee oo m’y hoiaghey kiongoyrt rish dt’eddin er son dy-bragh.

English: 13 Blessed bee the Lorde God of Israel : world without end. Amen.
Manx: 13 Bannit dy row yn Chiarn Jee d’Israel: seihll gyn jerrey. Amen.

English: Quemadmodum. Psal. 42.
Manx: Psal. 42. Quemadmodum.

English: Like as the hart desireth the water brookes : so longeth my soule after thee, O God.
Manx: 1 Myr ta’n feeaïh shirrey lurg ny strooanyn ushtey: myr shen ta m’annym goaill foddeeaght dty yeih’s, O Yee.

English: 2 My soule is athirst for God, yea, even for the living God : when shall I come to appeare before the presence of God?
Manx: 2 Ta m’annym pa-agh son Jee, eer son y Jee bio: cooinn higgym dy hassoo kionfenish Yee?

English: 3 My teares have bene my meate day and night : while they dayly say unto me, Where is now thy God?
Manx: 3 Ta my yheïr er ve my veaghey laa as oie: choud as t’ad gagh-laa gra rhym, Cre vel nish dty Yee?

English: 4 Nowe when I thinke thereupon, I powre out my heart by my selfe : for I went with the multitude, & brought them forth into the house of God;
Manx: 4 Nish tra ta mee smooinaghtyn er shoh, ta mee deayrtey magh my chree rhym pene: son hie mee marish y cheshaght, as hug mee lhiam adsyn mârym stiagh ayns thie Yee:

English: 5 In the voyce of praise and thankesgiving : among such as keepe holy day.
Manx: 5 Ayns y kiaulleeaght dy voylley as dy hoyrt‐booise: mastey ny lheid as ta freaylley laa feailley.

English: 6 Why art thou so full of heavinesse (O my soul) : and why art thou so disquieted within me?
Manx: 6 Cre’n‐fa t’ow cha laane dy hrimshey, O m’annym: as cre’n‐fa t’ow cha seaghnit cheu‐sthie jee’m?

English: 7 Put thy trust in God : for I will yet give him thankes for the helpe of his countenance.
Manx: 7 Cur dty hreishteil ayns Jee: son ver‐yms foast booise da son cooney e eddin.

English: 8 My God, my soul is vexed within mee : therefore will I remember thee, concerning the land of Jordane, and the little hill of Hermon.
Manx: 8 My Yee, ta m’annym seaghnit cheu‐sthie jee’m: shen‐y‐fa nee’ms cooinaghtyn orts mychione thalloo Yordan, as cronk beg Hermon.

English: 9 One deepe calleth another, because of the noyse of the water pipes : all thy waves and stormes are gone over me.
Manx: 9 Ta un tonn freggyrt gys tonn elley, liorish feiyr ny thooillaghyn ushtey: ta ooilley ny tonnyn as sterrymyn ayds er gholl harrym.
un tonn freggyrt gys tonn elley] 1769 diunit freggyrt gys diunit, 1777 diunid freggyrt gys diunid; gholl] 1765 goll

English: 10 The Lord hath granted his loving kindnes on the day time : and in the night season did I sing of him, and made my prayer unto the God of my life.
Manx: 10 Ta’n Chiarn er choyrt e chenjallys‐ghraihagh ’sy laa: as ayns imbagh ny hoie ghow mish arrane jehsyn, as ren mee my phadjer gys y Jee jeh my vea.

English: 11 I will say unto the God of my strength, Why hast thou forgotten me : why goe I thus heavily, while the enemie oppresseth me?
Manx: 11 Jir‐yms rish Jee my niart, Cre’n‐fa t’ow er my yarrood: kys ta mee myr shoh goll trimshagh, choud as ta’n noid jannoo tranlaase orrym?

English: 12 My bones are smitten asunder as with a sword : while mine enemies (that trouble me) cast me in the teeth;
Manx: 12 Ta my chraueyn er nyn scarrey veih my‐chielley myr lesh cliwe: choud as ta my noidyn ta dy my heaghney, ceau oltooanyn orrym;

English: 13 Namely, while they say dayly unto me : Where is now thy God?
Manx: 13 Ta shen, choud as t’ad dagh-laa gra rhym: Cre vel nish yn Jee ayd?

English: 14 Why art thou so vexed, O my soule : and why art thou so disquieted within me?
Manx: 14 Cre’n‐fa t’ow cha seaghnit, O m’annym: as cre hon t’ow cha anveagh cheu‐sthie jee’m?

English: 15 O put thy trust in GOD : for I will yet thanke him, which is the helpe of my countenance and my God.
Manx: 15 O cur dty hreishteil ayns Jee: son ver‐yms foast booise da, eh ta slaynt my eddin, as my Yee.

English: Iudica me Deus. Psal. 43.
Manx: Psal. 43. Judica me, Deus.

English: Give sentence with me, O God, and defend my cause against the ungodly people : O deliver me from the deceitfull and wicked man.
Manx: 1Cur briwnys er my cheu, O Yee, as jean my chooish y endeil noi’n sleih mee‐chrauee: O jean m’y livrey veih’n dooinney molteyragh as olkyssagh.
cheu] 1819 heu

English: 2 For thou art the God of my strength, why hast thou put mee from thee : and why goe I so heavily, while the enemie oppresseth me?
Manx: 2 Son uss Jee my niart, cre’n‐fa t’ow er my scughey voïd: as cre hon ta mee goll cha trimshagh choud as ta’n noid jannoo tranlaase orrym?

English: 3 Oh sende out thy light and thy trueth, that they may leade me : and bring me unto thy holy hill, & to thy dwelling.
