Manx: 3 O cur magh dty hoilshey as dty irriney, dy vod ad mee y leeideil: as mee y choyrt lhieu gys dty chronk chasherick, as gys dty ynnyd-vaghee.
mee y leeideil] 1769, 1777 m’y leeideil

English: 4 And that I may goe unto the Altar of God, even unto the God of my joy and gladnesse : and upon the harpe will I give thanks unto thee, O God my God.
Manx: 4 Dy voddym goll gys altar Yee, dy-jarroo gys y Jee jeh my voggey as my yennallys: as er y chlaasagh ver‐yms booise dhyts, O Yee, my Yee.
y Jee jeh my voggey +1777] 1769 y Jee my voggey, 1819 Jee my voggey

English: 5 Why art thou so heavie, O my soul : and why art thou so disquieted within me?
Manx: 5 Cre’n-fa t’ow cha trimshagh, O m’annym: as cre hon t’ow cha anveagh cheu‐sthie jee’m?

English: 6 O put thy trust in God : for I wil yet give him thanks, which is the helpe of my countenance, and my God.
Manx: 6 O cur dty hreishteil ayns Jee: son ver‐yms foast booise da, eh ta slaynt my eddin, as my Yee.

English: The ix. day.
Manx: The 9. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Deus auribus. Psal. 44
Manx: Psal. 44. Deus, auribus.

English: We have heard with our eares, O God, our fathers have tolde us : what thou hast done in their time of olde;
Manx: 1 Ta shin er chlashtyn lesh nyn gleayshyn, O Yee, ta nyn ayraghyn er n’insh dooin: cre ny obbraghyn ren uss ayns y traa ocsyn ’sy chenn earish;

English: 2 How thou hast driven out the Heathen with thy hand, and planted them in : how thou hast destroyed the nations and cast them out.
Manx: 2 Kys t’ow er eiyrt magh ny ashoonyn‐quaagh lesh dty laue, as er hoiaghey adsyn stiagh ’syn ynnyd oc: kys t’ow er stroie ny ashoonyn, as er n’eebyrt ad ersooyl.

English: 3 For they gate not the land in possession through their owne sword : neither was it their owne arme that helped them;
Manx: 3 Son cha dooar ad y cheer ayns nyn gummal liorish y chliwe oc hene: cha-moo she’n roih oc hene ren cooney lhieu.

English: 4 But thy right hand, and thine arme, and the light of thy countenance : because thou haddest a favour unto them.
Manx: 4 Agh dty laue yesh, as dty roih, as soilshey dt’eddin: son dy row aigney mie ayd daue.

English: 5 Thou art my King (O God) : send helpe unto Jacob.
Manx: 5 Uss my Ree, O Yee: cur cooney gys Jacob.

English: 6 Through thee wil we overthrow our enemies : and in thy Name will we tread them under that rise up against us.
Manx: 6 Dty hrooid’s ver mayd nyn noidyn fo-chosh: as ayns dt’Ennym nee mayd stampey sheese adsyn ta girree seose nyn ’oï.
Dty hrooid’s] 1765, 1769 Dy hrooid’s

English: 7 For I wil not trust in my bow : it is not my sword that shall helpe me;
Manx: 7 Son cha der‐ym my varrant gys my vhow: cha nee my chliwe chooinys lhiam.

English: 8 But it is thou that savest us from our enemies : and puttest them to confusion that hate us.
Manx: 8 Agh uss eh ta sauail shin veih nyn noidyn: as ta cur adsyn bun‐ry‐skyn ta dwoaie oc orrin.

English: 9 We make our boast of God all day long : and will praise thy Name for ever.
Manx: 9 Ta shin jannoo nyn moggys ayns Jee fey‐ny‐laa: as ver mayd moylley da dt’Ennym son dy-bragh.
jannoo nyn moggys] 1769 boggyssagh, 1777 boggysagh

English: 10 But now thou art farre off, and puttest us to confusion : and goest not foorth with our armies.
Manx: 10 Agh nish t’ow foddey jeh, as coyrt shin gys nearey: as cha vel oo goll magh marish nyn sheshaghtyn‐caggee.

English: 11 Thou makest us to turne our backs upon our enemies : so that they which hate us, spoile our goods.
Manx: 11 T’ow coyrt orrin chyndaa nyn gooyl er nyn noidyn: myr shen dy vel adsyn ta dwoaie oc orrin spooilley nyn gooid.
noidyn] 1819 naboonyn

English: 12 Thou lettest us be eaten up like sheep : and hast scattered us among the heathen.
Manx: 12 T’ow lhiggey dooin v’er nyn ee seose myr kirree: as er skeayley shin fud ny ashoonyn.

English: 13 Thou sellest thy people for nought : and takest no money for them.
Manx: 13 T’ow creck dty phobble son veg: as cha vel oo goaill veg yn argid er nyn son.

English: 14 Thou makest us to bee rebuked of our neighbours : to bee laughed to scorne and had in derision of them that are round about us.
Manx: 14 T’ow coyrt orrin ve er nyn naaraghey liorish nyn noidyn: as dy v’er nyn gharey orrin gys craid, as ayns faghid lioroosyn ta mygeayrt‐y-mooin.
v’er nyn gharey orrin gys craid] 1769, 1777 ve son gannidys

English: 15 Thou makest us to be a by-word among the heathen : and that the people shake their heads at us.
Manx: 15 T’ow coyrt orrin dy ve an-ghoo mastey ny ashoonyn: as dy vel y pobble craa nyn ghing orrin.

English: 16 My confusion is daily before me : and the shame of my face hath covered me;
Manx: 16 Ta my stayd hreih gagh-laa kiongoyrt rhym: as ta nearey m’eddin er my choodaghey.

English: 17 For the voice of the slanderer and blasphemer: for the enemie and avenger.
Manx: 17 Kyndagh rish goan yn fer‐lunagh as y mollaghtagh: kyndagh rish y noid as yn eulyssagh.

English: 18 And though all this be come upon us, yet do we not forget thee : nor behave our selves frowardly in thy Covenant.
Manx: 18 As ga dy vel ooilley shoh er jeet orrin, ny‐yeih cha vel shin dy dty yarrood: ny gymmyrkey shin hene dy-frourtagh ayns dty chonaant.

English: 19 Our heart is not turned back : neither our steps gone out of thy way;
Manx: 19 Cha vel nyn gree er choyrt cooyl rhyt: cha-moo ta ny kesmadyn ain er gholl ass dty raad;

English: 20 No not when thou hast smitten us into the place of Dragons : and covered us with the shadow of death.
Manx: 20 Cha vel, ga dy vel oo er woalley shin ayns ynnyd ny dragonyn: as er choodaghey shin lesh scadoo yn vaaish.

English: 21 If we have forgotten the Name of our God, and holden up our hands to any strange god : shall not God search it out? for he knoweth the very secrets of the heart.
Manx: 21 My ta shin er yarrood Ennym y Jee ain, as er chummal seose nyn laueyn gys Jee erbee joarree: nagh jean Jee eh y ronsaghey magh? son ta fys echey er eer folliaghtyn y chree.

English: 22 For thy sake also are wee killed all the day long : and are counted as sheepe appointed to be slaine.
Manx: 22 Er y ghraih ayds neesht ta shin er nyn gerraghey fey‐ny‐laa: as coontit myr kirree ta pointit dy v’er nyn stroie.

English: 23 Up Lord, why sleepest thou : awake, and be not absent from us for ever.
Manx: 23 Seose, Hiarn, cre’n‐fa t’ow cadley: dooisht, as ny fuirree voÏn er son dy-bragh.

English: 24 Wherefore hidest thou thy face : and forgettest our miserie and trouble?
Manx: 24 Cre’n‐oyr t’ow follaghey dt’eddin: as jarrood nyn dreihys as seaghyn?

English: 25 For our soule is brought low, even unto the dust : our belly cleaveth unto the ground.
Manx: 25 Son ta’n annym ain er ny chur lesh dy-inshil, dy-jarroo gys y joan: ta’n bolg ain lhiantyn gys y thalloo.

English: 26 Arise, and helpe us : and deliver us for thy mercies sake.
Manx: 26 Irree as cooin lhien: as livrey shin er graih dty vyghinyn.

English: Eructauit cor meum. Psal 45.
Manx: Psal. 45. Eructavit cor meum.

English: My heart is enditing of a good matter : I speake of the things which I have made unto the King.
Manx: 1 Ta my chree smooinaghtyn er cooish vie: ta mee loayrt rish y Ree ny reddyn ta mee er n’yannoo.
smooinaghtyn] 1769 smoinaghtyn dy dowin, 1777 smooinaghtyn dy dowin; loayrt rish y Ree ny reddyn ta mee er n’yannoo] 1769, 1777 goaill lesh bingys ny arraneyn ta mee er n’yannoo mychione y Ree

English: 2 My tongue is the pen : of a readie writer.
Manx: 2 Ta my hengey myr fedjag‐screeuee: yn scrudeyr tappee.

English: 3 Thou art fairer then the children of men : full of grace are thy lips, because God hath blessed thee for ever.
Manx: 3 T’ow ny s’aailey na cloan gheiney: laane dy ghrayse ta dty veillyn, er‐y‐fa dy vel Jee er dty vannaghey son dy‑bragh.

English: 4 Gird thee with thy sword upon thy thigh, O thou most mighty : according to thy worship and renowne.
Manx: 4 Kiangle dty chliwe gys dty lheayst, O uss smoo niartal: cordail rish dty ooashley as dty ghloyr.

English: 5 Good lucke have thou with thine honour : ride on, because of the word of trueth, of meekenesse, and righteousnes; and thy right hand shall teach thee terrible things.
Manx: 5 Ayïh mie dy row lhiat lesh dty ooashley: markee er dty hoshiaght, er coontey yn goo dy firrinys, dy veenid, as dy chairys; as nee dty laue yesh reddyn atchimagh y ynsaghey dhyt.
Ayïh] 1819 Aïgh

English: 6 Thy arrowes are very sharpe, and the people shall be subdued unto thee : even in the middes among the Kings enemies.
Manx: 6 Ta dty hideyn feer virragh, as bee’n pobble er nyn injillaghey hoods: dy-jarroo ayns y vean mastey noidyn y Ree.
dy-jarroo ayns y vean mastey] 1819 hed dty hideyn trooid cree

English: 7 Thy seate (O God) endureth for ever : the Scepter of thy kingdome is a right Scepter.
Manx: 7 Ta dty stoyl, O Yee, farraghtyn son dy-bragh: ta lorg‐reill dty reeriaght lorg-reill chairagh.

English: 8 Thou hast loved righteousnesse, and hated iniquitie : wherefore God (even thy God) hath anointed thee with the oyle of gladnesse above thy fellowes.
Manx: 8 T’ow er choyrt graih da cairys, as feoh da mee‐chairys: shen‐y‐fa ta Jee, dy-jarroo yn Jee ayds, er dt’ooïllaghey lesh yn ooïll dy yennallys er-skyn dty heshaghyn.

English: 9 All thy garments smell of Myrrhe, Aloes, and Cassia : out of the Ivory palaces, wherby they have made thee glad.
Manx: 9 Ta ooilley dty gharmadyn soaral jeh myrrh, aloes, as cassia: magh ass ny plaasyn ivory, lhieu t’ad er dty yannoo gennal.
plaasyn] 1765, 1769 phlaasyn

English: 10 Kings daughters were among thy honourable women : upon thy right hand did stand the Queene in a vesture of gold (wrought about with divers colours).
Manx: 10 Va inneenyn reeaghyn mastey dty vraane ooasle: er dty laue yesh hass y ven-reïn ayns coamrey d’airh, obbrit mygeayrt lesh caghlaaghyn daah.

English: 11 Hearken (O daughter) and consider, encline thine eare : forget also thine owne people, and thy fathers house.
Manx: 11 Clasht, O inneen, as smooinee, cromm dty chleaysh: jarrood myrgeddin dty phobble hene, as thie dty ayrey.
smooinee] 1769, 1777 smooinee ort

English: 12 So shall the King have pleasure in thy beautie : for he is thy Lord (God) and worship thou him.
Manx: 12 Myr shen bee taitnys ec y Ree ayns dty aalid: son eshyn y Chiarn dty Yee, as cur uss ooashley da.

English: 13 And the daughter of Tyre shal be there with a gift : like as the rich also among the people shall make their supplication before thee.
Manx: 13 As bee inneen Tyre ayns shen lesh gioot: myr nee ny berchee myrgeddin mast’ yn pobble nyn aghinyn y yannoo kiongoyrt rhyt.

English: 14 The Kings daughter is all glorious within : her clothing is of wrought gold.
Manx: 14 Ta inneen y Ree ooilley gloyroil er cheu‐sthie: ta’n coamrey eck dy airh obbrit.

English: 15 Shee shal be brought unto the King in raiment of needle worke : the Virgins that be her fellowes shall beare her company, and shall be brought unto thee.
Manx: 15 Bee ee er ny choyrt lh’ee gys y Ree ayns garmad dy obbyr snaidey: ny moidynyn ta e sheshaghyn, cummee ad sheshaght r’ee, as bee ad er nyn jebbal hoods.
lh’ee] 1765, 1769 lheie; ny moidynyn ta e sheshaghyn, cummee ad sheshaght r’ee] 1769, 1777 hig ny moidynyn ta feeau urree ayns dty enish ta e sheshaghyn

English: 16 With joy and gladnesse shall they be brought : and shall enter into the Kings palace.
Manx: 16 Lesh boggey as gennallys vees ad er nyn goyrt lhieu: as hed ad stiagh ayns plaase y Ree.
vees ad er nyn goyrt lhieu] 1769, hig ad maree lhieu, 1777 hig ad lhieu mâree

English: 17 In stead of thy fathers thou shalt have children: whom thou mayest make princes in all lands.
Manx: 17 Ayns ynnyd dt’ayraghyn bee ayd cloan: ad oddys oo y yannoo prinsyn ayns dy-chooilley heer.

English: 18 I wil remember thy Name from one generation to another : therefore shall the people give thankes unto thee world without end.
Manx: 18 Cooin‐yms er dt’Ennym veih sheeloghe gys sheeloghe: shen‐y‐fa ver y pobble booise dhyt, seihll gyn jerrey.

English: Deus noster refugium. Psal. 46.
Manx: Psal. 46. Deus noster refugium.

English: God is our hope and strength : a very present helpe in trouble.
Manx: 1 She Jee nyn dreishteil as niart: cooney feer faggys ayns seaghyn.

English: 2 Therefore will wee not feare though the earth be mooved : and though the hilles bee caried into the middes of the Sea.
Manx: 2 Shen‐y‐fa cha gow mayd aggle, ga dy beagh y seihll er ny chraa: as ga dy beagh ny croink er nyn scughey ayns mean yn aarkey.
ayns] 1769, 1777 gys

English: 3 Though the waters thereof rage & swell : and though the mountaines shake at the tempest of the same.
Manx: 3 Ga dy jinnagh ny ushtaghyn echey freaney as gatt: as ga dy jinnagh ny sleïtyn craa lesh dorrin y chooid cheddin.

English: 4 The rivers of the flood thereof shall make glad the Citie of God : the holy place of the Tabernacle of the most Highest.
Manx: 4 Nee ushtaghyn y thooilley echey ard‐valley Yee y yannoo gennal: ynnyd casherick cabbane‐agglish yn Jee smoo ard.

English: 5 God is in the middest of her, therefore shall shee not be remooved : God shall helpe her, and that right earely.
Manx: 5 Ta Jee ayns y vean ec, shen‐y‐fa cha bee ee er ny scughey: nee Jee cooney lh’ee, as shen dy feer voghey.
lh’ee] 1765, 1769 lheie

English: 6 The heathen make much ado, and the kingdomes are moved : but God hath shewed his voyce, and the earth shall melt away.
Manx: 6 Ta ny ashoonyn goaill lane bea orroo, as ta ny reeriaghtyn er nyn scughey: agh ta Jee er hoilshaghey e choraa, as nee’n seihll lheïe ersooyl.

English: 7 The Lord of hostes is with us : the God of Jacob is our refuge.
Manx: 7 Ta’n Chiarn dy heshaght‐chaggee flaunys mârin: she Jee Yacob yn chemmyrk ain.
1765, 1769, 1819 yn chemmyrk ain] 1777 nyn gemmyrk

English: 8 O come hither, and behold the workes of the Lord : what destruction he hath brought upon the earth.
Manx: 8 O tarr‐jee ayns shoh, as jeeagh‐jee er obbraghyn y Chiarn: cre’n traartys t’eh er choyrt lesh er y theihll.

English: 9 He maketh warres to cease in all the world : he breaketh the bow, and knappeth the speare in sunder, and burneth the chariots in the fire.
Manx: 9 T’eh cur er caggaghyn dy scuirr ayns ooilley yn seihll: t’eh brishey yn bow, as giarey yn shleïy dy peeshyn, as lostey ny fainaghyn ’syn aile.

English: 10 Be still then, and know that I am God : I will be exalted among the heathen, and I will be exalted in the earth.
Manx: 10 Bee‐jee feagh eisht, as toig‐jee dy vel mish Jee: bee’ms er my hoiaghey seose mastey ny ashoonyn, as bee’m er my hoiaghey seose er y thalloo.

English: 11 The Lord of hostes is with us : the God of Jacob is our refuge.
Manx: 11 Ta’n Jee dy heshaght‐chaggee flaunys mârin: she Jee Yacob nyn gemmyrk.

English: The ix. day.
Manx: The 9. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Omnes gentes plaudite. Psal. 47.
Manx: Psal. 47. Omnes gentes, plaudite.

English: O clap your hands together, (all ye people :) O Sing unto God with the voyce of melodie,
Manx: 1 O bwoaill‐jee nyn massyn cooidjagh, ooilley shiuish phobble: O gow‐jee arrane gys Jee lesh y choraa dy vingys.

English: 2 For the Lord is high, and to be feared : hee is the great King upon all the earth.
Manx: 2 Son ta’n Chiarn ard, as aggle dy v’er ny ghoaill roïsh: she eshyn y Ree mooar er fey‐ny‐cruinney.

English: 3 Hee shall subdue the people under us : and the nations under our feet.
Manx: 3 Ver eh sheese y pobble fo-in: as ny ashoonyn fo nyn gassyn.

English: 4 He shall chuse out an heritage for us : even the worship of Jacob whom he loved.
Manx: 4 Nee eshyn eiraght y reih magh nyn gour: dy-jarroo ynnyd ooasle Yacob hug eh graih da.

English: 5 God is gone up with a mery noise : and the Lord with the sound of the Trumpe.
Manx: 5 Ta Jee er gholl seose lesh kiaulleeaght ghennal: as y Chiarn lesh fiyr y chayrn.

English: 6 O sing praises, sing praises unto (our) God : O sing praises, sing praises unto our King.
Manx: 6 O gow‐jee arraneyn‐moyllee, gow‐jee arraneyn‐moyllee gys y Jee ain: O gow‐jee arraneyn‐moyllee, gow‐jee arraneyn‐moyllee gys nyn Ree.

English: 7 For God is the King of all the earth : sing yee praises with understanding.
Manx: 7 Son she Jee Ree’n theihll ooilley: gow‐jee arraneyn‐moyllee lesh tushtey.

English: 8 God reigneth over the heathen : God sitteth upon his Holy seat.
Manx: 8 Ta Jee reill harrish ny ashoonyn: ta Jee ny hoie er e stoyl‐reeoil chasherick.
1765, 1819 chasherick] 1769, 1777 casherick

English: 9 The princes of the people are joyned unto the people of the God of Abraham : for God (which is very high exalted) doeth defend the Earth as it were with a shield.
Manx: 9 Ta prinsyn ny ashoonyn er lhiantyn gys pobble Yee Abraham: son Jee, ta dy-ard er ny hoiaghey seose, ta fendeil y seihll, myr dy beagh eh lesh eïlley‐caggee.

English: Magnus Dominus. Psal. 48.
Manx: Psal. 48. Magnus Dominus.

English: Great is the Lord, and highly to be praised : in the Citie of our God, even upon his Holy hill.
Manx: 1 Mooar ta’n Chiarn, as dy-ard dy v’er ny voylley: ayns ard‐valley yn Jee ain, dy-jarroo er e chronk chasherick.

English: 2 The hill of Sion is a faire place, and the joy of the whole earth : upon the Northside lieth the Citie of the great King; God is well knowen in her palaces, as a sure refuge.
Manx: 2 Ta cronk Sion ynnyd aalin, as boggey yn seihll ooilley: er y cheu tooai ta ard‐valley yn Ree mooar; te ry akin dy vel Jee ayns ny plaasyn ec myr kemmyrk shickyr.
tooai] 1777 twoaie

English: 3 For loe, the Kings of the earth : are gathered and gone by together.
Manx: 3 Son cur‐my‐ner, ta reeaghyn y thallooin: er nyn jaglym, as er n’gholl shiaghey cooidjagh.

English: 4 They marveiled to see such things : they were astonied, and suddenly cast downe.
Manx: 4 Ghow ad yindys dy akin lheid ny reddyn: v’ad lhieent lesh atchim, as ayns y tullogh chaill ad nyn gree.
lhieent] 1765 llieent

English: 5 Feare came there upon them, and sorrow : as upon a woman in her travaile.
Manx: 5 Haink aggle orroo, as trimshey: myr er ben er‐troailt.

English: 6 Thou shalt breake the ships of the Sea : through the East winde.
Manx: 6 Nee uss brishey lhongyn ny marrey: lesh y gheay nharr.

English: 7 Like as we have heard, so have we seene in the City of the Lord of hosts, in the city of our God : God upholdeth the same for ever.
Manx: 7 Myr ta shin er chlashtyn, myr shen ta shin er vakin ayns ard‐valley yn Chiarn dy heshaght‐chaggee flaunys, ayns ard‐valley yn Jee ain: ta Jee dy chummal eh seose son dy-bragh.

English: 8 We wait for thy loving kindnesse (O God :) in the mids of thy Temple.
Manx: 8 Ta shin farkiaght er dty chenjallys-ghraihagh, O Yee: ayns mean dty hiamble.

English: 9 O God, according unto thy Name, so is thy praise unto the worlds end : thy right hand is full of righteousnesse.
Manx: 9 O Yee, myr ta dt’Ennym, myr shen ta dty voylley gys king y theihll: ta dty laue yesh laane dy chairys.

English: 10 Let the mount Sion rejoyce, and the daughters of Juda be glad : because of thy Judgements.
Manx: 10 Lhig da’n cronk Sion goaill boggey, as inneen Yudah ve gennal: er coontey dty vriwnyssyn.

English: 11 Walke about Sion, and go round about her : and tel the towres thereof.
Manx: 11 Shooill mygeayrt Sion, as immee mygeayrt‐y‐mooee: as gow coontey ny tooryn eck.
Shooill mygeayrt] 1769 Shooill-jee mooish, 1777 Shooill-jee mysh; immee] 1769, 1777 immee-jee; gow] 1769, 1777 gow-jee

English: 12 Marke well her bulwarks, set up her houses : that ye may tell them that come after.
Manx: 12 Gow tastey vie jeh ny voallaghyn lajer ec, soie‐jee seose ny thieyn ec: dy vod oo ginsh dauesyn hig nyn yeï.
Gow] 1769, 1777 Gow-jee; oo] 1769, 1777 shiu

English: 13 For this God is our God for ever and ever : he shall be our guide unto death.
Manx: 13 Son she’n Jee shoh yn Jee ain son dy-bragh as dy-bragh: eshyn vees y leeideilagh ain gys laa nyn maaish.

English: Audite hæc omnes. Psal. 49
Manx: Psal. 49. Audite hæc, omnes.

English: O Heare yee this all ye people : ponder it with your eares, all ye that dwell in the world;
Manx: 1 O clasht‐jee rish shoh, ooilley shiuish phobble: gow-jee baght jeh lesh nyn gleayshyn, ooilley shiuish ta vaghey ‘sy theihll.
gow-jee baght jeh lesh nyn gleayshyn] 1769, 1777 eaisht-jee rish

English: 2 High and low, rich and poore : one with another.
Manx: 2 Ard as injil, berchagh as boght: dagh unnane ry‐cheïley.

English: 3 My mouth shall speake of Wisedome : and my heart shall muse of understanding.
Manx: 3 Loayree my veeall jeh creenaght: as nee my chree smooinaghtyn er tushtey.

English: 4 I will incline mine eare to the parable : and shewe my darke speech upon the harpe.
Manx: 4 Cromm‐ym my chleaysh gys y coraa‐dorraghey: as nee’m soilshaghey my ghlare dowin er y chlaasagh.

English: 5 Wherefore should I feare in the days of wickednes : and when the wickednes of my heeles compasseth me round about?
Manx: 5 Cre hon yinnin aggle y ghoaill ayns ny laghyn dy olkys: tra ta olkys my vonnyn cruinnaghey mee mygeayrt.

English: 6 There bee some that put their trust in their goods : and boast themselves in the multitude of their riches.
Manx: 6 Ta paart ta cur nyn marrant gys nyn gooid: as boggyssagh ayns earroo nyn merchys.

English: 7 But no man may deliver his brother : nor make agreement unto God for him;
Manx: 7 Agh cha vod dooinney erbee e vraar y livrey: ny bargane y yannoo rish Jee er y hon.
e vraar] 1765, 1769 y vraar; bargane] 1769, 1777 coonrey

English: 8 For it cost more to redeeme their soules : so that he must let that alone for ever;
Manx: 8 Son haink eh gys ny smoo dy chionnaghey nyn anmeenyn: myr shen dy nhegin da shen y aagail voish er son dy-bragh;
chionnaghey] 1769 lhivrey, 1777 livrey

English: 9 Yea, though he live long : and see not the grave.
Manx: 9 Ga dy beagh eh foddey bio: as gyn yn oaie y akin.

English: 10 For he seeth that wise men also die, & perish together : as wel as the ignorant & foolish, and leave their riches for other.
Manx: 10 Son t’eh fakin dy vel deiney creeney neesht geddyn vaaish as cherraghtyn cooidjagh: chammah as ta’n sleih neu‐chreeney as ommijagh, as faagail nyn merchys da feallagh elley.
vaaish] 1819 baase

English: 11 And yet they thinke that their houses shall continue for ever : and that their dwelling places shall endure from one generation to another; and call their landes after their owne names.
Manx: 11 As foast t’ad sheiltyn dy jean ny thieyn oc farraghtyn son dy-bragh: as dy bee ny ynnydyn‐vaghee oc er‐mayrn veih sheeloghe gys sheeloghe; as t’ad genmys ny baljyn oc lurg nyn ennym hene.

English: 12 Neverthelesse, man wil not abide in honour : seeing he may be compared unto the beasts that perish; this is the way of them.
Manx: 12 Ny-yeih, cha jean dooinney tannaghtyn foddey ayns ooashley: fakin dy vod eh ve er ny hoyllaghey gys y maase ta cherraghtyn; shoh’n raad oc.

English: 13 This is their foolishnesse : and their posteritie praise their saying.
Manx: 13 Shoh’n ommijys oc: as ta nyn sluight moylley yn raa oc.

English: 14 They lie in the hell like sheepe, death gnaweth upon them, and the righteous shall have domination of them in the morning : their beautie shall consume in the sepulchre out of their dwelling.
Manx: 14 T’ad lhie ’syn oaie myr kirree, ta’n baase caigney orroo, as bee reill ec y sleih cairal harrystoo ’sy voghrey: hed yn aalid oc mow ayns yn oaie ass ny cummallyn oc.

English: 15 But God hath delivered my soule from the place of hell : for he shall receive me.
Manx: 15 Agh nee Jee m’annym y livrey veih pooar yn oaie: son nee eh m’y ghoaill huggey hene.

English: 16 Be not thou afraid though one bee made rich : or if the glory of his house be increased;
Manx: 16 Ny gow aggle, ga dy bee fer er ny yannoo berchagh: ny my ta gloyr e hie er ny vishaghey;

English: 17 For hee shall cary nothing away with him when he dieth : neither shall his pompe follow him.
Manx: 17 Son cha der eh lesh veg ersooyl mârish tra t’eh geddyn vaaish: cha-moo nee e stayd vooar geiyrt er.
vaaish] 1777 baase

English: 18 For while he lived, he counted himselfe an happy man : and so long as thou doest well unto thy selfe, men will speake good of thee.
Manx: 18 Son choud’s v’eh bio, yeeagh eh er hene dy ve dooinney maynrey: as choud’s t’ow jannoo dy-mie dhyt hene, loayree deiney dy-mie jeed.

English: 19 He shal follow the generation of his fathers : and shall never see light.
Manx: 19 Eiyree eshyn er sheeloghe e ayraghyn: as cha jean eh dy-bragh soilshey y akin.

English: 20 Man being in honour, hath no understanding: but is compared unto the beasts that perish.
Manx: 20 Dooinney ta ayns ooashley as fegooish tushtey: t’eh er ny hoyllaghey gys ny beïyn ta cherraghtyn.

English: The x. day.
Manx: The 10. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Deus deorum. Psal. 50.
Manx: Psal. 50. Deus deorum.

English: The Lord, even the most mightie God hath spoken : and called the world, from the rising up of the Sunne, unto the going downe thereof.
Manx: 1 Ta’n Chiarn, dy-jarroo yn Jee smoo niartal, er loayrt: as er choyrt eam da’n seihll veih irree seose ny greïney gys y gholl sheese echey.

English: 2 Out of Sion hath God appeared : in perfect beautie.
Manx: 2 Magh ass Sion ta Jee er hoilshaghey eh hene: ayns aalid firrinagh.

English: 3 Our God shall come, and shall not keepe silence: there shall goe before him a consuming fire, and a mightie tempest shall bee stirred up round about him.
Manx: 3 Hig y Jee ain, as cha bee eh ny‐host: hed aile roishyn nee toyrt mow, as bee dorrin niartal er ny ghoostey seose mygeayrt‐y‐mysh.

English: 4 He shal call the heaven from above : and the earth, that he may judge his people.
Manx: 4 Nee eh geamagh er ny niaughyn veih’n yrjid: as er y theihll, dy vod eh briwnys e phobble.

English: 5 Gather my Saints together unto me : those that have made a covenant with me with sacrifice.
Manx: 5 Chaggle‐jee my nooghyn cooidjagh hyms: ad shen ta er n’yannoo conaant rhym lesh oural;

English: 6 And the heavens shall declare his righteousnesse : for God is judge himselfe.
Manx: 6 As nee ny niaughyn fockley magh e chairys: son Jee hene yn Briw.

English: 7 Heare, O my people, and I wil speake : I myselfe will testifie against thee, O Israel; for I am God, even thy God.
Manx: 7 Clasht, O my phobble, as nee’ms loayrt: nee’ms mee hene feanish y ymmyrkey dt’oï, O Israel; son mish Jee, dy-jarroo yn Jee ayds.

English: 8 I will not reproove thee because of the sacrifices, or for thy burnt offerings : because they were not alway before mee.
Manx: 8 Cha der‐yms oghsan dhyt son dty ourallyn, ny son dty hebballyn‐losht: son nagh row ad kinjagh kiongoyrt rhym.

English: the sacrifices] thy sacrifices 1581, 1636, 1660, 1662
9 I wil take no bullocke out of thy house : nor hee goats out of thy folds.
Manx: 9 Cha jean‐ym soiagh jeh dow erbee ass dty hie: ny goar-yrryn ass dty woaillee.

English: 10 For all the beasts of the forest are mine : and so are the cattels upon a thousand hils.
Manx: 10 Son lhiam’s ta ooilley maase ny keilley: as myrgeddin ta’n ollagh er thousane cronk.

English: 11 I know all the foules upon the mountaines : and the wilde beasts of the field are in my sight.
Manx: 11 Shione dou ooilley ny eeanlee t’er ny sleïtyn: as ta maase feïe yn vagher ayns my hilley.

English: 12 If I be hungry, I wil not tel thee : for the whole world is mine, and all that is therein.
Manx: 12 My ta mee accryssagh, cha ninsh‐ym dhyts: son ta’n slane seihll lhiam’s, as ooilley ny t’ayn.

English: 13 Thinkest thou that I will eate buls flesh : and drinke the blood of Goates?
Manx: 13 Vel oo smooinaghtyn dy nee‐ym feill teirroo: as dy niu‐ym fuill goair?

English: 14 Offer unto God thankesgiving : and pay thy vowes unto the most Highest.
Manx: 14 Cheb yn oural dy hoyrt‐booise gys Jee: as eeck dty vreearaghyn dasyn smoo Ard;

English: 15 And call upon me in the time of trouble : so wil I heare thee, and thou shalt praise me.
Manx: 15 As eïe orryms ayns traa dy heaghyn: myr shen nee’ms geaishtagh rhyt, as nee oo mish y voylley.

English: 16 But unto the ungodly said God : Why doest thou preach my Lawes, and takest my Covenant in thy mouth?
Manx: 16 Agh rish ny mee‐chrauee dooyrt Jee: Cre hon t’ow preacheil my leighyn, as goaill my chonaant ayns dty veeall;

English: 17 Whereas thou hatest to be reformed : and hast cast my wordes behind thee.
Manx: 17 Fakin dy vel dwoaie ayd er lhiasaghey-bea: as t’ow er hilgey my ghoan cheu-dty-chooyloo.
cheu-dty-] 1765, 1769 cheu-dy-

English: 18 When thou sawest a thiefe, thou consentedst unto him : and hast bene partaker with the adulterers.
Manx: 18 Tra honnick oo maarliagh, va dt’aigney lesh: as t’ow er ghoaill ayrn mâroosyn ta brishey poosey.

English: 19 Thou hast let thy mouth speake wickednes : and with thy tongue thou hast set forth deceit.
Manx: 19 T’ow er choyrt reamys da dty veeall dy loayrt olkys: as lesh dty hengey t’ow er hoiaghey magh molteyraght.

English: 20 Thou satest and spakest against thy brother : yea, and hast slandered thine owne mothers sonne.
Manx: 20 Hoie oo, as loayr oo noi dty vraar: dy-jarroo, as t’ow er choyrt scammylt da mac dty vayrey.

English: 21 These things hast thou done, and I held my tongue, and thou thoughtest wickedly, that I am even such a one as thy selfe : but I wil reproove thee, and set before thee the things that thou hast done.
Manx: 21 Ny reddyn shoh t’ow er n’yannoo, as chumm mish my hengey; as heill oo dy-olkyssagh dy row mish eer dty lheid hene: agh ver‐yms oghsan dhyt, as soie‐ym kiongoyrt rhyt ny reddyn t’ow er n’yannoo.

English: 22 O consider this, ye that forget God : lest I plucke you away, and there be none to deliver you.
Manx: 22 O smooinee‐jee er shoh, shiuish ta jarrood Jee: er aggle dy raip‐ym shiu ersooyl, as nagh bee unnane erbee dy livrey shiu.

English: 23 Who so offereth me thankes and praise, he honoureth mee : and to him that ordereth his conversation right, will I shew the salvation of God.
Manx: 23 Quoi‐erbee ta chebbal dou booise as moylley, t’eh cur onnor dou: as dasyn, ta reill e ymmyrkey dy-cair, soilshee-yms saualtys Yee.

English: Miserere mei Deus. Psal. 51.
Manx: Psal. 51. Miserere mei, Deus.

English: Have mercie upon me, O God, after thy great goodnesse : according to the multitude of thy mercies do away mine offences.
Manx: 1 Jean myghin orrym, O Yee, lurg dty vieys vooar: cordail rish ymmodee dty vyghinyn cur ersooyl my loghtyn.

English: 2 Wash me throughly from my wickednesse : and cleanse me from my sinne.
Manx: 2 Niee mee dy-bollagh veih m’olkys: as glen mee veih my pheccah.

English: 3 For I knowledge my faults : & my sin is ever before me.
Manx: 3 Son ta mee goaill‐rish m’oiljyn: as ta my pheccah kinjagh kiongoyrt rhym.

English: 4 Against thee onely have I sinned, and done this evil in thy sight : that thou mightest bee justified in thy saying, and cleare when thou art judged.
Manx: 4 Dt’oï’s dty‐lomarcan ta mee er n’yannoo peccah, as er chur rish yn olk shoh ayns dty hilley: dy voddagh oo v’er dty heyrey ayns dty raa, as ynrick tra t’ow briwnys.
dty-lomarcan] 1765, 1769 dy-lomarcan; dty heyrey] 1765, 1769 dy heyrey

English: 5 Beholde, I was shapen in wickednesse : and in sinne hath my mother conceived me.
Manx: 5 Cur‐my‐ner va mee er my chummey ayns olkys: as ayns peccah ren my voir m’y yiennaghtyn.

English: 6 But loe, thou requirest trueth in the inward parts: and shalt make me to understand wisedome secretly.
Manx: 6 Agh cur‐my‐ner, t’ow shirrey firrinys ayns ny ayrnyn er cheu‐sthie: as ver oo orrym toiggal creenaght dy-follit.

English: 7 Thou shalt purge me with Hysope, & I shal be cleane : thou shalt wash me, and I shal be whiter then snow.
Manx: 7 Nee oo mish y ghlenney lesh hyssop, as bee’m glen: nee oo m’y niee, as bee’m ny s’gilley na sniaghtey.

English: 8 Thou shalt make me heare of joy and gladnesse : that the bones which thou hast broken may rejoyce.
Manx: 8 Ver oo orrym clashtyn jeh boggey as gennallys: dy vod ny craueyn t’ow er vrishey boggey ’ghoaill.

English: 9 Turne thy face from my sinnes : and put out all my misdeeds.
Manx: 9 Chyndaa dt’eddin veih my pheccah: as cur ersooyl ooilley my ghrogh‐yannoo.

English: 10 Make me a cleane heart, O God : and renew a right spirit within me.
Manx: 10 Croo ayn-ym cree glen, O Yee: as jean ass‐y‐noa spyrryd cairagh cheu‐sthie jee’m.

English: 11 Cast mee not away from thy presence : and take not thy holy Spirit from me.
Manx: 11 Ny tilg mee ersooyl veih dt’enish: as ny gow dty Spyrryd Casherick voym.

English: 12 O give me the comfort of thy helpe againe : and stablish me with thy free spirit.
Manx: 12 O cur dou reesht gerjagh dty chooney: as niartee mee lesh dty Spyrryd arryltagh.

English: 13 Then shall I teach thy wayes unto the wicked : and sinners shal be converted unto thee.
Manx: 13 Eisht nee’ms dty raaidyn y ynsaghey da ny mee‐chrauee: as bee peccee er nyn jyndaa hoods,

English: 14 Deliver me from bloodguiltines, O God, thou that art the God of my health : & my tongue shal sing of thy righteousnes.
Manx: 14 Livrey uss mee veih loght‐folley, O Yee, uss ta Jee my lhaynt: as nee my hengey arrane y ghoaill jeh dty chairys.
Livrey uss mee] 1769, 1777 Livrey mee; loght-folley] 1765 loght-foalley

English: 15 Thou shalt open my lips (O Lord :) and my mouth shall shew thy praise.
Manx: 15 Nee uss my veillyn y osley, O Hiarn: as nee my veeall soilshaghey magh dty voylley.

English: 16 For thou desirest no sacrifice, els would I give it thee : but thou delightest not in burnt offerings.
Manx: 16 Son cha vel oo shirrey oural, nonney yinnin dhyt eh: cha vel taitnys ayd ayns chebballyn‐losht.

English: 17 The sacrifice of God is a troubled spirit : a broken and contrite heart (O God) shalt thou not despise.
Manx: 17 Ta ourallyn Yee spyrryd seaghnit: cree brisht as arryssagh, O Yee, cha soie uss beg jeh.

English: 18 O be favourable and gracious unto Sion : build thou the walles of Hierusalem.
Manx: 18 O bee uss foayroil as graysoil da Sion: trogg seose voallaghyn Yerusalem.

English: 19 Then shalt thou be pleased with the sacrifice of righteousnesse, with the burnt offerings and oblations : then shall they offer yong bullocks upon thine Altar.
Manx: 19 Eisht nee uss boggey ’ghoaill aynsyn lesh oural dy chairys, ayns ourallyn‐losht as chebballyn: eisht nee ad chebbal dew aegey er dt’altar.
aynsyn lesh oural] 1769, 1777 ayns yn oural

English: Quid gloriaris? Psal. 52.
Manx: Psal. 52. Quid gloriaris?

English: Why boastest thou thy selfe, thou tyrant : that thou canst doe mischiefe?
Manx: 1 Cre hon t’ow boggyssagh jeed hene, uss hranlaasagh: dy vod oo olk y yannoo;

English: 2 Whereas the goodnesse of God : endureth yet dayly?
Manx: 2 Fakin dy vel mieys Yee: farraghtyn foast gagh‐laa?

English: 3 Thy tongue imagineth wickednes : and with lies thou cuttest like a sharpe rasor.
Manx: 3 Ta dty hengey soit er olkys: as lesh breagyn t’ow giarey goll‐rish skynn yhear.
yhear] 1819 ghyere

English: 4 Thou hast loved unrighteousnes more then goodnes : and to talke of lies more then righteousnes.
Manx: 4 T’ow er ny ve ny s’graihee er neu‐chairys na er mieys: as dy haggloo jeh breagyn ny smoo na jeh cairys.
er ny ve] 1819 er ve; s’graihagh] 1769, 1777 s’graihee

English: 5 Thou hast loved to speake all words that may do hurt : O thou false tongue.
Manx: 5 Va taitnys ayd dy loayrt dy-chooilley ockle oddagh assee y yannoo: O uss hengey oalsey.

English: 6 Therefore shall God destroy thee for ever : he shall take thee, and plucke thee out of thy dwelling, and roote thee out of the land of the living.
Manx: 6 Shen‐y‐fa nee Jee oo y stroie er son dy-bragh: gow-ee eh oo, as tayrnee eh oo ass dty chummal, as nee eh oo y astyrt magh ass cheer y sleih bio.
gow-ee eh oo] 1769 nee eh dy ghoaill, 1777 nee eh dty ghoaill; tayrnee eh oo] 1769 dy hayrn, 1777 dty hayrn

English: 7 The righteous also shall see this, and feare : and shall laugh him to scorne;
Manx: 7 Hee yn sleih cairal shoh myrgeddin, as gow-ee ad aggle: as nee ad craidey mysh as gearey;

English: 8 Lo, this is the man that tooke not God for his strength : but trusted unto the multitude of his riches, & strengthened himselfe in his wickednesse.
Manx: 8 Jeeagh, shoh’n dooinney nagh ghow Jee son e niart: agh hug e varrant gys e verchys vooar, as ren eh hene y niartaghey ayns e olkys.

English: 9 As for me, I am like a greene Olive tree in the house of God : my trust is in the tender mercie of God for ever & ever.
Manx: 9 Er my hon’s, ta mee myr billey‐olive glass ayns thie Yee: ta my hreishteil ayns myghin meigh Yee son dy-bragh as dy-bragh.

English: 10 I wil alwaies give thanks unto thee for that thou hast done : & I wil hope in thy Name, for thy Saints like it well.
Manx: 10 Ver‐yms booise dhyt dy-kinjagh son shen ny t’ow er n’yannoo: as nee’m treishteil ayns dt’Ennym, son shynney lesh dty nooghyn eh dy-mie.

English: The x. day.
Manx: The 10. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Dixit insipiens. Psal. 53.
Manx: Psal. 53. Dixit insipiens.

English: The foolish body hath saide in his heart : There is no God.
Manx: 1 Ta’n peccagh ommijagh er ghra ayns e chree: Cha vel Jee erbee.
erbee] 1769, 1777 erbee ayn

English: 2 Corrupt are they, and become abominable in their wickednes : there is none that doeth good.
Manx: 2 T’adsyn er jeet dy ve feer vee‐chrauee, as dwoaiagh ayns yn olkys oc: cha vel unnane erbee ta jannoo dy-mie.

English: 3 God looked downe from heaven upon the children of men : to see if there were any that would understand, and seeke after God.
Manx: 3 Yeeagh Jee neose veih niau er cloan gheiney: dy akin row veg jeu yinnagh toiggal, as shirrey lurg Jee.

English: 4 But they are all gone out of the way, they are altogether become abominable : there is also none that doeth good, no not one.
Manx: 4 Agh t’ad ooilley er gholl ass y raad, t’ad ooilley-cooidjagh er jeet dy ve feohdoil: cha vel unnane myrgeddin ta jannoo dy-mie, cha vel eer unnane.

English: 5 Are not they without understanding that worke wickednesse : eating up my people as if they would eate bread? they have not called upon God.
Manx: 5 Nagh vel adsyn fegooish tushtey ta gobbraghey olkys: gee seose my phobble myr ee‐agh ad arran? cha vel ad er eamagh er Jee.
er eamagh] 1819 er n’eamagh

English: 6 They were afraid where no feare was : for God hath broken the bones of him that besieged thee; thou hast put them to confusion, because God hath despised them.
Manx: 6 V’ad agglit raad nagh row oyr aggle: son ta Jee er vrishey ny craueyn echeysyn ren soiaghey ort; t’ow er choyrt ad gys nearey, son dy vel Jee er hoiaghey beg jeu.

English: 7 Oh that the Salvation were given unto Israel out of Sion : Oh that the Lord would deliver his people out of captivitie.
Manx: 7 Oh, dy jinnagh Jee Saualtys da Israel magh ass Sion: Oh, dy jinnagh y Chiarn e phobble y livrey magh ass cappeeys!

English: 8 Then should Jacob rejoyce : and Israel should bee right glad.
Manx: 8 Eisht yinnagh Jacob boggey ’ghoaill: as veagh Israel feer yennal.

English: Deus in Nomine. Psal. 54.
Manx: Psal. 54. Deus, in nomine.

English: Save me, O God, for thy Names sake : and avenge mee in thy strength.
Manx: 1 Saue mee, O Yee, er graih dt’Ennym: as gow my phaart ayns dty niart.

English: 2 Heare my prayer, O God : and hearken unto the wordes of my mouth.
Manx: 2 Cur clashtyn da my phadjer, O Yee: as eaisht rish goan my veeall.

English: 3 For strangers are risen up against mee : and tyrants (which have not God before their eyes) seeke after my soule.
Manx: 3 Son ta joarreeyn er n’irree seose m’oï: as ta tranlaasee nagh vel Jee oc roish nyn sooillyn shirrey lurg my vioys.

English: 4 Beholde, God is my helper : the Lord is with them that uphold my soule.
Manx: 4 Cur‐my‐ner, she Jee m’er‐coonee: ta’n Chiarn mâroosyn ta cummal seose m’annym.

English: 5 He shall reward evil unto mine enemies : destroy thou them in thy trueth.
Manx: 5 Cooilleenee eshyn olk da my noidyn: jean adsyn y stroie ayns dty ynrickys.

English: 6 An offering of a free heart will I give thee, and praise thy Name, O Lord : because it is so comfortable.
Manx: 6 Oural dy chree arryltagh ver‐ym dhyt, as dt’Ennym y voylley, O Hiarn: son dy vel eh cha gerjoilagh.

English: 7 For he hath delivered me out of all my trouble : & mine eye hath seene his desire upon mine enemies.
Manx: 7 Son t’eh er my livrey ass ooilley my heaghyn: as ta my hooill er vakin e eearree er my noidyn.

English: Exaudi Deus. Psal. 55.
Manx: Psal. 55. Exaudi, Deus.

English: Heare my prayer, O God : and hide not thy selfe from my petition.
Manx: 1 Clasht rish my phadjer, O Yee: as ny follee oo hene veih my accan.

English: 2 Take heed unto me, & heare me : how I mourne in my prayer, and am vexed.
Manx: 2 Gow tastey jee’m, as eaisht rhym: kys ta mee gaccan ayns my phadjer, as ta mee seaghnit.

English: 3 The enemie crieth so, and the ungodly commeth on so fast : for they are minded to doe me some mischiefe, so maliciously are they set against me.
Manx: 3 Ta lheid yn ullagh er my noid, as ta ny mee‐chrauee cheet orrym cha chion: son t’ad kiarit dy yannoo olk ennagh dou, cha goanlyssagh shen t’ad soit m’oï.

English: 4 My heart is disquieted within mee : and the feare of death is fallen upon me.
Manx: 4 Ta my chree anveagh cheu‐sthie jee’m: as ta aggle y vaaish er duittym orrym.

English: 5 Fearfulnesse and trembling are come upon mee : and an horrible dread hath overwhelmed mee.
Manx: 5 Ta aggle as creau er jeet orrym: as ta atchim seaghnagh er my hilgey harrish.

English: 6 And I saide, Oh that I had wings like a Dove : for then would I flee away, and be at rest.
Manx: 6 As dooyrt mee, O dy beagh aym skainyn myr t’ec calmane: son eisht etlin ersooyl, as veïn ec fea.

English: 7 Lo, then would I get me away far off : and remaine in the wildernesse.
Manx: 7 Cur‐my‐ner, yinnin eisht cosney roym foddey jeh: as fuirraght ayns yn aasagh.

English: 8 I would make haste to escape : because of the stormie winde and tempest.
Manx: 8 Yinnin siyr dy scapail: kyndagh rish y gheay stermagh as y dorrin.

English: 9 Destroy their tongues, O Lord, and divide them : for I have spied unrighteousnesse and strife in the Citie.
Manx: 9 Stroie ny chengaghyn oc, O Hiarn, as cur ad noï-ry‐hoï: son ta mee er vakin neu‐chairys as streeu ayns yn ard‐valley.

English: 10 Day and night they go about within the walles thereof : mischiefe also and sorrow are in the mids of it.
Manx: 10 Laa as oie t’ad goll mygeayrt ny voallaghyn eck; ta olkys neesht as trimshey ’sy vean eck.

English: 11 Wickednesse is therein : deceit and guile goe not out of their streets.
Manx: 11 Olkys t’ayn: cha vel molteyraght as foalsaght goll ass ny straidyn oc.

English: 12 For it is not an open enemie that hath done me this dishonour : for then I could have borne it.
Manx: 12 Son cha nee noid foshlit t’er n’yannoo yn vee‐onnor shoh dou: son eisht oddin v’er ymmyrkey eh.

English: 13 Neither was it mine adversary that did magnifie himselfe against me : for then (peradventure) I would have hid my selfe from him.
Manx: 13 Cha-moo she fer va ayns drogh aigney dou hrog eh hene seose m’oï: son eisht foddee dy beïn er vollaghey mee hene veih;
veih] 1769 woish, 1777 voish, 1819 veih

English: 14 But it was even thou my companion : my guide, and mine owne familiar friend.
Manx: 14 Agh oo hene v’ayn, my heshey: my leeideilagh, as my charrey ainjyssagh.

English: 15 We took sweete counsell together : and walked in the house of God as friends.
Manx: 15 Ghow shin coyrle villish cooidjagh, as ren shin shooyll gys thie Yee myr caarjyn.
shooyll] 1765 shoyll

English: 16 Let death come hastily upon them, and let them goe downe quicke into hell : for wickednesse is in their dwellings, and among them.
Manx: 16 Lhig da baase cheet orroo dy-siyragh, as lhig daue goll sheese bio ayns yn oaie: son ta olkys ayns nyn gummallyn, as ny mast’ oc.

English: 17 As for mee, I will call upon God : and the Lord shall save me.
Manx: 17 Er my hon’s, eïe‐ym er Jee: as nee’n Chiarn m’y hauail.

English: 18 In the evening and morning, and at noone day wil I pray, and that instantly : and he shall heare my voyce.
Manx: 18 Fastyr, as moghrey, as ec y vun‐laa nee’m padjer y ghoaill, as shen dy-jeean: as clynnee eh my choraa.

English: 19 It is he that hath delivered my soule in peace, from the battel that was against me : for there were many with me.
Manx: 19 She eshyn ta er livrey m’annym ayns shee, veih’n chaggey va m’oï: son va ymmodee mârym.

English: 20 Yea, even God that endureth for ever shall heare me, and bring them downe : for they wil not turne, nor feare God.
Manx: 20 Dy-jarroo, Jee hene, ta farraghtyn dy-bragh, nee m’y chlashtyn, as ver lesh adsyn sheese: son cha jean ad chyndaa, ny goaill aggle roish Jee.

English: 21 He layde his hands upon such as be at peace with him : and he brake his covenant.
Manx: 21 Chur eh [yn noid] e laueyn orroosyn va ayns shee rish: as vrish eh e chonaant.
[yn noid] absent in 1769, 1777, 1819

English: 22 The words of his mouth were softer then butter, having warre in his heart : his wordes are smoother then oile, and yet be they very swords.
Manx: 22 Va goan e veeall ny s’buiggey na eeym, as caggey ayns e chree: va e ghoan ny shliawney na ooïll, as foast t’ad cliwnyn hene.

English: are smoother] 1581, 1636, 1660, 1662 were smoother
23 O cast thy burden upon the Lord, and he shall nourish thee : and shall not suffer the righteous to fall for ever.
Manx: 23 O tilg dty errey er y Chiarn, as nee eh dty chummal seose: as cha lhig eh da’n fer‐cairagh tuittym son dy-bragh.

English: 24 And as for them : thou, O God, shalt bring them into the pit of destruction.
Manx: 24 Agh er nyn son ocsyn: ver uss lhiat ad, O Yee, ayns yn ooig dy hoyrt-mow.

English: 25 The bloodthirstie and deceitfull men shall not live out halfe their dayes : neverthelesse, my trust shall be in thee, O Lord.
Manx: 25 Cha bee ny deiney foalley as molteyragh bio yn derrey lieh jeh nyn laghyn: agh bee my hreishteil ayn-yds, O Hiarn.

English: The xi. day.
Manx: The 11. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Miserere mei Deus. Psal. 56.
Manx: Psal. 56. Miserere mei, Deus.

English: Be mercifull unto mee, O God, for man goeth about to devour me : he is dayly fighting, and troubling me.
Manx: 1 Bee myghinagh dooys, O Yee, son ta dooinney shirrey dy my stroie: t’eh gagh‐laa caggey as dy my heaghney.

English: 2 Mine enemies are dayly in hand to swallow mee up : for they bee many that fight against mee, O thou most Highest.
Manx: 2 Ta my noidyn gagh‐laa goaill ayns laue dy my luggey seose: son t’adsyn ymmodee ta caggey m’oï, O uss smoo Syrjey.

English: 3 Neverthelesse, though I am sometime afraide : yet put I my trust in thee.
Manx: 3 Ny‐yeih, ga dy vel aggle orrym ny cheayrtyn: foast ta mee coyrt my hreishteil ayn-yds.

English: 4 I will praise God, because of his word : I have put my trust in God, and will not feare what flesh can do unto me.
Manx: 4 Ver‐yms moylley da Jee son e ghoo: ta mee er choyrt my hreishteil ayns Jee, as cha goym aggle cre oddys dooinney y yannoo rhym.

English: 5 They dayly mistake my words : all that they imagine, is to doe me evil.
Manx: 5 T’ad gagh‐laa goaill my ghoan marran: ooilley ny t’ad smooinaghtyn er te dy yannoo olk dou.

English: 6 They holde all together, and keepe themselves close : and marke my steps, when they lay wait for my soule.
Manx: 6 T’ad ooilley lhiantyn ry-cheïley, as freayll ad hene dy-follit: as cur tastey da my chesmadyn, tra t’ad lhie farkiaght son m’annym.

English: 7 Shall they escape for their wickednesse : thou, O God, in thy displeasure shalt cast them downe.
Manx: 7 Jed ad gyn kerraghey son nyn olkys: nee uss, O Yee, ayns dty yymmoose ad y hilgey sheese.

English: 8 Thou tellest my flittings; put my teares into thy bottel : are not these things noted in thy Booke?
Manx: 8T’ow freayll coontey jeh my imman veih boayl dy boayl; cur my yheïr ayns dty voteil: nagh vel ny reddyn shoh scruit ayns dty lioar?

English: 9 Whensoever I call upon thee, then shall mine enemies be put to flight : this I know; for God is on my side.
Manx: 9 Cre‐erbee yn traa ta mee geamagh ort, eisht bee my noidyn eebrit ersooyl: shoh ta fys aym er; son ta Jee er my cheu.
cheu] 1819 heu

English: 10 In Gods word wil I rejoyce : in the Lords word will I comfort me.
Manx: 10 Ayns goo Yee goym boggey: ayns goo yn Chiarn nee’m mee hene y gherjaghey.

English: 11 Yea, in God have I put my trust : I will not be afraid what man can doe unto me.
Manx: 11 Dy-jarroo, ayns Jee ta mee er choyrt my hreishteil: cha goym aggle cre oddys dooinney y yannoo rhym.

English: 12 Unto thee, O God, will I pay my vowes : unto thee will I give thankes.
Manx: 12 Dhyts, O Yee, eeck‐ym my vreearaghyn: dhyts ver‐ym booise.

English: 13 For thou hast delivered my soul from death, and my feete from falling : that I may walke before God in the light of the living.
Manx: 13 Son t’ow er livrey m’annym veih baase, as my chassyn veih tuittym: dy voddym gimmeeaght kiongoyrt rish Jee ayns soilshey yn sleih bio.

English: Miserere mei Deus. Psal. 57.
Manx: Psal. 57. Miserere mei, Deus.

English: Be mercifull unto me, O God, be mercifull unto me, for my soule trusteth in thee : and under the shadow of thy wings shall be my refuge, untill this tyrannie be overpast.
Manx: 1 Bee myghinagh dooys, O Yee, bee myghinagh dou, son ta m’annym treishteil ayn-yd: as fo scaa dty skainyn vees my chemmyrk derrey vees y tranlaase shoh er n’gholl shiagh‐ym.

English: 2 I will call unto the most High God : even unto the God that shall performe the cause which I have in hand.
Manx: 2 Nee’m geam gys y Jee smoo ard: dy-jarroo gys y Jee nee yn chooish t’aym ayns laue y chooilleeney.

English: 3 He shall send from heaven : and save mee from the reproofe of him that would eate me up.
Manx: 3 Ver eh cooney hym veih niau: as sauee eh mee veih’n scammylt echeysyn ballish mee y stroie.

English: 4 God shall send foorth his mercie and trueth : my soule is among Lions.
Manx: 4 Ver Jee magh e vyghin as e ynrickys: ta m’annym mastey lionyn.

English: 5 And I lie even among the children of men (that are set on fire :) whose teeth are speares and arrowes, and their tongue a sharpe sword.
Manx: 5 As ta mee my lhie dy-jarroo mastey cloan gheiney, ta soit er aile: nyn veeacklyn t’ad shleïghyn as sideyn, as nyn jengey ny chliwe gyere.

English: 6 Set up thy selfe, O God, above the heavens : and thy glory above all the earth.
Manx: 6 Soie oo hene seose, O Yee, er-skyn ny niaughyn: as dty ghloyr er-skyn ooilley’n seihll.

English: 7 They have layde a net for my feete, and pressed downe my soule : they have digged a pit before me, and are fallen into the mids of it themselves.
Manx: 7 T’ad er hoiaghey lieen son my chassyn, as er hionney sheese m’annym: t’ad er chleigh jeeg roym, as ad hene er duittym ayns y vean echey.

English: 8 My heart is fixed, O God, my heart is fixed : I will sing and give praise.
Manx: 8Ta my chree soit, O Yee, ta my chree soit: goym arrane, as ver‐ym moylley.
soit] 1769 er soit ... soit er, 1777 soit er ´2

English: 9 Awake up my glory; awake Lute and Harp : I my selfe will awake right earely.
Manx: 9 Dooisht seose, my ghloyr; dooisht lute as chlaasagh: dooisht‐yms mee hene feer voghey.

English: 10 I wil give thanks unto thee, O Lord, among the people : and I wil sing unto thee among the Nations.
Manx: 10 Ver‐ym booise dhyts, O Hiarn, mastey’n pobble: as goym arrane hoods mastey ny ashoonyn;

English: 11 For the greatnesse of thy Mercy reacheth unto the heavens : and thy Trueth unto the cloudes.
Manx: 11 Son ta mooads dty vyghin roshtyn gys ny niaughyn: as dt’irriney gys ny bodjallyn.

English: 12 Set up thy selfe, O God, above the heavens : and thy glory above all the earth.
Manx: 12 Soie oo hene seose, O Yee, er-skyn ny niaughyn: as dty ghloyr er-skyn ooilley yn seihll.

English: Si verè vtique.Psal. 58.
Manx: Psal. 58. Si vere utique.

English: Are your minds set upon righteousnesse, O yee Congregation : and doe yee judge the thing that is right, O yee sonnes of men?
Manx: 1 Vel nyn aignaghyn soit er cairys, O shiuish phobble: as vel shiu briwnys shen ta cairagh, O shiuish cloan gheiney?

English: 2 Yea, ye imagine mischiefe in your heart upon the earth : and your hands deale with wickednesse.
Manx: 2 Dy-jarroo ta shiu smooinaghtyn er olkys ayns nyn gree er y thalloo: as ta ny laueyn eu dellal rish mee‐chraueeaght.

English: 3 The ungodly are froward even from their mothers wombe : assoone as they be borne, they go astray & speake lies.
Manx: 3 Ta ny mee‐chrauee frourtagh, dy-jarroo veih breïn nyn mayrey: cha leah as t’ad er nyn ruggey, t’ad goll er‐shaghryn, as loayrt breagyn.

English: be borne] 1662 are born
4 They are as venemous as the poyson of a Serpent : even like the deafe Adder that stoppeth her eares;
Manx: 4 T’ad cha nieunagh as pyshoon ard‐nieu: dy-jarroo myr yn addyr bouyr ta dooney ny cleayshyn eck;

English: 5 Which refuseth to heare the voyce of the charmer : charme he never so wisely.
Manx: 5 Ta gobbal dy eaishtagh rish bingys y khiaullyder: lhig e haase‐kiaullee ’ve cha millish as sallish.

English: 6 Breake their teeth (O God) in their mouthes; smite the jaw bones of the Lions, O Lord : let them fall away like water that runneth apace; and when they shoote their arrowes, let them be rooted out.
Manx: 6 Brish ny feeacklyn oc, O Yee, ayns nyn meeall; bwoaill craueyn‐keeill ny lionyn, O Hiarn: lhig daue tuittym ersooyl myr ushtey ta roih dy-tappee; as tra t’ad lhiggey nyn sideyn, lhig daue ve astyrit ass ny fraueyn.

English: 7 Let them consume away like a snaile, and bee like the untimely fruit of a woman : and let them not see the Sunne.
Manx: 7 Lhig daue lheïe ersooyl myr crammag, as ve goll‐rish mess ben ta er jeet roish y traa: as ny lhig daue fakin y ghrian.

English: 8 Or ever your pots be made hot with thornes : so let indignation vexe him, even as a thing that is raw.
Manx: 8 Ny roish ta ny pooiyt eu er ny hiow lesh drineyn: myr shen lhig da jymmoose eh y heaghney myr red ta’n vio rish.
er ny chiow] 1777 er ny hiow

English: 9 The righteous shall rejoyce when he seeth the vengeance : he shall wash his footsteps in the blood of the ungodly.
Manx: 9 Gow‐ee yn dooinney cairagh boggey tra hee eh yn kerraghey: nee eh e chesmadyn y niee ayns fuill ny mee‐chrauee.

English: 10 So that a man shal say, Verily there is a reward for the righteous : doubtlesse there is a God that judgeth the earth.
Manx: 10 Myr shen dy jirr dooinney, Dy-firrinagh ta leagh gour y sleih cairagh: gyn dooyt ta Jee ayn ta briwnys y theihll.

English: The xi. day.
Manx: The 11. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Eripe me de inimicis. Psal. 59.
Manx: Psal. 59 Eripe me de inimicis.

English: Deliver me from mine enemies (O God :) defend me from them that rise up against me.
Manx: 1 Livrey mee veih my noidyn, O Yee: jean m’y endeil vowesyn ta girree‐magh m’oï.

English: 2 O deliver me from the wicked doers : and save mee from the bloodthirstie men.
Manx: 2 O livrey mee veih ny drogh‐yantee: as saue mee veih ny deiney ta pa-agh lurg fuill.

English: 3 For loe, they lie waiting for my soule : the mightie men are gathered against mee, without any offence or fault of me, O Lord.
Manx: 3 Son cur‐my‐ner, t’ad lhie farkiaght son my vioys: ta ny deiney niartal er nyn jaglym m’oï, fegooish foill ny aggair erbee voyms, O Hiarn.

English: 4 They runne and prepare themselves without my fault : arise thou therefore to helpe me, and behold.
Manx: 4 T’ad roih as jannoo ad hene aarloo fegooish foill erbee ayn-yms: trog ort er‐y‐fa shen dy chooney lhiam, as cur‐my‐ner.

English: 5 Stand up (O Lord God of hosts) thou God of Israel, to visite all the heathen : and be not mercifull unto them that offend of malicious wickednesse.
Manx: 5 Shass seose, O Hiarn Yee dy heshaght‐chaggee flaunys, uss Yee Israel, dy ghoaill kerraghey er ooilley ny ashoonyn: as ny bee myghinagh dauesyn ta ass olkys goanlyssagh jannoo aggair.

English: 6 They goe to and fro in the evening : they grinne like a dogge, and runne about through the Citie.
Manx: 6 T’ad goll noon as noall ’syn astyr: t’ad grindee myr moddey, as roih mygeayrt trooid yn ard‐valley.

English: 7 Behold, they speake with their mouth, and swords are in their lips : for who doeth hear?
Manx: 7 Cur‐my‐ner, t’ad loayrt lesh nyn meeall, as ta cliwnyn ayns nyn meillyn: son quoi ta clashtyn?

English: 8 But thou, O Lord, shalt have them in derision : and thou shalt laugh all the heathen to scorne.
Manx: 8 Bee ad, O Hiarn, ayds ayns faghid: as nee oo garaghtee er ooilley ny ashoonyn‐quaagh gys craid.

English: 9 My strength will I ascribe unto thee : for thou art the God of my refuge.
Manx: 9 My niart goym rish dy nee voïds te: son uss yn Jee dy my chemmyrk.

English: 10 God sheweth me his goodnesse plenteously : and God shall let me see my desire upon mine enemies.
Manx: 10 Ta Jee jeeaghyn dou e vieys dy-palchey: as lhiggee Jee dou my yeearree y akin er my noidyn.

English: 11 Slay them not, lest my people forget it : but scatter them abroad among the people, and put them downe, O Lord, our defence.
Manx: 11 Ny marr ad, er aggle dy jarrood my phobble eh: agh skeayll ad dy-lhean mastey’n pobble, as cur sheese ad, O Hiarn, nyn vendeilagh.

English: 12 For the sinne of their mouth, and for the words of their lips, they shall be taken in their pride : and why? their preaching is of cursing and lies.
Manx: 12 Kyndagh rish peccah nyn meeall, as goan nyn meillyn, bee ad goit ayns y voyrn oc hene: as cre’n‐oyr? ta’n ghlare oc jeant jeh gweeaghyn as breagyn.

English: 13 Consume them in thy wrath, consume them, that they may perish : and know that it is God which ruleth in Jacob, and unto the ends of the world.
Manx: 13 Cur mow ad ayns dty chorree, cur mow ad, dy vod ad cherraghtyn: as toiggal dy nee Jee ta reill ayns Jacob, as gys khing y theihll.

English: which ruleth] 1662 that ruleth
14 And in the evening they will returne : grinne like a dogge, and will goe about the Citie.
Manx: 14 As ayns yn astyr nee ad chyndaa reesht: grindee myr moddey, as hed ad mygeayrt yn ard‐valley.

English: 15 They wil runne here and there for meate : and grudge if they be not satisfied.
Manx: 15 Roih‐ee ad noon as noall son bee: as gow‐ee ad dy-olk rish mannagh bee ad jeant magh.

English: 16 As for me, I will sing of thy power, and will praise thy mercy betimes in the morning : for thou hast bene my defence and refuge in the day of my trouble.
Manx: 16 Er my hon’s, goym arrane jeh dty phooar, as nee’m dty vyghin y voylley dy-leah ’sy voghrey: son t’ow uss er ve my choadey as my chemmyrk ayns laa my heaghyn.

English: 17 Unto thee (O my strength) will I sing : for thou, O God, art my refuge, and my mercifull God.
Manx: 17 Hoods, O my niart, goym arrane: son t’ow uss, O Yee, my chemmyrk, as my Yee vyghinagh.

English: Deus repulisti nos. Psal. 60.
Manx: Psal. 60. Deus repulisti nos.

English: O God, thou hast cast us out, & scattered us abroad : thou hast also bene displeased; O turne thee unto us againe.
Manx: 1 O Yee, t’ow er hilgey shin magh, as er skeayley shin dy-lhean: t’ow myrgeddin er ve jymmoosagh rooin; O chyndaa hooinyn reesht.

English: 2 Thou hast mooved the land, and divided it : heale the sores thereof, for it shaketh.
Manx: 2 T’ow er ghleashaght y cheer, as er scarrey eh: slaanee ny chingyn echey, son te craa.

English: 3 Thou hast shewed thy people heavy things : thou hast given us a drinke of deadly wine.
Manx: 3 T’ow er yeeaghyn da dty phobble reddyn trimshagh: t’ow er choyrt dooin jough feeyn baasoil.
feeyn] 1769, 1777 feeyney

English: 4 Thou hast given a token for such as feare thee : that they may triumph because of the Trueth.
Manx: 4 T’ow er choyrt cowrey da nyn lheid as ta goaill aggle royd: dy vod ad boggyssagh er coontey yn irriney.

English: 5 Therefore were thy beloved delivered : helpe me with thy right hand, and heare me.
Manx: 5 Shen‐y‐fa va’n vooinjer bynney lhiat er nyn livrey: cooin lhiam lesh dty laue yesh, as clasht rhym.

English: 6 God hath spoken in his Holinesse, I will rejoyce and divide Sichem : and mete out the valley of Succoth.
Manx: 6 Ta Jee er loayrt ayns e chasherickys, Nee’m boggey ‘ghoaill as rheynn‐ym Sichem: as towse‐ym magh coan Succoth.

English: 7 Gilead is mine, and Manasses is mine : Ephraim also is the strength of my head; Juda is my Lawgiver;
Manx: 7 Ta Gilead lhiam’s, as lhiam’s Manasses: ta Ephraim myrgeddin niart my chione; she Juda ta coyrt my leigh.

English: 8 Moab is my washpot; over Edom will I cast out my shooe : Philistia be thou glad of me.
Manx: 8 Moab my haagh‐nieeaghyn, harrish Edom ceau-ym magh my vraag: Philistia, gow uss boggey jee’m.
harrish Edom ceau-ym magh my vraag] 1769, 1777 shooill‐ym harrish Edom

English: 9 Who will leade me into the strong Citie : who wil bring me into Edom?
Manx: 9 Quoi nee m’y leeideil ayns yn ard‐valley lajer: quoi ver lesh mee stiagh gys Edom?

English: 10 Hast not thou cast us out, O God : wilt not thou, O God, goe out with our hostes?
Manx: 10 Nagh vel uss er hilgey magh shin, O Yee: Nagh jean uss, O Yee, goll magh marish ny sheshaghtyn‐caggee ain?

English: 11 O bee thou our helpe in trouble : for vaine is the helpe of man.
Manx: 11 O bee uss nyn gooney ayns seaghyn: son s’fardalagh ta cooney dooinney.

English: 12 Through God will wee do great actes : for it is hee that shall tread downe our enemies.
Manx: 12 Trooid Jee nee mayd obbraghyn mooarey: son she eshyn stampys sheese nyn noidyn.

English: Exaudi Deus. Psal. 61.
Manx: Psal. 61. Exaudi, Deus.

English: Heare my crying, O God : give eare unto my prayer.
Manx: 1 Clasht rish my eam, O Yee: eaisht rish my phadjer.

English: 2 From the ends of the earth will I call unto thee: when my heart is in heavinesse.
Manx: 2 Veih khing y theihll nee’m geamagh ort: tra ta my chree ayns trimshey.

English: unto thee] 1662 upon thee
3 Oh set me up upon the rocke that is higher then I: for thou hast bene my hope, and a strong tower for mee against the enemie.
Manx: 3 O soie mee seose er y chreg ta ny syrjey na mee: son t’ow er ve my hreishteil, as toor lajer dooys noi yn noid.

English: 4 I will dwell in thy Tabernacle for ever : and my trust shall be under the covering of thy wings.
Manx: 4 Nee’m cummal ayns dty chabbane‐agglish son dy-bragh: as bee my hreishteil fo scaa dty skainyn.

English: 5 For thou, O Lord, hast heard my desires : and hast given an heritage unto those that feare thy Name.
Manx: 5 Son t’ow uss, O Hiarn, er chlashtyn my yeearreeyn: as er choyrt eiraght dauesyn ta goaill aggle roish dt’ Ennym.

English: 6 Thou shalt grant the King a long life : that his yeeres may endure throughout all generations.
Manx: 6 Ver oo da’n Ree bea liauyr: dy vod e vleeantyn farraghtyn trooid magh dy-chooilley heeloghe.

English: 7 Hee shall dwell before God for ever : O prepare thy loving mercie and faithfulnesse, that they may preserve him.
Manx: 7 Nee eh vaghey fenish Yee son dy-bragh: O kiare dty vyghin ghraihagh as dt’irriney, dy vod ad eh y choadey.

English: 8 So will I alwayes sing praise unto thy Name : that I may dayly performe my vowes.
Manx: 8 Myr shen goym dy-kinjagh arrane‐moyllee gys dt’ Ennym: dy voddym gagh‐laa my vreearaghyn y chooilleeney.

English: The xii. day.
Manx: The 12. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Nonne Deo. Psal. 62.
Manx: Psal. 62. Nonne Deo?

English: My soul truely waiteth still upon God : for of him commeth my salvation.
Manx: 1 Ta m’annym dy-firrinagh farkiaght dy-kinjagh er Jee: son veihsyn ta my haualtys cheet.
haualtys cheet.] 1769, 1777 haualtys.

English: 2 He verily is my strength and my salvation : hee is my defence, so that I shall not greatly fall.
Manx: 2 Eshyn dy-feer my niart as my haualtys: eshyn my endeil, myr shen nagh bee my lhieggey mooar.

English: 3 How long will yee imagine mischiefe against every man : ye shall bee slaine all the sort of you; yea as a tottering wall shall ye be, and like a broken hedge.
Manx: 3 Caid smooinys shiu er olk noi dy-chooilley ghooinney: hed shiu er stroie ooilley yn sorch eu; dy-jarroo, myr voall ta aarloo dy huittym vees shiu, as myr cleiy brisht.
voall] 1769, 1777 voalley

English: 4 Their device is onely how to put him out whom God will exalt : their delight is in lies; they give good words with their mouth, but curse with their heart.
Manx: 4 Ta’n smooinaghtyn croutagh oc ny‐lomarcan kys dy chur eshyn sheese ballish Jee y hoiaghey seose: t’ad goaill taitnys ayns breagyn; t’ad cur goan mie lesh nyn meeall, agh gweeaghyn ayns nyn gree.

English: 5 Neverthelesse, my soule wait thou still upon God : for my hope is in him.
Manx: 5 Ny‐yeih, m’annym, farkee uss dy-kinjagh er Jee: son ta my hreishteil aynsyn.

English: 6 Hee truely is my strength and my salvation : he is my defence, so that I shall not fall.
Manx: 6 Eshyn dy-firrinagh my niart as my haualtys: eshyn my endeilagh, myr shen nagh duittym.

English: 7 In God is my health and my glory : the rocke of my might, and in God is my trust.
Manx: 7 Ayns Jee ta my lhaynt as my ghloyr: creg my niart, as ayns Jee ta my hreishteil.

English: 8 O put your trust in him alway (yee people :) powre out your hearts before him, for God is our hope.
Manx: 8 O cur‐jee nyn marrant er dy-kinjagh, shiuish phobble: deayrt‐jee magh nyn greeaghyn kiongoyrt rish; son ta Jee nyn dreishteil.

English: 9 As for the children of men, they are but vaine: the children of men are deceitful upon the weights, they are altogether lighter then vanitie it selfe.
Manx: 9 Er son cloan gheiney, cha vel ad agh fardail: ta cloan gheiney molteyragh er ny meihaghyn, t’ad ooilley-cooidjagh ny s’eddrym na fardailys hene.

English: vaine] 1662 vanity
10 O trust not in wrong and robbery, give not your selves unto vanitie : if riches increase, set not your heart upon them.
Manx: 10 O ny treisht‐jee ayns aggair as roosteyrys; ny cur‐jee shiu hene seose gys molteyrys; my ta berchys bishaghey, ny soie‐jee nyn gree orroo.

English: 11 God spake once and twise : I have also heard the same, that power belongeth unto God;
Manx: 11 Loayr Jee un cheayrt, as daa cheayrt ta mish er chlashtyn y lheid cheddin: dy vel pooar bentyn gys Jee;

English: once and twise : I have] 1662 once : and twice I have
12 And that thou Lord art mercifull : for thou rewardest every man according to his worke.
Manx: 12 As dy vel uss, Hiarn, myghinagh: son t’ow cooilleeney dy-chooilley ghooinney cordail rish e obbyr.

English: Deus Deus meus. Psal. 63.
Manx: Psal. 63. Deus, deus meus.

English: O God, thou art my God : earely will I seeke thee.
Manx: 1 O Yee, uss my Yee: dy moghey nee’m dty hirrey.

English: 2 My soule thirsteth for thee, my flesh also longeth after thee : in a barren and dry land, where no water is.
Manx: 2 Ta m’annym pa-agh er dty hon, ta m’eill myrgeddin goaill foddiaght dty yeï: ayns thalloo gennish as chirrym raad nagh vel veg yn ushtey.

English: 3 Thus have I looked for thee in holinesse : that I might behold thy power and glory.
Manx: 3 Myr shoh ta mee er yeeaghyn er dty hon ayns casherickys: dy voddin dty phooar as dty ghloyr y akin.

English: 4 For thy loving kindnesse is better then the life it selfe : my lips shall praise thee.
Manx: 4 Son ta dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh ny share n’yn vioys hene: nee my veillyn oo y voylley.

English: 5 As long as I live, wil I magnifie thee on this manner : and lift up my hands in thy Name.
Manx: 5 Choud’s vee’m bio ver‐ym ard‐voylley dhyt er yn aght shoh: as trogg‐ym seose my laueyn ayns dt’ Ennym.

English: 6 My soule shall be satisfied even as it were with marow and fatnesse : when my mouth praiseth thee with joyfull lips.
Manx: 6 Bee m’annym er ny yannoo magh, dy-jarroo myr dy beagh eh lesh smuir as meeaylys: tra ta my veeall dy dty voylley lesh meillyn gerjoil.

English: 7 Have I not remembred thee in my bed : and thought upon thee when I was waking?
Manx: 7 Nagh vel mee er chooinaghtyn orts ayns my lhiabbee: as er smooinaghtyn ort tra va mee doostey?

English: 8 Because thou hast bene my helper : therefore under the shadow of thy wings will I rejoyce.
Manx: 8 Er‐yn‐oyr dy vel oo er ve m’er‐coonee: shen‐y‐fa fo scaa dty skainyn goym boggey.

English: 9 My soule hangeth upon thee : thy right hand hath upholden me.
Manx: 9 Ta m’annym lhiantyn hoods: ta dty laue yesh er my chummal seose.

English: 10 These also that seeke the hurt of my soule : they shall goe under the earth.
Manx: 10 Ad shoh myrgeddin ta shirrey aggair m’annym: hed ad fo’n thalloo.

English: 11 Let them fall upon the edge of the sword : that they may be a portion for Foxes.
Manx: 11 Lhig daue tuittym er foyr y chliwe: dy vod ad ve son beaghey da shynnee.

English: 12 But the King shall rejoyce in God; all they also that sweare by him, shall bee commended : for the mouth of them that speak lies, shall be stopped.
Manx: 12 Agh gow‐ee yn Ree boggey ayns Jee; adsyn ooilley myrgeddin ta lhoo biallys dasyn, vees er nyn moylley: son bee yn beeall ocsyn ta loayrt breagyn er ny yeigh.

English: Exaudi Deus. Psal. 64.
Manx: Psal. 64. Exaudi, Deus.

English: Hear my voyce, O God, in my prayer : preserve my life from feare of the enemie.
Manx: 1 Clasht rish my choraa, O Yee, ayns my phadjer: freill my vioys veih aggle y noid.

English: 2 Hide mee from the gathering together of the froward : and from the insurrection of wicked doers;
Manx: 2 Follee mee veih chaglym cooidjagh ny mee‐viallee: as veih irree‐magh ny drogh-yantee;

English: 3 Which have whet their tongue like a sword : and shoot out their arrowes, even bitter words;
Manx: 3 T’er shlieeu nyn jengey myr cliwe: as ta lhiggey nyn sideyn, dy-jarroo goan sharroo;

English: Which have] 1662 Who have
4 That they may privily shoote at him that is perfect : suddenly doe they hit him, and feare not.
Manx: 4 Dy vod ad dy-follit lhiggey ersyn ta firrinagh: t’ad dy woalley eh doaltattym, as cha vel aggle orroo.

English: 5 They courage themselves in mischiefe : and commune among themselves how they may lay snares; and say that no man shall see them.
Manx: 5 T’ad jannoo ad hene daaney ayns olkys: as cur nyn goyrle dy-cheïley, kys oddys ad ribbaghyn y hoiaghey; as gra, nagh vaik dooinney erbee ad.

English: courage] 1662 incourage
6 They imagine wickednesse and practise it : that they keepe secret among themselves, every man in the deepe of his heart.
Manx: 6 T’ad smooinaghtyn dy-dowin er olkys, as dy chliaghtey eh: shen t’ad dy reayll follit eddyr ad hene, dy-chooilley ghooinney ayns diunid e chree.

English: 7 But God shall suddenly shoot at them with a swift arrow : that they shall be wounded.
Manx: 7 Agh nee Jee lhiggey doaltattym orroo lesh side leah: dy bee ad lhottit.
side leah] 1769, 1777 side; bee ad lhottit] 1769, 1777 bee ad dy leah lhottit

English: 8 Yea their owne tongues shall make them fall : in so much that who so seeth them, shall laugh them to scorne.
Manx: 8 Dy-feer, ver nyn jengaghyn hene orroo tuittym: ayns wheesh as dy jean adsyn ta fakin ad, garaghtee as craid y yannoo jeu.

English: 9 And all men that see it, shall say, This hath God done : for they shall perceive that it is his worke.
Manx: 9 As jirr dy-chooilley ghooinney hee eh, She Jee t’er n’yannoo shoh: son ver ad tastey dy nee eh yn obbyr echeysyn.

English: 10 The righteous shall rejoyce in the Lord, and put his trust in him : and all they that are true of heart, shall be glad.
Manx: 10 Gow-ee yn dooinney cairagh boggey ayns y Chiarn, as ver eh e hreishteil ayn: as nee adsyn ooilley ta firrinagh ayns cree, boggey ’ghoaill.

English: The xii. day.
Manx: The 12. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Te decet hymnus. Psal. 65.
Manx: Psal. 65. Te decet hymnus.

English: Thou, O God, art praised in Sion : and unto thee shall the vowe bee performed in Hierusalem.
Manx: 1 T’ow uss, O Yee, er ny voylley ayns Sion: as dhyts vees y breearrey er ny chooilleeney ayns Jerusalem.

English: 2 Thou that hearest the prayer : unto thee shall all flesh come.
Manx: 2 Uss ta clashtyn y phadjer: hoods nee dy-chooilley eill cheet.

English: 3 My misdeedes prevaile against me : oh be thou mercifull unto our sinnes.
Manx: 3 Ta my ghrogh‐yannoo geddyn y varriaght orrym: O bee uss myghinagh da nyn beccaghyn.

English: 4 Blessed is the man whom thou choosest and receivest unto thee : hee shall dwell in thy Court, and shall bee satisfied with the pleasures of thy house, even of thy holy Temple.
Manx: 4 Bannit ta’n dooinney t’ow uss dy reih, as dy ghoaill hood hene: nee eh vaghey ayns dty chooyrt, as bee eh jeant magh lesh eunyssyn dty hie, dy-jarroo dy dty hiamble casherick.
chooyrt] 1765, 1769, 1777 choort

English: 5 Thou shalt shewe us wonderfull things in thy righteousnesse, O God of our salvation : thou that art the hope of all the ends of the earth, and of them that remaine in the broad sea.
Manx: 5 Nee oo jeeaghyn dooin reddyn yindyssagh ayns dty chairys, O Yee nyn Saualtys: uss ta sauchys ooilley khing y theihll, as dauesyn ta cummal er y faarkey lhean.

English: 6 Which in his strength setteth fast the mountaines: and is girded about with power.
Manx: 6 Ta ayns e niart soiaghey ny sleïtyn dy-shickyr: as t’er ny chomm’rey lesh pooar.

English: Which] 1662 Who
7 Who stilleth the raging of the sea : and the noyse of his waves, and the madnesse of his people.
Manx: 7 Ta kuinaghey sterrym ny marrey: as feiyr ny tonnyn echey, as mee‐reilltys y pobble.

English: Which] 1662 Who; his people] 1662 the people
8 They also that dwell in the uttermost partes of the earth, shall be afraid at thy tokens : thou that makest the outgoings of the morning and evening to praise thee.
Manx: 8 Adsyn myrgeddin ta vaghey ayns ny ayrnyn sodjey magh jeh’n seihll, vees agglagh roish dty chowraghyn: uss ta cur er immeeaght [coorse] y voghrey as yn astyr dy chur dhyt moylley.

English: 9 Thou visitest the earth, and blessest it : thou makest it very plenteous.
Manx: 9 T’ow cheet dy yeeaghyn y thalloo, as dy vannaghey eh: t’ow jannoo eh feer vessoil.
cheet dy yeeaghyn y thalloo] 1769, 1777 jeeaghyn er y thalloo

English: 10 The river of God is full of water : thou preparest their corne, for so thou providest for the earth.
Manx: 10 Ta awin Yee laane dy ushtey: t’ow cur er yn arroo oc bishaghey; son myr shoh t’ow kiarail son y seihll.

English: 11 Thou waterest her furrowes, thou sendest raine into the little valleyes thereof : thou makest it soft with the drops of raine, and blessest the increase of it.
Manx: 11 T’ow gushtaghey ny creaghyn eck, t’ow cur fliaghey neose er ny coanyn beggey eck: t’ow boggaghey ee lesh ny bineyn dy ’liaghey, as bannaghey yn mess eck.

English: 12 Thou crownest the yeere with thy goodnes : and thy cloudes drop fatnesse.
Manx: 12 T’ow coamrey yn vleïn lesh dty vieys: as ta dty vodjallyn shilley neose meeaylys.

English: 13 They shall droppe upon the dwellings of the wildernesse : and the little hilles shall rejoyce on every side.
Manx: 13 Nee ad shilley neose er cummallyn yn aasagh, as gow-ee ny croink veggey boggey er dagh cheu.

English: 14 The folds shall be full of sheepe : the valleys also shall stand so thicke with corne, that they shall laugh and sing.
Manx: 14 Bee ny bwoailchyn laane dy chirree: nee ny coanyn myrgeddin shassoo cha chiu lesh arroo, dy jean ad gearey as goaill arrane.

English: Iubilate Deo. Psal. 66.
Manx: Psal. 66. Jubilate Deo.

English: O be joyfull in God all ye lands : sing praises unto the honour of his Name, make his praise to be glorious.
Manx: 1 O bee‐jee gerjoil ayns Jee, ooilley shiuish cheeraghyn: gow‐jee arraneyn‐moyllee gys onnor e Ennym; cur‐jee er e voylley dy ve gloyroil.

English: 2 Say unto God, O how wonderful art thou in thy workes : through the greatnes of thy power shall thine enemies be found lyars unto thee.
Manx: 2 Abbyr‐jee rish Jee, O cre cha yindyssagh as t’ow ayns dt’obbraghyn: trooid mooads dty phooar vees dty noidyn er nyn gheddyn nyn mreageryn ayns dt’enish.

English: 3 For all the world shall worship thee : sing to thee, and praise thy Name.
Manx: 3 Son nee ooilley yn seihll ooashley ’chur dhyt: goaill arrane jeed, as moylley dt’ Ennym.

English: sing to thee] 1581, 1636, 1660, 1662 sing of thee
4 O come hither, and behold the workes of God : how wonderfull he is in his doing toward the children of men.
Manx: 4 O tar‐jee ayns shoh, as cur‐jee tastey da obbraghyn Yee: cre cha yindyssagh as t’eh ayns e yannoo gys cloan gheiney!

English: 5 He turned the sea into drie land : so that they went thorow the water on foote; there did we rejoyce thereof.
Manx: 5 Hyndaa eh yn faarkey gys thalloo chirrym: myr shen dy jagh ad trooid yn ushtey rish nyn gosh; ayns shen ghow shin boggey jeh.
gosh] 1765, 1769 ghosh

English: 6 He ruleth with his power for ever; his eyes behold the people : and such as will not beleeve, shall not be able to exalt themselves.
Manx: 6 T’eh reill lesh e phooar son dy-bragh; ta e hooillyn cur tastey da’n pobble: as ny lheid as nagh jean credjal, cha bee abyl ad hene y hoiaghey seose.

English: 7 O praise our God (ye people :) and make the voyce of his praise to be heard;
Manx: 7 O cur‐jee moylley da’n Jee ain, shiuish phobble: as cur‐jee er coraa e voylley dy ve er ny chlashtyn;

English: 8 Which holdeth our soule in life : and suffereth not our feete to slip.
Manx: 8 Ta freayll yn annym ain ayns bioys: as nagh vel lhiggey da nyn gassyn dy skyrraghtyn,

English: Which] 1662 Who
9 For thou (O God) hast proved us : thou also hast tried us, like as silver is tried.
Manx: 9 Son t’ow uss, O Yee, er phrowal shin: t’ow myrgeddin er hrial shin, myr ta argid er ny hrial.

English: 10 Thou broughtest us into the snare : and layedst trouble upon our loynes.
Manx: 10 Hug oo lhiat shin ayns y ribbeh: as hug oo seaghyn er nyn meeaghyn.

English: 11 Thou sufferedst men to ride over our heads : we went through fire and water, and thou broughtest us out into a wealthy place.
Manx: 11 Lhig oo da deiney dy varkiagh harrish nyn ghing: hie shin trooid aile as ushtey, as hug oo lhiat shin magh gys ynnyd berchagh.

English: 12 I wil go into thy house with burnt offrings: and wil pay thee my vowes which I promised with my lips, & spake with my mouth when I was in trouble.
Manx: 12 Hem stiagh gys dty hie lesh chebballyn‐losht: as eeck-ym dhyt my vreearaghyn, yiall mee lesh my veillyn, as loayr mee lesh my veeall, tra va mee ayns seaghyn.

English: 13 I wil offer unto thee fat burnt sacrifices, with the incense of rammes : I will offer bullocks and goats.
Manx: 13 Chebb‐yms dhyt ourallyn‐losht roauyrey, marish oural millish reaghyn: chebb‐ym dew as goair.

English: 14 O come hither, and hearken all ye that feare God : and I wil tell you what he hath done for my soule.
Manx: 14 O tar‐jee ayns shoh, as eaisht‐jee, ooilley shiuish ta goaill aggle roish Jee: as insh-ym diu cre t’eh er n’yannoo son m’annym.

English: 15 I called unto him with my mouth : and gave him praises with my tongue.
Manx: 15 Deïe mee er lesh my veeall: as hug mee moylley da lesh my hengey.

English: 16 If I incline unto wickednes with my heart : the Lord will not heare me.
Manx: 16 My ta my chree goaill taitnys ayns mee‐chairys: cha jean y Chiarn m’y chlashtyn.

English: 17 But God hath heard mee : and considered the voyce of my prayer.
Manx: 17 Agh ta Jee er my chlashtyn: as er choyrt tastey da coraa my phadjer.

English: 18 Praised bee God, which hath not cast out my prayer : nor turned his mercie from me.
Manx: 18 Moylley dy row gys Jee, nagh vel er hoiaghey beg jeh my phadjer: ny er hyndaa e vyghin voym.

English: which] 1662 who
Deus misereatur. Psal. 67.
Manx: Psal. 67. Deus misereatur.

English: God be mercifull unto us, and blesse us : and shew us the light of his countenance, and be mercifull unto us:
Manx: 1 Dy row Jee myghinagh dooin, as dy bannee eh shin: as soilshey e eddin y yeeaghyn dooin, as dy row eh myghinagh dooin.

English: 2 That thy way may be knowen upon earth : thy saving health among all nations.
Manx: 2 Dy vod enney v’er ny choyrt er dty raad er y thalloo: dty haualtys anmey mastey dy-chooilley ashoon.

English: 3 Let the people praise thee, O God : yea, let all the people praise thee.
Manx: 3 Lhig da’n pobble uss y voylley, O Yee: dy-jarroo lhig da ooilley’n pobble moylley ’choyrt dhyt.
