English: 4 O let the nations rejoyce & be glad, for thou shalt judge the folke righteously : and governe the nations upon earth.
Manx: 4 O lhig da ny ashoonyn boggey ’ghoaill as ve gennal: son nee uss y pobble y vriwnys dy-cairal, as ny ashoonyn y reill er y thalloo.

English: be glad, ... righteously : and] 1636, 1660, 1662 be glad : ... righteously, and
5 Let the people praise thee, O God : let all the people praise thee.
Manx: 5 Lhig da’n pobble uss y voylley, O Yee: dy-jarroo lhig da ooilley’n pobble moylley ’choyrt dhyt.

English: 6 Then shall the earth bring foorth her increase : and God, even our owne God, shall give us his blessing.
Manx: 6 Eisht nee’n thalloo cur magh e bishaghey: as nee Jee, dy-jarroo yn Jee ain, e vannaght y choyrt dooin.
e bishaghey] 1765, 1769 y bishaghey

English: 7 God shall blesse us : and all the ends of the world shall feare him.
Manx: 7 Nee Jee shin y vannaghey: as nee dy-chooilley chione jeh’n seihll aggle y ghoaill roish.
chione] 1769, 1777 ard

English: The xiii. day.
Manx: The 13. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Exurgat Deus. Psal. 68.
Manx: Psal. 68. Exurgat Deus.

English: Let God arise, and let his enemies bee scattered : let them also that hate him, flee before him.
Manx: 1 Lhig da Jee girree seose, as lhig da e noidyn v’er nyn skeayley: lhig dauesyn myrgeddin ta dwoaie oc er, roie er-chea roïshyn.

English: 2 Like as the smoke vanisheth, so shalt thou drive them away : and like as waxe melteth at the fire, so let the ungodly perish at the presence of God.
Manx: 2 ’Naght myr ta’n jaagh goll ass nyn shilley, myr shen nee oo gimman ad ersooyl: as myr ta kere lheïe rish yn aile, myr shen lhig da’n vee‐chrauee cherraghtyn ec kionfenish Yee.
’Naght myr] 1769, 1777 Myr, 1819 ’Naght myr

English: 3 But let the righteous be glad and rejoyce before God : let them also be merie and joyfull.
Manx: 3 Agh lhig da’n vooinjer chairagh ve gerjoil, as boggey ’ghoaill kiongoyrt rish Jee: lhig daue myrgeddin ve gennal as laane dy voggey.

English: 4 O sing unto God, and sing praises unto his Name : magnifie him that rideth upon the heavens as it were upon an horse; praise him in his Name, yea, and rejoyce before him.
Manx: 4 O gow‐jee arrane gys Jee, as arraneyn‐moyllee gys e Ennym: cur‐jee ard‐voylley dasyn ta markiagh er ny niaughyn, myr er cabbyl; cur‐jee moylley da ayns e Ennym Jah, as gow‐jee boggey kiongoyrt rish.

English: Name, yea,] 1703 Name, Jah
5 He is a father of the fatherlesse, and defendeth the cause of the widowes : even God in his holy habitation.
Manx: 5 Eshyn Ayr yn chloan gyn ayr, ta fendeil cooish ny mraane-treoghe: dy-jarroo Jee ayns e ynnyd‐vaghee casherick.

English: 6 He is the God that maketh men to bee of one minde in an house, and bringeth the prisoners out of captivitie : but letteth the runnagates continue in scarcenesse.
Manx: 6 Eshyn y Jee ta cur er deiney dy ve jeh un aigney ayns thie, as ta cur lesh ny pryssoonee magh ass cappeeys: agh lhiggey da ny wagaanee tannaghtyn ayns genney.
wagaanee] 1819 wagaantee

English: 7 O God, when thou wentest foorth before the people : when thou wentest thorow the wildernesse;
Manx: 7 O Yee, tra hie uss magh roish y pobble: tra hie oo rowe trooid yn aasagh,

English: 8 The earth shooke, and the heavens dropped at the presence of God : even as Sinai also was mooved at the presence of God, which is the God of Israel.
Manx: 8 Chrie yn thalloo, as ren ny niaughyn shilley ec kionfenish Yee: myr va Sinai myrgeddin er ny chraa ec fenish Yee, eh ta Jee Israel.

English: which is] 1662 who is
9 Thou, O God, sentest a gracious raine upon thine inheritance : and refreshedst it when it was wearie.
Manx: 9 Hug uss, O Yee, fliaghey graysoil er dt’eiraght: as dooiree oo eh tra ve tooillit.

English: 10 Thy Congregation shall dwell therein : for thou, O God, hast of thy goodnesse prepared for the poore.
Manx: 10 Nee dty hioltane cummal ayn: son t’ow uss, O Yee, jeh dty vieys er chiarail son ny boghtyn.

English: 11 The Lord gave the word : great was the company of the Preachers.
Manx: 11 Ren y Chiarn yn fockle y choyrt: smooar va sheshaght ny preachooryn.

English: 12 Kings with their armies did flee and were discomfited : and they of the houshold divided the spoile.
Manx: 12 Ren reeaghyn lesh nyn sheshaghtyn-caggee roih er‐chea, as v’ad er nyn goyrt fo-chosh: as adsyn jeh’n lught‐thie rheynn ad y spooilley.

English: 13 Though ye have lien among the pots, yet shall ye bee as the wings of a Dove : that is covered with silver wings, and her feathers like gold.
Manx: 13 Ga dy vel shiu er ve ny lhie mastey ny pooiyt, foast vees shiu myr skainyn calmane: ta coodit lesh skainyn argid, as ny fedjagyn eck goll‐rish airh.

English: 14 When the Almightie scattered Kings for their sake : then were they as white as snow in Salmon.
Manx: 14 Tra ren yn Ooilley‐niartal reeaghyn y skeayley er y choontey ocsyn: eisht v’ad cha gial as sniaghtey ayns Salmon.

English: 15 As the hill of Basan, so is Gods hill : even an high hill, as the hill of Basan.
Manx: 15 Myr ta cronk Vasan, myr shen ta cronk Yee: dy-jarroo cronk ard, myr cronk Vasan.

English: 16 Why hop ye so ye high hils? this is Gods hill, in the which it pleaseth him to dwell : yea, the Lord will abide in it for ever.
Manx: 16 Cre’n‐fa ta shiu lieme myr shen, shiuish chroink ard? shoh cronk Yee, ayn s’gooidsave lesh dy chummal: dy-jarroo, nee yn Chiarn tannaghtyn ayn son dy-bragh.

English: 17 The charets of God are twenty thousand, even thousands of Angels : and the Lord is among them, as in the holy place of Sinai.
Manx: 17 Ta fainee Yee feed thousane, dy-jarroo thousaneyn dy ainlyn: as ta’n Chiarn ny mast’ oc, myr ayns ynnyd casherick Sinai.

English: 18 Thou art gone up on high, thou hast led captivitie captive, and received gifts for men : yea, even for thine enemies, that the Lord God might dwell among them.
Manx: 18 T’ow er n’gholl seose er yn yrjid, t’ow er leeideil cappeeys ayns bondiaght, as er gheddyn giootyn son deiney: dy-jarroo, son dt’eer noidyn, dy voddagh y Chiarn Jee cummal ny mast’ oc.

English: 19 Praised bee the Lord dayly : even the God which helpeth us, and powreth his benefits upon us.
Manx: 19 Moylley dy row gys y Chiarn gagh‐laa: dy-jarroo yn Jee ta cooney lhien, as deayrtey e hoyrtyssyn orrin.

English: which] 1662 who
20 He is our God, even the God of whom commeth salvation : God is the Lord, by whom we escape death.
Manx: 20 Eshyn y Jee ain, dy-jarroo yn Jee veih ta cheet nyn saualtys: Jee yn Chiarn, liorishyn ta shin shiaghney baase.
liorishyn] 1777 liorish, 1819 liorishyn

English: 21 God shall wound the head of his enemies : and the hairie scalpe of such a one as goeth on still in his wickednesse.
Manx: 21 Nee Jee broo kione e noidyn: as claigin renaigagh lheid y fer as ta goll kinjagh er e hoshiaght ayns e vee‐chraueeaght.

English: 22 The Lord hath said, I will bring my people againe, as I did from Basan : mine owne will I bring againe, as I did sometime from the deepe of the Sea.
Manx: 22 Ta’n Chiarn er ghra, Ver‐yms lhiam my phobble reesht, myr ren mee veih Basan: my vooinjer hene ver‐ym lhiam reesht myr ren mee keayrt dy-row veih diunid ny marrey;

English: 23 That thy foot may be dipped in the blood of thine enemies : and that the tongue of thy dogs may bee red through the same.
Manx: 23 Dy vod dty chass ve er ny hummey ayns fuill dty noidyn: as dy vod chengey dty voddee ve jiarg lesh yn uill cheddin.

English: 24 It is well seene, O God, how thou goest : how thou my God and King goest in the Sanctuary.
Manx: 24 Smie te ry akin, O Yee, kys t’ow uss gimmeeaght: kys t’ow uss, my Yee as Ree, gimmeeaght ayns yn ynnyd casherick.

English: 25 The singers goe before, the minstrels follow after : in the middest are the damosels playing with the timbrels.
Manx: 25 T’adsyn ta goaill arraneyn shooyll hoshiaght, adsyn ta jannoo bingys er greïnyn-kiaull cheet nyn‐yeï: ayns y vean ta ny mraane‐aegey cloie er ny timbrelyn.

English: 26 Give thankes, O Israel, unto God the Lord in the Congregations : from the ground of the heart.
Manx: 26 Cur booise, O Israel, da Jee yn Chiarn ayns y chaglym cooidjagh: veih grunt y chree.

English: 27 There is little Benjamin their ruler, and the princes of Juda their counsaile : the princes of Zabulon, & the princes of Nephthali.
Manx: 27 Ayns shen ta Benjamin beg nyn er‐reill, as prinsyn Yuda nyn fir‐choyrlee: prinsyn Zabulon, as prinsyn Nephthali.
er-reill] 1777 ver-reill; fir-choyrlee] 1777 vir-choyrlee

English: 28 Thy God hath sent foorth strength for thee : stablish the thing, O God, that thou hast wrought in us,
Manx: 28 Ta dty Yee er choyrt magh niart er dty hon’s: jean y red y hickyraghey, O Yee, t’ow er n’obbraghey aynin.

English: 29 For thy Temples sake at Hierusalem : so shall Kings bring presents unto thee.
Manx: 29 Son graih dty hiamble ec Jerusalem: myr shen ver reeaghyn lhieu giootyn hoods.

English: 30 When the company of the spearemen, and multitude of the mighty are scattered abroad among the beastes of the people (so that they humbly bring pieces of silver :) and when he hath scattered the people that delight in warre;
Manx: 30 Tra vees sheshaght ny deiney-shleiy, as earrooyn ny deiney niartal er nyn skeayley dy-lhean (mastey feïeys y pobble,) myr shen dy vel ad dy-imlee cur lhieu peeshyn dy argid: as tra t’eh er skeayley yn pobble ta goaill taitnys ayns caggey;

English: 31 Then shall the princes come out of Egypt : the Morians land shall soone stretch out her hands unto God.
Manx: 31 Eisht hig ny prinsyn magh ass Egypt: nee cheer ny Morianee dy-leah ny laueyn eck y heeyney magh gys Jee.

English: 32 Sing unto God, O ye kingdomes of the earth : O sing praises unto the Lord;
Manx: 32 Gow‐jee arrane gys Jee, O shiuish reeriaghtyn yn ooir: O gow‐jee arraneyn‐moyllee gys y Chiarn,

English: 33 Which sitteth in the heavens over all from the beginning : lo, he doth send out his voice, yea, & that a mighty voice.
Manx: 33 Ta ny hoie ayns ny niaughyn er-skyn ooilley er dyn toshiaght: cur‐my‐ner, t’eh cur magh e choraa, dy-jarroo, as shen coraa niartal.

English: Which] 1662 Who
34 Ascribe ye the power to God over Israel : his worship and strength is in the cloudes.
Manx: 34 Gow‐jee rish dy nee ec Jee ta’n phooar harrish Israel: ta e ooashley as e niart ayns ny bodjallyn.

English: 35 O God, wonderfull art thou in thy holy places : even the God of Israel, hee wil give strength and power unto his people; blessed be God.
Manx: 35 O Yee, yindyssagh t’ow uss ayns dt’ynnydyn casherick: dy-jarroo yn Jee dy Israel; ver eshyn niart as pooar da e phobble; bannit dy row Jee.

English: The xiii. day.
Manx: The 13. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Saluum me fac. Psal. 69.
Manx: Psal. 69. Salvum me fac.

English: Save mee, O God : for the waters are come in, even unto my soule.
Manx: 1 Saue mee, O Yee: son ta ny ushtaghyn er jeet stiagh, dy-jarroo gys m’annym.

English: 2 I sticke fast in the deepe myre, where no ground is : I am come into deepe waters, so that the floods runne over me.
Manx: 2 Ta mee cummit shickyr ayns y laagh dowin, raad nagh vel grunt erbee: ta mee er jeet ayns ushtaghyn dowiney, myr shen dy vel ny thooillaghyn roih harrym.

English: 3 I am weary of crying; my throat is dry : my sight faileth mee for waiting so long upon my God.
Manx: 3 Ta mee skee lesh geam, ta my scoarnagh chirrym: ta my hoilshey dy m’ailleil son farkiaght choud er my Yee.
geam] 1769, 1777 geamagh

English: 4 They that hate mee without a cause, are moe then the haires of my head : they that are mine enemies, and would destroy me guiltlesse, are mighty.
Manx: 4 Adsyn ta dwoaie oc orrym gyn oyr, t’ad ny sliee na renaigyn my ching: adsyn ta my noidyn, as bailliu mish ta neu‐chyndagh y stroie, t’ad niartal.

English: 5 I payd them the things that I never tooke : God, thou knowest my simplenes, and my faults are not hid from thee.
Manx: 5 Deeck mee daue my reddyn nagh ren mee rieau y ghoaill: Yee, ta fys ayd er my ônid, as cha vel m’oiljyn kellit voïds.

English: 6 Let not them that trust in thee, O Lord God of hosts, be ashamed for my cause : let not those that seeke thee be confounded through me, O Lord God of Israel.
Manx: 6 Ny lhig dauesyn ta treishteil ayn-yds, O Hiarn Yee dy heshaghtyn‐caggee, v’er nyn naaraghey son y chooish ayms: ny lhig dauesyn ta dy dty hirrey, v’er nyn goyrt mow my hrooid’s, O Hiarn Yee dy Israel.

English: 7 And why? for thy sake have I suffred reproofe : shame hath covered my face.
Manx: 7 As cre’n‐oyr? er y choontey ayds ta mee er hurranse oghsan: ta nearey er choodaghey m’eddin.

English: 8 I am become a stranger unto my brethren : even an aliant unto my mothers children.
Manx: 8 Ta mee myr dooinney joarree da my vraaraghyn: dy-jarroo myr fer-quaagh da cloan my vayrey.

English: 9 For the zeale of thy house hath even eaten me: and the rebukes of them that rebuked thee, are fallen upon me.
Manx: 9 Son ta’n graih jeean t’aym da dty hie dy-jarroo er ghuinney mee gys y chree: as ta ny oghsanyn ocsyn hug scammylt dhyts, er duittym orryms.

English: 10 I wept, and chastened my selfe with fasting : and that was turned to my reproofe.
Manx: 10 Ren mee dobberan as smaghtaghey mee hene lesh trostey: as va shen er ny hyndaa gys my scammylt.

English: 11 I put on a sackcloth also : and they jested upon me.
Manx: 11 Hug mee orrym aanrit-sack myrgeddin: as ren ad craidey moo’m.

English: 12 They that sit in the gate speake against mee : and the drunkards make songs upon me.
Manx: 12 T’adsyn ta soie ’sy ghiat loayrt m’oï: as ta’n vooinjer veshtal jannoo ronneeaght orrym.

English: 13 But Lord, I make my prayer unto thee : in an acceptable time.
Manx: 13 Agh, Hiarn, ta mee jannoo my phadjer hoods: ayns traa nee oo soiaghey jeh.

English: 14 Heare me, O God, in the multitude of thy mercie : even in the trueth of thy salvation.
Manx: 14 Clasht rhym, O Yee, ayns earroo dty vyghin: dy-jarroo ayns firrinys dty haualtys.

English: 15 Take me out of the myre, that I sinke not : O let me bee delivered from them that hate mee, and out of the deepe waters.
Manx: 15 Gow mee ass y laagh, nagh jem fo: O lhig dou ve er my livrey vowesyn ta feoh oc orrym, as ass ny ushtaghyn dowin.

English: 16 Let not the water flood drowne mee, neither let the deepe swallow me up : and let not the pit shut her mouth upon me.
Manx: 16 Ny lhig da ny thooillaghyn-ushtey mee y vaih, cha-moo lhig da’n diunid mee y luggey seose: as ny lhig da’n ooig e beeall y yeigh orrym.

English: 17 Heare me, O Lord, for thy loving kindnesse is comfortable : turne thee unto mee, according to the multitude of thy mercies.
Manx: 17 Clasht rhym, O Hiarn, son ta dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh gerjoilagh: chyndaa uss hyms cordail rish earroo dty vyghinyn.

English: 18 And hide not thy face from thy servant, for I am in trouble : Oh haste thee, and heare me.
Manx: 18 As ny follee dt’eddin veih dty harvaant, son ta mee ayns seaghyn: O jean siyr, as eaisht rhym.
eaisht] 1777 clasht, 1819 eaisht

English: 19 Draw nigh unto my soule, and save it : Oh deliver me, because of mine enemies.
Manx: 19 Tayrn er‐gerrey gys m’annym, as saue eh: O livrey mee, kyndagh rish my noidyn.

English: 20 Thou hast knowen my reproofe, my shame, and my dishonour : mine adversaries are all in thy sight.
Manx: 20 T’ow uss er hoiggal m’oghsan, my nearey, as my vee‐onnor: ta my noidyn ooilley ayns dty hilley.

English: 21 Thy rebuke hath broken my heart; I am full of heavinesse : I looked for some to have pitie on me, but there was no man, neither found I any to comfort me.
Manx: 21 Ta dt’oghsan er vrishey my chree, ta mee laane dy hrimshey: yeeagh mee son fer ennagh dy ghoaill chymmey orrym, agh cha row dooinney erbee; cha-moo hooar mee unnane erbee dy my gherjaghey.

English: 22 They gave me gall to eate : and when I was thirstie, they gave me vineger to drinke.
Manx: 22 Hug ad dou gall dy ee: as tra va mee pa-agh, hug ad dou vinegar dy iu.

English: 23 Let their table bee made a snare to take themselves withall : and let the things, that should have bene for their wealth, be unto them an occasion of falling.
Manx: 23 Lhig da’n voayrd oc ve er ny yannoo ny ribbeh dy ghoaill ad hene lesh: as lhig da ny reddyn lhisagh y ve son y foays oc, ve dauesyn oyr tuittym.

English: 24 Let their eyes bee blinded that they see not : and ever bow downe their backs.
Manx: 24 Lhig da ny sooillyn oc ve er nyn gholley, nagh jean ad fakin: as jean uss dy-kinjagh yn dreeym oc y chrommey sheese.

English: bow downe] 1562, 1662 bow thou down
25 Powre out thine indignation upon them : and let thy wrathfull displeasure take hold of them.
Manx: 25 Deayrt magh dt’eulys orroo: as lhig dty yymmoose hrome ad y ghreimmey.

English: 26 Let their habitation be voyd : and no man to dwell in their tents.
Manx: 26 Lhig da’n ynnyd‐vaghee oc ve follym faase: as gyn dooinney erbee dy chummal ayns ny cabbaneyn oc;

English: 27 For they persecute him whom thou hast smitten : and they talke how they may vexe them whom thou hast wounded.
Manx: 27 Son t’ad jannoo tranlaase ersyn t’ow er woalley: as ta’n taggloo oc kys oddys ad adsyn y heaghney t’ow uss er lhottey.

English: 28 Let them fall from one wickednesse to another: and not come into thy righteousnesse.
Manx: 28 Lhig daue tuittym veih un pheccah gys peccah elley: as gyn cheet stiagh gys dty ynrickys.

English: 29 Let them be wiped out of the booke of the living : and not be written among the righteous.
Manx: 29 Bee ad er ny chrossey ass lioar ny bio: as cha bee ad scruit mastey’n vooinjer chairagh.
bio] 1769, 1777 bioee

English: 30 As for mee, when I am poore and in heavinesse : thy helpe, O God, shall lift me up.
Manx: 30 Er my hon’s, tra ta mee boght as ayns trimshey: nee dty chooney, O Yee, mish y hroggal seose.

English: 31 I will praise the Name of God with a song : and magnifie it with thankesgiving.
Manx: 31 Nee’m Ennym Yee y voylley lesh arrane: as ver‐ym ard‐voylley da lesh toyrt‐booise.

English: 32 This also shall please the Lord : better then a bullocke, that hath hornes and hoofes.
Manx: 32 Nee shoh myrgeddin yn Chiarn y wooieys: ny share na dow ta eairkyn as yngnyn er.
ta eairkyn as yngnyn er] 1769, 1777 lesh eairkyn as yngnyn

English: 33 The humble shall consider this, and be glad : seeke yee after God, and your soule shall live.
Manx: 33 Ver y vooinjer imlee tastey da shoh, as bee ad gennal: shir-jee lurg Jee, as bee’n annym eu bio.

English: 34 For the Lord heareth the poore : and despiseth not his prisoners.
Manx: 34 Son ta’n Chiarn clashtyn ny boghtyn: as cha vel eh soiaghey beg jeh e phryssoonee.

English: 35 Let heaven and earth praise him : the sea and all that mooveth therein.
Manx: 35 Lhig da niau as thalloo eh y voylley: yn faarkey as ooilley ny ta gleashaght ayn.

English: 36 For God will save Sion, and build the cities of Juda : that men may dwell there, and have it in possession.
Manx: 36 Son nee Jee Sion y hauail, as troggee eh ard‐valjyn Yudah: dy vod deiney vaghey ayns shen, as eh y ghoaill ayns nyn gummal.

English: 37 The posteritie also of his servants shall inherit it : and they that love his Name shall dwell therein.
Manx: 37 Nee sluight e harvaantyn myrgeddin y ghoaill eh ayns eiraght: as adsyn ta graihagh er e Ennym nee ad vaghey ayn.

English: Deus in adiutorium. Psal. 70.
Manx: Psal. 70. Deus in adjutorium.

English: Haste thee, O God, to deliver me : make haste to helpe me, O Lord.
Manx: 1 Jean siyr, O Yee, dy my livrey: jean siyr dy chooney lhiam, O Hiarn.

English: 2 Let them be ashamed and confounded that seeke after my soule : let them bee turned backward and put to confusion that wish me evill.
Manx: 2 Lhig dauesyn v’er nyn goyrt gys nearey, as er nyn gastey cooidjagh, ta shirrey lurg m’annym dy stroie eh: lhig daue v’er nyn imman gour nyn drommey dy-scammyltagh, ta wooishal olk dou.

English: 3 Let them for their reward be soone brought to shame : that cry over me, There, there.
Manx: 3 Lhig daue son y leagh oc ve dy-leah er nyn goyrt lhieu gys nearey: ta geamagh harrym, Shen, shen.
goyrt lhieu] 1769, 1777 goyrt

English: 4 But let those that seeke thee, be joyful and glad in thee : and let all such as delight in thy Salvation, say alway, The Lord be praised.
Manx: 4 Agh lhig dauesyn ooilley ta dy dty hirrey, ve gennal as boggoil ayn-yds: as lhig dauesyn ta graihagh er dty haualtys, dy-kinjagh gra, Dy row moylley gys y Chiarn.

English: 5 As for mee, I am poore and in miserie : haste thee unto me, O God.
Manx: 5 Er my hon’s, ta mee boght as ayns treihys: jean siyr hym, O Yee.

English: 6 Thou art my helper and my Redeemer : O Lord, make no long tarying.
Manx: 6 Uss my Er‐coonee as my Er‐kionnee: ny lhig shiaghey foddey, O Hiarn.

English: The xiiii. day.
Manx: The 14. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: In te, Domine, speraui. Psal. 71.
Manx: Psal. 71. In te, Domine, speravi.

English: In thee, O Lorde, have I put my trust, let mee never be put to confusion : but rid me, and deliver mee in thy righteousnesse, encline thine eare unto mee, and save me.
Manx: 1 Ayn-yds, O Hiarn, ta mee er choyrt my hreishteil; ny lhig dou dy-bragh v’er my choyrt gys nearey: agh feayshil orrym, as livrey mee ayns dty chairys; cromm dty chleaysh hym, as saue mee.

English: 2 Be thou my strong hold, whereunto I may alway resort : thou hast promised to helpe mee, for thou art my house of defence, and my castle.
Manx: 2 Bee oo my chummal lajer, huggey oddyms kinjagh goll son sauchys: t’ow er yialldyn dy chooney lhiam; son oo thie m’endeilys as my chashtal.
chashtal] 1765 chastall, 1769 chashtall

English: 3 Deliver mee, O my God, out of the hande of the ungodly : out of the hand of the unrighteous and cruel man.
Manx: 3 Livrey mee, O my Yee, veih pooar ny mee‐chrauee: veih laue yn dooinney neu‐chairagh as dewill.

English: 4 For thou, O Lord God, art the thing that I long for : thou art my hope, even from my youth.
Manx: 4 Son dty lurg’s, O Hiarn Yee, ta mee goaill foddeeaght: uss my hreishteil, dy-jarroo veih m’aegid.

English: 5 Through thee have I bene holden up ever since I was borne : thou art hee that tooke me out of my mothers wombe; my praise shal be alway of thee.
Manx: 5 Liort ta mee er ny chummal seose neayr as ruggyr mee: uss ren m’y ghoaill ass breïn my vayrey; bee my voylley dy-bragh jeeds.

English: alway] 1636 alwayes
6 I am become as it were a monster unto many : but my sure trust is in thee.
Manx: 6 Ta mee er jeet dy ve shilley agglagh da ymmodee: agh ta my hreishteil shickyr ayn-yds.

English: 7 O let my mouth be filled with thy praise : that I may sing of thy glory and honour, all the day long.
Manx: 7 O lhig da my veeall v’er ny lhieeney lesh dty voylley: dy voddym arrane y ghoaill jeh dty ghloyr as dty onnor slane liurid y laa.

English: 8 Cast mee not away in the time of age : forsake me not when my strength faileth me.
Manx: 8 Ny tilg mee ersooyl ayns my henn eash: ny treig mee tra ta my niart dy m’ailleil;

English: 9 For mine enemies speake against me, & they that lay waite for my soule, take their counsell together, saying : God hath forsaken him; persecute him, and take him, for there is none to deliver him.
Manx: 9 Son ta my noidyn loayrt m’oï, as t’adsyn ta lhie farkiaght son m’annym, coyrt nyn goyrle dy-cheïley, gra: Ta Jee er hreigeil eh; eiyr‐jee er, as gow‐jee eh; son cha vel fer erbee dy livrey eh.

English: 10 Go not farre from me, O God : my God, haste thee to helpe me.
Manx: 10 Ny gow foddey voym, O Yee: my Yee, jean siyr dy chooney lhiam.

English: 11 Let them bee confounded and perish, that are against my soule : let them bee covered with shame and dishonour, that seeke to doe me evil.
Manx: 11 Lhig dauesyn ta noi m’annym ve er nyn goyrt mow as cherraghtyn: lhig daue ve coodit lesh nearey as mee‐ooashley ta shirrey dy yannoo aggair dou.

English: 12 As for mee, I will patiently abide alway : and will praise thee more and more.
Manx: 12 Agh er my hon’s, nee’m dy-meen farkiaght dy-kinjagh: as moyll‐ym oo ny smoo as ny smoo.

English: 13 My mouth shall dayly speak of thy righteousnes and salvation : for I know no ende thereof.
Manx: 13 Loayr-ee my veeall dagh‐laa jeh dty chairys as jeh dty livrey-ys: son cha nione dou yn earroo oc.

English: 14 I will goe forth in the strength of the Lord God: and wil make mention of thy righteousnesse onely.
Manx: 14 Hem magh ayns niart y Chiarn Jee: as loayr‐ym ynrycan jeh dty chairys.

English: 15 Thou, O God, hast taught mee from my youth up untill now : therefore will I tell of thy wonderous workes.
Manx: 15 T’ow uss, O Yee, er m’ynsaghey veih my aegid derrey nish: shen‐y‐fa soilshee‐yms magh dty obbraghyn yindyssagh.

English: 16 Forsake me not, O God, in mine old age, when I am gray headed : until I have shewed thy strength unto this generation, and thy power to all them that are yet for to come.
Manx: 16 Ny treig mee, O Yee, ayns my henn eash, tra ta my chione lheeah; derrey ta mee er hoilshaghey dty niart da’n cheeloghe shoh, as dty phooar dauesyn ooilley ta foast roï cheet.
roï] 1777 ry hoï

English: 17 Thy righteousnesse, O God, is very high : and great things are they that thou hast done, O God, who is like unto thee?
Manx: 17 Ta dty chairys, O Yee, feer ard, as smooar ny reddyn shen t’ow er n’yannoo: O Yee, quoi ta dy ve er ny hoyllaghey hoods!

English: 18 O what great troubles and adversities hast thou shewed me, and yet diddest thou turne & refresh me : yea, and broughtest me from the deepe of the earth againe.
Manx: 18 O cre’n seaghyn as yn arkys trome t’ow er choyrt my raad! as foast hyndaa oo as ren oo mee y ooraghey: dy-jarroo, as hug oo lhiat mee reesht veih diunid ny hooirey.

English: 19 Thou hast brought me to great honour : and comforted me on every side.
Manx: 19 T’ow er chur lhiat mee gys onnor; as er my gherjaghey er dy-chooilley cheu;
cheu] 1819 heu

English: 20 Therefore will I praise thee and thy faithfulnes, O God, playing upon an instrument of musicke : unto thee will I sing upon the harpe, O thou holy one of Israel.
Manx: 20 Shen‐y‐fa nee’m uss as dt’irriney y voylley, O Yee, cloie er greïe dy vingys: hoods goym arrane er y chlaasagh, O uss Er casherick dy Israel.
casherick] 1765, 1769 chasherick

English: 21 My lips will be faine when I sing unto thee : and so wil my soule whom thou hast delivered.
Manx: 21 Bee my veillyn gennal tra ta mee goaill arrane hoods: as myr shen vees my annym t’ow uss er ny livrey.
er ny livrey] 1777 er livrey, 1819 er ny livrey

English: 22 My tongue also shall talke of thy righteousnes all the day long : for they are confounded and brought unto shame that seeke to do me evill.
Manx: 22 Nee my hengey myrgeddin loayrt jeh dty chairys fey‐ny‐laa: son t’ad er nyn goyrt mow as er nyn goyrt lhieu gys nearey, ta shirrey olk y yannoo dooys.
goyrt] 1765, 1769 ghoyrt ´2

English: Deus, iudicium. Psal. 72.
Manx: Psal. 72. Deus, judicium.

English: Give the King thy judgements, O God : and thy righteousnesse unto the Kings sonne.
Manx: 1 Cur da’n Ree dty vriwnyssyn, O Yee: as dty chairys da mac y Ree.

English: 2 Then shall he judge the people according unto right : and defend the poore.
Manx: 2 Eisht nee eh dty phobble y vriwnys cordail rish cairys: as nee eh ny boghtyn y endeil.

English: the people] 1662 thy people
3 The mountaines also shall bring peace : and the litle hilles righteousnes unto the people.
Manx: 3 Ver ny sleïtyn myrgeddin lhieu shee: as ny croink veggey cairys da’n pobble.

English: 4 He shall keepe the simple folke by their right : defende the children of the poore, and punish the wrong doer.
Manx: 4 Freilee eh yn vooinjer ôney ayns nyn gair: cloan y voght nee eh y endeil, as ny tranlaasee y cherraghey.

English: 5 They shall feare thee, as long as the Sunne and Moone endureth : from one generation to another.
Manx: 5 Gow‐ee ad aggle royd choud as ta’n ghrian as yn eayst er-mayrn: veih un heeloghe gys sheeloghe elley.

English: 6 He shall come downe like the raine into a fleece of wooll : even as the drops that water the earth.
Manx: 6 Hig eh neose myr y fliaghey ayns loamrey olley: dy-jarroo myr ny bineyn ta gushtaghey yn thalloo.

English: 7 In his time shall the righteous flourish : yea, and abundance of peace, so long as the Moone endureth.
Manx: 7 Ayns y lhing echeysyn nee yn vooinjer chairagh bishaghey: dy-jarroo, as palchey dy hee, choud as ta’n eayst farraghtyn.

English: 8 His dominion shal be also from the one sea to the other : and from the flood unto the worlds ende.
Manx: 8 Bee yn reilltys echey myrgeddin veih un aarkey gys faarkey elley: as veih’n awin vooar gys ayrnyn sodjey yn ooir.

English: 9 They that dwell in the wildernesse shall kneele before him : his enemies shall licke the dust.
Manx: 9 Adsyn ta vaghey ’syn aasagh nee ad gliooney sheese kiongoyrt rish: nee e noidyn yn joan y liee.

English: 10 The Kings of Tharsis and of the Iles shall give presents : the Kings of Arabia and Saba shall bring gifts.
Manx: 10 Reeaghyn Tharsis as ny ellanyn, ver ad lhieu toyrtyssyn: ver reeaghyn Arabia as Saba lhieu giootyn.

English: 11 All Kings shall fall downe before him : all nations shall doe him service.
Manx: 11 Nee dy-chooilley ree tuittym sheese kiongoyrt rish: nee dy-chooilley ashoon eh y hirveish.

English: 12 For he shal deliver the poore when he crieth : the needie also, and him that hath no helper.
Manx: 12 Son nee eh yn boght y livrey tra t’eh geam: yn ymmyrchagh neesht, as eshyn nagh vel fer‐coonee erbee echey.

English: 13 He shall bee favourable to the simple and needie : and shall preserve the soules of the poore.
Manx: 13 Bee eh foayroil da’n vooinjer ôney as ny ymmyrchee: as nee eh anmeenyn ny boghtyn y choadey.

English: 14 He shall deliver their soules from falshood and wrong : and deare shall their blood be in his sight.
Manx: 14 Nee eh ny anmeenyn oc y livrey veih foalsaght as aggair: as deyr vees yn uill oc ayns e hilley.

English: 15 He shall live, and unto him shall be given of the gold of Arabia : prayer shall be made ever unto him, and dayly shall he be praised.
Manx: 15 Bee eh bio, as dasyn vees er ny choyrt jeh airh Arabia: bee padjer er ny yannoo dy-kinjagh huggey, as gagh‐laa vees moylley er ny choyrt da.

English: 16 There shall bee an heape of corne in the earth, high upon the hils : his fruit shall shake like Libanus, and shall bee greene in the Citie, like grasse upon the earth.
Manx: 16 Bee palchey arroo er y thalloo, ard er ny croink: nee’n mess echey craa myr Libanus, as bee eh glass ’syn ard‐valley myr faiyr er y thalloo.

English: 17 His Name shall endure for ever; his Name shall remaine under the Sunne among the posterities : which shall be blessed through him; and all the heathen shall praise him.
Manx: 17 Nee yn Ennym echey farraghtyn son dy-bragh, bee yn Ennym echey er‐mayrn fo’n ghrian mastey ny sheelogheyn ta foast ry heet: vees er nyn mannaghey ny-hrooidsyn, as nee ooilley ny ashoonyn eh y voylley.

English: 18 Blessed bee the Lord God, even the God of Israel : which onely doeth wonderous things;
Manx: 18 Bannit dy row yn Chiarn Jee, dy-jarroo yn Jee dy Israel: ta ny-lomarcan jannoo reddyn yindyssagh;

English: 19 And blessed be the Name of his Majestie for ever : and all the earth shall be filled with his Majestie. Amen, Amen.
Manx: 19 As bannit dy row Ennym yn Ard‐ooashley echey son dy-bragh: as bee ooilley yn seihll er ny lhieeney lesh e Ard‐ooashley. Amen, Amen.

English: The xiiii. day.
Manx: The 14. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Quàm bonus Israel. Psal. 73.
Manx: Psal. 73. Quam bonus Israel!

English: Truely God is loving unto Israel : even unto such as are of a cleane heart.
Manx: 1 Dy-firrinagh ta Jee graihagh er Israel: dy-jarroo er nyn lheid as ta jeh cree glen.

English: 2 Neverthelesse, my feete were almost gone : my treadings had welnigh slipt.
Manx: 2 Ny-yeih, va my chassyn faggys er n’gholl voym: va my chesmadyn er‐gerrey dy skyrraghtyn.

English: 3 And why? I was grieved at the wicked : I doe also see the ungodly in such prosperitie.
Manx: 3 As cre’n‐oyr? va mee seaghnit er coontey ny mee‐chrauee: ta mee myrgeddin fakin drogh ’leih ayns lheid y raah.

English: 4 For they are in no perill of death : but are lustie and strong.
Manx: 4 Son cha vel ad ayns gaue erbee jeh’n vaase: agh t’ad trean as lajer.

English: 5 They come in no misfortune like other folke : neither are they plagued like other men.
Manx: 5 Cha vel ad cheet ayns drogh‐haghyrt erbee myr sleih elley: cha-moo t’ad er nyn gerraghey myr deiney elley.

English: 6 And this is the cause that they be so holden with pride : and overwhelmed with crueltie.
Manx: 6 As shoh yn oyr dy vel ad sheidit seose lesh moyrn: as coodit harrish lesh dewlys.

English: be so holden] 1662 are so holden
7 Their eies swel with fatnes : & they do even what they lust.
Manx: 7 Ta ny sooillyn oc gatt lesh riurid: as t’ad jannoo dy-jarroo myr sailliu.

English: 8 They corrupt other, and speake of wicked blasphemie : their talking is against the most highest.
Manx: 8 T’ad mhilley sleih elley, as dy-mee‐chrauee loayrt goan mollaghtagh: ta’n ghlare oc noi yn Er‐syrjey;

English: most highest] 1662 most High
9 For they stretch foorth their mouth unto the heaven : and their tongue goeth through the world.
Manx: 9 Son t’ad sheeyney magh nyn meeall noi niau: as ta’n chengey oc goll trooid y theihll.

English: 10 Therefore fall the people unto them : and thereout sucke they no small advantage.
Manx: 10 Shen‐y‐fa ta’n pobble tuittym lhieu: as cha nee beggan cosney t’ad dy hayrn ass shen.

English: 11 Tush (say they) how should God perceive it : is there knowledge in the most highest?
Manx: 11 Twish, t’ad gra, Kys ver Jee tastey da: vel fyssyree ayns yn Er‐syrjey?

English: most Highest] 1662 most High
12 Lo, these are the ungodly, these prosper in the world, and these have riches in possession : & I said, Then have I cleansed my heart in vaine, and washed mine hands in innocencie.
Manx: 12 Jeeagh, ad shoh ny mee‐chrauee, ad shoh ta bishaghey ayns y theihll, as oc shoh ta berchys ayns nyn gummal: as dooyrt mee, Eisht ta mish er ghlenney my chree ayns fardail, as er niee my laueyn ayns ônid.

English: 13 All the day long have I bene punished : and chastened every morning.
Manx: 13 Fey‐ny‐laa ta mee er ve er my cherraghey: as er my smaghtaghey dy-chooilley voghrey;

English: 14 Yea, and I had almost said even as they : but loe, then should I have condemned the generation of thy children.
Manx: 14 Dy-jarroo, as va mee er loayrt faggys myr ren adsyn: agh cur‐my‐ner, veïn eisht er gheyrey sheeloghe dty chloan.

English: then should I] 1662 then I should
15 Then thought I to understand this : but it was too hard of me,
Manx: 15 Eisht ghow mee ayns laue dy hoiggal shoh: agh ve ro ghoillee er my hon,

English: hard of me] 1599, 1636, 1660 hard for me
16 Untill I went into the Sanctuarie of God : then understood I the end of these men;
Manx: 16 Derrey hie mee stiagh ayns ynnyd-casherick Yee: eisht hoigg mee jerrey ny deiney shoh;

English: 17 Namely how thou doest set them in slipperie places : and castest them downe, and destroyest them.
Manx: 17 Ta shen, Kys t’ow uss dy hoiaghey ad ayns ynnydyn shliawin: as dy hilgey ad sheese, as dy stroie ad.

English: 18 Oh how suddenly doe they consume : perish, and come to a fearefull end!
Manx: 18 Oh, cre cha leah as t’ad goll naardey: cherraghtyn, as cheet gys jerrey agglagh!

English: 19 Yea, even like as a dreame when one awaketh : so shalt thou make their image to vanish out of the Citie.
Manx: 19 Dy-jarroo, eer myr dreamal tra ta fer doostey: myr shen ver oo er y chaslys oc dy lheïe ersooyl ass yn ard‐valley.

English: 20 Thus my heart was grieved : and it went even through my reines.
Manx: 20 Shoh myr va my chree seaghnit: as hie eh eer trooid my veeghyn.

English: 21 So foolish was I and ignorant : even as it were a beast before thee.
Manx: 21 Cha ommijagh shen va mee, as cha mee‐hushtagh: dy-jarroo myr dy beagh eh baagh kiongoyrt rhyts.
myr dy beagh eh baagh 1765, 1777] 1769 myr dy beagh, 1819 myr baagh

English: 22 Neverthelesse, I am alway by thee : for thou hast holden me by my right hand.
Manx: 22 Ny-yeih, ta mee kinjagh liort’s: son t’ow er my chummal rish my laue yesh.

English: 23 Thou shalt guide me with thy counsaile : and after that receive me with glory.
Manx: 23 Nee oo m’y leeideil lesh dty choyrle: as ny lurg m’y ghoaill gys gloyr.

English: 24 Whom have I in heaven but thee : and there is none upon earth that I desire in comparison of thee.
Manx: 24 Quoi t’aym ayns niau agh uss: as cha vel unnane erbee er y thalloo ta mee dy yeearree ayns solaghey jeeds.

English: 25 My flesh and my heart faileth : but God is the strength of my heart, and my portion for ever.
Manx: 25 Ta m’eill as my chree failleil: agh ta Jee niart my chree, as my hoghyr son dy-bragh.

English: 26 For loe, they that forsake thee shall perish : thou hast destroyed all them that commit fornication against thee.
Manx: 26 Son cur‐my‐ner, nee adsyn ta dy dty hreigeil, cherraghtyn: t’ow er stroie adsyn ooilley ta kyndagh jeh maarderys dt’oï.

English: 27 But it is good for me to holde mee fast by God, to put my trust in the Lord God : and to speake of all thy works (in the gates of the daughter of Sion.)
Manx: 27 Agh te mie er my hon’s dy chummal shickyr gys Jee, dy chur my hreishteil ayns y Chiarn Jee: as dy loayrt jeh ooilley dt’obbraghyn ayns giattyn inneen Sion.
dy loayrt] 1765 loayrt

English: Vt quid Deus. Psal. 74.
Manx: Psal. 74. Ut quid Deus.

English: O God, wherefore art thou absent from us so long : why is thy wrath so hote against the sheepe of thy pasture?
Manx: 1 O Yee, cre’n‐fa t’ow freayll oo hene voïn choud dy hraa: cre’n‐fa ta dty yymmoose cha cheh noi kirree dty phastyr?

English: 2 O thinke upon thy Congregation : whom thou hast purchased and redeemed of old.
Manx: 2 O smooinee er dty phobble t’ow er chionnaghey, as er veaysley er dyn chenn earish.

English: 3 Thinke upon the tribe of thine inheritance : and mount Sion wherein thou hast dwelt.
Manx: 3 Smooinee er sheeloghe dt’eiraght: as er cronk Sion, ayn t’ow er chummal.

English: 4 Lift up thy feet, that thou maiest utterly destroy every enemie : which hath done evill in thy Sanctuary.
Manx: 4 Trogg seose dty chassyn, dy vod oo dy-bollagh dy-chooilley noid y stroie: t’er n’yannoo olk ayns dt’ynnyd casherick.

English: 5 Thine adversaries roar in the middes of thy Congregations : and set up their banners for tokens.
Manx: 5 Ta dty noidyn gullaghey ayns mean dty haglym cooidjagh: as soiaghey seose nyn mergaghyn son cowraghyn.

English: 6 Hee that hewed timber afore out of the thicke trees : was knowen to bring it to an excellent worke.
Manx: 6 Eshyn ren feigh y ghiarey sheese roish nish ass ny biljyn chiu: v’eh ry akin dy chur lesh eh gys obbyr aalin.
feigh] 1777 fuygh

English: 7 But now they breake downe all the carved worke thereof : with axes and hammers.
Manx: 7 Agh nish t’ad brishey sheese ooilley yn obbyr ghranit eck: lesh teighyn as oardyn.
ghranit] 1765, 1769 granit

English: 8 They have set fire upon thy Holy places : and have defiled the dwelling place of thy Name, even unto the ground.
Manx: 8 T’ad er hoiaghey dt’ynnydyn casherick er aile: as er lhieggal sheese ynnyd‐vaghee dt’ Ennym, eer gys y laare.
ynnydyn] 1765, 1769 ynyndyn

English: 9 Yea, they said in their hearts, Let us make havocke of them altogether : thus have they burnt up all the houses of God in the land.
Manx: 9 Dy-jarroo, dooyrt ad ayns nyn greeaghyn, Lhig dooin ad y stroie dy-bollagh ooilley‐cooidjagh: myr shoh t’ad er lostey seose ooilley thieyn Yee ’sy cheer.

English: 10 We see not our tokens, there is not one Prophet more : no, not one is there among us, that understandeth any more.
Manx: 10 [155][Cha vel shin fakin nyn gowraghyn; cha vel phadeyr er-mayrn: cha vel unnane ta toiggal caid.

English: 11 O God, how long shal the adversary do this dishonour : how long shall the enemie blaspheme thy Name for ever?
Manx: 11] O Yee, caid nee eshyn ta dt’oï yn vee‐onnor shoh y yannoo: caid nee yn noid loayrt dy-mollaghtagh noi dt’ Ennym, nee son dy-bragh?

English: 12 Why withdrawest thou thy hand : why pluckest not thou thy right hand out of thy bosome to consume the enemie?
Manx: 12 Cre’n‐fa t’ow tayrn back dty laue: kys te nagh vel oo goaill dty laue yesh ass dt’oghrish dy chur mow yn noid?

English: pluckest not thou] 1662 pluckest thou not
13 For God is my King of olde : the helpe that is done upon earth, he doeth it himselfe.
Manx: 13 Son Jee my Ree er dyn chenn earish: yn cooney ta jeant er y thalloo, eh hene ta dy yannoo eh.

English: 14 Thou diddest divide the sea through thy power : thou brakest the heads of the Dragons in the waters.
Manx: 14 Ren oo yn aarkey y scarrey trooid dty phooar: vrish oo khing ny dragonyn ayns ny ushtaghyn.

English: 15 Thou smotest the heads of Leviathan in pieces: and gavest him to be meat for the people in the wildernesse.
Manx: 15 Voaill oo khing y Leviathan ayns peeshyn: as hug oo eh dy ve son beaghey da’n pobble ayns yn aasagh.

English: 16 Thou broughtest out fountaines and waters out of the hard rocks : thou driedst up mighty waters.
Manx: 16 Hug oo lhiat farraneyn, as ushtaghyn magh ass ny creggyn creoi: hyrmee oo seose ushtaghyn niartal.

English: 17 The day is thine, and the night is thine : thou hast prepared the light and the Sunne.
Manx: 17 She lhiats yn laa, as lhiats yn oie: uss t’er phointeil yn soilshey as y ghrian.

English: 18 Thou hast set all the borders of the earth : thou hast made Summer and Winter.
Manx: 18 T’ow er hoiaghey ooilley cagliaghyn ny hooirey: t’ow er yannoo sourey as geurey.

English: 19 Remember this, O Lord, how the enemie hath rebuked : and how the foolish people hath blasphemed thy Name.
Manx: 19 Cooinee er shoh, O Hiarn, kys ta’n noid er oltooaney: as kys ta’n pobble ommijagh er loayrt goan mollaghtagh noi dt’ Ennym.

English: 20 O deliver not the soule of thy Turtle Dove unto the multitude of the enemies : and forget not the Congregation of the poore for ever.
Manx: 20 O ny livrey annym dty chalmane meen gys earroo ny noidyn: as ny jarrood sheshaght ny boghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 21 Looke upon the Covenant : for all the earth is full of darkenesse and cruell habitations.
Manx: 21 Jeeagh er y chonaant: son ta ooilley yn ooir laane dy ghorraghys as dy chummallyn dewil.

English: 22 Oh let not the simple goe away ashamed : but let the poore and needy give praise unto thy Name.
Manx: 22 O ny lhig da’n vooinjer gyn loght goll roue lesh nearey: agh lhig da ny boghtyn as ny ymmyrchee moylley ’choyrt da dt’ Ennym.

English: 23 Arise, O God, maintaine thine owne cause : remember how the foolish man blasphemeth thee dayly.
Manx: 23 Trogg, O Yee, jean dty chooish hene y chummal seose: cooinee kys ta’n dooinney ommijagh dy dt’oltooaney dy-chooilley laa.

English: 24 Forget not the voice of thine enemies : the presumption of them that hate thee, increaseth ever more and more.
Manx: 24 Ny jarrood coraa dty noidyn: ta’n daanys vooaralagh ocsyn ta feoh oc ort, gaase dy-kinjagh ny smoo as ny smoo.

English: The xv. day.
Manx: The 15. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Confitebimur tibi. Psal. 75.
Manx: Psal. 75. Confitebimur tibi.

English: Unto thee, O God, do we give thankes : yea, unto thee doe we give thanks.
Manx: 1 Dhyts, O Yee, ta shin cur booise: dy-jarroo dhyts ta shin cur booise.

English: 2 Thy Name also is so nigh : and that do thy wonderous works declare.
Manx: 2 Ta dt’ Ennym myrgeddin cha faggys: as shen ta dt’obbraghyn yindyssagh dy hoilshaghey.

English: 3 When I receive the Congregation : I shall judge according unto right.
Manx: 3 Tra hig chaglym cooidjagh y pobble reesht ayns m’enish: nee’m briwnys cordail rish cairys.

English: 4 The earth is weake, and all the inhabiters thereof : I beare up the pillars of it.
Manx: 4 Ta’n seihll annoon, as ooilley e cummaltee: mish ta gymmyrkey seose ny pillaryn eck.

English: 5 I said unto the fooles, Deale not so madly : and to the ungodly, Set not up your horne.
Manx: 5 Dooyrt mee rish ny ommydanyn, Ny jean‐jee cha keoi: as rish y vooinjer vee‐chrauee, Ny soie‐jee seose nyn eairk;

English: 6 Set not up your horne on high : and speake not with a stiffe necke.
Manx: 6 Ny soie‐jee seose nyn eairk dy-ard: as ny loayr‐jee lesh mwannal mooaralagh;

English: 7 For promotion commeth neither from the East, nor from the West : nor yet from the South.
Manx: 7 Son cha vel stayd ard cheet veih’n niar, ny veih’n neear: ny foast veih’n jiass.

English: 8 And why? God is the Judge : he putteth downe one, and setteth up another.
Manx: 8 As cre’n‐oyr? she Jee yn Briw: t’eh cur sheese fer, as soiaghey seose fer elley.

English: 9 For in the hand of the Lord there is a cup, and the wine is red : it is full mixt, and he powreth out the same.
Manx: 9 Son ayns laue yn Chiarn ta cappan, as ta’n feeyn jiarg: te laane as seiyt, as t’eh deayrtey ass yn chooid cheddin.

English: out the same 1599, 1605] out of the same 1581, 1636, 1660
10 As for the dregs thereof : all the ungodly of the earth shall drinke them, and sucke them out.
Manx: 10 Er son y drundin echey: nee ooilley mee‐chrauee y theihll ad y iu, as y yiole ass.

English: 11 But I will talke of the God of Jacob : and praise him for ever.
Manx: 11 Agh loayr‐yms jeh Jee Yacob: as nee’m eh y voylley son dy-bragh.
y voylley] 1765, 1769 e voylley

English: 12 All the hornes of the ungodly also will I breake : and the horns of the righteous shall be exalted.
Manx: 12 Ooilley eairkyn y vooinjer vee‐chrauee myrgeddin nee’ms y vrishey: as bee niart y vooinjer chairagh er ny hoiaghey seose.

English: Notus in Iudæa. Psal. 76.
Manx: Psal. 76. Notus in Judæa.

English: In Jury is God knowen : his Name is great in Israel.
Manx: 1 Ayns Judea ta enney er ny choyrt er Jee: ta’n Ennym echey mooar ayns Israel.

English: 2 At Salem is his tabernacle : and his dwelling in Sion.
Manx: 2 Ec Salem ta e chabbane‐agglish: as e chummal ayns Sion.

English: 3 There brake hee the arrowes of the bow : the shield, the sword and the battaile.
Manx: 3 Ayns shen vrish eh sideyn y vhow: yn shleïy, yn cliwe, as y ghreï‐chaggee.

English: 4 Thou art of more honour and might : then the hilles of the robbers.
Manx: 4 T’ow jeh onnor as niart smoo: na croink ny roosteyryn.

English: 5 The proud are robbed, they have slept their sleepe : and all the men whose hands were mighty, have found nothing.
Manx: 5 Ta’n vooinjer voyrnagh er nyn roostey, t’ad er chadley nyn gadley: as ooilley ny deiney va ny laueyn oc niartal, cha vel ad er gheddyn monney.
chadley nyn gadley] 1769, 1777 ghoaill nyn gadley baaish

English: 6 At thy rebuke, O God of Jacob : both the charet and horse are fallen.
Manx: 6 Ec yn oghsan ayds, O Yee Yacob: ta chammah yn ainagh as y cabbyl er duittym.

English: 7 Thou, even thou art to bee feared : and who may stand in thy sight when thou art angrie?
Manx: 7 T’ow uss, dy-jarroo uss as aggle dy ve er ny ghoaill royd: as quoi oddys shassoo ayns dty hilley tra t’ow corree?

English: 8 Thou diddest cause thy Judgement to bee heard from heaven : the earth trembled, and was still;
Manx: 8 Hug oo er dty vriwnys dy ve er ny chlashtyn veih niau: va’n ooir er‐creau, as ve ny‐host,

English: 9 When God arose to judgement : and to helpe all the meeke upon earth.
Manx: 9 Tra dirree Jee gys briwnys: as dy chooney lesh ooilley yn vooinjer imlee er y thalloo.

English: 10 The fiercenesse of man shal turne to thy praise : and the fiercenesse of them shalt thou refraine.
Manx: 10 Nee elgys dooinney chyndaa gys dty voylley: as yn elgys ocsyn nee uss eh y smaghtaghey.

English: 11 Promise unto the Lord your God, and keepe it, all yee that be round about him : bring presents unto him that ought to be feared.
Manx: 11 Jean‐jee gialdyn da’n Chiarn y Jee eu, as cooilleen‐jee eh, ooilley shiuish ta mygeayrt‐y‐mysh: cur-jee lhieu giootyn huggeysyn lhisagh aggle ve goit roïsh.

English: be round] 1662 are round
12 He shall refraine the spirit of princes : and is wonderfull among the Kings of the earth.
Manx: 12 Nee eshyn ginjillaghey spyrryd prinsyn: as t’eh yindyssagh mastey reeaghyn y thallooin.

English: Voce mea ad Dominum. Psal. 77.
Manx: Psal. 77. Voce mea.

English: I will cry unto God with my voyce : even unto God will I cry with my voyce, and he shall hearken unto me.
Manx: 1 Eam‐ym gys Jee lesh my choraa: dy-jarroo gys Jee nee’m geamagh lesh my choraa, as nee eh m’y chlashtyn.

English: 2 In the time of my trouble I sought the Lord : my sore ranne and ceased not, in the night-season my soule refused comfort.
Manx: 2 Ayns traa my heaghyn hirr mee yn Chiarn: ren my hing roih, as cha ghow eh fea fud‐ny‐hoie: ren m’annym gerjagh y obbal.

English: 3 When I am in heavinesse, I will thinke upon God: when my heart is vexed, I will complaine.
Manx: 3 Tra ta mee ayns trimshey, smooinee‐ym er Jee: tra ta my chree seaghnit, nee’m gaccan.

English: 4 Thou holdest mine eyes waking : I am so feeble that I cannot speake.
Manx: 4 T’ow cummal my hooillyn dooisht: ta mee cha annoon nagh voddym loayrt.

English: 5 I have considered the dayes of old : and the yeeres that are past.
Manx: 5 Ta mee er smooinaghtyn rhym pene er laghyn y chenn earish: as er ny bleeantyn t’er n’gholl shiaghey.

English: 6 I call to remembrance my song : and in the night I commune with mine owne heart, and search out my spirits.
Manx: 6 Ta mee tayrn gys cooinaghtyn m’arrane: as ayns yn oie ta mee resooney rish my chree hene, as ronsaghey magh m’annym.

English: 7 Will the Lord absent himselfe for ever : and will he be no more intreated?
Manx: 7 Jean y Chiarn eh hene y reayll voym son dy-bragh: as nagh bee eh foayroil arragh?

English: 8 Is his mercie cleane gone for ever : and is his promise come utterly to an end for evermore?
Manx: 8 Vel e vyghin dy-slane er n’immeeaght son dy-bragh: as vel e ghialdyn er jeet dy-bollagh gys jerrey brâ?

English: 9 Hath God forgotten to be gracious : and wil he shut up his loving kindenesse in displeasure?
Manx: 9 Vel Jee er yarrood dy ve graysoil: as jean eh dooney e chenjallys‐ghraihagh ayns jymmoose?

English: 10 And I said, It is mine owne infirmitie : but I wil remember the yeeres of the right hand of the most Highest.
Manx: 10 As dooyrt mee, She m’annooinid hene eh: agh cooinee‐yms er bleeantyn laue yesh yn Er smoo syrjey.

English: 11 I will remember the workes of the Lord : and call to minde thy wonders of old time.
Manx: 11 Nee’m cooinaghtyn er obbraghyn y Chiarn: as tayrn-ym gys my smooinaghtyn ny yindyssyn ayds ayns y chenn earish.

English: 12 I will thinke also of all thy workes : and my talking shall be of thy doings.
Manx: 12 Nee’m smooinaghtyn myrgeddin er ooilley dt’obbraghyn: as bee my haggloo jeh dty yannoo.

English: 13 Thy way, O God, is holy : who is so great a God (as our God?)
Manx: 13 Dty raad, O Yee, te casherick: quoi eh ta Jee cha niartal as y Jee ain?

English: 14 Thou art the God that doeth wonders : and hast declared thy power among the people.
Manx: 14 Uss y Jee ta jannoo yindyssyn: as t’er hoilshaghey dty phooar mastey’n pobble.

English: 15 Thou hast mightily delivered thy people : even the sonnes of Jacob and Joseph.
Manx: 15 T’ow dy-niartal er livrey dty phobble: dy-jarroo mec Yacob as Yoseph.

English: 16 The waters saw thee, O God, the waters saw thee, and were afraid : the depths also were troubled.
Manx: 16 Honnick ny hushtaghyn oo, O Yee, honnick ny hushtaghyn oo, as v’ad agglit: ny diunidyn myrgeddin v’ad er nyn seiy.

English: 17 The cloudes powred out water, the aire thundered : and thine arrowes went abroad.
Manx: 17 Gheayrt ny bodjallyn magh ushtey, ren yn aer thaarnaghey: as hie dty hideyn magh dy-lhean.

English: 18 The voyce of thy thunder was heard round about : the lightnings shone upon the ground; the earth was mooved, and shooke withall.
Manx: 18 Va feiyr dty haarnagh er ny chlashtyn dy-chooilley raad mygeayrt: ren dty hendeil cur soilshey er y thalloo, va’n ooir er ny ghleashaght, as ooilley er-creau.

English: 19 Thy way is in the sea, and thy pathes in the great waters : and thy footsteps are not knowen.
Manx: 19 Ta dty raad ayns yn aarkey, as dty chassanyn ayns ny hushtaghyn mooarey: as kesmadyn dty choshey, cha vel ad er nyn gronnaghey.

English: 20 Thou leddest thy people like sheepe : by the hand of Moses and Aaron.
Manx: 20 Ren oo dty phobble y leeideil myr kirree: liorish laueyn Voses as Aaron.

English: The xv. day.
Manx: The 15. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Attendite popule. Psal. 78.
Manx: Psal. 78. Attendite, popule.

English: Heare my law, O my people : encline your eares unto the words of my mouth.
Manx: 1 Clasht‐jee rish my leigh’s, O my phobble: cromm‐jee nyn gleayshyn gys goan my veeall’s.

English: 2 I will open my mouth in a parable : I will declare hard sentences of old;
Manx: 2 Nee’m my veeall y osley ayns coraa‐dorraghey: ver-ym y bun diu jeh raaghyn doillee yn chenndeeaght;

English: 3 Which wee have heard and knowen : and such as our fathers have told us;
Manx: 3 Ad ta shin er chlashtyn as er hoiggal: as lheid as ta nyn ayraghyn er n’insh dooin;

English: 4 That we should not hide them from the children of the generations to come : but to shewe the honour of the Lord, his mightie and wonderfull workes that he hath done.
Manx: 4 Nagh jinnagh shin ad y chieltyn veih cloan ny sheelogheyn ta ry heet: agh dy hoilshaghey onnor y Chiarn, ny obbraghyn niartal as yindyssagh t’eh er n’yannoo.

English: 5 Hee made a covenant with Jacob, and gave Israel a Law : which he commaunded our forefathers to teach their children;
Manx: 5 Ren eh conaant rish Jacob, as hug eh leigh da Israel: shen ren eh saarey nyn shenn‐ayraghyn dy ynsaghey da nyn gloan;
nyn gloan] 1765 nyn ghloan

English: 6 That their posteritie might know it : and the children which were yet unborne;
Manx: 6 Dy voddagh y sluight oc toiggal ’ghoaill jeh: as y chloan nagh row foast er nyn ruggey;

English: 7 To the intent that when they came up : they might shew their children the same;
Manx: 7 Dy voddagh adsyn tra veagh ad er n’aase seose: yn chooid cheddin y hoilshaghey da nyn gloan;
nyn gloan] 1765, 1769 nyn ghloan

English: 8 That they might put their trust in God : and not to forget the workes of God, but to keepe his Commandements;
Manx: 8 Dy voddagh ad nyn dreishteil y choyrt ayns Jee: as gyn obbraghyn Yee y yarrood, agh ny annaghyn echeysyn y reayll.

English: 9 And not to be as their forefathers, a faithlesse and stubburne generation : a generation that set not their heart aright, and whose spirit cleaveth not stedfastly unto God;
Manx: 9 As gyn ve myr nyn shenn‐ayraghyn, sheeloghe vee‐chredjuagh as mee‐viallagh: sheeloghe nagh ren nyn gree y hoiaghey dy-cairagh, as y spyrryd oc cha ren lhiantyn dy-shickyr gys Jee;

English: 10 Like as the children of Ephraim : which being harnessed, and carrying bows, turned themselves backe in the day of battaile.
Manx: 10 Goll-rish cloan Ephraim: lurg daue ve eïllit son caggey, as cur lhieu bowaghyn, hyndaa ad nyn gooyll ayns laa yn chaggey.

English: which being] 1662 who being
11 They kept not the Covenant of God : and would not walk in his Law;
Manx: 11 Cha dreill ad conaant Yee: as cha jinnagh ad gimmeeaght ayns e leigh;

English: 12 But forgate what hee had done : and the wonderfull worke that he had shewed for them.
Manx: 12 Agh yarrood ad ny v’eh er n’yannoo: as ny obbraghyn yindyssagh v’eh er hoilshaghey er nyn son oc.

English: worke] 1662 works
13 Marveilous things did hee in the sight of our forefathers, in the land of Egypt : even in the field of Zoan.
Manx: 13 Reddyn mirrillagh ren eshyn ayns shilley ny shenn‐ayraghyn ainyn, ayns thalloo Egypt: dy-jarroo ayns magher Zoan.

English: 14 He divided the sea, and let them goe through : he made the waters to stand on an heape.
Manx: 14 Ren eh yn aarkey y scarrey, as lhig eh daue goll ny‐hrooid: hug eh er ny hushtaghyn dy hassoo er mooin‐y‐chielley [myr voall er dagh cheu.]

English: 15 In the day time also hee led them with a cloud : and all the night through with a light of fire.
Manx: 15 Ayns y laa neesht ren eh ad y leeideil lesh bodjal: as fud‐ny‐hoie lesh soilshey dy aile.

English: 16 He clave the hard rocks in the wildernesse : and gave them drinke thereof, as it had bene out of the great depth.
Manx: 16 Ren eh ny creggyn creoi y scoltey ’syn aasagh: as hug eh jough daue assdoo, myr dy beagh eh ass y diunid vooar.

English: 17 Hee brought waters out of the stonie rocke : so that it gushed out like the Rivers.
Manx: 17 Hug eh lesh ushtaghyn ass y chreg chloaie: myr shen dy vrish ad magh goll‐rish ny awinyn.

English: 18 Yet for all this they sinned more against him : and provoked the most Highest in the wildernesse.
Manx: 18 Ny‐yeih son shoh as ooilley hie ad ny sodjey er nyn doshiaght ayns peccah n’oï: as ren ad yn Fer smoo syrjey y vrasnaghey ’syn aasagh.

English: 19 They tempted God in their hearts : and required meat for their lust.
Manx: 19 Ren ad Jee y hrial ayns nyn greeaghyn: as hirr ad bee son y thaynt oc.

English: 20 They spake against God also, saying : Shall God prepare a table in the Wildernesse?
Manx: 20 Loayr ad noi Jee myrgeddin, gra: Jean Jee boayrd y chiarail nyn gour ayns yn aasagh?

English: 21 He smote the stonie rock in deed, that the waters gushed out, and the streames flowed withall : but can hee give bread also, or provide flesh for his people?
Manx: 21 Voaill eh yn chreg chloaie dy-jarroo, dy ren yn ushtey brishey magh, as dy roih eh ooilley ny strooanyn: agh vod eh arran y choyrt myrgeddin, ny feill y chiarail gour e phobble?

English: 22 When the Lord heard this, hee was wroth : so the fire was kindled in Jacob, and there came up heavie displeasure against Israel;
Manx: 22 Tra cheayll y Chiarn shoh, v’eh jymmoosagh: myr shen va’n aile er ny oaddey ayns Jacob, as haink jymmoose trome seose noi Israel;

English: 23 Because they beleeved not in God : and put not their trust in his helpe.
Manx: 23 Er‐y‐fa nagh ren ad credjal ayns Jee: as nagh dug ad nyn dreishteil ayns e chooney.

English: 24 So he commanded the cloudes above : and opened the doores of heaven.
Manx: 24 Myr shen ren eh ny bodjallyn heose y haarey: as doshil eh dorryssyn yn aer.

English: 25 He rained downe Manna also upon them for to eate : and gave them food from heaven.
Manx: 25 Gheayrt eh neose orroo myrgeddin frassyn dy Vanna dy ee: as hug eh beaghey daue veih niau.

English: 26 So man did eate Angels food : for hee sent them meate ynough.
Manx: 26 Myr shen ren dooinney bee ainleyn y ee: son hug eh daue beaghey dy-liooar.

English: 27 He caused the East wind to blow under heaven : and through his power he brought in the South west winde.
Manx: 27 Hug eh er y gheay niar dy heidey fo’n aer: as trooid e phooar hug eh lesh stiagh yn gheay‐neear-ass.

English: 28 He rained flesh upon them as thicke as dust : and feathered foules like as the sand of the sea.
Manx: 28 Gheayrt eh feill neose orroo cha chiu as joan: as eeanlee skainagh myr geinnagh ny marrey.

English: 29 He let it fall among their tents : even round about their habitation.
Manx: 29 Lhig eh da tuittym mastey ny cabbaneyn oc: dy-jarroo eer mygeayrt nyn gummallyn.

English: 30 So they did eate and were wel filled, for he gave them their owne desire : they were not disappointed of their lust.
Manx: 30 Myr shen ren ad gee, as v’ad jeant magh, son hug eh daue nyn aigney hene: cha row ad giarit jeh nyn yeearree.

English: 31 But while the meat was yet in their mouthes, the heavy wrath of God came upon them, & slue the wealthiest of them : yea, and smote downe the chosen men that were in Israel.
Manx: 31 Agh choud as va’n bee foast ayns nyn meeall, haink jymmoose trome Yee orroo, as varr eh yn vooinjer by verchee jeu: dy-jarroo, as voaill eh sheese ny reih deiney va ayns Israel.

English: 32 But for all this they sinned yet more : and beleeved not his wonderous workes.
Manx: 32 Agh son shoh as ooilley, hie ad ny sodjey er nyn doshiaght ayns peccah: as cha chred ad ny obbraghyn yindyssagh echey.

English: 33 Therefore their dayes did he consume in vanitie: and their yeeres in trouble.
Manx: 33 Shen‐y‐fa ny laghyn oc hug eh shiaghey ayns fardaalys: as ny bleeantyn oc ayns seaghyn.

English: 34 When he slew them, they sought him : and turned them early, and enquired after God.
Manx: 34 Tra stroie eh ad, ren ad eh y hirrey: as hyndaa ad ad hene dy-moghey, as ren ad briaght lurg Jee.

English: 35 And they remembred that God was their strength : and that the high God was their Redeemer.
Manx: 35 As chooinee ad dy nee Jee va’n niart oc: as dy row yn Jee ard nyn Ver‐kionnee.

English: 36 Neverthelesse, they did but flatter him with their mouth : and dissembled with him in their tongue.
Manx: 36 Ny‐yeih, cha ren ad agh brynnyraght rish lesh nyn meeall: as foalsaght y yannoo rish lesh nyn jengey.

English: 37 For their heart was not whole with him : neither continued they stedfast in his Covenant.
Manx: 37 Son cha row yn cree oc slane leshyn: cha-moo ren ad tannaghtyn shickyr ayns e chonaant.

English: 38 But hee was so mercifull that hee forgave their misdeeds : and destroyed them not.
Manx: 38 Agh v’eh cha myghinagh shen, dy leih eh daue nyn voiljyn: as cha ren eh ad y stroie.

English: 39 Yea many a time turned hee his wrath away : and would not suffer his whole displeasure to arise.
Manx: 39 Dy-jarroo, shimmey keayrt hyndaa eh e chorree ersooyl: as cha lhiggagh eh da’n slane jymmoose echey brishey magh.

English: 40 For he considered that they were but flesh : and that they were even a winde that passeth away, and commeth not againe.
Manx: 40 Son chooinee eh nagh row ad agh feill: as nagh row ad agh myr geay ta goll ersooyl as nagh vel cheet reesht.

English: 41 Many a time did they provoke him in the wildernesse : and grieved him in the desert.
Manx: 41 Shimmey keayrt ren ad eh y vrasnaghey ’syn aasagh: as eh y heaghney ’sy chaitnys ghennish.

English: 42 They turned backe, and tempted God : and mooved the Holy one in Israel.
Manx: 42 Hyndaa ad back as ren ad Jee y vrasnaghey: as ghreinnee ad yn Er Casherick ayns Israel.

English: 43 They thought not of his hand : and of the day when he delivered them from the hand of the enemie;
Manx: 43 Cha smooinee ad er y laue echey: as er y laa tra ren eh ad y livrey veih laue yn noid.

English: 44 How he had wrought his miracles in Egypt : and his wonders in the field of Zoan.
Manx: 44 Kys v’eh er n’obbraghey e virrillyn ayns Egypt: as e yindyssyn ayns magher Zoan.

English: 45 He turned their waters into blood : so that they might not drinke of the Rivers.
Manx: 45 Hyndaa eh ny hushtaghyn gys fuill: myr shen nagh dod ad giu jeh ny awinyn.

English: 46 He sent lice among them, and devoured them up : and frogs to destroy them.
Manx: 46 Hug eh meeyllyn ny mast’ oc, dy chur mow ad: as froggyn dy stroie ad.

English: 47 He gave their fruit unto the Caterpiller : and their labour unto the Grashopper.
Manx: 47 Hug eh yn vess oc da’n phraddag [caterpillar]: as yn laboraght oc da’n locust.
phraddag [caterpillar] ] 1819 vraddag

English: 48 He destroyed their Vines with hailestones : and their Mulberie trees with the frost.
Manx: 48 Stroie eh ny biljyn‐feeyney oc lesh claghyn‐sniaghtee: as ny biljyn‐mulberry oc lesh y rio.

English: 49 He smote their cattell also with hailestones : and their flocks with hot thunderbolts.
Manx: 49 Voaill eh yn ollagh oc myrgeddin lesh claghyn‐sniaghtee: as ny shioltaneyn oc lesh claghyn‐taarnee.

English: 50 He cast upon them the furiousnes of his wrath, anger, displeasure, and trouble : and sent evil angels among them.
Manx: 50 Hilg eh eulys e chorree orroo, farg, jymmoose, as seaghyn: as hug eh magh drogh ainleyn ny‐vud oc.

English: 51 Hee made a way to his indignation, & spared not their soule from death : but gave their life over to the pestilence;
Manx: 51 Hug eh raad da e elgys, as cha ren eh yn annym oc y haghney veih baase: agh livrey eh seose yn vioys oc gys y chramp;

English: 52 And smote all the first borne in Egypt : the most principall and mightiest in the dwellings of Ham.
Manx: 52 As voaill eh ooilley yn chied v’er nyn ruggey ayns Egypt: yn vooinjer b’yrjey as by niartal ayns cummallyn Ham.

English: 53 But as for his owne people, hee ledde them foorth like sheepe : and caried them in the wildernesse like a flocke.
Manx: 53 Agh er son e phobble hene, ren eh ad y leeideil magh myr kirree: as hug eh lesh ad ’syn aasagh myr shioltane.

English: 54 He brought them out safely that they should not feare : and overwhelmed their enemies with the Sea.
Manx: 54 Hug eh lesh ad magh dy-sauchey, nagh jinnagh ad aggle y ghoaill: as vaih eh nyn noidyn lesh yn aarkey.

English: 55 And brought them within the borders of his Sanctuarie : even to his mountaine which hee purchased with his right hand.
Manx: 55 As hug eh lesh ad cheu‐sthie jeh cagliaghyn e ynnyd casherick: dy-jarroo gys y chronk t’eshyn er chionnaghey lesh e laue yesh.
chionnaghey] 1769, 1777 chosney

English: 56 Hee cast out the heathen also before them : caused their land to be divided among them for an heritage, and made the tribes of Israel to dwel in their tents.
Manx: 56 Hilg eh magh ny ashoonyn‐quaagh myrgeddin kiongoyrt roo: hug eh er y cheer oc dy ve er ny rheynn ny mast’ ocsyn son eiraght, as hug eh er sheelogheyn Israel dy chummal ayns ny cabbaneyn oc.
mast’ ocsyn] 1769, 1777 mast’ oc

English: 57 So they tempted and displeased the most high God : and kept not his Testimonies;
Manx: 57 Myr shen vrasnee ad as hug ad jymmoose er y Jee smoo ard: as cha dreill ad ny recortyssyn echey;

English: 58 But turned their backes, and fell away like their forefathers : starting aside like a broken bow.
Manx: 58 Agh hyndaa ad nyn gooyll, as huitt ad ersooyl goll-rish ny shenn‐ayraghyn oc: leïme ry‐liattee myr bhow brisht.
leïme] 1777 lheim

English: 59 For they grieved him with their hill altars : and provoked him to displeasure with their images.
Manx: 59 Son ren ad eh y heaghney lesh nyn altaryn ayns ynnydyn ard: as vrasnee ad eh gys jymmoose lesh ny jallooyn oc.

English: 60 When God heard this, he was wroth : and tooke sore displeasure at Israel.
Manx: 60 Tra cheayll Jee shoh, v’eh corree: as ghow eh jymmoose trome noi Israel;

English: 61 So that hee forsooke the Tabernacle in Silo : even the tent that he had pitched among men.
Manx: 61 Myr shen dy hreig eh yn cabbane‐agglish ayns Silo: dy-jarroo yn cabbane v’eh er hoiaghey seose mastey deiney.

English: 62 He delivered their power into captivitie : and their beautie into the enemies hand.
Manx: 62 Livrey eh yn phooar oc harrish gys cappeeys: as yn aalid oc gys laue yn noid.

English: 63 He gave his people over also unto the sword : and was wroth with his inheritance.
Manx: 63 Livrey eh yn pobble echey myrgeddin harrish gys y chliwe: as v’eh jymmoosagh rish e eiraght.

English: 64 The fire consumed their yong men : and their maidens were not given to mariage.
Manx: 64 Ren yn aile ny deiney aegey oc y stroie: as cha row ny moidynyn oc er nyn goyrt ayns poosey.
goyrt] 1765, 1769 ghoyrt

English: 65 Their Priestes were slaine with the sword : and there were no widowes to make lamentation.
Manx: 65 Va ny saggyrtyn oc er nyn stroie lesh y chliwe: as cha row mraane-treoghe erbee dy yannoo dobberan.

English: 66 So the Lord awaked as one out of sleepe : and like a Giant refreshed with wine.
Manx: 66 Myr shen ghooisht yn Chiarn myr fer ass cadley: as myr fowyr er ny niartaghey lesh feeyn;

English: 67 He smote his enemies in the hinder parts : and put them to a perpetuall shame.
Manx: 67 Voaill eh ny noidyn echey ayns ny ayrnyn cheu‐chooylloo: as hug eh ad gys nearey kinjagh.

English: 68 He refused the Tabernacle of Joseph : and chose not the tribe of Ephraim;
Manx: 68 Dobb eh cabbane‐agglish Yoseph: as cha ren eh reih sheeloghe Ephraim;

English: 69 But chose the tribe of Juda : even the hill of Sion, which he loved.
Manx: 69 Agh reih eh sheeloghe Yudah: dy-jarroo cronk Sion bynney lesh.

English: 70 And there he builded his temple on high : & laid the foundation of it like the ground which he hath made continually.
Manx: 70 As ayns shen hrog eh e hiamble dy-ard: as hoie eh yn undin echey, myr y thalloo t’eh er n’yannoo son eashyn.

English: 71 He chose David also his servant : and tooke him away from the sheepe folds.
Manx: 71 Reih eh myrgeddin David e harvaant: as ghow eh ersooyl eh veih ny bwoaillchyn‐keyrragh;

English: 72 As hee was following the Ewes great with yong ones, he tooke him : that he might feed Jacob his people, and Israel his inheritance.
Manx: 72 Myr v’eh geiyrt er ny kirree trome lesh eayin, ghow eshyn eh: dy voddagh eh bochillaght Jacob e phobble, as Israel e eiraght.

English: 73 So he fed them with a faithfull and true heart : and ruled them prudently with all his power.
Manx: 73 Myr shen yeeagh eh daue lesh cree ynrick as firrinagh: as reill eh ad dy-tushtagh lesh ooilley e phooar.

English: The xvi. day.
Manx: The 16. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Deus, venerunt. Psal. 79.
Manx: Psal. 79. Deus, venerunt.

English: O God, the heathen are come into thine inheritance : thy holy Temple have they defiled, and made Hierusalem an heape of stones.
Manx: 1 O Yee, ta ny ashoonyn‐quaagh er jeet stiagh ayns dt’eiraght: dty hiamble casherick t’ad er yannoo neu‐ghlen, as er yannoo Jerusalem carnane dy chlaghyn.

English: 2 The dead bodies of thy servants have they given to bee meate unto the foules of the aire : and the flesh of thy Saints unto the beasts of the land.
Manx: 2 Kirp marroo dty harvaantyn t’ad er choyrt dy ve beaghey da eeanlee’n aer: as feill dty nooghyn da beïyn y thallooin.

English: 3 Their blood have they shed like water on every side of Hierusalem : and there was no man to burie them.
Manx: 3 Yn uill oc t’ad er gheayrtey myr ushtey er dy-chooilley cheu dy Yerusalem: as cha row dooinney erbee dy oanluckey ad.

English: 4 Wee are become an open shame to our enemies : a very scorne and derision unto them that are round about us.
Manx: 4 Ta shin er jeet dy ve nearey foshlit da nyn noidyn: eer craid as faghid dauesyn ta mygeayrt‐y‐mooin.

English: 5 Lord, how long wilt thou bee angrie : shall thy jelousie burne like fire for ever?
Manx: 5 Hiarn, caid vees oo corree: jean dty eadolys lostey myr aile son dy-bragh?

English: 6 Powre out thine indignation upon the heathen that have not knowen thee : and upon the kingdomes that have not called upon thy Name.
Manx: 6 Deayrt magh dt’eulys er ny ashoonyn nagh vel er choyrt enney orts: as er ny reeriaghtyn nagh vel er n’eamagh er dt’ Ennym;

English: 7 For they have devoured Jacob : and layde waste his dwelling place.
Manx: 7 Son t’ad er choyrt mow Jacob: as er choyrt naardey e ynnyd‐vaghee.

English: 8 O remember not our old sinnes, but have mercy upon us, and that soone : for we are come to great misery.
Manx: 8 O ny cooinee er ny shenn pheccaghyn ain, agh jean myghin orrin, as shen dy-leah: son ta shin er jeet gys treihys vooar.

English: 9 Helpe us, O God of our salvation, for the glory of thy Name : O deliver us, and be merciful unto our sinnes for thy Names sake.
Manx: 9 Cooin lhien, O Yee jeh nyn saualtys, son gloyr dt’ Ennym: O livrey shin, as bee myghinagh da nyn beccaghyn son graih dt’ Ennym.

English: 10 Wherefore doe the heathen say : Where is now their God?
Manx: 10 Cre’n‐fa ta ny ashoonyn‐quaagh gra: Cre vel nish yn Jee oc?

English: 11 O let the vengeance of thy servants blood that is shed : be openly shewed upon the heathen in our sight.
Manx: 11 O lhig da kerraghey fuill dty harvaantyn t’er ny gheayrtey: ve dy-foshlit er ny hoilshaghey er ny ashoonyn‐quaagh ’sy chilley ain.

English: 12 O let the sorowful sighing of the prisoners come before thee : according to the greatnesse of thy power preserve thou those that are appointed to die.
Manx: 12 O lhig da osnaghyn trimshagh ny pryssoonee cheet kiongoyrt rhyt: cordail rish mooads dty phooar, jean uss adsyn y choadey t’er nyn oardaghey gys baase;

English: 13 And for the blasphemie wherewith our neighbors have blasphemed thee : reward thou them, O Lord, seven fold into their bosome.
Manx: 13 As son ny goan mollaghtagh lhieu ta nyn naboonyn er dty oltooaney: jean uss ad y chooilleeney, O Hiarn, shiaght filley ayns yn oghrish oc.

English: 14 So wee that bee thy people and sheepe of thy pasture, shall give thee thankes for ever : and will alway be shewing foorth thy praise from generation to generation.
Manx: 14 Myr shen ver shinyn ta dty phobble, as kirree dty phastyr, booise dhyts son dy-bragh: as bee mayd dy-kinjagh soilshaghey magh dty voylley veih sheeloghe gys sheeloghe.

English: wee that bee] 1662 we that are
Qui regis Israel. Psal. 80.
Manx: Psal. 80. Qui regis Israel.

English: Heare, O thou Shepheard of Israel, thou that leadest Joseph like a sheepe : shew thy selfe also thou that sittest upon the Cherubims.
Manx: 1 Clasht, O uss vochilley Israel, uss ta leeideil Joseph myr keyrrey: soilshee oo hene myrgeddin, uss ta dty hoie er ny cherubimyn.
dty hoie] 1765 dy hoie; 1769, 1777 ny hoie; cherubimyn] 1819 cherubim

English: 2 Before Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasses : stirre up thy strength, and come, and helpe us.
Manx: 2 Kiongoyrt rish Ephraim, Benjamin, as Manasses: gleashee seose dty niart, as tarr as cooin lhien.

English: 3 Turne us againe, O God : shew the light of thy countenance, and we shall be whole.
Manx: 3 Chyndaa shinyn reesht, O Yee: jeeagh soilshey dt’eddin, as bee mayd slaane.

English: 4 O Lord God of hostes : how long wilt thou be angrie with thy people that prayeth?
Manx: 4 O Hiarn Yee dy heshaght‐chaggee flaunys: caid vees oo corree rish dty phobble ta goaill padjer?

English: 5 Thou feedest them with the bread of teares : and givest them plenteousnesse of teares to drinke.
Manx: 5 T’ow beaghey ad lesh yn arran dy yheïr: as coyrt daue palchey dy yheïr dy iu.

English: 6 Thou hast made us a very strife unto our neighbours : and our enemies laugh us to scorne.
Manx: 6 T’ow uss er n’yannoo shin eer streeu da nyn naboonyn: as ta nyn noidyn garaghtee orrin gys craid.

English: 7 Turne us againe, thou God of hostes : shew the light of thy countenance, and we shal be whole.
Manx: 7 Chyndaa shinyn reesht, uss Yee dy heshaght‐chaggee flaunys: jeeagh soilshey dt’eddin, as bee mayd slaane.

English: 8 Thou hast brought a Vine out of Egypt : thou hast cast out the heathen, and planted it.
Manx: 8 T’ow er choyrt lhiat billey‐feeyney magh ass Egypt: t’ow er n’eiyrt magh ny ashoonyn‐quaagh, as er hoiaghey eh.

English: 9 Thou madest roome for it : and when it had taken root, it filled the land.
Manx: 9 Ren oo ynnyd da: as tra ve er ghoaill fraue, lhieen eh yn cheer.

English: 10 The hils were covered with the shadow of it : and the boughes thereof were like the goodly Cedar trees.
Manx: 10 Va ny croink er nyn goodaghey lesh y scaa echey: as va ny banganyn echey myr ny biljyn‐cedar aalin.

English: 11 She stretched out her branches unto the Sea : and her boughes unto the river.
Manx: 11 Heeyn ee magh ny banglaneyn eck gys yn aarkey: as ny banganyn eck gys yn awin.

English: 12 Why hast thou then broken downe her hedge : that all they that goe by plucke off her grapes?
Manx: 12 Cre’n‐fa eisht t’ow uss er lhieggal sheese yn cleiy eck: dy vel adsyn ooilley ta goll shiaghey dy raipey j’ee e mess?
cleiy] 1765 cley; dy raipey] 1769, 1777 raipey

English: 13 The wilde Bore out of the wood doeth root it up: and the wilde beasts of the field devoure it.
Manx: 13 Ta muc feïe ass y cheyll reurey seose ny fraueyn eck: as ta maase feïe yn vagher dy chur mow ee.

English: 14 Turne thee againe, thou God of hostes, look down from heaven : behold, and visit this Vine;
Manx: 14 Chyndaa uss reesht, uss Yee yn cheshaght‐chaggee flaunyssagh, jeeagh neose veih niau: cur‐my‐ner, as jeeagh er y villey‐feeyney shoh;

English: 15 And the place of the vineyard, that thy right hand hath planted : & the branch that thou madest so strong for thy selfe.
Manx: 15 As er ynnyd y gharey‐feeyney ta dty laue yesh er hoiaghey: as er y vanglane ren oo cha lajer er dty hon hene.

English: 16 It is burnt with fire, and cut downe : and they shall perish at the rebuke of thy countenance.
Manx: 16 Te er ny lostey lesh aile, as giarit sheese: as nee ad cherraghtyn ec oghsan dt’eddin.

English: 17 Let thy hand be upon the man of thy right hand : and upon the sonne of man whom thou madest so strong for thine owne selfe.
Manx: 17 Lhig dty laue ve er dooinney dty laue yesh: as er mac dooinney, ren oo y yannoo cha lajer er dty hon hene;

English: 18 And so will not we goe backe from thee : O let us live, and we shall call upon thy Name.
Manx: 18 As myr shen cha jed mayd back voids: O lhig dooin ’ve bio, as nee mayd geamagh er dt’ Ennym.
dt’ Ennym] 1765 d’ Ennym, 1769 dt y Ennym

English: 19 Turne us againe, O Lord God of hosts : shew the light of thy countenance, and we shall be whole.
Manx: 19 Chyndaa shin reesht, O Hiarn Yee jeh’n cheshaght‐chaggee flaunyssagh: jeeagh soilshey dt’eddin, as bee mayd er nyn sauail.

English: Exultate Deo. Psal. 81.
Manx: Psal. 81. Exultate Deo.

English: Sing we merily unto God our strength : make a cheereful noyse unto the God of Jacob.
Manx: 1 Lhig dooin arrane gennal y ghoaill gys Jee nyn niart: jean‐jee kiaull gherjoil y yannoo gys Jee Yacob.

English: 2 Take the Psalme, bring hither the Tabret : the merrie Harpe, with the Lute.
Manx: 2 Gow‐jee arrane‐moyllee, lhieu‐jee ayns shoh yn tabret: yn chlaasagh villish, as y lute.
arrane-moyllee] 1777 arraneyn-moyllee

English: 3 Blow up the Trumpet in the new Moone : even in the time appointed, and upon our solemne feast day.
Manx: 3 Sheid‐jee yn cayrn dy-ard ec yn eayst noa: dy-jarroo ec y traa ta pointit, as er y laa-feailley casherick ain.

English: 4 For this was made a statute for Israel : and a Law of the God of Jacob.
Manx: 4 Son va shoh er ny yannoo ny ’lattyss son Israel: as ny leigh liorish Jee Yacob.

English: 5 This he ordained in Joseph for a testimonie : when he came out of the land of Egypt, and had heard a strange language.
Manx: 5 Shoh doardee eh ayns Joseph son recortys: tra haink eh magh ass cheer Egypt, as er chlashtyn glaare yoarree.

English: 6 I eased his shoulder from the burden : and his handes were delivered from making the pots.
Manx: 6 Hug mee aash da ny geayltyn echey veih’n errey: as va ny laueyn echey er nyn livrey veih jannoo ny pooiyt.

English: 7 Thou calledst upon mee in troubles, and I delivered thee : and heard thee what time as the storme fell upon thee.
Manx: 7 Deïe oo orrym ayns seaghyn, as livrey mee oo: as hug mee clashtyn dhyt tra shen huitt y sterrym ort.

English: 8 I prooved thee also : at the waters of strife.
Manx: 8 Phrow mee oo myrgeddin: ec ushtaghyn y streeu.

English: 9 Heare, O my people, and I wil assure thee, O Israel : if thou wilt hearken unto me,
Manx: 9 Clasht‐jee, O my phobble, as nee’ms soilshaghey dhyt, O Israel: my nee oo geaishtagh rhyms,

English: 10 There shall no strange god bee in thee : neither shalt thou worship any other God.
Manx: 10 Cha bee Jee erbee joarree ayn-yds: cha-moo ver oo ooashley da Jee erbee elley.

English: 11 I am the Lord thy God, who brought thee out of the land of Egypt : open thy mouth wide, and I shal fil it.
Manx: 11 Mish y Chiarn dty Yee, hug lhiam uss magh ass thalloo Egypt: foshil dty veeall dy-lhean, as lhieen‐ym eh.

English: 12 But my people would not heare my voice : and Israel would not obey me.
Manx: 12 Agh cha ballish my phobble geaishtagh rish my choraa: as cha ballish Israel biallys y choyrt dou.

English: 13 So I gave them up unto their owne hearts lusts: and let them follow their owne imaginations.
Manx: 13 Myr shen livrey mee ad seose gys sayntyn nyn greeaghyn hene: as lhig mee daue geiyrt er ny smooinaghtyn fardalagh oc hene.

English: 14 O that my people would have hearkened unto mee : for if Israel had walked in my wayes,
Manx: 14 O dy beagh my phobble er n’eaishtagh rhyms: son dy beagh Israel er n’immeeaght ayns my raaidyn,

English: 15 I should soone have put downe their enemies : and turned my hand against their adversaries.
Manx: 15 Veïn dy-leah er choyrt sheese ny noidyn oc: as er hyndaa my laue noi ny tranlaasee oc.
