English: 16 The haters of the Lord should have bene found lyars : but their time should have endured for ever.
Manx: 16 Veagh adsyn va dwoaie oc er y Chiarn er ny gheddyn nyn mreageryn: agh veagh y traa ocsyn er varraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 17 Hee should have fed them also with the finest wheate flowre : and with honie out of the stonie rocke should I have satisfied thee.
Manx: 17 Veagh eh er veaghey ad myrgeddin lesh y flooyr curnaght s’glenney: as lesh mill ass y chreg chloaie veïn er dty yannoo magh.

English: The xvi. day.
Manx: The 16. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Deus stetit. Psal. 82.
Manx: Psal. 82. Deus stetit.

English: God standeth in the Congregation of princes : he is a Judge among gods.
Manx: 1 Ta Jee shassoo ayns chaglym‐cooidjagh ny prinsyn: t’eshyn briw mastey Jeeaghyn [fir-reill].

English: 2 How long will yee give wrong judgement : and accept the persons of the ungodly?
Manx: 2 Caid ver shiu briwnys aggairagh: as soiaghey jeh persoonyn ny mee‐chrauee?

English: 3 Defend the poore and fatherlesse : see that such as bee in need and necessitie, have right.
Manx: 3 Jean‐jee ny boghtyn as y chloan gyn ayr y endeil: jeeagh‐jee dy vow adsyn cairys ta ayns feme as ymmyrch.

English: such as bee] 1662 such as are
4 Deliver the outcast and poore : save them from the hand of the ungodly.
Manx: 4 Livrey‐jee yn vooinjer ta treigit as ny boghtyn: saue‐jee ad veih laue ny mee‐chrauee.

English: 5 They will not bee learned, nor understand, but walke on still in darkenesse : all the foundations of the earth be out of course.
Manx: 5 Cha naillieu ’ve ynsit, cha-moo nee ad toiggal y ghoaill, agh goll er nyn doshiaght kinjagh ayns dorraghys: ta ooilley undinyn y thallooin ass nyn goorse.

English: bee out] 1662 are out
Manx: goorse] 1765, 1769 ghoorse

English: 6 I have said, Ye are gods : and ye all are children of the most Highest.
Manx: 6 Dooyrt mee, She Jee’ghyn shiu: as ta shiu ooilley nyn gloan jeh’n Fer smoo syrjey;

English: ye all are] 1662 ye are all the
Manx: gloan] 1765, 1769 ghloan

English: 7 But ye shall die like men : and fall like one of the princes.
Manx: 7 Agh yiow shiu baase goll‐rish deiney: as tuittee shiu myr fer jeh ny prinsyn.

English: 8 Arise, O God, and judge thou the earth : for thou shalt take all heathen to thine inheritance.
Manx: 8 Trogg ort, O Yee, as jean uss y seihll y vriwnys: son nee uss ooilley ny ashoonyn‐quaagh y ghoaill son dt’eiraght.

English: Deus quis similis? Psal. 83.
Manx: Psal. 83. Deus, quis similis?

English: Holde not thy tongue, O God, keepe not still silence : refraine not thy selfe, O God.
Manx: 1 Ny jean dty hengey y chummal, O Yee, ny bee kinjagh dty-host: ny freill dty chooney voïn, O Yee.
dty-host] 1765, 1769 dy-host

English: 2 For loe, thine enemies make a murmuring : and they that hate thee, have lift up their head.
Manx: 2 Son cur‐my‐ner, ta dty noidyn baggyrt dy-ard: as t’adsyn ta feoh oc orts er droggal seose nyn ghing.

English: 3 They have imagined craftily against thy people: and taken counsaile against thy secret ones.
Manx: 3 T’ad er ghoaill smooinaghtyn croutagh noi dty phobble: as er chur nyn goyrle dy-cheïley noi dty chloan chasherick.

English: 4 They have said, Come, and let us roote them out, that they bee no more a people : and that the name of Israel may be no more in remembrance.
Manx: 4 T’ad er ghra, Tarr‐jee, as lhig dooin ad y astyrt ass ny fraueyn, nagh bee ad arragh nyn bobble: as nagh bee ennym Israel ny sodjey ayns cooinaghtyn.
bobble] 1765, 1769 pobble

English: 5 For they have cast their heads together with one consent : and are confederate against thee;
Manx: 5 Son t’ad er chur nyn ghing cooidjagh lesh un aigney: as er n’yannoo conaant cooidjagh dt’oï’s;

English: 6 The tabernacles of the Edomites and the Ismaelites : the Moabites and Hagarenes;
Manx: 6 Cabbaneyn ny Edomiteyn, as ny Ishmaeliteyn: ny Moabiteyn, as ny Hagareneyn;

English: 7 Gebal and Ammon, and Amalech : the Philistines, with them that dwel at Tyre.
Manx: 7 Gebal, as Ammon, as Amalek: ny Philistinee, marish cummaltee Tyre.

English: 8 Assur also is joyned unto them : and have holpen the children of Lot.
Manx: 8 Ta Assur neesht er hassoo lhieu: as er chooney lesh cloan Lot.

English: joyned unto] 1662 joined with
9 But doe thou to them as unto the Madianites : unto Sisera, and unto Jabin, at the brooke of Kison;
Manx: 9 Agh jean uss roosyn myr rish ny Midianiteyn: rish Sisera, as rish Jabin ec awin Kison;
Midianiteyn] 1765, 1769 Madianiteyn

English: 10 Which perished at Endor : and became as the dung of the earth.
Manx: 10 Va er nyn stroie ec Endor: as haink dy ve myr eoylley er y thalloo.

English: Which perished] 1662 Who perished
11 Make them and their princes like Oreb and Zeb : yea, make all their princes like as Zeba and Salmana;
Manx: 11 Jean uss adsyn as ny prinsyn oc goll‐rish Oreb as Zeb: dy-jarroo, jean ooilley ny prinsyn oc myr Zeba as Salmana;

English: 12 Which say, Let us take to our selves : the houses of God in possession.
Manx: 12 Ta gra, Lhig dooin goaill dooin hene: thieyn Yee son spooilley.

English: Which say] 1662 Who say
13 O my God, make them like unto a wheele : and as the stubble before the winde;
Manx: 13 O my Yee, jean ad y yannoo goll-rish queeyll: as myr y yiare choonlagh roish y gheay.
jean ad y yannoo goll-rish] 1769, 1777 cur orroo dy ve myr; y yiare choonlagh] 1769, 1777 coau

English: 14 Like as the fire that burneth up the wood : and as the flame that consumeth the mountaines.
Manx: 14’ Naght myr ta’n aile lostey seose yn cheyll: as myr ta’n lossey lommey ny sleïtyn.

English: 15 Persecute them even so with thy tempest : & make them afraid with thy storme.
Manx: 15 Eiyr ad er yn aght cheddin lesh dty ghoirrin: as jean ad agglagh lesh dty sterrym.

English: 16 Make their faces ashamed, O Lord : that they may seeke thy Name.
Manx: 16 Jean yn eddin oc y choodaghey lesh nearey, O Hiarn: dy vod ad shirrey dty Ennym.

English: 17 Let them be confounded and vexed ever more & more : let them be put to shame and perish.
Manx: 17 Lhig daue ve er nyn goyrt naardey as seaghnit dy-bragh ny smoo as ny smoo: lhig daue ve er nyn goyrt gys nearey, as cherraghtyn.
goyrt] 1765, 1769 ghoyrt ´2

English: 18 And they shall know that thou, whose name is Jehovah : art onely the most Highest over all the earth.
Manx: 18 As bee fys oc, dy nee uss ta’n Ennym ayd Jehovah: yn ynrycan Er smoo syrjey harrish ooilley yn seihll.

English: Quàm dilecta. Psal. 84.
Manx: Psal. 84. Quam dilecta!

English: O how amiable are thy dwellings : thou Lord of hostes!
Manx: 1 O cre cha eunyssagh ta dty chummallyn: uss Hiarn dy heshaght flaunys!

English: 2 My soule hath a desire and longing to enter into the Courts of the Lord : my heart and my flesh rejoyce in the living God.
Manx: 2 Ta m’annym geearree as goaill foddeeaght dy gholl stiagh ayns cooyrtyn y Chiarn: ta my chree as m’eill goaill boggey ayns y Jee bio.

English: 3 Yea, the sparow hath found her an house, and the swallow a nest, where she may lay her yong : even thy Altars, O Lord of hostes, my King and my God.
Manx: 3 Ta’n sparroo hene er gheddyn ynnyd, as yn gollan-geayee edd raad oddys ee e heïn y hroggal: dy-jarroo ny altaryn ayds, O Hiarn jeh’n cheshaght flaunyssagh, my Ree as my Yee.

English: 4 Blessed are they that dwell in thy house : they will bee alway praising thee.
Manx: 4 Bannit t’adsyn ta vaghey ayns dty hie: bee ad dy-kinjagh cur moylley dhyt.

English: 5 Blessed is the man whose strength is in thee : in whose heart are thy wayes.
Manx: 5 Bannit ta’n dooinney ta’n niart echey ayn-yds: ayns e chree ta ny raaidyn ayds.

English: 6 Who going thorow the vale of misery, use it for a well : and the pooles are filled with water.
Manx: 6 Quoi ga dy vel eh goll trooid coan dy hreihys, t’eh jeeaghyn er myr farrane: as myr puill er nyn lhieeney lesh ushtey.

English: 7 The will goe from strength to strength : and unto the God of gods appeareth every one of them in Sion.
Manx: 7 Hed ad veih niart gys niart: as ta dagh unnane oc chebbal eh hene fenish yn Jee dy Yee’ghyn ayns Sion.

English: The will] 1599, 1636, etc. They will
8 O Lord God of hostes, heare my prayer : hearken, O God of Jacob.
Manx: 8 O Hiarn Yee dy heshaght flaunys, clasht rish my phadjer: eaisht, O Yee Yacob.

English: 9 Behold, O God our defender : and looke upon the face of thine Anointed.
Manx: 9 Cur‐my‐ner, O Yee nyn vendeilagh: as jeeagh er eddin dt’er‐ooïllit.

English: 10 For one day in thy Courts : is better then a thousand.
Manx: 10 Son ta un laa ayns dty chooyrtyn: ny share na thousane.

English: 11 I had rather bee a doore-keeper in the house of my God : then to dwell in the tents of ungodlinesse.
Manx: 11 Baare lhiam currym y dorrys y ve orrym ayns thie my Yee: na dy vaghey ayns cabbaneyn ny mee‐chrauee.

English: 12 For the Lord God is a light and defence : the Lord wil give grace and worship, and no good thing shall he withhold from them that live a godly life.
Manx: 12 Son ta’n Chiarn Jee ny hoilshey as fendeilagh: ver y Chiarn grayse as gloyr: as cha bee nhee mie erbee er ny chummal vowesyn ta leeideil bea chrauee.

English: 13 O Lord God of hostes : blessed is the man that putteth his trust in thee.
Manx: 13 O Hiarn Yee dy heshaght flaunys;

English: Benedixisti Domine. Psal. 85.
Manx: Psal. 85. Benedixisti, Domine.

English: Lord, thou art become gracious unto thy land: thou hast turned away the captivitie of Jacob.
Manx: 1 Hiarn, t’ow er jeet dy ve graysoil da dty heer: t’ow er hyndaa ersooyl cappeeys Yacob.

English: 2 Thou hast forgiven the offence of thy people : and covered all their sinnes.
Manx: 2 T’ow er leih mee‐chraueeaght dty phobble: as er goodaghey ooilley nyn beccaghyn.

English: 3 Thou hast taken away all thy displeasure : and turned thy selfe from thy wrathfull indignation.
Manx: 3 T’ow er choyrt voïd ooilley dty yymmoose: as er hyndaa oo hene veih chiass dty chorree.

English: 4 Turne us then, O God our Saviour : and let thine anger cease from us.
Manx: 4 Chyndaa shin reesht, O Yee nyn Saualtagh: as lhig da dty chorree scuir voïn.

English: 5 Wilt thou bee displeased at us for ever : and wilt thou stretch out thy wrath from one generation to another?
Manx: 5 Bee oo jymmoosagh rooin son dy-bragh: as jean oo dty chorree y heeyney magh veih un heeloghe gys sheeloghe elley?

English: 6 Wilt thou not turne againe, and quicken us : that thy people may rejoyce in thee?
Manx: 6 Nagh jean oo chyndaa reesht, as shinyn y vioghey: dy vod dty phobble boggey y ghoaill ayn-yd?

English: 7 Shew us thy mercy, O Lord : & grant us thy salvation.
Manx: 7 Soilshee dooin dty vyghin, O Hiarn: as giall dooin dty haualtys.

English: 8 I wil hearken what the Lord God will say concerning me : for he shall speake peace unto his people, & to his Saints that they turne not againe.
Manx: 8 Eaisht‐ym cre jirr y Chiarn my mychione’s: son nee eh shee y loayrt rish e phobble, as rish e nooghyn, nagh jyndaa ad reesht gys ommijys.

English: 9 For his salvation is nigh them that feare him : that glorie may dwell in our land.
Manx: 9 Son ta e haualtys er‐gerrey dauesyn ta goaill aggle roïsh: dy vod gloyr tannaghtyn ayns y cheer ain.

English: 10 Mercy and trueth are met together : righteousnes and peace have kissed each other.
Manx: 10 Ta myghin as firrinys er choyrt qualtys dy chielley: ta cairys as shee er phaagey yn derrey yeh yn jeh elley.
dy chielley] 1765, 1769 d’y chielley

English: 11 Trueth shall flourish out of the earth : and righteousnesse hath looked downe from heaven.
Manx: 11 Nee firrinys blaaghey ass y thalloo: as ta cairys er yeeaghyn neose veih niau.

English: 12 Yea, the Lord shal shew loving kindnesse : and our land shall give her increase.
Manx: 12 Dy-jarroo, nee yn Chiarn kenjallys‐ghraihagh y hoilshaghey: as ver y cheer ain magh e mess.

English: 13 Righteousnesse shall goe before him : and he shall direct his going in the way.
Manx: 13 Nee cairys goll roïshyn: as e immeeaght y leeideil er y raad.

English: The xvii. day.
Manx: The 17. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Inclina Domine. Psal. 86.
Manx: Psal. 86. Inclina, Domine.

English: Bow downe thine eare, O Lord, and heare me : for I am poore, and in miserie.
Manx: 1 Cromm dty chleaysh, O Hiarn, as clasht rhym: son ta mee boght, as ayns treihys.

English: 2 Preserve thou my soule, for I am holy : my God save thy servant that putteth his trust in thee.
Manx: 2 Freill uss m’annym, son ta mee ynrick: my Yee, saue dty harvaant ta coyrt e hreishteil ayn-yds.

English: 3 Be merciful unto me, O Lord : for I wil call dayly upon thee.
Manx: 3 Bee trokroil dooys, O Hiarn: son nee’m geamagh orts gagh‐laa.
trokroil] 1769, 1777 trocoil

English: 4 Comfort the soule of thy servant : for unto thee, O Lord doe I lift up my soule.
Manx: 4 Gerjee annym dty harvaant: son hoods, O Hiarn, ta mee troggal seose m’annym.

English: 5 For thou Lord art good and gracious : and of great mercie unto all them that call upon thee.
Manx: 5 Son t’ow uss, Hiarn, mie as graysoil: as jeh myghin vooar dauesyn ooilley ta geamagh ort.

English: 6 Give eare Lord unto my prayer : and ponder the voyce of mine humble desires.
Manx: 6 Cur clashtyn, Hiarn, da my phadjer: as smooinee er coraa my aghin’s imlee.

English: 7 In the time of my trouble I will call upon thee : for thou hearest me.
Manx: 7 Ayns earish my heaghyn nee’m geamagh ort: son t’ow dy my chlashtyn.

English: 8 Among the gods there is none like unto thee, O Lord : there is not one that can doe as thou hast done.
Manx: 8 Mastey ny Jee’ghyn cha vel unnane erbee casley rhyts, O Hiarn: cha vel unnane oddys jannoo myr t’ow uss dy yannoo.

English: as thou hast done] 1599, 1636, 1660, 1662 as thou do(e)st
9 All nations whom thou hast made, shal come and worship thee, O Lord : and shall glorifie thy Name.
Manx: 9 Hig ooilley ny ashoonyn t’ow er yannoo, as ver ad ooashley dhyts, O Hiarn: as nee ad dt’ Ennym y ghloyraghey.

English: 10 For thou art great, and doest wonderous things : thou art God alone.
Manx: 10 Son t’ow uss ard, as jannoo reddyn yindyssagh: uss yn ynrycan Jee.

English: 11 Teach me thy way, O Lord, and I will walke in thy trueth : O knit my heart unto thee, that I may feare thy Name.
Manx: 11 Ynsee dooys dty raad, O Hiarn, as nee’m gimmeeaght ayns dt’irriney: O jean my chree y sniemmey hood, dy voddym aggle y ghoaill roish dt’ Ennym.

English: 12 I wil thanke thee, O Lord my God, with al my heart : and wil praise thy Name for evermore.
Manx: 12 Ver‐ym booise dhyts, O Hiarn my Yee, lesh ooilley my chree: as nee’m dt’ Ennym y voylley son dy-bragh.

English: 13 For great is thy mercy toward me : and thou hast delivered my soule from the nethermost hell.
Manx: 13 Son s’mooar ta dty vyghin hym’s: as t’ow er livrey m’annym veih diunid ny hoaie.

English: 14 O God, the proud are risen against mee : and the Congregations of naughtie men have sought after my soule, and have not set thee before their eyes.
Manx: 14 O Yee, ta ny mooaralee er n’irree magh m’oï: as ta sheshaght dy ghrogh ’leih er hirrey lurg m’annym, as cha vel ad er hoiaghey uss kiongoyrt rish ny sooillyn oc.

English: 15 But thou (O Lord God) art full of compassion and mercie : long suffering, plenteous in goodnesse and trueth.
Manx: 15 Agh t’ow uss, O Hiarn Yee, laane dy hymmey as dy vyghin: surranse‐foddey, feoylt ayns mieys as firrinys.

English: 16 O turne thee then unto me, and have mercy upon me : give thy strength unto thy servant, and helpe the sonne of thine handmayd.
Manx: 16 O chyndaa uss eisht hym’s, as jean myghin orrym: cur dty niart da dty harvaant, as cooin lesh mac dt’inney-veyl.

English: 17 Shew some good token upon mee for good, that they which hate mee, may see it, and bee ashamed : because thou Lord hast holpen me, and comforted me.
Manx: 17 Soilshee orrym cowrey ennagh jeh dt’oayr, dy vod adsyn ta feoh oc orrym shen y akin, as goaill nearey: er‐y‐fa dy vel uss, Hiarn, er chooney lhiam, as er my gherjaghey.

English: good token] 1662 token; they which hate] 1662 they who hate
Fundamenta eius. Psal. 87.
Manx: Psal. 87. Fundamenta ejus.

English: Her foundations are upon the holy hils : the Lord loveth the gates of Sion, more then all the dwellings of Jacob.
Manx: 1 Ta ny undinyn eck er ny croink chasherick: shynney lesh y Chiarn giattyn Sion ny share na ooilley cummallyn Yacob.

English: 2 Very excellent things are spoken of thee : thou city of God.
Manx: 2 Ta reddyn feer ooasle er nyn loayrt jeed’s: uss ard‐valley dy Yee.

English: 3 I will thinke upon Rahab and Babylon : with them that know me.
Manx: 3 Smooinee‐ym er Rahab as Babylon: mâroosyn ta enney oc orrym.

English: 4 Behold ye the Philistines also : and they of Tyre, with the Morians; loe, there was he borne.
Manx: 4 Cur-jee my‐ner ny Philistinee neesht: as adsyn jeh Tyre, marish ny Morianee; jeeagh, ayns shen v’eh er ny ruggey.

English: 5 And of Sion it shall bee reported, that he was borne in her : and the most High shall stablish her.
Manx: 5 As mychione Sion bee eh er ny ghra, dy row eh er ny ruggey ayn‐jee: as nee yn Er smoo syrjey ee y niartaghey.

English: 6 The Lord shall rehearse it when he writeth up the people : that he was borne there.
Manx: 6 Nee yn Chiarn shoh y imraa tra t’eh scrieu coontey yn pobble: dy row eh ruggit ayns shen.

English: 7 The singers also and trumpetters shal he rehearse : All my fresh springs shall be in thee.
Manx: 7 Adsyn neesht ta goaill arraneyn‐moyllee as jannoo bingys ver eh ’sy choontey: bee ooilley my ushtaghyn geill oor ayn-yds.

English: Domine Deus. Psal. 88.
Manx: Psal. 88. Domine Deus.

English: O Lord God of my salvation, I have cried day and night before thee : O let my prayer enter into thy presence, encline thine eare unto my calling.
Manx: 1 O Hiarn Yee dy my haualtys, ta mee er n’eamagh laa as oie kiongoyrt rhyts: O lhig da my phadjer cheet stiagh ayns yn enish ayds, cromm dty chleaysh gys m’eam;

English: 2 For my soule is ful of trouble : and my life draweth nigh unto hell.
Manx: 2 Son ta m’annym laane dy heaghyn: as ta my vioys tayrn er‐gerrey gys yn oaie.

English: 3 I am counted as one of them that goe downe into the pit : and I have bene even as a man that hath no strength.
Manx: 3 Ta mee coontit myr fer jeusyn ta goll sheese ’syn ooig: as ta mee er ve dy-jarroo myr dooinney nagh vel veg y vree ayn.

English: 4 Free among the dead, like unto them that be wounded and lie in the grave : which be out of remembrance, and are cut away from thy hand.
Manx: 4 Er my scarrey mastey ny merriu, goll roosyn ta gooint dy baase, as ta nyn lhie ’syn oaie: ta ass cooinaghtyn, as ta giarit ersooyl veih dty laue.

English: be wounded] 1662 are wounded; which be out] 1662 who are out
5 Thou hast laid me in the lowest pit : in a place of darknesse, and in the deepe.
Manx: 5 T’ow er my choyrt ’sy lagg s’inshilley: ayns boayl dy ghorraghys, as ayns y diunid.

English: 6 Thine indignation lyeth hard upon mee : and thou hast vexed me with all thy stormes.
Manx: 6 Ta dty yymmoose lhie dy-trome orrym: as t’ow er my heaghney lesh ooilley dty ster’myn.

English: 7 Thou hast put away mine acquaintance farre from me : and made me to be abhorred of them.
Manx: 7 T’ow er choyrt m’ainjys foddey voym: as er chur orrym dy ve feohdoil daue.

English: 8 I am so fast in prison : that I cannot get foorth.
Manx: 8 Ta mee cha shickyr ayns pryssoon: nagh voddym geddyn ass.

English: 9 My sight faileth for very trouble : Lord, I have called dayly upon thee, I have stretched out mine hands unto thee.
Manx: 9 Ta my hoilshey gaase moal lesh eer seaghyn: Hiarn, ta mee er eamagh orts gagh‐laa, ta mee er heeyney magh my laueyn hoods.

English: stretched out] 1662 stretched forth
10 Doest thou shew wonders among the dead : or shal the dead rise up againe, and praise thee?
Manx: 10 Vel uss soilshaghey yindyssyn mastey ny merriu: ny jean ny merriu girree seose reesht, as uss y voylley?

English: 11 Shall thy loving kindnesse be shewed in the grave : or thy faithfulnesse in destruction?
Manx: 11 Bee dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh er ny hoilshaghey ’syn oaie: ny dty irrinys ayns toyrt-mow?

English: 12 Shall thy wonderous works be knowen in the darke : and thy righteousnesse in the land where all things are forgotten?
Manx: 12 Bee dt’obbraghyn yindyssagh er nyn gronnaghey ’sy dorraghys: as dty chairys ’sy cheer raad ta dy-chooilley nhee er ny yarrood?

English: 13 Unto thee have I cried, O Lord : and earely shall my prayer come before thee.
Manx: 13 Hoods ta mee er eamagh, O Hiarn: as dy-moghey hig my phadjer kiongoyrt rhyt.

English: 14 Lord, why abhorrest thou my soule : and hidest thou thy face from me?
Manx: 14 Hiarn, cre’n‐fa t’ow treigeil m’annym: as follaghey dt’eddin voym?

English: 15 I am in misery, and like unto him that is at the point to die : (even from my youth up) thy terrours have I suffered with a troubled minde.
Manx: 15 Ta mee ayns treihys, as goll rishyn ta raad y vaaish: dy-jarroo veih m’aegid derrey nish dt’atchimyn ta mee er hurranse lesh aigney seaghnit.

English: 16 Thy wrathful displeasure goeth over me : and the fear of thee hath undone me.
Manx: 16 Ta dty yymmoose lhie dy-trome orrym: as ta’n aggle t’orrym royds er my chraghey.

English: 17 They came round about mee dayly like water : and compassed me together on every side.
Manx: 17 Haink ad cruinn mygeayrt-y-moo’m gagh‐laa myr thooilley: as ren ad m’y chionney cooidjagh er dy-chooilley cheu.
chionney] 1777 hionney;[187] cheu] 1777 heu

English: 18 My lovers and friends hast thou put away from mee : and hid mine acquaintance out of my sight.
Manx: 18 My chaarjyn graihagh as my gheiney mooinjerey t’ow er goyrt ersooyl voym: as er vollaghey m’ainjys ass my hilley.

English: The xvii. day.
Manx: The 17. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Misericordias Domini. Psal. 89.
Manx: Psal. 89. Misericodias Domini.

English: My song shall bee alway of the loving kindenesse of the Lord : with my mouth will I ever be shewing thy trueth, from one generation to another.
Manx: 1 Bee m’arrane kinjagh jeh kenjallys‐ghraihagh y Chiarn: lesh my veeall bee’ms dy-bragh soilshaghey dt’irriney veih un sheeloghe gys sheeloghe elley.

English: 2 For I have said, Mercie shal be set up for ever : thy trueth shalt thou stablish in the heavens.
Manx: 2 Son ta mee er ghra, Bee myghin er ny hoiaghey seose son dy-bragh: dt’irriney nee oo y hickyraghey ayns ny niaughyn.

English: 3 I have made a covenant with my chosen : I have sworne unto David my servant;
Manx: 3 Ta mee er yannoo conaant rish my er‐reiht: ta mee er vreearrey da David my harvaant;

English: 4 Thy seede will I stablish for ever : and set up thy throne from one generation to another.
Manx: 4 Dty ’luight’s nee’ms y hickyraghey son dy-bragh: as dty stoyl‐reeoil y hoiaghey seose veih sheeloghe gys sheeloghe.

English: 5 O Lord, the very heavens shall praise thy wonderous workes : and thy trueth in the Congregation of the Saints.
Manx: 5 O Hiarn, nee ny niaughyn hene dt’obbraghyn yindyssagh y voylley: as dt’irriney ayns sheshaght ny nooghyn.

English: 6 For who is he among the cloudes : that shal be compared unto the Lord?
Manx: 6 Son quoi eh er-skyn ny bodjallyn: vees er ny hoyllaghey rish y Chiarn?

English: 7 And what is he among the gods : that shal be like unto the Lord?
Manx: 7 As quoi eshyn mastey ny Jee’ghyn: vees casley rish y Chiarn?

English: 8 God is very greatly to bee feared in the counsel of the saints : & to be had in reverence of al them that are about him.
Manx: 8 Ta aggle feer vooar dy v’er ny ghoaill roish Jee ayns chaglym‐cooidjagh ny nooghyn: as ta arrym dy ve er ny choyrt da lioroosyn ooilley ta mygeayrt‐y‐mysh.

English: about] 1662 round about
9 O Lord God of hosts, who is like unto thee : thy trueth (most mighty Lord) is on every side.
Manx: 9 O Hiarn Yee jeh sheshaght flaunys, quoi ta goll rhyts: ta dt’irriney, Hiarn smoo niartal, er dy-chooilley cheu.
cheu] 1819 heu

English: 10 Thou rulest the raging of the sea : thou stillest the waves thereof when they arise.
Manx: 10 T’ow reill dewlys ny marrey: t’ow kuinaghey ny tonnyn eck tra t’ad troggal.

English: 11 Thou hast subdued Egypt, and destroyed it : thou hast scattered thine enemies abroad with thy mighty arme.
Manx: 11 T’ow er choyrt Egypt fo‐chosh, as er stroie eh: t’ow er skeayley dty noidyn dy-lhean lesh dty roih niartal.

English: 12 The heavens are thine, the earth also is thine : thou hast layde the foundation of the round world, & all that therein is.
Manx: 12 Ta ny niaughyn lhiats, lhiats myrgeddin yn thalloo: t’ow er hoiaghey undin y seihll rhunt, as ooilley ny t’ayn.

English: 13 Thou hast made the North and the South : Tabor and Hermon shal rejoyce in thy Name.
Manx: 13 T’ow er yannoo yn twoaie as y jiass: nee Tabor as Hermon boggey y ghoaill ayns dt’ Ennym.

English: 14 Thou hast a mighty arme : strong is thy hand, & high is thy right hand.
Manx: 14 Ta roih niartal ayd: s’lajer ta dty laue’s, as ard ta dty laue yesh.

English: 15 Righteousnes and equitie is the habitation of thy seat : mercy and trueth shal goe before thy face.
Manx: 15 Cairys as cor’mid ta stoyl‐reeoil dty ynnyd‐vaghee: hed myghin as firrinys roish dt’eddin.

English: equitie is] 1662 equity are
16 Blessed is the people (O Lord) that can rejoyce in thee : they shal walke in the light of thy countenance.
Manx: 16 Bannit ta’n pobble, O Hiarn, oddys boggey y ghoaill ayn-yd: nee ad gimmeeaght ayns soilshey dt’eddin.

English: 17 Their delight shall bee dayly in thy Name : and in thy righteousnesse shall they make their boast.
Manx: 17 Bee yn taitnys oc gagh‐laa ayns dt’ Ennym’s: as ayns dty chairys nee ad boggyssagh;

English: 18 For thou art the glory of their strength : and in thy loving kindnesse thou shalt lift up our hornes.
Manx: 18 Son uss gloyr y niart oc: as ayns dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh nee oo nyn ghing y hroggal seose.

English: 19 For the Lord is our defence : the Holy-one of Israel is our King.
Manx: 19 Son ta’n Chiarn nyn vendeilagh: ta’n Er Casherick dy Israel nyn Ree.

English: 20 Thou spakest sometime in visions unto thy Saints, and saydest : I have layde helpe upon one that is mightie; I have exalted one chosen out of the people.
Manx: 20 Loayr oo keayrt dy row ayns ashlishyn rish dty nooghyn, as dooyrt oo: Ta mee er choyrt cooney er fer ta niartal; Ta mee er hoiaghey seose fer reiht ass y pobble.

English: 21 I have found David my servant : with my holy oyle have I anoynted him.
Manx: 21 Ta mee er gheddyn David my harvaant: lesh my ooïll chasherick ta mee er n’ooïllaghey eh.

English: 22 My hand shal holde him fast : and my arme shall strengthen him.
Manx: 22 Cummee my laue eshyn dy-shickyr: as nee my roih eh y niartaghey.

English: 23 The enemie shall not be able to doe him violence: the sonne of wickednesse shall not hurt him.
Manx: 23 Cha bee yn noid abyl tranlaase y yannoo er: cha jean mac yn olkys aggair y yannoo da.

English: 24 I shall smite downe his foes before his face : & plague them that hate him.
Manx: 24 Bwoaill‐ym sheese e noidyn kiongoyrt rish yn eddin echey: as nee’m adsyn y stroie ta feoh oc ersyn.

English: shall smite] 1662 will smite
Manx: Bwoaill-ym] 1765 Boaill-ym

English: 25 My trueth also and my mercy shall be with him: and in my Name shall his horne be exalted.
Manx: 25 Bee m’irriney neesht as my vyghin mârish: as ayns m’ Ennym’s bee’n niart echey er ny hoiaghey seose.

English: 26 I will set his dominion also in the sea : and his right hand in the floods.
Manx: 26 Soie‐ym seose yn reill echey neesht er yn aarkey: as e laue yesh ayns ny thooillaghyn.

English: 27 He shall call mee, Thou art my Father : my God, and my strong salvation.
Manx: 27 Nee eh geamagh hym, She uss my Ayr: my Yee, as my haualtys lajer.

English: 28 And I will make him my first borne : higher then the Kings of the earth.
Manx: 28 As nee’ms eh y yannoo my vac shinney: ny syrjey na reeaghyn y thallooin.

English: 29 My mercy will I keepe for him for evermore : and my Covenant shall stand fast with him.
Manx: 29 Freill‐ym my vyghin er e hon son dy-bragh: as shassee my chonaant shickyr mârishyn.

English: 30 His seed also will I make to endure for ever : and his throne as the dayes of heaven.
Manx: 30 Ver‐ym er y sluight echey myrgeddin dy arraghtyn son dy-bragh: as y stoyl‐reeoil echey myr laghyn niau.

English: 31 But if his children forsake my Law : and walke not in my Judgements;
Manx: 31 Agh my hreigys yn chloan echey my leigh: as nagh nimmee ad ayns my vriwnyssyn;

English: 32 If they breake my Statutes, and keepe not my Commandements : I will visite their offences with the rod, and their sinne with scourges.
Manx: 32 My vrishys ad my ’lattyssyn, as nagh vreill ad m’annaghyn: nee’ms ny foilljyn oc y cherraghey lesh y clatt, as nyn beccah lesh booillaghyn.

English: 33 Neverthelesse, my loving kindnesse will I not utterly take from him : nor suffer my trueth to faile.
Manx: 33 Ny‐yeih, my chenjallys‐ghraihagh cha goym dy-bollagh voïsh: cha-moo lhiggym da m’irriney dy ailleil.

English: 34 My Covenant will I not breake, nor alter the thing that is gone out of my lips : I have sworne once by my Holiness, that I wil not faile David.
Manx: 34 My chonaant cha jean-ym y vrishey, ny yn red y chaghlaa t’er n’gholl magh ass my veillyn: ta mee er n’yannoo breearrey un cheayrt liorish my chasherickys, nagh vail‐ym David.

English: 35 His seed shall endure for ever : and his seate is like as the Sunne before me.
Manx: 35 Nee yn sluight echey tannaghtyn son dy-bragh: as ta’n stoyll echey goll‐rish y ghrian kiongoyrt rhym.

English: 36 He shall stand fast for evermore as the Moone : and as the faithfull witnesse in heaven.
Manx: 36 Nee eh shassoo shickyr son dy-bragh myr yn eayst: as myr yn feanish firrinagh ayns niau.

English: 37 But thou hast abhorred and forsaken thine Anointed : and art displeased at him.
Manx: 37 Agh t’ow er chur cooyll rish as er hreigeil dt’ Er‐ooïllit: as t’ow jymmoosagh rish.

English: 38 Thou hast broken the covenant of thy servant: and cast his Crowne to the ground.
Manx: 38 T’ow er vrishey conaant dty harvaant: as er hilgey yn attey echey gys y thalloo.

English: 39 Thou hast overthrowen all his hedges : and broken downe his strong holds.
Manx: 39 T’ow er lieggal ooilley e voallaghyn: as er vrishey sheese ny tooryn lajer echey.

English: 40 All they that goe by, spoile him : and he is become a rebuke to his neighbours.
Manx: 40 T’adsyn ooilley ta goll shiaghey dy spooilley eh: as t’eh er jeet dy ve ny oltooan da e naboonyn.

English: rebuke] 1662 reproach
41 Thou hast set up the right hand of his enemies : and made all his adversaries to rejoyce.
Manx: 41 T’ow er hoiaghey seose laue yesh e noidyn: as er chur orroosyn ooilley va n’oï dy ghoaill boggey.

English: 42 Thou hast taken away the edge of his sword : and givest him not victorie in the battaile.
Manx: 42 T’ow er ghoaill ersooyl foyr e chliwe: as cha vel oo cur da barriaght ayns y chaggey.

English: 43 Thou hast put out his glory : and cast his throne downe to the ground.
Manx: 43 T’ow er choyrt ass e ghloyr: as er hilgey e stoyl‐reeoil sheese gys y thalloo.

English: 44 The dayes of his youth hast thou shortened : and covered him with dishonour.
Manx: 44 Laghyn e aegid t’ow er yannoo giare: as er choodaghey eh lesh mee‐ooashley.

English: 45 Lord, how long wilt thou hide thy selfe, for ever: and shall thy wrath burne like fire?
Manx: 45 Hiarn, caid nee uss oo hene y ollaghey, son dy-bragh: as jean dty chorree lostey goll‐rish aile?
son dy-bragh] 1769, 1777 nee son dy bragh

English: 46 O remember how short my time is : wherefore hast thou made all men, for nought?
Manx: 46 O cooinee cre cha giare as ta my hraa: cre’n‐fa t’ow uss er n’yannoo dy-chooilley ghooinney dy ve fardalagh?

English: 47 What man is he that liveth, and shall not see death : and shall he deliver his soule from the hand of hell?
Manx: 47 Quoi’n dooinney ta bio, nagh vaik y baase: as jean eh yn annym echey y livrey veih laue yn oaie?

English: 48 Lord, where are thy old loving kindnesses : which thou swarest unto David in thy trueth?
Manx: 48 Hiarn, cre vel dty henn chenjallyssyn-ghraihagh: yiall oo lesh breearrey da David ayns dt’irriney?
chenjallyssyn-ghraiagh] 1777 chenjallys-ghraihagh

English: 49 Remember, Lord, the rebuke that thy servants have : and how I doe beare in my bosome the rebukes of many people;
Manx: 49 Cooinee, Hiarn, er yn oltooan t’ec dty harvaantyn: as kys ta mee gymmyrkey ayns m’oghrish scammyltyn ymmodee sleih;

English: 50 Wherewith thine enemies have blasphemed thee, and slandered the footsteps of thine anointed : praised bee the Lord for evermore. Amen, Amen.
Manx: 50 Lhieu ta dty noidyn er dty oltooaney; as er hilgey scammylt er kesmadyn dt’ Er‐ooïllit: dy row yn Chiarn er ny voylley son dy-bragh. Amen, as Amen.

English: Amen, Amen.] 1662 Amen, and Amen.
The xviii. day.
Manx: The 18. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Domine, refugium. Psal. 90.
Manx: Psal. 90. Domine, refugium.

English: Lord, thou hast bene our refuge : from one generation to another.
Manx: 1 Hiarn, t’ow uss er ve nyn gemmyrk: veih sheeloghe gys sheeloghe.

English: 2 Before the mountaines were brought foorth, or ever the earth and the world were made : thou art God from everlasting, and world without end.
Manx: 2 Roish my daink ny sleïtyn rish, ny rieau yn thalloo as y seihll er nyn groo: she uss Jee er dy-rieau, as seihll gyn jerrey.
Roish my] 1765 Roish ny

English: 3 Thou turnest man to destruction : againe thou sayest, Come againe ye children of men.
Manx: 3 T’ow chyndaa dooinney gys toyrt‐mow: reesht t’ow gra, Tarr‐jee reesht, shiuish chloan gheiney.

English: 4 For a thousand yeres in thy sight, are but as yesterday : seeing that is past as a watch in the night.
Manx: 4 Son cha vel thousane blein ayns dty hilley’s agh myr y laa jea: fakin dy vel shen er n’gholl shiaghey myr arrey ’syn oie.

English: 5 Assoone as thou scatterest them, they are even as a sleepe : and fade away suddenly like the grasse.
Manx: 5 Cha leah as t’ow dyn skeayley ad, t’ad dy-jarroo myr cadley: as fioghey ersooyl chelleeragh myr y faiyr.

English: 6 In the morning it is greene, and groweth up : but in the evening it is cut downe, dried up, and withered.
Manx: 6 Ayns y voghrey te glass, as gaase seose: agh ayns yn astyr te giarit sheese, te creen as fiojit.

English: 7 For wee consume away in thy displeasure : and are afraid at thy wrathfull indignation.
Manx: 7 Son ta shin lheïe ersooyl ayns dty yymmoose: as ta aggle orrin roish dty chorree hrome.
yymmoose] 1765 ymmoose

English: 8 Thou hast set our misdeedes before thee : and our secret sinnes in the light of thy countenance.
Manx: 8 T’ow er hoiaghey nyn ghrogh‐yannoo kiongoyrt rhyt: as nyn beccaghyn follit ayns soilshey dt’eddin.

English: 9 For when thou art angrie, all our dayes are gone : wee bring our yeeres to an end, as it were a tale that is told.
Manx: 9 Son tra t’ow uss corree, ta ooilley nyn laghyn er n’immeeaght: ta ny bleeantyn ain ec kione myr skeeall t’er ny insh.

English: 10 The dayes of our age are threescore yeres and ten; and though men be so strong that they come to foursecore yeeres : yet is their strength then but labour and sorrow; so soone passeth it away, and we are gone.
Manx: 10 Ta laghyn yn eash ain three‐feed blein as jeih; as ga dy vod deiney ’ve cha lajer as dy roshtyn kiare‐feed blein: ny-yeih cha vel y troshid oc eisht agh deïnys as trimshey; cha leah shen te er n’gholl shiaghey, as ta shin goit jeh.

English: 11 But who regardeth the power of thy wrath : for even thereafter as a man feareth, so is thy displeasure.
Manx: 11 Agh quoi ta toiggal pooar dty yymmoose: son dy-jarroo myr ta dooinney goaill aggle, shen myr ta dty chorree.

English: 12 O teach us to number our dayes : that wee may apply our hearts unto Wisedome.
Manx: 12 Ynsee dooin myr shen dy earroo nyn laghyn: dy vod ny creeaghyn ainyn ve soit er creenaght.

English: O teach] 1662 So teach
13 Turne thee againe (O Lord) at the last : and be gracious unto thy servants.
Manx: 13 Chyndaa uss reesht, O Hiarn, ec y jerrey: as bee graysoil da dty harvaantyn.

English: 14 O satisfie us with thy mercie, and that soone : so shall we rejoyce and be glad all the dayes of our life.
Manx: 14 O jean shin y yannoo magh lesh dty vyghin, as shen dy-leah: myr shen nee mayd boggey ’ghoaill, as bee mayd gennal ooilley laghyn nyn mea.
jean shin y yannoo magh] 1769, 1777 jean shin magh, 1819 jean uss shin y yannoo magh

English: 15 Comfort us againe now after the time that thou hast plagued us : & for the yeres wherein we have suffered adversitie.
Manx: 15 Gerjee shin reesht, nish lurg y traa t’ow er cherraghey shin: as son ny bleeantyn ayndoo ta shin er hurranse seaghyn.

English: 16 Shew thy servants thy worke : and their children thy glory.
Manx: 16 Soilshee dt’obbyr da dty harvaantyn: as da nyn gloan dty ghloyr.

English: 17 And the glorious Majestie of the Lord our God be upon us : prosper thou the worke of our hands upon us, O prosper thou our handy worke.
Manx: 17 As dy row Ard‐ooashley gloyroil y Chiarn yn Jee ain orrin: bishee uss obbyr nyn laueyn orrin, O bishee uss ny ta shin dy ghoaill ayns laue.

English: Qui habitat. Psal. 91.
Manx: Psal. 91. Qui habitat.

English: Who so dwelleth under the defence of the most High : shall abide under the shadow of the Almightie.
Manx: 1 Quoi‐erbee ta cummal fo coadey yn Fer smoo ard: nee eh tannaghtyn fo scaa yn Ooilley‐niartal.

English: 2 I wil say unto the Lord, Thou art my hope and my strong hold : my God, in him wil I trust.
Manx: 2 Jirr‐ym rish y Chiarn, Uss my hreishteil, as my hoor lajer: my Yee, ersyn ver‐ym my varrant;

English: 3 For he shall deliver thee from the snare of the Hunter : and from the noysome pestilence.
Manx: 3 Son nee eh dty livrey veih ribbeh yn shelgeyr: as veih’n chramp baasoil.

English: 4 Hee shall defend thee under his wings, and thou shalt be safe under his feathers : his faithfulnesse and trueth shall be thy shield and buckler.
Manx: 4 Nee eh uss y choadey fo e skainyn, as bee oo sauchey fo ny fedjagyn echey: e irrinys as e ynrickys vees dty eïlley as dt’endeil.

English: 5 Thou shalt not be afraid for any terrour by night: nor for the arrow that flyeth by day;
Manx: 5 Cha bee aggle ort roish atchim erbee ’syn oie: ny roish y tiyde ta lhiggit ’sy laa:

English: 6 For the pestilence that walketh in darknesse : nor for the sicknesse that destroyeth in the noone day.
Manx: 6 Roish y chramp ta shooyll ’sy dorraghys: ny roish y chingys ta stroie ec y vun-laa.

English: 7 A thousand shall fall beside thee, and ten thousand at thy right hand : but it shall not come nigh thee.
Manx: 7 Nee thousane tuittym rish dty lhiattee, as jeih thousaneyn ec dty laue yesh: agh cha jig eh dt’aar.

English: 8 Yea, with thine eyes shalt thou behold : and see the reward of the ungodly.
Manx: 8 Dy-jarroo, lesh dty hooillyn ver oo my-ner: as hee oo leagh ny mee‐chrauee.

English: 9 For thou Lord art my hope : thou hast set thine house of defence very high.
Manx: 9 Son t’ow uss, Hiarn, my yerkal: t’ow er hoiaghey yn thie ayd dy chemmyrk feer ard.

English: 10 There shall no evill happen unto thee : neither shall any plague come nigh thy dwelling.
Manx: 10 Cha jean olk erbee taghyrt dhyt: cha-moo nee chingys trome erbee cheet faar dty chummal;

English: 11 For he shall give his Angels charge over thee : to keepe thee in all thy wayes.
Manx: 11 Son ver eh currym da e ainleyn harryd: dy dty reayll ayns ooilley dty raaidyn.

English: 12 They shall beare thee in their handes : that thou hurt not thy foot against a stone.
Manx: 12 Nee ad oo y ymmyrkey ayns nyn laueyn: nagh gortee oo dty chass noi clagh.

English: 13 Thou shalt goe upon the Lion and Adder : the yong Lion and the Dragon shalt thou tread under thy feet.
Manx: 13 Nee oo shooyll er y lion as yn adder: stampee oo yn lion aeg as y dragon fo dty chassyn.

English: 14 Because he hath set his love upon me, therefore shall I deliver him : I shall set him up, because hee hath knowen my Name.
Manx: 14 Er‐yn‐oyr dy vel eh er hoiaghey e ghraih orrym, shen‐y‐fa livrey‐ym eh: nee’ms eh y hoiaghey seose, er‐y‐fa dy vel enney echey er m’ Ennym.

English: therefore shall I] 1662 therefore will I; I shall set] 1662 I will set
15 He shal cal upon me, & I wil heare him : yea, I am with him in trouble; I wil deliver him, and bring him to honour.
Manx: 15 Nee eh geamagh orrym, as ver-ym clashtyn da: dy-jarroo, ta mee mârish ayns seaghyn; livrey‐ym eh, as ver-ym lhiam eh gys onnor.

English: 16 With long life will I satisfie him : and shewe him my salvation.
Manx: 16 Lesh bea liauyr nee’ms eh y yannoo booiagh: as soilshee‐ym da my haualtys.

English: Bonum est confiteri. Psal. 92.
Manx: Psal. 92. Bonum est confiteri.

English: It is a good thing to give thankes unto the Lord : and to sing praises unto thy Name, O most Highest;
Manx: 1 Te red gerjoilagh dy chur booise da’n Chiarn: as dy ghoaill arraneyn‐moyllee gys dt’ Ennym’s, O Uss smoo syrjey;

English: 2 To tell of thy loving kindenesse early in the morning : and of thy trueth in the night season;
Manx: 2 Dy insh jeh dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh dy-moghey ’sy voghrey: as jeh dt’ynrickys ayns traa ny hoie.

English: 3 Upon an instrument of ten strings, and upon the Lute : upon a lowd instrument, and upon the Harpe.
Manx: 3 Er greïe‐chiaull dy yeih strengyn, as er y lute: er greïe ard, as er y chlaasagh.

English: 4 For thou Lord hast made me glad through thy works : and I will rejoyce in giving praise for the operations of thy hands.
Manx: 4 Son t’ow uss, Hiarn, er my yannoo gennal trooid dt’obbraghyn: as goym boggey ayns coyrt moylley son obbraghyn dty laueyn.

English: 5 O Lord, how glorious are thy works : & thy thoughts are very deepe.
Manx: 5 O Hiarn, cre cha gloyroil as ta dt’obbraghyn: ta dty smooinaghtyn feer dowin!

English: & thy thoughts] 1662 thy thoughts
6 An unwise man doth not wel consider this : and a foole doeth not understand it.
Manx: 6 Cha vel dooinney neu-chreeney cur tastey mie da shoh: as cha vel ommydan dy hoiggal eh.

English: 7 When the ungodly are greene as the grasse, & when all the workers of wickednesse doe flourish : then shall they bee destroyed for ever; but thou Lord art the most highest for evermore.
Manx: 7 Tra ta’n vee‐chrauee glass myr y faiyr, as tra t’adsyn ooilley ta gobbraghey olkys bishaghey: eisht bee ad er nyn stroie son dy-bragh; agh uss, Hiarn, yn Fer smoo syrjey son dy-bragh.

English: 8 For loe, thine enemies (O Lord) loe thine enemies shall perish : and all the workers of wickednesse shall bee destroyed.
Manx: 8 Son cur‐my‐ner, nee dty noidyn, O Hiarn, cur‐my‐ner, nee dty noidyn cherraghtyn: as bee adsyn ooilley ta gobbraghey mee‐chraueeaght er nyn stroie;

English: 9 But my horne shal be exalted like the horne of an Unicorn : for I am anoynted with fresh oyle.
Manx: 9 Agh bee my chione’s er ny hroggal seose myr eairk unicorn: son ta mee er m’ooïllaghey lesh ooïll noa.

English: 10 Mine eye also shall see his lust of his enemies : and mine eare shall heare his desire of the wicked that arise up against me.
Manx: 10 Hee my hooill neesht e aigney er my noidyn: as nee my chleaysh clashtyn e yeearree er ny mee‐chrauee ta girree magh m’oï.

English: his enemies] 1599, 1636, 1660 mine enemies
11 The righteous shal flourish like a palme tree : and shall spread abroad like a Cedar in Libanus.
Manx: 11 Nee yn dooinney cairagh blaaghey myr y billey-palm: as skeayley dy-lhean myr y billey‐cedar ayns Libanus.

English: 12 Such as are planted in the house of the Lord : shall flourish in the Courts (of the house) of our God.
Manx: 12 Nee nyn lheid as t’er nyn soiaghey ayns thie yn Chiarn: bishaghey ayns cooyrtyn thie yn Jee ain.

English: Such as be] 1662 Such as are
13 They also shall bring foorth more fruite in their age : and shal be fat and well liking.
Manx: 13 Ver ad magh neesht ny smoo dy vess ayns nyn shenn eash: as bee ad roauyr as jeeaghyn dy-mie.

English: 14 That they may shew how true the Lord my strength is : and that there is no unrighteousnesse in him.
Manx: 14 Dy vod ad soilshaghey cre cha firrinagh as ta’n Chiarn my niart: as nagh vel veg y neu‐ynrickys aynsyn.

English: The xviii. day.
Manx: The 18. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Dominus regnauit. Psal. 93
Manx: Psal. 93. Dominus regnavit.

English: The Lord is King, and hath put on glorious apparel : the Lord hath put on his apparell, and girded himselfe with strength.
Manx: 1 Ta’n Chiarn ny Ree, as er choyrt mysh coamrey gloyroil: ta’n Chiarn er choyrt er e gharmad, as er chomm’rey eh hene lesh niart.

English: 2 He hath made the round world so sure : that it cannot be mooved.
Manx: 2 T’eh er yannoo yn seihll rhunt cha shickyr: nagh vod eh v’er ny scughey.

English: 3 Ever since the world beganne hath thy seate been prepared : thou art from everlasting.
Manx: 3 Rieau er dy hoshiaght y theihll ta dty stoyl er ve er ny hoiaghey seose: t’ow uss veih dy-bragh.
er ve er ny hoiaghey] 1769, 1777 er ny hoiaghey

English: 4 The floods are risen (O Lord) the floods have lift up their voyce : the floods lift up their waves.
Manx: 4 Ta ny thooillaghyn er hroggal, O Hiarn, ta ny thooillaghyn er hroggal seose nyn goraa: ta ny thooillaghyn er hroggal seose ny tonnyn oc.

English: 5 The waves of the sea are mightie, and rage horribly : but yet the Lord that dwelleth on high, is mightier.
Manx: 5 Ta tonnyn ny marrey niartal, as jannoo fiyr atchimagh: agh ny-yeih ta’n Chiarn, ta cummal er yn yrjid, ny s’niartal.

English: that dwelleth] 1662 who dwelleth
Manx: ny s’niartal] 1765, 1769 na s’niartal

English: 6 Thy Testimonies, O Lord, are very sure : holinesse becommeth thine house for ever.
Manx: 6 Ta ny recortyssyn ayds, O Hiarn, feer shickyr: ta casherickys cooie da dty hie son dy-bragh.

English: Deus vltionum. Psal. 94.
Manx: Psal. 94. Deus ultionum.

English: O Lord God, to whom vengeance belongeth: thou God to whom vengeance belongeth, shew thy selfe.
Manx: 1 O Hiarn Yee, dhyts ta bentyn dy ghoaill kerraghey: uss Yee, dhyts ta kerraghey bentyn, jean oo hene y hoilshaghey.

English: 2 Arise thou Judge of the world : and reward the proud after their deserving.
Manx: 2 Trogg ort, uss Vriw y theihll: as jean ny mooaralee y chooilleeney lurg nyn doilchin.

English: 3 Lord, how long shall the ungodly : how long shall the ungodly triumph?
Manx: 3 Hiarn, caid nee ny mee‐chrauee: caid nee yn vooinjer vee‐chrauee boggyssagh?

English: 4 How long shall all wicked doers speake so disdainefully : and make such proud boasting?
Manx: 4 Caid nee ooilley ny drogh‐yantee loayrt cha mooaralagh: as goaill orroo lheid y voggyssagh voyrnagh?

English: 5 They smite downe thy people, O Lord : and trouble thine heritage.
Manx: 5 T’ad bwoalley sheese dty phobble, O Hiarn: as jannoo tranlaase er dt’eiraght.

English: 6 They murther the widow and the stranger : and put the fatherlesse to death.
Manx: 6 T’ad dunverys y ven‐treoghe, as y joarree: as cur y liannoo gyn ayr dy baase.

English: 7 And yet they say, Tush, the Lord shall not see : neither shall the God of Jacob regard it.
Manx: 7 As foast t’ad gra, Cha n’aggle dooin, cha jean y Chiarn fakin: cha-moo ver Jee Yacob geill da.

English: 8 Take heed ye unwise among the people : O yee fooles, when will ye understand?
Manx: 8 Gow‐jee tastey, shiuish vee‐hushtee mastey’n pobble: O shiuish ommydanyn, cooinn nee shiu toiggal?

English: 9 He that planted the eare, shall he not heare : or hee that made the eye, shall he not see?
Manx: 9 Eshyn ren y chleaysh y hoiaghey, nagh jean eh clashtyn: ny eshyn ren y thooill, nagh jean eh fakin?

English: 10 Or he that nurtureth the heathen : it is hee that teacheth man knowledge, shall not he punish?
Manx: 10 Ny eshyn ta cummal seose ny ashoonyn: she eshyn ta gynsaghey da dooinney tushtey, nagh jean eshyn kerraghey?

English: 11 The Lord knoweth the thoughts of man : that they are but vaine.
Manx: 11 Ta fys ec y Chiarn er smooinaghtyn dooinney: nagh vel ad agh fardail.

English: 12 Blessed is the man whom thou chastenest (O Lord :) and teachest him in thy Law;
Manx: 12 Bannit yn dooinney t’ow dy smaghtaghey, O Hiarn: as dy ynsaghey ayns dty leigh;

English: 13 That thou mayest give him patience in time of adversitie : untill the pit be digged up for the ungodly.
Manx: 13 Dy vod oo surranse y choyrt da ayns earish seaghyn: derrey vees yn ooig er ny chleiy son ny mee‐chrauee.

English: 14 For the Lord will not faile his people : neither will hee forsake his inheritance;
Manx: 14 Son cha jean y Chiarn failleil e phobble: cha-moo nee eh treigeil e eiraght;

English: 15 Untill righteousnes turne againe unto Judgement : all such as be true in heart shall follow it.
Manx: 15 Derrey hyndaa’s cairys reesht gys briwnys: nee adsyn ooilley ta firrinagh ayns cree, geiyrt er.

English: be true] 1662 are true
16 Who will rise up with me against the wicked : or who will take my part against the evill doers?
Manx: 16 Quoi nee girree seose mârym noi ny mee‐chrauee: ny quoi hassys er my cheu noi ny drogh-yantee?
my cheu] 1819 my heu

English: 17 If the Lord had not helped mee : it had not failed but my soule had bene put to silence.
Manx: 17 Mannagh beagh y Chiarn er chooney lhiam: cha row saase my chour nagh beagh m’annym er ny choyrt ny-host.

English: 18 But when I said, My foote hath slipt : thy mercie (O Lord) held me up.
Manx: 18 Agh tra dooyrt mee, Ta my chass er skyrraghtyn: ren dty vyghin’s, O Hiarn, mish y chummal seose.

English: 19 In the multitude of the sorrowes that I had in my heart : thy comforts have refreshed my soule.
Manx: 19 Ayns ymmodee ny smooinaghtyn trimshagh v’aym ayns my chree: ta dty gherjagh er ooraghey m’annym.

English: 20 Wilt thou have any thing to do with the stoole of wickednesse : which imagineth mischiefe as a law?
Manx: 20 Bee veg ayds dy yannoo rish y stoyl‐briwnys dy vee‐chairys: ta cummey yn aggair myr y leigh?

English: 21 They gather them together against the soule of the righteous : and condemne the innocent blood.
Manx: 21 T’ad chaglym cooidjagh noi annym y dooinney cairagh: as deyrey gy baase yn uill neu-chyndagh.

English: 22 But the Lord is my refuge : & my God is the strength of my confidence.
Manx: 22 Agh yn Chiarn my chemmyrk: as my Yee niart my hreishteil.

English: 23 He shall recompense them their wickednesse, and destroy them in their owne malice : yea, the Lord our God shall destroy them.
Manx: 23 Cooilleenee eh orroosyn nyn olkys, as stroie‐ee eh ad ayns y ghoanlys oc hene: dy-jarroo, nee’n Chiarn yn Jee ain ad y stroie.

English: The xix. day.
Manx: The 19. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Venite exultemus. Psal. 95.
Manx: Psal. 95. Venite, exultemus.

English: O come, let us sing unto the Lord : let us heartily rejoyce in the strength of our Salvation.
Manx: 1 O tar‐jee, lhig dooin arrane y ghoaill gys y Chiarn: lhig dooin dy-creeoil boggey ’ghoaill ayns niart nyn saualtys.

English: 2 Let us come before his presence with thankesgiving : and shew our selves glad in him with Psalmes.
Manx: 2 Lhig dooin cheet kiongoyrt rish yn enish echey lesh toyrt‐booise: as soilshaghey shin hene gennal aynsyn lesh arraneyn‐moyllee.

English: 3 For the Lord is a great God : and a great King above all Gods.
Manx: 3 Son ta’n Chiarn ny Yee mooar: as ny Ree mooar er-skyn dy-chooilley Yee.

English: 4 In his hand are all the corners of the earth : and the strength of the hils is his also.
Manx: 4 Ayns y laue echeysyn ta ooilley corneilyn y thallooin: as niart ny croink she leshyn eh myrgeddin.

English: 5 The sea is his, and he made it : and his hands prepared the dry land.
Manx: 5 Yn faarkey she leshyn eh, as eh ren eh: as ny laueyn echeysyn ren aarloo yn thalloo chirrym.

English: 6 O Come, let us worship and fall downe : and kneele before the Lord our Maker.
Manx: 6 O tarr‐jee, lhig dooin ooashley y choyrt, as tuittym sheese: as gliooney kiongoyrt rish y Chiarn y Fer ren shin.

English: 7 For he is (the Lord) our God : and we are the people of his pasture, and the sheepe of his hand.
Manx: 7 Son eshyn y Chiarn y Jee ain: as shinyn pobble e phastyr, as kirree e laue.

English: 8 To day if yee will heare his voyce, harden not your hearts : as in the provocation, and as in the day of temptation in the wildernesse;
Manx: 8 Jiu my nee shiu clashtyn e choraa, ny creoi‐jee nyn greeaghyn: myr ayns y vrasnagh, as ayns laa yn violagh ayns yn aasagh;

English: 9 When your fathers tempted me : prooved me, and saw my workes.
Manx: 9 Tra ren ny ayraghyn eu mish y vrasnaghey: phrow ad mee, as honnick ad m’obbraghyn.

English: 10 Fortie yeeres long was I grieved with this generation, and said : It is a people that doe erre in their hearts, for they have not knowen my wayes;
Manx: 10 Da‐eed bleïn liauyr va mee corree rish y cheeloghe shoh, as dooyrt mee: She pobble ad ta goll er‐shaghryn ayns nyn greeaghyn, son cha vel enney er ve oc er my raaidyn.

English: 11 Unto whom I sware in my wrath : that they should not enter into my rest.
Manx: 11 Dauesyn loo mee ayns my chorree: nagh ragh ad stiagh ayns m’ea.

English: Cantate Domino. Psal. 96.
Manx: Psal. 96. Cantate Domino.

English: O sing unto the Lord a new Song : sing unto the Lord all the whole earth.
Manx: 1 O gow‐jee arrane noa da’n Chiarn: gow-jee arrane da’n Chiarn, ooilley yn slane seihll.

English: 2 Sing unto the Lord, and praise his Name : be telling of his salvation from day to day.
Manx: 2 Gow‐jee arrane da’n Chiarn, as moylley‐jee yn Ennym echey: bee-jee ginsh jeh e haualtys veih laa dy laa.
moylley-jee] 1765 myolley-jee; bee-jee ginsh jeh e haualtys] 1769, 1777 insh jee magh e haualtys

English: 3 Declare his honour unto the heathen : and his wonders unto all people.
Manx: 3 Jean‐jee e onnor y hoilshaghey da ny ashoonyn‐quaagh: as e yindyssyn da dy-chooilley phobble.
onnor] 1769, 1777 ooashley

English: 4 For the Lord is great, and cannot worthily be praised : he is more to be feared then all gods.
Manx: 4 Son ta’n Chiarn mooar, as cha vod eh dy-feeu ’ve er ny voylley: ta ny smoo dy aggle dy ve goit roïshyn na dy-chooilley Yee.

English: 5 As for all the gods of the heathen, they bee but idoles : but it is the Lord that made the heavens.
Manx: 5 Son cha vel ooilley Jee’ghyn ny ashoonyn agh jallooyn: agh she’n Chiarn chroo ny niaughyn.

English: they bee] 1662 they are
6 Glory and worship are before him : power and honour are in his Sanctuary.
Manx: 6 Ta gloyr as ooashley ayns e enish: ta pooar as onnor ayns ynnyd e chasherickys.

English: 7 Ascribe unto the Lord (O yee kinreds of the people :) ascribe unto the Lord worship and power.
Manx: 7 Cur‐jee da’n Chiarn, O shiuish chynneeyn y phobble: chebb‐jee da’n Chiarn ooashley as pooar.

English: 8 Ascribe unto the Lord the honour due unto his Name : bring presents, and come into his Courts.
Manx: 8 Cur‐jee da’n Chiarn yn onnor cair da’n Ennym echey: chebb‐jee ourallyn, as tarr‐jee stiagh ayns e chooyrtyn.

English: 9 O worship the Lord in the beautie of holinesse : let the whole earth stand in awe of him.
Manx: 9 O cur‐jee ooashley da’n Chiarn ayns yn ynnyd aalin dy chasherickys: lhig da’n slane seihll ’ve arrymagh ayns e enish.

English: 10 Tell it out among the heathen, that the Lord is King : and that it is hee which hath made the round world so fast that it cannot bee mooved; and how that hee shall judge the people righteously.
Manx: 10 Insh-jee mastey ny ashoonyn, dy nee yn Chiarn y Ree: as dy nee eshyn eh t’er n’yannoo yn seihll rhunt cha shickyr nagh vod eh ve er ny scughey, as kys dy jean eh yn pobble y vriwnys dy-cairagh.

English: hee which] 1662 he who
11 Let the heavens rejoyce, and let the earth bee glad : let the sea make a noise, and all that therein is.
Manx: 11 Lhig da ny niaughyn goaill boggey, as lhig da’n thalloo ’ve gennal: lhig da’n faarkey fiyr y yannoo, as ooilley ny t’ayn.
fiyr y yannoo] 1769 fiyral, 1777 feiyral

English: 12 Let the field bee joyfull, and all that is in it : then shall all the trees of the wood rejoyce before the Lord.
Manx: 12 Lhig da’n magher ’ve laane dy voggey, as ooilley ny t’ayn: eisht nee ooilley biljyn y cheyll boggey ’ghoaill kiongoyrt rish y Chiarn.

English: 13 For he commeth, for hee commeth to judge the earth : and with righteousnesse to judge the world, and the people with his trueth.
Manx: 13 Son t’eh cheet, t’eh cheet dy vriwnys y thalloo: as lesh cairys dy vriwnys y seihll, as y pobble lesh e ynrickys.

English: Dominus regnauit. Psal. 97.
Manx: Psal. 97. Dominus regnavit.

English: The Lord is King, the earth may be glad thereof : yea, the multitude of the Isles may be glad thereof.
Manx: 1 Ta’n Chiarn yn Ree, foddee’n seihll goaill boggey jeh: dy-jarroo, foddee ny ymmodee ellanyn boggey ’ghoaill jeh.

English: 2 Cloudes and darkenesse are round about him : righteousnesse and judgement are the habitation of his seat.
Manx: 2 Ta bodjallyn as dorraghys cruinn mygeayrt‐y-mysh: ta cairys as briwnys coamrey e stoyl‐reeoil.
cruinn] absent in 1769, 1777

English: 3 There shall go a fire before him : and burne up his enemies on every side.
Manx: 3 Hed aile magh roïsh: as loshtee eh seose e noidyn er dy-chooilley cheu.
cheu] 1819 heu

English: 4 His lightnings gave shine unto the world : the earth saw it and was afraid.
Manx: 4 Ren ny tendeilyn echey soilshey y choyrt da’n seihll: honnick y thalloo shen, as ve agglit.
tendeilyn] 1769, 1777 tendreilyn

English: 5 The hils melted like waxe at the presence of the Lord : at the presence of the Lord of the whole earth.
Manx: 5 Ren ny croink lheïe goll‐rish kere ec fenish y Chiarn: ec fenish Chiarn y slane seihll.

English: 6 The heavens have declared his righteousnesse : and all the people have seene his glory.
Manx: 6 Ta ny niaughyn er hoilshaghey e chairys: as ta ooilley yn pobble er akin e ghloyr.
akin] 1819 vakin

English: 7 Confounded bee all they that worship carved images, and that delight in vaine gods : worship him all ye gods.
Manx: 7 Bee adsyn ooilley er nyn goyrt gys nearey ta cur ooashley da jallooyn granit, as ta goaill taitnys ayns Jee’ghyn fardalagh: cur‐jee ooashley dasyn, ooilley shiuish Yee’ghyn.

English: 8 Sion heard of it, and rejoyced : and the daughters of Juda were glad, because of thy Judgements, O Lord.
Manx: 8 Cheayll Sion jeh shoh, as ghow ee boggey: as va inneenyn Yudah gennal, er graih dty vriwnyssyn, O Hiarn.

English: 9 For thou Lord art higher then al that are in the earth : thou art exalted farre above all gods.
Manx: 9 Son t’ow uss, Hiarn, ny syrjey na adsyn ooilley t’er y thalloo: t’ow er dty hoiaghey seose foddey er-skyn dy-chooilley Yee.
dty hoiaghey] 1765, 1769 dy hoiaghey

English: 10 O yee that love the Lord, see that yee hate the thing which is evill : the Lord preserveth the soules of his Saints; he shall deliver them from the hand of the ungodly.
Manx: 10 O shiuish ta graihagh er y Chiarn, jeeagh‐jee dy der shiu dwoaie da’n olk: ta’n Chiarn coadey anmeenyn e nooghyn; nee eh ad y livrey veih laue ny mee‐chrauee.

English: 11 There is sprung up a light for the righteous : and joyful gladnesse for such as be true hearted.
Manx: 11 Ta soilshey er n’irree son y vooinjer chairagh: as gennallys gherjoilagh dauesyn ta dy chree firrinagh.

English: such as be] 1662 such as are
12 Rejoyce in the Lord ye righteous : and give thanks for a remembrance of his holinesse.
Manx: 12 Gow‐jee boggey ayns y Chiarn, shiuish sleih ynrick: as cur‐jee booise ayns cooinaghtyn jeh e chasherickys.

English: The xix. day.
Manx: The 19. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Cantate Domino. Psal. 98.
Manx: Psal. 98. Cantate Domino.

English: O sing unto the Lord a new song : for hee hath done marveilous things.
Manx: 1 O gow‐jee arrane noa gys y Chiarn: son t’eh er n’yannoo reddyn yindyssagh.

English: 2 With his owne right hand, and with his holy arme : hath he gotten himselfe the victory.
Manx: 2 Lesh e laue yesh hene, as lesh e roih chasherick: t’eh er gheddyn da hene yn varriaght.

English: 3 The Lord declared his salvation : his righteousnesse hath hee openly shewed in the sight of the heathen.
Manx: 3 Ta’n Chiarn er hoilshaghey e haualtys: e chairys t’eh er hoiaghey magh dy-foshlit ayns shilley ny ashoonyn.

English: 4 He hath remembered his mercy and trueth toward the house of Israel : and all the ends of the world have seene the salvation of our God.
Manx: 4 T’eh er chooinaghtyn er e vyghin as e ynrickys gys thie Israel: as ta ny ardjyn sodjey mooie jeh’n theihll er vakin saualtys y Jee ain.

English: 5 Shew your selves joyfull unto the Lord, all ye lands : sing, rejoyce, and give thankes.
Manx: 5 Jeeagh‐jee shiu hene gennal gys y Chiarn, ooilley shiuish cheeraghyn: gow‐jee arrane, gow‐jee boggey, as cur‐jee booise.

English: 6 Praise the Lord upon the Harpe : sing to the Harpe with a Psalme of thankesgiving.
Manx: 6 Moylley‐jee yn Chiarn er y chlaasagh: gow‐jee arrane marish y chlaasagh lesh psalm dy hoyrt‐booise.
marish] 1769, 1777 er

English: 7 With trumpets also & shawmes : O shew your selves joyfull before the Lord the King.
Manx: 7 Lesh cayrnyn myrgeddin as shawmyn: O jeeagh‐jee shiu hene gennal kiongoyrt rish y Chiarn y Ree.

English: 8 Let the Sea make a noise, and all that therein is: the round world, and they that dwell therein.
Manx: 8 Lhig da’n faarkey feiyr y yannoo, as ooilley ny t’ayn: yn seihll cruïnn, as adsyn ta vaghey ayn.

English: 9 Let the floods clap their hands, & let the hils be joyfull together before the Lord : for he is come to judge the earth.
Manx: 9 Lhig da ny thooillaghyn nyn massyn y woalley, as lhig da ny croink ve gennal cooidjagh kiongoyrt rish y Chiarn: son t’eh cheet dy vriwnys y thalloo.

English: 10 With righteousnesse shall he judge the world : and the people with equitie.
Manx: 10 Lesh ynrickys nee eh yn seihll y vriwnys: as y pobble lesh cairys.

English: Dominus regnauit. Psal. 99.
Manx: Psal. 99. Dominus regnavit.

English: The Lord is King, be the people never so unpatient : hee sitteth betweene the Cherubims, bee the earth never so unquiet.
Manx: 1 She yn Chiarn y Ree, lhig da’n pobble girree magh myr sailliu: t’eh ny hoie eddyr ny cherubimyn ga dy vel y seihll cha anveagh.
cherubimyn] 1819 cherubim

English: 2 The Lord is great in Sion : and high above all people.
Manx: 2 S’mooar ta’n Chiarn ayns Sion: as ard er-skyn dy-chooilley phobble.

English: 3 They shall give thankes unto thy Name : which is Great, Wonderfull, and Holy.
Manx: 3 Ver ad booise da dt’ Ennym’s: ta mooar, yindyssagh, as casherick.

English: 4 The Kings power loveth Judgement; thou hast prepared equitie : thou hast executed Judgement, and righteousnesse in Jacob.
Manx: 4 Ta pooar y ree graihagh er briwnys; t’ow er hoiaghey seose cairys: t’ow er chooilleeney briwnys as ynrickys ayns Jacob.

English: 5 O magnifie the Lord our God : and fall downe before his footestoole, for he is Holy.
Manx: 5 O cur‐jee ard‐voylley da’n Chiarn y Jee ain: as tuitt‐jee sheese er nyn ghlioonyn kiongoyrt rish stoyl e choshey, son t’eshyn casherick.

English: 6 Moses and Aaron among his Priests, and Samuel among such as call upon his Name : these called upon the Lord, and he heard them.
Manx: 6 Moses as Aaron mastey e haggyrtyn, as Samuel mâroosyn ta geamagh er e Ennym: deïe ad shoh er y Chiarn, as cheayll eh ad.

English: 7 He spake unto them out of the cloudy pillar : for they kept his Testimonies, and the Law that he gave them.
Manx: 7 Loayr eh roo ass y phillar vodjallagh: son dreill ad e recortyssyn, as y leigh v’eh er choyrt daue.

English: 8 Thou heardest them (O Lord our God :) thou forgavest them, O God, and punishedst their owne inventions.
Manx: 8 Cheayll oo ad, O Hiarn nyn Yee: leih oo daue, O Yee, as ren oo kerraghey ny obbraghyn fardalagh oc.

English: 9 O magnifie the Lord our God, and worship him upon his Holy hill : for the Lord our God is Holy.
Manx: 9 O cur‐jee ard voylley da’n Chiarn yn Jee ain, as jean‐jee eshyn y ooashlaghey er e chronk casherick: son ta’n Chiarn yn Jee ain casherick.

English: Iubilate Deo. Psal. 100.
Manx: Psal. 100. Jubilate Deo.

English: O be joyfull in the Lord all ye lands : serve the Lord with gladnesse, and come before his presence with a Song.
Manx: 1 O bee‐jee gerjoil ayns y Chiarn, ooilley shiuish cheeraghyn: shirveish‐jee yn Chiarn lesh gennallys, as tarr‐jee roish e enish lesh arrane.

English: 2 Bee ye sure that the Lord he is God; it is he that hath made us, and not we our selves : we are his people, and the sheepe of his pasture.
Manx: 2 Bee‐jee shickyr dy nee’n Chiarn ta Jee: eshyn t’er n’yannoo shin, as cha nee shin hene, shinyn e phobble, as kirree e phastyr.

English: 3 O goe your way into his Gates with thankesgiving, and into his Courts with praise : be thankefull unto him, and speake good of his Name.
Manx: 3 O gow‐jee stiagh ayns e yiattyn lesh toyrt‐booise, as ayns e chooyrtyn lesh moylley: bee‐jee booisal dasyn, as loayr-jee mie jeh’n Ennym echey.

English: 4 For the Lord is gracious, his Mercie is everlasting : and his Trueth endureth from generation to generation.
Manx: 4 Son ta’n Chiarn graysoil, ta e vyghin son dy-bragh: as ta’n firrinys echey farraghtyn veih sheeloghe gys sheeloghe.

English: Misericordiam & iudicium. Psal. 101.
Manx: Psal. 101. Misericordiam & judicium.

English: My song shall bee of mercie and Judgement : unto thee, O Lord, will I sing.
Manx: 1 Bee m’arrane jeh myghin as briwnys: hoods, O Hiarn, goym arrane.

English: 2 O let me have understanding : in the way of godlines.
Manx: 2 O lhig dou tushtey y ve aym: ayns y raad dy chraueeaght.
lhig dou] 1819 lhig da

English: 3 When wilt thou come unto mee : I will walke in my house with a perfect heart.
Manx: 3 Tra hig oo hym: nee’m gimmeeaght ayns my hie lesh cree ynrick.
Tra hig oo hym] 1769, 1777 Tra nee oo my niartaghey

English: 4 I will take no wicked thing in hand; I hate the sinnes of unfaithfulnesse : there shall no such cleave unto me.
Manx: 4 Cha goym drogh chooish erbee ayns laue: ta dwoaie aym er ny peccaghyn dy neu‐firrinys: cha jean veg nyn lheid lhiantyn hym.

English: 5 A froward heart shal depart from me : I wil not know a wicked person.
Manx: 5 Bee cree camlaagagh er n’eiyrt ass m’enish: cha bee ainjys aym rish drogh phersoon.

English: 6 Who so privily slandereth his neighbour : him will I destroy.
Manx: 6 Quoi‐erbee ta cooyl-chassid e naboo: eshyn nee’m y stroie.

English: 7 Who so hath also a proud looke and high stomacke : I will not suffer him.
Manx: 7 Quoi‐erbee myrgeddin t’echey shilley mooaralagh as cree ard: cha surr‐ym eh.

English: 8 Mine eyes looke upon such as be faithfull in the land : that they may dwell with me.
Manx: 8 Ta my hooillyn jeeaghyn orroosyn ta ynrick ’sy cheer: dy vod ad cummal mârym.

English: such as be] 1662 such as are
9 Who so leadeth a godly life : he shal be my servant.
Manx: 9 Quoi‐erbee ta leeideil bea chrauee: eshyn vees my harvaant.

English: 10 There shall no deceitfull person dwell in my house : he that telleth lies shall not tary in my sight.
Manx: 10 Cha jean persoon erbee molteyragh cummal ayns my hie: cha surr‐ym breagerey dy ve ayns my hilley.

English: 11 I shall soone destroy all the ungodly that are in the land : that I may roote out all wicked doers from the Citie of the Lord.
Manx: 11 Stroie‐ym dy-leah ooilley’n vee‐chrauee ta ’sy cheer: dy voddym ooilley ny drogh‐yantee y astyrt ass ard‐valley’n Chiarn.

English: The xx. day.
Manx: The 20. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Domine exaudi. Psal. 102.
Manx: Psal. 102. Domine, exaudi.

English: Heare my prayer, O Lord : and let my crying come unto thee.
Manx: 1 Clasht rish my phadjer, O Hiarn: as lhig da my eam roshtyn hood.

English: 2 Hide not thy face from me in the time of my trouble : encline thine eares unto mee when I cal, O hear me, & that right soon.
Manx: 2 Ny follee dt’eddin voym ayns earish my heaghyn: cromm dty chleayshyn hym tra ta mee geamagh; O eaisht rhym, as shen dy feer leah.

English: thine eares] 1662 thine ear
3 For my dayes are consumed away like smoke : and my bones are burnt up as it were a firebrand.
Manx: 3 Son ta my laghyn er lheïe ersooyl myr jaagh: as ta my chraueyn chyrmit seose myr smaraag aile.

English: 4 My heart is smitten downe, and withered like grasse : so that I forget to eat my bread.
Manx: 4 Ta my chree er vailleil as fioghit goll‐rish faiyr: myr shen dy vel mee jarrood dy ee m’arran.

English: 5 For the voice of my groning : my bones wil scarse cleave to my flesh.
Manx: 5 Kyndagh rish coraa my accan: scoan nee my chraueyn lhiantyn gys m’eill.

English: 6 I am become like a Pelicane in the wildernesse : and like an Owle that is in the desert.
Manx: 6 Ta mee goll‐rish y pelican ’syn aasagh: as myr yn hullet ta goaill ayns yn aaynagh.
hullet] 1819 hullad

English: 7 I have watched, and am even as it were a sparrow : that sitteth alone upon the house top.
Manx: 7 Ta my chadley er gholl voym, as ta mee eer myr sparroo: ta soie ny‐lomarcan er mullagh thie.

English: 8 Mine enemies revile me all the day long : and they that are mad upon me, are sworne together against me.
Manx: 8 Ta my noidyn dy m’oltooaney fey‐ny‐laa: as adsyn ta eulyssagh m’oï, t’ad er vreearrey cooidjagh dy my stroie.

English: 9 For I have eaten ashes as it were bread : and mingled my drinke with weeping;
Manx: 9 Son ta mee er n’ee leoie myr arran: as er heiy my yough lesh jeïr;

English: 10 And that because of thine indignation and wrath : for thou hast taken me up, and cast me downe.
Manx: 10 As shen er coontey dty yymmoose as dty chorree: son t’ow er my hroggal seose, as er my hilgey sheese.

English: 11 My dayes are gone like a shadow : and I am withered like grasse.
Manx: 11 Ta my laghyn er n’gholl shiaghey myr scaa: as ta mee fioghit myr faiyr.

English: 12 But thou (O Lord) shalt endure for ever : and thy remembrance throughout all generations.
Manx: 12 Agh nee uss, O Hiarn, farraghtyn son dy-bragh: as yn chooinaghtyn jeed trooid dy-chooilley heeloghe.

English: 13 Thou shalt arise and have mercy upon Sion : for it is time that thou have mercy upon her, yea, the time is come.
Manx: 13 Nee oo girree as bee chymmey ayd er Sion: son te traa dy beagh myghin ayd urree, dy-jarroo, ta’n traa er jeet.

English: 14 And why? thy servants thinke upon her stones: and it pitieth them to see her in the dust.
Manx: 14 As cre’n‐oyr? ta dty harvaantyn smooinaghtyn er ny voallaghyn eck: as s’treih lhieu dy akin ee ’sy joan.
lhieu] 1765, 1769, 1777 lhien

English: 15 The heathen shall feare thy Name, O Lord : and all the Kings of the earth thy Majestie;
Manx: 15 Nee ny ashoonyn aggle y ghoaill roish dt’ Ennym, O Hiarn: as ooilley reeaghyn y theihll roish dt’ Ard‐ooashley;

English: 16 When the Lord shall builde up Sion : and when his glory shall appeare;
Manx: 16 Tra nee yn Chiarn Sion y hroggal seose: as tra vees y ghloyr echey er ny hoilshaghey;

English: 17 When hee turneth him unto the prayer of the poore destitute : and despiseth not their desire.
Manx: 17 Tra t’eh dy hyndaa eh hene gys padjer ny boghtyn treigit: as nagh vel eh soiaghey beg jeh nyn aghin.

English: 18 This shal be written for those that come after: and the people which shal be borne shall praise the Lord.
Manx: 18 Bee shoh er ny scrieu son cooinaghtyn da sheelogheyn ry heet: as nee pobble nagh vel foast er ny ruggey yn Chiarn y voylley;

English: 19 For hee hath looked downe from his Sanctuarie : out of the heaven did the Lord behold the earth;
Manx: 19 Son t’eh er yeeaghyn neose veih ynnyd e chasherickys: magh ass niau hug y Chiarn yn seihll my‐ner;

English: 20 That hee might heare the mournings of such as be in captivitie : and deliver the children appointed unto death;
Manx: 20 Dy voddagh eh dobberan nyn lheid as ta ayns cappeeys y chlashtyn: as y chloan y livrey t’er nyn gheyrey gys baase;

English: such as be] 1662 such as are
21 That they may declare the Name of the Lord in Sion : and his worship at Hierusalem;
Manx: 21 Dy voddagh ad Ennym y Chiarn y hoilshaghey ayns Sion: as e ooashley ec Jerusalem;

English: 22 When the people are gathered together : and the kingdomes also, to serve the Lord.
Manx: 22 Tra ta’n pobble er nyn jaglym cooidjagh: as ny reeriaghtyn myrgeddin dy hirveish y Chiarn.

English: 23 Hee brought downe my strength in my journey: and shortened my dayes.
Manx: 23 Ghow eh ersooyl my niart er my yurnah: as ren eh my laghyn giare.

English: 24 But I said, O my God, take me not away in the middest of mine age : as for thy yeeres, they endure throughout all generations.
Manx: 24 Agh dooyrt mee, O my Yee, ny gow mee ersooyl ayns mean m’eash: er son dty vleeantyn’s t’ad farraghtyn trooid dy-chooilley heeloghe.

English: 25 Thou Lord in the beginning hast layd the foundation of the earth : and the heavens are the worke of thy hands.
Manx: 25 T’ow uss, Hiarn, ayns y toshiaght er hoiaghey undin y thallooin: as ta ny niaughyn obbyr dty laueyn;

English: 26 They shall perish, but thou shalt endure : they all shall waxe old as doeth a garment;
Manx: 26 Hed adsyn naardey, agh bee uss er-mayrn: aasee ad ooilley shenn myr garmad;

English: 27 And as a vesture shalt thou change them, & they shal be changed : but thou art the same, and thy yeeres shall not faile.
Manx: 27 As myr coamrey nee oo ad y chaghlaa, as bee ad er nyn gaghlaa: agh uss yn Jee cheddin, as cha jean dty vleeantyn’s failleil.

English: 28 The children of thy servants shall continue : and their seed shall stand fast in thy sight.
Manx: 28 Nee cloan dty harvaantyn tannaghtyn: as shassee yn sluight oc shickyr ayns dty hilley.

English: Benedic anima. Psal. 103.
Manx: Psal. 103. Benedic anima mea.

English: Praise the Lord, O my soule : and all that is within mee, praise his holy Name.
Manx: 1 Bannee yn Chiarn, O m’annym: as ooilley ny ta cheu‐sthie jee’m bannee e Ennym casherick.

English: 2 Praise the Lord, O my soule : and forget not all his benefits;
Manx: 2 Bannee yn Chiarn, O m’annym: as ny jarrood ooilley e hoyrtyssyn;

English: 3 Which forgiveth all thy sinne : and healeth all thine infirmities;
Manx: 3 Ta leih ooilley dty pheccah: as slaanaghey ooilley dty ghoghanyn;

English: Which] 1662 Who
4 Which saveth thy life from destruction : and crowneth thee with mercie and loving kindnesse;
Manx: 4 Ta sauail dty vioys veih toyrt‐mow: as dy dty chomm’rey lesh myghin as kenjallys‐ghraihagh;

English: Which] 1662 Who
5 Which satisfieth thy mouth with good things : making thee young and lustie as an Eagle.
Manx: 5 Ta jannoo magh dty veeall lesh nheeghyn mie: jannoo oo aeg as lajer myr urley.

English: Which] 1662 Who
6 The Lord executeth righteousnesse and Judgement : for all them that are oppressed with wrong.
Manx: 6 Ta’n Chiarn cooilleeney cairys as briwnys: er nyn son ocsyn ooilley ta tranlaasit lesh aggair.

English: 7 Hee shewed his wayes unto Moses : his workes unto the children of Israel.
Manx: 7 Hoilshee eh e raaidyn da Moses: e obbraghyn da cloan Israel.

English: 8 The Lord is full of compassion and mercy : long suffering and of great goodnesse.
Manx: 8 Ta’n Chiarn laane dy hymmey as dy vyghin: surranse‐foddey, as jeh mieys vooar.

English: 9 He will not alway be chiding : neither keepeth hee his anger for ever.
Manx: 9 Cha bee eh kinjagh corree: cha-moo t’eh freayll e yymmoose son dy-bragh.

English: 10 He hath not dealt with us after our sinnes : nor rewarded us according to our wickednesse.
Manx: 10 Cha vel eh er ghellal rooin lurg nyn beccaghyn: ny er chooilleeney shin cordail rish nyn mee‐chraueeaght;

English: wickednesse] 1662 wickednesses
11 For looke how high the heaven is in comparison of the earth : so great is his mercy also toward them that feare him.
Manx: 11 Son jeeagh cre cha ard as ta niau ayns co‐soyllaghey jeh’n thalloo: wheesh cheddin ta e vyghin dauesyn ta goaill aggle roïsh.

English: 12 Looke how wide also the East is from the West : so farre hath he set our sinnes from us.
Manx: 12 Jeeagh cre cha lhean as ta’n shar veih’n sheear: choud cheddin t’eh er hoiaghey nyn beccaghyn voïn.

English: 13 Yea, like as a father pitieth his owne children : even so is the Lord mercifull unto them that feare him.
Manx: 13 Dy-jarroo, myr ta chymmey ec ayr er e chloan hene: myr shen ta’n Chiarn myghinagh dauesyn ta goaill aggle roïsh.

English: 14 For he knoweth whereof we be made : he remembereth that we are but dust.
Manx: 14 Son shione da cre jeh ta shin jeant: t’eh cooinaghtyn nagh vel shin agh joan.

English: be made] 1662 are made
15 The dayes of man are but as grasse : for he flourisheth as a flower of the field.
Manx: 15 Cha vel laghyn dooinney agh myr faiyr: son t’eh gaase myr blaa yn vagher.

English: 16 For assoone as the winde goeth over it, it is gone: and the place thereof shall know it no more.
Manx: 16 Son cha leah as ta’n gheay goll harrish, te ersooyl: as cha der yn ynnyd ve ayn enney er ny sodjey.

English: 17 But the mercifull goodnesse of the Lord endureth for ever and ever, upon them that feare him: and his righteousnesse upon childrens children;
Manx: 17 Agh ta mieys myghinagh y Chiarn farraghtyn son dy-bragh as dy-bragh orroosyn ta goaill aggle roïsh: as e chairys er cloan chlienney;
chlienney ] 1765, 1769 chlenney

English: 18 Even upon such as keepe his Covenant : and thinke upon his Commandements to doe them.
Manx: 18 Orroosyn dy-jarroo ta freayll e chonaant: as ta smooinaghtyn er e annaghyn dy yannoo ad.

English: 19 The Lord hath prepared his seate in heaven : and his kingdome ruleth over all.
Manx: 19 Ta’n Chiarn er hoiaghey seose e stoyl-reeoil ayns niau: as ta e reeriaght reill harrish ooilley.

English: 20 O praise the Lord, ye Angels of his, yee that excell in strength : yee that fulfill his Commandement, and hearken unto the voyce of his words.
Manx: 20 O bannee‐jee yn Chiarn, shiuish e ainleyn, shiuish ta pooaral ayns niart: shiuish ta cooilleeney e haarey, as ta geaishtagh rish coraa e ghoan.

English: 21 O praise the Lord all ye his hostes : yee servants of his that doe his pleasure.
Manx: 21 O bannee‐jee yn Chiarn, ooilley shiuish e heshaght-flaunys: shiuish e harvaantyn ta cooilleeney e aigney.

English: 22 O speake good of the Lord all ye workes of his, in all places of his dominion : Praise thou the Lord, O my soule.
Manx: 22 O loayr‐jee dy-mie jeh’n Chiarn, ooilley shiuish e obbraghyn, ayns dy-chooilley ynnyd jeh e reilltys: bannee yn Chiarn, O m’annym.

English: The xx. day.
Manx: The 20. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Benedic anima mea. Psal.104.
Manx: Psal. 104. Benedic, anima mea.

English: Praise the Lord, O my soule : O Lord my God, thou art become exceeding glorious; thou art clothed with Majestie and honour.
Manx: 1 Bannee yn Chiarn, O m’annym: O Hiarn my Yee, t’ow er-skyn towse gloyroil, t’ow er ny choamrey lesh Ard‐ooashley as onnor.

English: 2 Thou deckest thy selfe with light as it were with a garment : and spreadest out the heavens like a curtaine.
Manx: 2 T’ow dy choamrey oo hene lesh soilshey myr lesh garmad: as skeayley magh ny niaughyn myr curtan;

English: 3 Which layeth the beames of his chamber in the waters : and maketh the cloudes his charet, and walketh upon the wings of the winde.
Manx: 3 Ta soiaghey beamyn e hiamyryn ayns ny hushtaghyn: as jannoo ny bodjallyn e ainagh, as goll er skainyn ny geayee.

English: Which] 1662 Who; chamber, 1599, 1636] 1660, 1662 chambers
4 He maketh his Angels spirits : and his ministers a flaming fire.
Manx: 4 T’eh jannoo e ainleyn spyrrydyn [ny geayghyn]: as e hirveishee lossey dy aile.

English: 5 Hee layde the foundations of the earth : that it never should moove at any time.
Manx: 5 T’eh er hoiaghey undinyn y thallooin: nagh bee eh ec traa erbee er ny scughey.

English: 6 Thou coveredst it with the deepe like as with a garment : the waters stand in the hilles.
Manx: 6 Choodee oo eh lesh y diunid myr lesh garmad: ta ny hushtaghyn lhie ayns ny croink.

English: 7 At thy rebuke they flee : at the voyce of thy thunder they are afraid.
Manx: 7 Ec yn oghsan ayds t’ad chea ersooyl: ec coraa dty haarnagh ta aggle orroo.

English: 8 They goe up as high as the hilles, and downe to the valleys beneath : even unto the place which thou hast appointed for them.
