Manx: 8 T’ad goll seose cha ard as ny croink, as sheese gys ny coanyn: eer gys yn ynnyd t’ow er phointeil daue.

English: 9 Thou hast set them their bounds which they shall not passe : neither turne againe to cover the earth.
Manx: 9 T’ow er hoiaghey ny cagliaghyn oc nagh jed ad harrish: ny chyndaa reesht dy choodaghey yn thalloo.

English: 10 He sendeth the springs into the rivers : which runne among the hilles.
Manx: 10 T’eh cur ny geillyn gys ny awinyn: ta roih mastey ny croink.

English: 11 All beasts of the field drinke thereof : and the wilde asses quench their thirst.
Manx: 11 Ta ooilley beïyn y vagher giu jeu: as ta ny assyllyn feïe cuir nyn baa.

English: 12 Besides them shall the foules of the aire have their habitation : and sing among the branches.
Manx: 12 Lioroo vees nyn gummal ec eeanlee’n aer: as nee ad bingys mastey ny banglaneyn.

English: Besides, 1636] 1599, 1660 Beside
13 Hee watereth the hilles from above : the earth is filled with the fruit of thy workes.
Manx: 13 T’eh gushtaghey ny croink veih yn yrjid: ta’n seihll er ny lhieeney lesh mess dt’obbraghyn.

English: 14 Hee bringeth foorth grasse for the cattell : and greene herbe for the service of men;
Manx: 14 T’eh cur magh faiyr son y maase: as lhuss glass son ymmyd dooinney;
lhuss glass] 1769, 1777 messyn y vagheragh

English: 15 That hee may bring food out of the earth, & wine that maketh glad the heart of man : and oile to make him a cheerefull countenance, and bread to strengthen mans heart.
Manx: 15 Dy vod eh beaghey y chur lesh magh ass y thalloo, as feeyn ta gerjaghey cree dooinney: as ooïll dy chur da eddin ghennal, as arran dy niartaghey cree dooinney.

English: 16 The trees of the Lord also are full of sap : even the Cedars of Libanus, which he hath planted;
Manx: 16 Ta biljyn y Chiarn myrgeddin laane dy hoo: dy-jarroo cedaryn Libanus t’eshyn er hoiaghey;

English: 17 Wherein the birdes make their nestes : and the Firre-trees are a dwelling for the Storke.
Manx: 17 Ayndoo ta ny eeanlee jannoo nyn idd: as ta ny biljyn-juys ynnyd‐cummal son y stork.

English: 18 The high hilles are a refuge for the wilde goates : and so are the stony rockes for the conies.
Manx: 18 Ta ny croink ard oayll son ny goair feïe: as myr shen ta ny creggyn son ny conninyn.

English: 19 He appointed the Moone for certaine seasons : and the Sunne knoweth his going downe.
Manx: 19 Ren eh yn eayst y phointeil son imbaghyn shickyr: as shione da’n ghrian yn traa dy lhie.

English: 20 Thou makest darknesse that it may be night : wherein al the beasts of the Forest do moove.
Manx: 20 T’ow jannoo dorraghys dy chur stiagh yn oie: ayn ta ooilley beïyn y cheyll rowail mygeayrt.

English: 21 The Lions roaring after their praye : doe seeke their meat at God.
Manx: 21 Ta ny lionyn garveagagh son nyn spooilley: shirrey nyn meaghey veih Jee.

English: at God] 1662 from God
22 The Sunne ariseth, and they get them away together : and lay them downe in their dennes.
Manx: 22 Ta’n ghrian girree, as t’ad cosney rhymboo cooidjagh: as lhie sheese ayns nyn ooigyn.

English: 23 Man goeth foorth to his worke, and to his labour : untill the evening.
Manx: 23 Ta dooinney goll magh gys e obbyr, as gys e laboraght: derrey’n astyr.

English: 24 O Lord, how manifolde are thy workes : in wisdome hast thou made them all; the earth is full of thy riches.
Manx: 24 O Hiarn, cre cha ymmodee ta dt’obbraghyn: ayns creenaght t’ow er n’yannoo ad ooilley, ta’n seihll laane jeh dty verchys!

English: 25 So is the great and wide sea also : wherein are things creeping innumerable, both small and great beasts.
Manx: 25 Myr shen ta’n faarkey mooar as feayn myrgeddin: ayn ta cretooryn snaauee gyn earroo, beishtyn chammah beg as mooar.
feayn] 1765, 1769 faayn

English: 26 There goe the shippes, and there is that Leviathan: whom thou hast made to take his pastime therein.
Manx: 26 Shen y raad ta ny lhongyn shiauley, as ayns shen ta’n Leviathan: t’ow uss er n’yannoo dy ghoaill yn reamys echey ayn.

English: 27 These wait all upon thee : that thou mayest give them meate in due season.
Manx: 27 T’ad shoh ooilley farkiaght ort: dy vod oo beaghey y chur daue ayns imbagh cooie.

English: 28 When thou givest it them they gather it : & when thou openest thy hand they are filled with good.
Manx: 28 Tra t’ow dy chur daue eh, t’ad dy hagglym eh: as tra t’ow fosley dty laue, t’ad jeant magh lesh mie.

English: 29 When thou hidest thy face, they are troubled : when thou takest away their breath, they die, and are turned againe to their dust.
Manx: 29 Tra t’ow follaghey dt’eddin, t’ad seaghnit: tra t’ow goaill ersooyl yn ennal oc, t’ad geddyn baase, as t’ad chyndaait reesht gys nyn ooir;

English: 30 When thou lettest thy breath goe foorth they shall bee made : and thou shalt renue the face of the earth.
Manx: 30 Tra t’ow lhiggey magh dt’ennal, bee ad er nyn groo: as t’ow cur eddin noa da eaghtyr y thallooin.

English: 31 The glorious Majestie of the Lord shall endure for ever : the Lord shall rejoyce in his workes.
Manx: 31 Nee Ard‐ooashley gloyroil y Chiarn farraghtyn son dy-bragh: nee yn Chiarn boggey ’ghoaill ayns e obbraghyn.

English: 32 The earth shal tremble at the looke of him : if he do but touch the hilles, they shall smoke.
Manx: 32 Bee yn thalloo er‐creau ec e hilley: my nee eh agh bennaylt rish ny sleïtyn, bee ad ayns jaagh.
bennaylt] 1769, 1777 bentyn

English: 33 I will sing unto the Lord as long as I live : I will praise my God, while I have my being.
Manx: 33 Goym arrane da’n Chiarn choud as s’bio mee: nee’m my Yee y voylley choud as vee’m er-mayrn.

English: 34 And so shall my wordes please him : my joy shall bee in the Lord.
Manx: 34 As shen myr nee my ghoan eshyn y wooiys: bee my voggey ayns y Chiarn.

English: 35 As for sinners, they shall be consumed out of the earth, and the ungodly shall come to an ende : praise thou the Lord, O my soule, praise the Lord.
Manx: 35 Er son peccee, bee adsyn er nyn goyrt mow veih’n thalloo, as hig jerrey er ny mee‐chrauee: cur uss moylley da’n Chiarn, O m’annym, cur moylley da’n Chiarn.
goyrt] 1765, 1769 ghoyrt

English: The xxi. day.
Manx: The 21. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Confitemini Domino. Psal. 105.
Manx: Psal. 105. Confitemini Domino.

English: O give thankes unto the Lord, and call upon his Name : tell the people what things he hath done.
Manx: 1 O cur‐jee booise da’n Chiarn, as eïe‐jee er yn Ennym echey: insh‐jee da’n pobble cre ny reddyn t’eh er n’yannoo.

English: 2 O let your songs bee of him, and praise him : and let your talking bee of all his wonderous workes.
Manx: 2 O lhig da ny arraneyn eu ’ve jehsyn, as moylley‐jee eh: as lhig da’n taggloo eu ’ve mychione ooilley e obbraghyn yindyssagh.

English: 3 Rejoyce in his holy Name : let the heart of them rejoyce that seeke the Lord.
Manx: 3 Gow‐jee boggey ayns yn Ennym casherick echey: lhig da’n cree ocsyn ’ve gennal ta shirrey lurg y Chiarn.

English: 4 Seeke the Lord & his strength : seeke his face evermore.
Manx: 4 Shirr‐jee yn Chiarn as e niart: shirr‐jee e eddin er son dy-bragh.

English: 5 Remember the marveilous works that he hath done : his wonders, and the Judgements of his mouth,
Manx: 5 Cooinee‐jee er ny obbraghyn yindyssagh t’eh er n’yannoo: e virrillyn, as briwnyssyn e veeall;

English: 6 O ye seede of Abraham his servant : yee children of Jacob his chosen.
Manx: 6 O shiuish sluight Abraham e harvaant: shiuish chloan Yacob t’eh er reih.

English: 7 Hee is the Lord our God : his Judgements are in all the world.
Manx: 7 Eshyn y Chiarn y Jee ain: ta e vriwnyssyn ayns ooilley’n seihll.

English: 8 He hath bene alway mindfull of his Covenant and promise : that he made to a thousand generations;
Manx: 8 T’eh er ny ve kinjagh cooinaghtagh jeh e chonaant as e yialdinyn: ren eh da thousane dy heelogheyn;

English: 9 Even the Covenant that he made with Abraham: and the othe that he sware unto Isahac;
Manx: 9 Yn eer conaant ren eh rish Abraham: as y breearrey loo eh da Isaac;

English: Isahac] 1660 Isaac
10 And appointed the same unto Jacob for a Lawe : and to Israel for an everlasting Testament;
Manx: 10 As shen doardee eh da Jacob son leigh: as da Israel son conaant dy-bragh farraghtyn;

English: 11 Saying, Unto thee will I give the land of Chanaan : the lot of your inheritance;
Manx: 11 Gra, Dhyts ver‐ym thalloo Canaan: cronney nyn eiraght.

English: 12 When there were yet but a few of them : & they strangers in the land;
Manx: 12 Tra nagh row ad foast agh beggan jeu: as adsyn nyn yoarreeyn ayns y cheer;

English: 13 What time as they went from one nation to another : from one kingdome to another people;
Manx: 13 Tra v’ad scughey veih ashoon gys ashoon: veih un reeriaght gys pobble elley;

English: 14 Hee suffered no man to doe them wrong : but reproved even Kings for their sakes;
Manx: 14 Cha lhig eh da dooinney erbee aggair ’yannoo daue: agh hug eh oghsan da eer reeaghyn er y ghraih oc.

English: 15 Touch not mine Anointed : and doe my Prophets no harme.
Manx: 15 Ny benn‐jee rish my Er‐ooïllit: as ny jean‐jee veg y skielley da my adeyryn.

English: 16 Moreover, he called for a dearth upon the land : and destroyed all the provision of bread.
Manx: 16 Marish shen, doardee eh genney er y cheer: as stroie eh yn slane beaghey dy arran.

English: 17 But hee had sent a man before them : even Joseph which was sold to be a bond servant;
Manx: 17 Agh hug eshyn dooinney rhymboo: dy-jarroo Joseph, va er ny chreck son sharvaant ayns bondiaght;

English: which] 1662 who
18 Whose feete they hurt in the stocks : the yron entered into his soule;
Manx: 18 E chassyn ren ad y lhottey lesh geulaghyn: hie gooin y yiarn stiagh gys e chree;

English: 19 Untill the time came that his cause was knowen: the word of the Lord tried him.
Manx: 19 Derrey haink y traa dy row e chooish er ny hoilshaghey: ren goo yn Chiarn eshyn y phrowal.

English: 20 The King sent and delivered him : the Prince of the people let him goe free.
Manx: 20 Hug y ree chaghter dy eaysley eh: hug prince y phobble e reamys da.
chaghter] 1765 chagter

English: 21 He made him lord also of his house : and ruler of all his substance;
Manx: 21 Ren eh eh ny Hiarn myrgeddin harrish e hie: as kiannoort harrish ooilley e ream;

English: 22 That he might informe his princes after his wil : and teach his Senators wisedome.
Manx: 22 Dy oardrail e phrinsyn lurg e aigney: as creenaght y ynsaghey da e ir‐choyrlee.

English: 23 Israel also came into Egypt : and Jacob was a stranger in the land of Ham.
Manx: 23 Haink Israel myrgeddin gys Egypt: as va Jacob ny yoarree ayns cheer Ham.

English: 24 And hee increased his people exceedingly : and made them stronger then their enemies;
Manx: 24 As vishee eh yn pobble echey dy-yindyssagh: as ren eh ad ny s’troshey na nyn noidyn;

English: 25 Whose heart turned, so that they hated his people : and dealt untruely with his servants.
Manx: 25 Ny creeaghyn ocsyn va myr shen er ny hyndaa, dy row dwoaie oc er e phobble: as hug ad drogh ghellal da e harvaantyn.

English: 26 Then sent hee Moses his servant : and Aaron whom he had chosen.
Manx: 26 Eisht hug eshyn Moses e harvaant: as Aaron, v’eh er ny reih;

English: 27 And these shewed his tokens among them : and wonders in the land of Ham.
Manx: 27 As hoilshee ad shoh e chowraghyn ny mast’ oc: as yindyssyn ayns cheer Ham.

English: 28 He sent darknesse, and it was darke : and they were not obedient unto his word.
Manx: 28 Doardee eh dorraghys, as ve dorraghey: agh cha row ad arrymagh da e ghoo.

English: 29 He turned their waters into blood : and slue their fish.
Manx: 29 Hyndaa eh ny hushtaghyn oc gys fuill: as stroie eh yn eeast oc.

English: 30 Their land brought foorth frogs : yea, even in their Kings chambers.
Manx: 30 Ren y cheer oc gymmyrkey magh froggyn: ayns eer shamyryn nyn reeaghyn.

English: 31 Hee spake the word, and there came all manner of flies : and lice in all their quarters.
Manx: 31 Loayr eh yn fockle, as haink dy-chooilley cheint dy veishteigyn: as meeylyn ayns ooilley ny ardjyn oc.

English: 32 He gave them hailestones for raine : and flames of fire in their land.
Manx: 32 Hug eh daue claghyn‐sniaghtee ayns ynnyd fliaghey: as lossaghyn aile ayns y cheer oc.

English: 33 He smote their vines also and figtrees : and destroyed the trees that were in their coasts.
Manx: 33 Woaill eh neesht ny biljyn‐feeyney as ny biljyn‐figgagh oc: as hug eh naardey ny biljyn v’ayns ny ardjyn oc.

English: 34 He spake the word, and the grashoppers came, and caterpillers innumerable : and did eate up all the grasse in their land, and devoured the fruit of their ground.
Manx: 34 Loayr eh yn fockle, as haink ny locustyn, as praddagyn er-skyn‐earroo: as die ad seose ooilley yn faiyr v’ayns y cheer oc, as stroie ad messyn y thallooin.

English: 35 He smote all the first borne in their land : even the chiefe of all their strength.
Manx: 35 Varr eh ooilley yn chied er ny ruggey ayns nyn jeer: dy-jarroo toshiaght ooilley nyn niart.

English: 36 He brought them forth also with silver and gold : there was not one feeble person among their tribes.
Manx: 36 Hug eh lesh ad magh myrgeddin lesh argid as airh: cha row un phersoon annoon mastey ny kynneeyn oc.

English: 37 Egypt was glad at their departing : for they were afraid of them.
Manx: 37 Va Egypt laane dy voggey tra jimmee ad rhymboo: son v’ad ayns aggle roue.

English: 38 Hee spread out a cloud to be a covering : and fire to give light in the night season.
Manx: 38 Skeayll eh magh bodjal dy choodaghey ad: as aile dy chur soilshey daue ’syn oie.

English: 39 At their desire he brought quailes : and hee filled them with the bread of heaven.
Manx: 39 Ec nyn yeearree hug eh lesh quaylyn: as lhieen eh ad lesh arran veih niau.

English: 40 Hee opened the rocke of stone, and the waters flowed out : so that Rivers ranne in the dry places.
Manx: 40 Doshil eh yn chreg chloaie, as haink yn ushtey magh myr thooilley: myr shen dy roih awinyn ayns ynnydyn chyrmey.

English: 41 For why? he remembred his holy Promise : and Abraham his servant.
Manx: 41 Son cre’n‐oyr? chooinee eh er e yialdyn casherick: as er Abraham e harvaant.

English: 42 And he brought forth his people with joy : and his chosen with gladnesse;
Manx: 42 As hug eh lesh magh e phobble lesh boggey: as e chloan reiht lesh gennallys;
e chloan] 1765, 1769, 1777 eh chloan

English: 43 And gave them the landes of the Heathen : and they tooke the labours of the people in possession;
Manx: 43 As hug eh daue thalloo ny ashoonyn: as ghow ad laboraght y phobble son eiraght:

English: 44 That they might keep his statutes : & observe his laws.
Manx: 44 Dy voddagh ad freayll e ’lattyssyn: as geill y choyrt da e leighyn.

English: The xxi. day.
Manx: The 21. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Confitemini Domino. Psal. 106.
Manx: Psal. 106. Confitemini Domino.

English: O give thankes unto the Lord, for he is gracious : and his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 1 O cur‐jee booise da’n Chiarn, son t’eh graysoil: as ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 2 Who can expresse the noble acts of the Lord : or shew foorth all his praise?
Manx: 2 Quoi oddys obbraghyn ooasle y Chiarn y ockley magh: ny ooilley e voylley y hoilshaghey?

English: 3 Blessed are they that alway keepe Judgement : and doe righteousnesse.
Manx: 3 Bannit t’adsyn ta kinjagh freayll briwnys: as jannoo cairys.

English: 4 Remember me, O Lord, according to the favour that thou bearest unto thy people : O visit me with thy salvation;
Manx: 4 Cooinee orrym, O Hiarn, cordail rish y foayr shen t’ow d’ymmyrkey gys dty phobble: O jeeagh orryms lesh dty haualtys.

English: 5 That I may see the felicitie of thy chosen : and rejoyce in the gladnesse of thy people, and give thankes with thine inheritance.
Manx: 5 Dy voddym fakin maynrys dty chloan reiht: as boggey ’ghoaill ayns gennallys dty phobble, as booise y choyrt marish dty eiraght.

English: 6 Wee have sinned with our fathers : wee have done amisse, and dealt wickedly.
Manx: 6 Ta shin er n’yannoo peccah marish nyn ayraghyn: ta shin er chur rish aggair, as er ghellal dy-holk.

English: 7 Our fathers regarded not thy wonders in Egypt, neither kept they thy great goodnesse in remembrance : but were disobedient at the Sea, even at the Red sea.
Manx: 7 Cha dug nyn ayraghyn tastey da dty yindyssyn ayns Egypt, cha-moo dreill ad dty vieys vooar ayns cooinaghtyn: agh v’ad mee-viallagh ec yn aarkey, dy-jarroo ec y faarkey Jiarg.

English: 8 Neverthelesse, he helped them for his Names sake : that he might make his power to be knowen.
Manx: 8 Ny‐yeih chooin eh lhieu er graih e Ennym: dy voddagh eh yn phooar echey y hoilshaghey.

English: 9 He rebuked the Red sea also, and it was dried up : so he led them through the deepe, as through a wildernesse.
Manx: 9 Hug eh saarey da’n aarkey Jiarg myrgeddin, as ve chyrmit seose: myr shen ren eh adsyn y leeideil trooid y diunid, myr trooid yn aasagh.

English: 10 And he saved them from the adversaries hand : and delivered them from the hand of the enemy.
Manx: 10 As haue eh ad veih laue ny tranlaasee: as livrey eh ad veih pooar y noid.

English: 11 As for those that troubled them, the waters overwhelmed them : there was not one of them left.
Manx: 11 As er son adsyn va chionney orroo, choodee ny hushtaghyn ad: cha row unnane oc faagit er‐mayrn.

English: 12 Then beleeved they his words : & sang praise unto him.
Manx: 12 Eisht chred adsyn e ghoan: as ghow ad arraneyn‐moyllee huggeysyn.

English: 13 But within a while they forgat his works : and would not abide his counsell.
Manx: 13 Agh ayns gerrit dy hraa yarrood ad ny obbraghyn echey: as cha jinnagh ad ad hene y injillaghey gys e choyrle.

English: 14 But lust came upon them in the wildernesse : and they tempted God in the desert.
Manx: 14 Agh hug ad raad da yeearreeyn mee-reilltagh ayns yn aasagh: as ayns cheer gyn ushtey ren ad Jee y vrasnaghey.

English: 15 And he gave them their desire : and sent leannesse withall into their soule.
Manx: 15 As hug eh daue nyn yeearree: as lesh shoh shangid ayns nyn anmeenyn.

English: 16 They angered Moses also in the tents : and Aaron the Saint of the Lord.
Manx: 16 Hug ad corree er Moses neesht ayns ny cabbaneyn: as er Aaron noo yn Chiarn.

English: 17 So the earth opened, and swallowed up Dathan : and covered the congregation of Abiram.
Manx: 17 Myr shen doshil y thalloo, as slug eh seose Dathan: as choodee eh sheshaght Abiram.

English: 18 And the fire was kindled in their company : the flame burnt up the ungodly.
Manx: 18 As ren aile brishey magh mastey’n cheshaght oc: as ren y lossey stroie ny mee‐chrauee.

English: 19 They made a calfe in Horeb : and worshipped the molten image.
Manx: 19 Ren ad cummey lheiy ayns Horeb: as hug ad ooashley da’n jalloo lheït.
lheiy] 1769, 1777 dow

English: 20 Thus they turned their glory : into the similitude of a calfe that eateth hay.
Manx: 20 Myr shoh chaghlaa ad nyn ghloyr: gys co‐chaslys lheiy ta gee faiyr;
lheiy] 1769 beagh, 1777 baagh

English: 21 And they forgat God their Saviour : which had done so great things in Egypt;
Manx: 21 As yarrood ad Jee yn Saualtagh oc: v’er n’yannoo lheid ny reddyn mooarey ayns Egypt;

English: which] 1662 who
22 Wonderous works in the land of Ham : and fearefull things by the Red sea.
Manx: 22 Obbraghyn yindyssagh ayns cheer Ham: as reddyn atchimagh ec y faarkey Jiarg.

English: 23 So he said he would have destroyed them, had not Moses his chosen stand before him in the gap : to turne away his wrathfull indignation, lest he should destroy them.
Manx: 23 Er shoh dooyrt eh, dy jinnagh eh ad y stroie, er‐be dy hass Moses e harvaant reiht kiongoyrt rish ayns y vrishey-magh: dy hyndaa ersooyl e yymmoose hrome, nagh jinnagh eh ad y stroie.

English: stand, 1599] 1636, 1660 stood
24 Yea, they thought scorne of that pleasant land : and gave no credence unto his word;
Manx: 24 Dy-jarroo cha ren ad scansh jeh’n cheer eunyssagh shen: cha-moo ren ad credjal ny goan echey;
ny goan echey] 1769, 1777 e ghoan

English: 25 But murmured in their tents : and hearkened not unto the voyce of the Lord.
Manx: 25 Agh dirree ad magh ayns ny cabbaneyn oc: as cha ren ad geaishtagh gys coraa’n Chiarn.
gys] 1777 rish

English: 26 Then lift he up his hand against them : to overthrow them in the wildernesse;
Manx: 26 Eisht hrogg eh seose e laue nyn ’oï: dy chur ad naardey ayns yn aasagh;

English: 27 To cast out their seede among the Nations : and to scatter them in the lands.
Manx: 27 Dy hilgey magh yn sluight oc mastey ny ashoonyn: as dy skeayley ad trooid ny cheeraghyn.

English: 28 They joyned themselves unto Baal-Peor : and ate the offerings of the dead.
Manx: 28 Ren ad lhiantyn gys Baal‐peor: as die ad ourallyn ny merriu.

English: 29 Thus they provoked him to anger with their owne inventions : and the plague was great among them.
Manx: 29 Myr shoh ghreinnee ad eh gys corree lesh nyn ghrogh obbraghyn: as va’n chramp dewil nyn mast’ oc.

English: 30 Then stood up Phinees & praied : & so the plague ceased.
Manx: 30 Eisht hass Phinehas seose as ghow eh padjer: as myr shen scuirr y chramp.

English: 31 And that was counted unto him for righteousnesse : among all posterities for evermore.
Manx: 31 As va shen coontit dasyn son cairys: mastey dy-chooilley heeloghe er son dy-bragh.

English: 32 They angred him also at the waters of strife : so that he punished Moses for their sakes;
Manx: 32 Hug ad corree er myrgeddin ec ushtaghyn y streeu: myr shen dy ren eh Moses y cherraghey kyndagh roosyn.

English: 33 Because they provoked his spirit : so that hee spake unadvisedly with his lips.
Manx: 33 Er‐yn‐oyr dy ren ad yn spyrryd echey y vrasnaghey: ayns wheesh as dy loayr eh dy-siyragh lesh e veillyn.

English: 34 Neither destroyed they the heathen : as the Lord commanded them;
Manx: 34 Cha-moo stroie ad ny ashoonyn: myr ren y Chiarn ad y haarey.

English: 35 But were mingled among the heathen : and learned their workes.
Manx: 35 Agh ren ad sheshaght rish ny ashoonyn: as dynsee ad nyn gliaghtaghyn.

English: 36 In so much that they worshipped their idoles, which turned to their owne decay : yea, they offered their sonnes and their daughters unto devils;
Manx: 36 Ayns wheesh as dy dug ad ooashley da ny jallooyn oc, shoh ren chyndaa gys y toyrt‐mow oc hene: dy-jarroo, hebb ad ny mec as ny inneenyn oc gys jouyil;

English: 37 And shed innocent blood, even the blood of their sonnes and of their daughters : whom they offered unto the idoles of Chanaan; and the land was defiled with blood.
Manx: 37 As gheayrt ad yn uill gyn loght; dy-jarroo fuill ny mec as ny inneenyn oc: hebb ad ayns ourallyn gys jallooyn Canaan; as va’n cheer fo mollaght lesh fuill.

English: 38 Thus were they stained with their owne works: and went a whoring with their owne inventions.
Manx: 38 Myr shoh v’ad fo broïd lesh ny obbraghyn oc hene: as hie ad er maarderys lurg nyn yeearreeyn hene.
fo broïd] 1769, 1777 neu‐ghlen

English: 39 Therefore was the wrath of the Lord kindled against his people : insomuch that he abhorred his owne inheritance.
Manx: 39 Shen-y-fa va jymmoose y Chiarn er ny vrasnaghey noi e phobble: ayns wheesh as dy row dwoaie echey er e eiraght hene,

English: 40 And he gave them over into the hand of the heathen : and they that hated them were lords over them.
Manx: 40 As livrey eh ad harrish gys laue ny ashoonyn: as v’adsyn va dwoaie oc orroo ny hiarnyn harrystoo.

English: 41 Their enemies oppressed them : & had them in subjection.
Manx: 41 Ren nyn noidyn tranlaase orroo: as v’ad fo nyn booar.

English: 42 Many a time did he deliver them : but they rebelled against him with their owne inventions, and were brought downe in their wickednesse.
Manx: 42 Shimmey keayrt ren eh ad y livrey: agh dirree ad magh ny oï lesh nyn goyrlyn hene, as v’ad er nyn injillaghey son nyn olkys.
ny oï] 1819 noï

English: 43 Neverthelesse, when he saw their adversitie : he heard their complaint.
Manx: 43 Ny‐yeih tra honnick eh nyn seaghyn: ren eh nyn accan y chlashtyn.

English: 44 Hee thought upon his Covenant, and pitied them according unto the multitude of his mercies : yea, hee made all those that led them away captive to pitie them.
Manx: 44 Chooinee eh er e chonaant, as va chymmey echey orroo, cordail rish earroo e vyghinyn: hug eh dy-jarroo orroosyn ooilley va leeideil ad ersooyl ayns cappeeys dy ve erreeishagh daue.

English: 45 Deliver us (O Lord our God) and gather us from among the heathen : that we may give thankes unto thy holy Name, and make our boast of thy praise.
Manx: 45 Livrey uss shinyn, O Hiarn nyn Yee, as chaggil shin veih mastey ny ashoonyn: dy vod mayd booise y chur da dty Ennym casherick, as imraa gloyroil y yannoo jeh dty voylley.

English: 46 Blessed be the Lord God of Israel from everlasting and world without end : and let all the people say, Amen.
Manx: 46 Bannit dy row yn Chiarn Jee d’ Israel veih dy-bragh, as seihll gyn jerrey: as lhig da ooilley’n pobble gra, Amen.

English: The xxii. day.
Manx: The 22.day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Confitemini Domino. Psal. 107.
Manx: Psal. 107. Confitemini Domino.

English: O give thankes unto the Lord, for hee is gracious : and his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 1 O cur-jee booise da’n Chiarn, son t’eh graysoil: as ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 2 Let them give thankes whom the Lord hath redeemed : and delivered from the hand of the enemie;
Manx: 2 Lhig dauesyn booise y choyrt ta’n Chiarn er nyn veaysley: as er nyn livrey veih laue yn noid;
er nyn veaysley] 1769, 1777 er veaysley; er nyn livrey] 1769, 1777 er livrey

English: 3 And gathered them out of the lands, from the East & from the West : from the North and from the South.
Manx: 3 As er nyn jaglym ass ny cheeraghyn, veih’n niar, as veih’n neear: veih’n tooaie, as veih’n jiass.

English: 4 They went astray in the wildernesse out of the way : and found no Citie to dwell in;
Manx: 4 Hie ad er‐shaghryn ayns yn aasagh ass y raad: as cha dooar ad ard‐valley erbee dy chummal ayn;

English: 5 Hungrie and thirstie : their soule fainted in them.
Manx: 5 Accryssagh as pa-agh: hug yn annym oc naardey ayndoo.

English: 6 So they cried unto the Lord in their trouble : and hee delivered them from their distresse.
Manx: 6 Eisht deïe ad er y Chiarn ayns nyn seaghyn: as livrey eh ad ass nyn jennid.

English: 7 Hee led them forth by the right way : that they might goe to the Citie where they dwelt.
Manx: 7 Leeid eh ad magh er y raad cair: dy voddagh ad goll gys ard‐valley dy ooraghey ad hene.
dy ooraghey ad hene] 1769, 1777 va kiarit daue

English: 8 O that men would therefore praise the Lord for his goodnes : and declare the wonders that hee doth for the children of men.
Manx: 8 O dy jinnagh deiney er‐y‐fa shen yn Chiarn y voylley son e vieys: as fockley magh ny yindyssyn t’eh dy yannoo son cloan gheiney!

English: 9 For hee satisfieth the emptie soule : and filleth the hungry soule with goodnes.
Manx: 9 Son t’eh jannoo magh yn annym follym: as lhieeney yn annym accryssagh lesh mieys;

English: 10 Such as sit in darkenes, and in the shadow of death : being fast bound in miserie and yron;
Manx: 10 Lheid as ta ny hoie ayns dorraghys, as ayns scadoo yn vaaish: kainlt dy-shickyr ayns geulaghyn yiarn.
dy-shickyr] 1777 ayns treihys

English: 11 Because they rebelled against the wordes of the Lord : and lightly regarded the counsaile of the most High;
Manx: 11 Er‐yn‐oyr dy row ad mee‐viallagh gys goan y Chiarn: as ren ad beg y hoiaghey jeh coyrle yn Er syrjey;

English: most High] 1662 most highest
12 He also brought downe their heart through heavines : they fell downe, and there was none to helpe them up.
Manx: 12 Ren eh neesht ny creeaghyn oc y injillaghey trooid seaghyn: huitt ad sheese, as cha row unnane erbee dy chooney lhieu.

English: helpe them up.] 1662 help them.
13 So when they cried unto the Lord in their trouble : he delivered them out of their distresse.
Manx: 13 Myr shen tra deïe ad gys y Chiarn ayns nyn seaghyn: livrey eh ad ass nyn jennid.

English: 14 For he brought them out of darkenesse, and out of the shadow of death : and brake their bonds in sunder.
Manx: 14 Hug eh lesh ad magh ass dorraghys, as scadoo yn vaaish: as vrish eh ny kianglaghyn oc veih my‐chielley.

English: 15 O that men would therefore praise the Lord for his goodnesse : and declare the wonders that he doth for the children of men!
Manx: 15 O dy jinnagh deiney er‐y‐fa shen yn Chiarn y voylley son e vieys: as fockley magh ny yindyssyn t’eh dy yannoo son cloan gheiney!

English: 16 For he hath broken the gates of brasse : and smitten the barres of yron in sunder.
Manx: 16 Son t’eh er vrishey ny giattyn-prash: as er yiarey ny barryn yiarn veih my‐chielley.

English: 17 Foolish men are plagued for their offence : and because of their wickednesse.
Manx: 17 Ta deiney ommijagh er nyn gerraghey son nyn ghrogh‐yannoo: as kyndagh rish nyn olkys.
gerraghey] 1765, 1769 gherraghey

English: 18 Their soule abhorred all manner of meate : and they were even hard at deaths doore.
Manx: 18 Va dwoaie ec yn annym oc er dy-chooilley cheint dy veaghey: as v’ad dy-jarroo faggys ec dorrys y vaaish.

English: 19 So when they cried unto the Lord in their trouble : he delivered them out of their distresse.
Manx: 19 Myr shen tra deïe ad gys y Chiarn ayns nyn seaghyn: livrey eh ad ass nyn jennid.

English: 20 He sent his word and healed them : and they were saved from their destruction.
Manx: 20 Chur eh magh e ockle, as ren eh ad y lheihys: as v’ad er ny sauail veih nyn doyrt‐mow.
er ny sauail] 1777 er nyn sauail

English: 21 O that men would therefore praise the Lord for his goodnesse : and declare the wonders that he doth for the children of men.
Manx: 21 O dy jinnagh deiney er‐y‐fa shen yn Chiarn y voylley son e vieys: as fockley magh ny yindyssyn t’eh dy yannoo son cloan gheiney!

English: 22 That they would offer unto him the sacrifice of thanksgiving : and tell out his workes with gladnesse.
Manx: 22 Dy jebbagh ad da oural dy hoyrt‐booise: as ny obbraghyn echey y ockley magh lesh gennallys.

English: 23 They that go downe to the sea in ships : and occupie their businesse in great waters;
Manx: 23 Adsyn ta goll er yn aarkey ayns lhongyn: as ta dellal ayns ny hushtaghyn mooarey,

English: 24 These men see the workes of the Lord : and his wonders in the deepe.
Manx: 24 Ad shoh ta fakin obbraghyn y Chiarn: as e yindyssyn ayns y diunid.

English: 25 For at his word the stormie winde ariseth : which lifteth up the waves thereof.
Manx: 25 Son ec e ockle ta’n gheay stermagh girree: ta troggal seose ny tonnyn echey.

English: 26 They are caried up to the heaven, and downe againe to the deepe : their soule melteth away because of the trouble.
Manx: 26 T’ad er nyn ymmyrkey seose ’syn aer, as sheese reesht gys y diunid: ta’n annym oc lheïe ersooyl er coontey nyn seaghyn.

English: up to the heaven] 1605 up the heaven
27 They reele to and fro, and stagger like a drunken man : and are at their wits end.
Manx: 27 T’ad criht noon as noall, as leaystey myr dooinney meshtal: as t’ad ec kione nyn geïlley.

English: 28 So when they cry unto the Lord in their trouble : hee delivereth them out of their distresse.
Manx: 28 Myr shen tra t’ad geamagh gys y Chiarn ayns nyn seaghyn: t’eh dy livrey ad ass nyn jennid.

English: 29 For hee maketh the storme to cease : so that the waves thereof are still.
Manx: 29 T’eh cur er y sterrym dy ve kuine: myr shen dy vel ny tonnyn goaill fea.

English: 30 Then are they glad, because they be at rest : and so hee bringeth them unto the haven where they would be.
Manx: 30 Eisht t’ad gennal, er‐yn‐oyr dy vel ad ec fea: as myr shen t’eh dy chur lesh ad gys y phurt baïlliu ’ve ayn.

English: they be] 1662 they are
31 O that men would therefore praise the Lord for his goodnesse : and declare the wonders that he doth for the children of men.
Manx: 31 O dy jinnagh deiney er‐y‐fa shen yn Chiarn y voylley son e vieys: as fockley magh ny yindyssyn t’eh dy yannoo son cloan gheiney!

English: 32 That they would exalt him also in the Congregation of the people : and praise him in the seate of the Elders.
Manx: 32 Dy jinnagh ad eshyn neesht y ghloyraghey ayns sheshaght y pobble: as eh y voylley ayns stoyl y chanstyr!

English: 33 Which turneth the floods into a wildernesse : and drieth up the water springs.
Manx: 33 Ta chyndaa ny thooillaghyn gys faasagh: as chyrmaghey seose ny farraneyn-ushtey.

English: Which] 1662 Who
34 A fruitfull land maketh he barren : for the wickednes of them that dwell therein.
Manx: 34 Cheer messoil t’eh dy yannoo faase: er coontey’n drogh‐yannoo ocsyn ta vaghey ayn.

English: 35 Againe he maketh the wildernesse a standing water : and water springs of a drie ground.
Manx: 35 Reesht t’eh jannoo yn aasagh ny loghan ushtey: as geillyn jeh thalloo chirrym.

English: 36 And there he setteth the hungrie : that they may build them a Citie to dwell in;
Manx: 36 As ayns shen t’eh soiaghey ny accryssee: dy vod ad ard‐valley y hroggal daue hene dy chummal ayn;

English: 37 That they may sow their land, and plant Vineyards : to yeeld them fruits of increase.
Manx: 37 Dy vod ad nyn dhalloo y chuirr, as garaghyn‐feeyney y hoiaghey: dy ymmyrkey magh daue ny messyn dy vishaghey.

English: 38 He blesseth them, so that they multiply exceedingly : and suffereth not their cattell to decrease.
Manx: 38 T’eh dy nyn mannaghey ad, dy vel ad bishaghey er-skyn towse: as cha vel eh surranse da’n maase oc dy ve ny sloo ayns earroo.

English: 39 And againe, when they are minished and brought low : through oppression, through any plague or trouble;
Manx: 39 Reesht, tra t’ad er nyn leodaghey as er nyn injillaghey: liorish tranlaase, trooid arkys ny seaghyn erbee;

English: 40 Though he suffer them to bee evil intreated through tyrants : and let them wander out of the way in the wildernesse;
Manx: 40 Ga dy vel eh surranse ad dy gheddyn drogh ghellal veih reilltee tranlaasagh: as lhiggey daue goll er‐shaghryn jeh’n raad ayns yn aasagh;

English: 41 Yet helpeth hee the poore out of miserie : and maketh him housholds like a flocke of sheepe.
Manx: 41 Ny-yeih t’eh cooney lesh y voght ass e heaghyn: as bishaghey’n lught‐thie echey myr shioltane keyrragh.

English: 42 The righteous will consider this, and rejoyce : and the mouth of all wickednesse shall be stopped.
Manx: 42 Smooinee yn vooinjer chairagh er shoh, as gow‐ee ad boggey: as bee beeall dy-chooilley olkys er ny yeigh.

English: 43 Who so is wise wil ponder these things : and they shall understand the loving kindenesse of the Lord.
Manx: 43 Quoi‐erbee ta creeney nee ad goaill ny reddyn shoh gys nyn gree: as toigg-ee ad kenjallys‐ghraihagh y Chiarn.

English: The xxii. day.
Manx: The 22. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Paratum cor meum. Psal. 108.
Manx: Psal. 108. Paratum cor meum.

English: O God my heart is ready (my heart is ready :) I will sing & give praise with the best member that I have.
Manx: 1 O Yee, ta my chree aggindagh, ta my chree aggindagh: goym arrane, as ver-ym moylley lesh rere my phooar.

English: 2 Awake thou Lute and Harpe : I my selfe will awake right earely.
Manx: 2 Dooisht, uss lute as chlaasagh: dooisht‐yms mee-hene feer voghey.

English: 3 I wil give thanks unto thee, O Lord, among the people : I will sing praises unto thee among the nations.
Manx: 3 Ver-ym booise dhyts, O Hiarn, mastey’n pobble: goym arraneyn‐moyllee hoods mastey ny ashoonyn.

English: 4 For thy mercie is greater then the heavens : and thy trueth reacheth unto the clouds.
Manx: 4 Son ta dty vyghin ny syrjey na ny niaughyn: as ta dty ynrickys roshtyn gys ny bodjallyn.

English: 5 Set up thy selfe (O God) above the heavens : and thy glory above all the earth.
Manx: 5 Soie oo hene seose, O Yee, er-skyn ny niaughyn: as dty ghloyr er-skyn ooilley yn seihll;

English: 6 That thy beloved may be delivered : let thy right hand save them, and heare thou me.
Manx: 6 Dy vod dty chloan reiht v’er nyn livrey: lhig da dty laue yesh ad y hauail, as clasht uss rhyms.

English: 7 God hath spoken in his holinesse : I wil rejoyce therefore and divide Sichem, and mete out the valley of Sucoth.
Manx: 7 Ta Jee er loayrt ayns e chasherickys, Nee’m er‐y‐fa-shen boggey ’ghoaill, as rheynn-ym Sichem: as towse‐ym magh coan Succoth.

English: 8 Gilead is mine, and Manasses is mine : Ephraim also is the strength of my head.
Manx: 8 Ta Gilead lhiam’s, as lhiam’s Manasses: ta Ephraim myrgeddin troshid my khing;

English: 9 Juda is my lawgiver, Moab is my washpot : over Edom will I cast out my shoe, upon the Philistines wil I triumph.
Manx: 9 Ta Judah m’er‐reill ’sy leigh, Moab my haagh‐nieeaghyn: shooill‐ym harrish Edom; harrish Philistia yioym y varriaght.

English: the Philistines 1599, 1636, 1660] 1605 the Philistims, 1662 Philistia
10 Who will leade me into the strong Citie : and who will bring me into Edom?
Manx: 10 Quoi nee m’y leeideil gys yn ard‐valley lajer: quoi ver lesh mee stiagh gys Edom?

English: 11 Hast not thou forsaken us, O God : and wilt not thou God goe foorth with our hostes?
Manx: 11 Nagh vel uss er hreigeil shin, O Yee: as nagh jean uss, O Yee, goll magh marish ny sheshaghtyn‐caggee ain?

English: thou God goe, 1599] 1636, 1660 thou, O God, go
12 O helpe us against the enemy : for vaine is the help of man.
Manx: 12 O cooin lhien noi’n noid: son s’fardalagh ta cooney dooinney.

English: 13 Through God we shall doe great actes : and it is he that shall tread downe our enemies.
Manx: 13 Trooid Jee nee mayd obbraghyn mooarey: as eshyn eh ver fo-chosh nyn noidyn.

English: Deus laudem. Psal. 109
Manx: Psal. 109. Deus laudem.
laudem] laudum 1765 &c.

English: Hold not thy tongue, O God of my praise : for the mouth of the ungodly, yea, and the mouth of the deceitfull is opened upon me.
Manx: 1 Ny bee uss dty-host, O Yee jeh my voylley: son ta beeall ny mee‐chrauee, dy-jarroo, ta beeall yn vooinjer volteyragh er ny osley m’oï.

English: and the mouth] 1662 the mouth
Manx: dty-host] 1765 dy-host; Yee jeh my voylley] 1777 Yee my voylley

English: 2 And they have spoken against mee with false tongues : they compassed mee about also with wordes of hatred, and fought against me without a cause.
Manx: 2 As t’ad er loayrt m’oï lesh chengaghyn foalsey: t’ad er jeet mygeayrt‐y‐moo’m lesh focklyn dwoaiagh, as er chaggey m’oï gyn oyr.

English: 3 For the love that I had unto them, loe, they take now my contrary part : but I give my selfe unto prayer.
Manx: 3 Son y ghraih v’aym orroosyn, cur‐my‐ner, t’ad nish shassoo m’oï: agh ta mish dy chur mee hene seose gys padjer.

English: 4 Thus have they rewarded me evill for good : and hatred for my good will.
Manx: 4 Myr shoh t’ad er chooilleeney dou olk son mie: as goanlys er son my aigney-mie.

English: 5 Set thou an ungodly man to bee ruler over him : and let Satan stand at his right hand.
Manx: 5 Nee dooinney mee‐chrauee reill y ymmyrkey harrish: as shassee Noid‐ny‐hanmey ec e laue yesh.

English: 6 When sentence is given upon him, let him bee condemned : and let his prayer be turned into sinne.
Manx: 6 Tra vees briwnys er ny choyrt er, bee eh er ny gheyrey: as bee’n phadjer echey er ny hyndaa gys peccah.

English: 7 Let his dayes be few : and let another take his office.
Manx: 7 Bee e laghyn giare: as gow‐ee fer elley yn oik echey.

English: 8 Let his children be fatherlesse : and his wife a widow.
Manx: 8 Bee’n chloan echey gyn ayr: as y ven echey treoghe.

English: 9 Let his children be vagabonds, and beg their bread : let them seeke it also out of desolate places.
Manx: 9 Bee’n chloan echey nyn gercheenyn, as shooyll ny dhieyn son jeirk: shirree ad eh ayns buill fadane.

English: 10 Let the extortioner consume all that hee hath : and let the stranger spoile his labour.
Manx: 10 Nee’n dooinney tranlaasagh ooilley ny t’echey y chur mow: as nee’n joarree e laboraght y spooilley.

English: 11 Let there be no man to pitie him : nor to have compassion upon his fatherlesse children.
Manx: 11 Cha gow dooinney erbee chymmey jeh: ny erreeish y hoilshaghey da e chloan gyn ayr.

English: 12 Let his posteritie be destroyed : & in the next generation let his name be cleane put out.
Manx: 12 Bee’n sluight echey er ny chur naardey: as ayns yn nah heeloghe, bee’n ennym echey dy-bollagh er ny yarrood.

English: 13 Let the wickednesse of his fathers bee had in remembrance in the sight of the Lord : and let not the sinne of his mother be done away.
Manx: 13 Bee olkys ny ayraghyn echey er ny reayll ayns cooinaghtyn ayns shilley’n Chiarn: as cha bee peccah e voir er ny chieltyn.

English: 14 Let them alway be before the Lord : that he may root out the memoriall of them from off the earth.
Manx: 14 Bee ad dy-kinjagh kiongoyrt rish y Chiarn: dy vod eh yn imraa jeu y astyrt dy-bollagh jeh’n ooir.

English: 15 And that, because his minde was not to doe good : but persecuted the poore helpelesse man, that hee might slay him that was vexed at the heart.
Manx: 15 As shoh, son nagh row e aigney dy yannoo mie: agh ren eh tranlaase er y voght gyn cooney, dy voddagh eh eshyn y stroie va seaghnit ayns cree.

English: 16 His delight was in cursing, & it shall happen unto him : he loved not blessing, therefore shall it be farre from him.
Manx: 16 Va e haitnys ayns gweeaghyn, as hig eh er: cha bynney lesh bannaght, shen‐y‐fa bee eh foddey voish.

English: 17 Hee clothed himselfe with cursing like as with a raiment : and it shall come into his bowels like water, and like oyle into his bones.
Manx: 17 Choamree eh eh hene lesh gweeaghyn myr lesh garmad: as hed eh stiagh ayns e vynnagh myr ushtey, as myr ooïll ayns e chraueyn.

English: 18 Let it be unto him as the cloke that he hath upon him : and as the girdle that he is alway girded withall.
Manx: 18 Bee eh da myr y cloagey t’eh dy cheau: as myr y cryss ta dy-kinjagh mysh.

English: 19 Let it thus happen from the Lord unto mine enemies : and to those that speake evill against my soule.
Manx: 19 Shoh myr nee eh taghyrt da my noidyn veih’n Chiarn: as dauesyn myrgeddin ta loayrt dy-holk noi m’annym.

English: 20 But deale thou with me, O Lord God, according unto thy Name : for sweete is thy mercie.
Manx: 20 Agh dell uss rhym’s, O Hiarn my Yee, cordail rish dty Ennym: son s’millish ta dty vyghin.

English: 21 O deliver mee, for I am helpelesse and poore : and my heart is wounded within me.
Manx: 21 O livrey mee, son ta mee ymmyrchagh as gyn cooney: as ta my chree gooint cheu-sthie jee’m.

English: 22 I goe hence like the shadow that departeth : and am driven away as the Grashopper.
Manx: 22 Ta mee goll ass shoh myr y scadoo ta scughey ersooyl: ta mee eiyrit noon as noall myr y locust.

English: 23 My knees are weake through fasting : my flesh is dried up for want of fatnesse.
Manx: 23 Ta my ghlioonyn annoon lesh trostey: ta my eill shymlit son laccal soo.

English: 24 I became also a rebuke unto them : they that looked upon me, shaked their heads.
Manx: 24 Haink mee myrgeddin dy ve oltooan daue: adsyn va jeeaghyn orrym chrie ad nyn ghing.

English: rebuke] 1662 reproach
25 Helpe me, O Lord my God : Oh save me according to thy mercie.
Manx: 25 Cooin lhiam, O Hiarn my Yee: O jean uss mish y hauail cordail rish dty vyghin.

English: 26 And they shall know how that this is thy hand : and that thou Lord hast done it.
Manx: 26 As bee fys oc dy nee shoh dty laue: as dy nee uss, Hiarn, t’er n’yannoo eh.

English: 27 Though they curse, yet blesse thou : & let them bee confounded that rise up against me; but let thy servant rejoyce.
Manx: 27 Ga dy vel adsyn gweeaghyn, ny-yeih jean uss bannaghey: as lhig daue ve er nyn goyrt gys nearey ta girree seose m’oï; agh lhig da dty harvaant boggey ’ghoaill.

English: 28 Let mine adversaries be clothed with shame : & let them cover themselves with their owne confusion, as with a cloke.
Manx: 28 Lhig da my noidyn ve er nyn goamrey lesh nearey: as lhig daue ve coodit lesh nyn scammylt hene myr lesh cloagey.

English: 29 As for mee, I will give great thankes unto the Lord with my mouth : and praise him among the multitude.
Manx: 29 Er my hon’s, ver-ym mooarane booise da’n Chiarn lesh my veeall: as nee’m eshyn y voylley mastey earroo yn pobble.

English: 30 For he shal stand at the right hand of the poore : to save his soule from unrighteous Judges.
Manx: 30 Son shassee eh ec laue yesh y voght: dy hauail e annym veih briwnyn neu‐chairagh.

English: The xxiii. day.
Manx: The 23. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Dixit Dominus. Psal. 110.
Manx: Psal. 110. Dixit Dominus.

English: The Lord saide unto my Lord : Sit thou on my right hand, untill I make thine enemies thy footestoole.
Manx: 1 Dooyrt y Chiarn rish my Hiarn’s: Soie uss er my laue yesh, derrey nee’m dty noidyn y yannoo stoyl dty choshey.

English: 2 The Lord shall send the rod of thy power out of Sion : be thou ruler, even in the middes among thine enemies.
Manx: 2 Nee’n Chiarn lorg dty phooar y chur ass Sion: bee uss dt’er‐reill, eer ayns mean dty noidyn.
ass Sion] 1769, 1777 veih Sion; dt’er-reill] 1765, 1769 d’er-reill

English: 3 In the day of thy power shall the people offer thee free wil offerings with an holy worship : the dewe of thy birth is of the wombe of the morning.
Manx: 3 Ayns laa dty phooar nee’n pobble ourallyn-arryltagh y hebbal hoods lesh ooashley crauee: ta druight yn cheet ayd er y theihll veih brein y voghrey.

English: 4 The Lord sware and wil not repent : thou art a Priest for ever, after the order of Melchisedech.
Manx: 4 Ta’n Chiarn er vreearrey, as cha gow eh arrys: T’ow uss Ard‐saggyrt dy-bragh myr va Melchisedech.

English: 5 The Lord upon thy right hand : shall wound even Kings in the day of his wrath.
Manx: 5 Nee’n Chiarn er dty laue yesh: eer reeaghyn y chur-mow ayns laa e yymmoose.

English: 6 He shall judge among the heathen; hee shall fill the places with the dead bodies : and smite in sunder the heads over divers countreys.
Manx: 6 Ver eh briwnys mastey ny ashoonyn; lhieenee eh ny ynnydyn lesh ny kirp marroo: as ard-reilltee ymmodee cheeraghyn y chur fo‐chosh.
ard-reilltee] 1765, 1769 ard-reillee

English: 7 He shall drinke of the brooke in the way : therefore shall he lift up his head.
Manx: 7 Iu‐ee eh jeh’n strooan er y raad: shen‐y‐fa troggee eh seose e chione.

English: Confitebor tibi. Psal. 111.
Manx: Psal. 111. Confitebor tibi.

English: I will give thankes unto the Lord with my whole heart : secretly among the faithfull, and in the Congregation.
Manx: 1 Ver-yms booise da’n Chiarn lesh ooilley my chree: ayns sheshaght er‐lheh yn vooinjer chrauee, as ayns chaglym y pobble.

English: 2 The workes of the Lord are great : sought out of all them that have pleasure therein.
Manx: 2 Ta obbraghyn y Chiarn mooar: er nyn gheddyn magh lioroosyn ooilley ta goaill taitnys ayndoo.

English: 3 His worke is worthy to bee praised and had in honour : and his righteousnesse endureth for ever.
Manx: 3 Ta’n obbyr echey feeu moylley as ooashley: as ta e chairys farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 4 The mercifull & gracious Lord hath so done his marveilous workes : that they ought to be had in remembrance.
Manx: 4 Ta’n Chiarn myghinagh as graysoil myr shen er n’yannoo e obbraghyn yindyssagh: dy lhisagh ad ve freillt ayns cooinaghtyn.

English: 5 He hath given meat unto them that feare him : he shall ever be mindfull of his Covenant.
Manx: 5 T’eh er chur beaghey dauesyn ta goaill aggle roïsh: bee eh dy-bragh cooinaghtyn er e chonaant.

English: 6 Hee hath shewed his people the power of his workes : that he may give them the heritage of the Heathen.
Manx: 6 T’eh er hoilshaghey da e phobble pooar e obbraghyn: dy voddagh eh cur daue eiraght ny ashoonyn.

English: 7 The workes of his hands are veritie & judgement : all his Commandements are true.
Manx: 7 Ta obbraghyn e laueyn ynrickys as briwnys: ta ooilley e annaghyn firrinagh.

English: 8 They stand fast for ever and ever : and are done in trueth and equitie.
Manx: 8 T’ad shassoo shickyr son dy-bragh as dy-bragh: as t’ad jeant ayns firrinys as corrymid.

English: 9 He sent redemption unto his people : he hath commanded his Covenant for ever; holy and reverent is his Name.
Manx: 9 T’eh er choyrt feaysley da e phobble: t’eh er haarey e chonaant son dy-bragh; casherick as arrymagh ta’n Ennym echey.

English: reverent] 1660 reverend
10 The feare of the Lord is the beginning of wisedome : a good understanding have all they that doe thereafter; the praise of it endureth for ever.
Manx: 10 Ta aggle y Chiarn toshiaght creenaght: toiggal mie t’ocsyn ooilley ta dy ymmyrkey ad hene cordail rish; ta’n moylley echey farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: Beatus vir. Psal. 112
Manx: Psal. 112. Beatus vir.

English: Blessed is the man that feareth the Lord : hee hath great delight in his Commandements.
Manx: 1 Bannit ta’n dooinney ta goaill aggle roish y Chiarn: ta taitnys mooar echey ayns e annaghyn.

English: 2 His seed shal be mightie upon earth : the generation of the faithfull shal be blessed.
Manx: 2 Bee yn sluight echey niartal er y thalloo: bee bannaght gour yn vooinjer ynrick.

English: 3 Riches and plenteousnesse shal be in his house: and his righteousnesse endureth for ever.
Manx: 3 Bee berchys as palchey ayns e hie: as nee e chairys farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 4 Unto the godly there ariseth up light in the darknes : he is mercifull, loving, and righteous.
Manx: 4 Da’n dooinney crauee ta soilshey brishey magh ayns y dorraghys: t’eh myghinagh, graihagh, as cairagh.

English: 5 A good man is mercifull, and lendeth : and will guide his words with discretion.
Manx: 5 Ta dooinney mie erreeishagh, as coyrt er eeasaght: as nee eh e ghlaare y reill lesh tushtey.

English: 6 For he shall never be mooved : and the righteous shall be had in everlasting remembrance.
Manx: 6 Son cha bee eh dy-bragh er ny scughey: as bee’n dooinney ynrick freillt ayns cooinaghtyn er son dy-bragh.

English: 7 He will not be afraid of any evill tidings : for his heart standeth fast, and beleeveth in the Lord.
Manx: 7 Cha bee eh agglagh jeh drogh naight erbee: son ta e chree shassoo shickyr, as credjal ayns y Chiarn.

English: 8 His heart is stablished and wil not shrinke : until he see his desire upon his enemies.
Manx: 8 Ta e chree er ny hickyraghey, as cha vaill eh: derrey hee eh e aigney er e noidyn.

English: 9 He hath dispersed abroad, and given to the poore : and his righteousnesse remaineth for ever; his horne shall be exalted with honour.
Manx: 9 T’eh er skeayley dy-lhean as er choyrt da ny boghtyn: as ta e chairys farraghtyn son dy-bragh; bee’n ennym echey er ny hoiaghey seose lesh ooashley.

English: 10 The ungodly shall see it, and it shall grieve him : hee shall gnash with his teeth, and consume away; the desire of the ungodly shall perish.
Manx: 10 Hee yn mee‐chrauee eh, as bee eh trimshey da: nee eh snaggeraght lesh e eeacklyn, as lheïe ersooyl; nee yeearree yn vooinjer vee‐chrauee cherraghtyn.

English: Laudate pueri. Psal. 113.
Manx: Psal. 113. Laudate, pueri.

English: Praise the Lord, yee servants : O praise the Name of the Lord.
Manx: 1 Moylley‐jee yn Chiarn, shiuish e harvaantyn: O moylley‐jee Ennym y Chiarn.

English: 2 Blessed bee the Name of the Lord : from this time foorth for evermore.
Manx: 2 Bannit dy row Ennym y Chiarn: veih’n traa shoh magh er son dy-bragh.

English: 3 The Lords Name is praised : from the rising up of the Sunne, unto the going downe of the same.
Manx: 3 Ta Ennym y Chiarn er ny voylley: veih irree gys lhie ny greïney.

English: 4 The Lord is high above all heathen : and his glory above the heavens.
Manx: 4 Ta’n Chiarn ard er-skyn dy-chooilley ashoon: as ta e ghloyr er-skyn ny niaughyn.

English: 5 Who is like unto the Lord our God, that hath his dwelling so high : and yet humbleth himselfe to beholde the things that are in heaven and earth?
Manx: 5 Quoi ta casley rish y Chiarn y Jee ain, ta e ynnyd‐vaghee cha ard: as ny-yeih t’eh ginjillaghey eh hene dy chur my‐ner ny reddyn t’ayns niau as er y thalloo?

English: 6 Hee taketh up the simple out of the dust : and lifteth the poore out of the myre;
Manx: 6 T’eh goaill seose yn fer imlee ass y joan: as troggal yn ymmyrchagh veih’n thorran;

English: 7 That hee may set him with the princes : even with the princes of his people.
Manx: 7 Dy vod eh eshyn y hoiaghey seose mastey ny prinsyn: dy-jarroo mastey prinsyn e phobble.

English: 8 Hee maketh the barren woman to keepe house : and to be a joyfull mother of children.
Manx: 8 T’eh cur er y ven ghennish dy reayll thie: as dy ve ny moir ghennal dy chloan.

English: The xxiii. day.
Manx: The 23. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: In exitu Israel. Psal. 114.
Manx: Psal. 114. In exitu Israel.

English: When Israel came out of Egypt : and the house of Jacob from among the strange people,
Manx: 1 Tra haink Israel magh ass Egypt: as thie Yacob veih mastey’n pobble joarree,

English: 2 Juda was his Sanctuary : and Israel his dominion.
Manx: 2 Va Judah e ynnyd casherick: as Israel e reeriaght.

English: 3 The sea sawe that, and fled : Jordan was driven backe.
Manx: 3 Honnick y faarkey shoh, as ren eh chea: va Jordan er ny imman noi’n choorse.

English: 4 The mountains skipped like Rams : & the little hils like yong sheep.
Manx: 4 Ren ny sleïtyn lheïme myr reaghyn: as ny croink veggey myr eayin.

English: 5 What aileth thee, O thou sea, that thou fleddest : and thou Jordan that thou wast driven backe?
Manx: 5 Cre haink orts, O aarkey, dy ren oo chea: as orts, Yordan, dy row er dty imman back?

English: 6 Ye mountaines that yee skipped like Rammes : and ye little hils like yong sheepe?
Manx: 6 Shiuish sleïtyn dy lheïme shiu myr reaghyn: as shiuish chroink veggey myr eayin?

English: 7 Tremble thou earth at the presence of the Lord : at the presence of the God of Jacob;
Manx: 7 Bee er‐creau, uss halloo, ec fenish y Chiarn: ec fenish Jee Yacob;

English: 8 Which turned the hard rocke into a standing water : and the flint stone into a springing well.
Manx: 8 Hyndaa yn chreg chreoi gys poyll-ushtey: as y chlagh-flint gys chibbyr gheill.

English: Which] 1662 Who
Non nobis Domine. Psal. 115.
Manx: Psal. 115. Non nobis, Domine.

English: Not unto us, O Lord, not unto us, but unto thy Name give the praise : for thy loving mercie, and for thy trueths sake.
Manx: 1 Cha nee dooinyn, O Hiarn, cha nee dooinyn, agh da dt’ Ennym cur yn moylley: son dty vyghin ghraihagh, as er coontey dt’ynrickys.

English: 2 Wherefore shall the heathen say : Where is now their God?
Manx: 2 Cre’n‐fa jirr ny ashoonyn‐quaagh: Cre’n raad ta nish yn Jee oc?

English: 3 As for our God, he is in heaven : he hath done whatsoever pleased him.
Manx: 3 Er son y Jee ainyn, t’eh ayns niau: t’eh er n’yannoo myr s’gooidsave lesh.

English: 4 Their idoles are silver and golde : even the worke of mens hands.
Manx: 4 Ta ny jallooyn oc argid as airh: eer obbyr laueyn deiney.

English: 5 They have mouthes, and speake not : eyes have they and see not.
Manx: 5 Ta beïll oc as cha vel ad loayrt: ta sooillyn oc as cha vel ad fakin.

English: 6 They have eares, and heare not : noses have they, and smell not.
Manx: 6 Ta cleayshyn oc as cha vel ad clashtyn: ta stroanyn oc as cha vel ad soaral.

English: 7 They have hands, and handle not; feete have they, and walke not : neither speake they through their throat.
Manx: 7 Ta laueyn oc as cha vel ad loaghtey, cassyn t’oc as cha vel ad shooyll: cha-moo t’ad loayrt trooid nyn scoarnagh.

English: 8 They that make them, are like unto them : and so are all such as put their trust in them.
Manx: 8 T’adsyn ta jannoo ad casley roo: as myr shen t’adsyn ooilley ta cur nyn dreishteil ayndoo.

English: 9 But thou house of Israel, trust thou in the Lord : he is their succour and defence.
Manx: 9 Agh uss hie Israel, treisht uss ayns y Chiarn: she eshyn nyn gemmyrk as nyn vendeil.

English: 10 Ye house of Aaron, put your trust in the Lord : hee is their helper and defender.
Manx: 10 Shiuish hie Aaron, cur‐jee nyn dreishteil ayns y Chiarn: eshyn y fer-coonee as y fendeilagh oc.

English: 11 Ye that feare the Lord, put your trust in the Lord: hee is their helper and defender.
Manx: 11 Shiuish ta goaill aggle roish y Chiarn, cur‐jee nyn dreishteil ayns y Chiarn: eshyn y fer‐coonee as y fendeilagh oc.

English: 12 The Lord hath bene mindfull of us, and he shall blesse us : even he shall blesse the house of Israel, he shall blesse the house of Aaron.
Manx: 12 Ta’n Chiarn er chooinaghtyn orrin, as bannee eh shin: dy-jarroo nee eh thie Israel y vannaghey, nee eh bannaghey thie Aaron.

English: 13 He shal blesse them that feare the Lord : both smal and great.
Manx: 13 Nee eh adsyn y vannaghey ta goaill aggle roish y Chiarn: chammah beg as mooar.

English: 14 The Lord shall increase you more and more : you and your children.
Manx: 14 Nee’n Chiarn shiuish y vishaghey ny smoo as ny smoo: shiuish as nyn gloan.

English: 15 Ye are the blessed of the Lord : which made heaven and earth.
Manx: 15 Shiuish ta cloan bannit y Chiarn: chroo niau as y thalloo.

English: which] 1662 who
16 All the whole heavens are the Lords : the earth hath he given to the children of men.
Manx: 16 Ta ny slane niaughyn lesh y Chiarn: yn thalloo t’eh er choyrt da cloan gheiney.

English: 17 The dead praise not thee, O Lord : neither all they that goe downe into silence.
Manx: 17 Cha vel ny merriu coyrt moylley dhyts, O Hiarn: ny adsyn ooilley ta goll sheese ayns yn oaie.

English: 18 But we will praise the Lord : from this time foorth for evermore. Praise the Lord.
Manx: 18 Agh nee shinyn y Chiarn y voylley: veih’n traa shoh magh son dy-bragh. Moylley‐jee yn Chiarn.

English: The xxiiii. day.
Manx: The 24. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Dilexi quoniam. Psal. 116.
Manx: Psal. 116. Dilexi quoniam.

English: I am well pleased : that the Lord hath heard the voyce of my prayer;
Manx: 1 Ta mee feer wooiagh: dy vel y Chiarn er chlashtyn coraa my phadjer;

English: 2 That hee hath inclined his eare unto mee : therefore will I call upon him as long as I live.
Manx: 2 Dy vel eh er chrommey e chleaysh hym: shen‐y‐fa nee’m geamagh er choud as vee’m bio.

English: 3 The snares of death compassed mee round about : and the paines of hell gate hold upon me.
Manx: 3 Ren ribbaghyn y vaaish mee y chombaasal mygeayrt: as hooar pianyn niurin greme orrym.
Ren ribbaghyn y vaaish mee y chombaasal mygeayrt: as hooar] 1769, 1777 Haink ribbaghyn y vaaish mygeayrt‐y‐moom: as ghow

English: 4 I shal finde trouble & heavinesse, & I shal call upon the Name of the Lord : O Lord I beseech thee, deliver my soule.
Manx: 4 Hooar mee seaghyn as trimshey, as ren mee geamagh er Ennym y Chiarn:[246] O Hiarn, ta mee guee ort, livrey m’annym.

English: I shal call] 1662 I will call
5 Gracious is the Lord, and righteous : yea our God is mercifull.
Manx: 5 Ta’n Chiarn graysoil as cairal: dy-jarroo, ta’n Jee ainyn myghinagh.

English: 6 The Lord preserveth the simple : I was in misery, and he helped me.
Manx: 6 Ta’n Chiarn coadey adsyn ta gyn loght: va mish ayns seaghyn, as chooin eh lhiam.

English: 7 Turne againe then unto thy rest, O my soule : for the Lord hath rewarded thee.
Manx: 7 Chyndaa reesht eisht gys dt’ea, O my annym: son ta’n Chiarn er choyrt leagh dhyt.
er choyrt leagh dhyt] 1769, 1777 er dty chooilleeney

English: 8 And why? thou hast delivered my soule from death : mine eyes from teares, and my feet from falling.
Manx: 8 As cre’n-fa? t’ow er livrey m’annym veih baase: my hooillyn veih jeïr, as my chassyn veih tuittym.

English: 9 I wil walke before the Lord : in the land of the living.
Manx: 9 Nee’ms gimmeeaght kiongoyrt rish y Chiarn: ayns cheer y sleih bio.

English: 10 I beleeved, and therefore will I speak; but I was sore troubled : I said in my haste, All men are liars.
Manx: 10 Ren mee credjal, as shen‐y‐fa nee’m loayrt; agh va mee dy-mooar seaghnit: dooyrt mee ayns my hiyr, Ta dy-chooilley ghooinney ny vreagerey.
ny vreagerey] 1769 fardailys, 1777 fardalys, 1819 mollit

English: 11 What reward shall I give unto the Lord : for all the benefits that he hath done unto me?
Manx: 11 Cre’n cooilleeney ver-ym da’n Chiarn: son ooilley ny bannaghtyn t’eh er hoilshaghey dou?

English: 12 I will receive the cup of salvation : and call upon the Name of the Lord.
Manx: 12 Nee’ms goaill cappan y taualtys: as nee’m geamagh er Ennym y Chiarn.

English: 13 I will pay my vowes now in the presence of all his people : right deare in the sight of the Lord, is the death of his Saints.
Manx: 13 Nee’m my vreearaghyn y eeck nish kionfenish ooilley e phobble: feer deyr ayns shilley’n Chiarn ta baase e nooghyn.

English: 14 Behold (O Lord) how that I am thy servant : I am thy servant, and the sonne of thy handmaid; thou hast broken my bonds in sunder.
Manx: 14 Cur‐my‐ner, O Hiarn, kys dy vel mish dty harvaant: ta mish dty harvaant, as mac dt’inney-veyl; t’ow er vrishey my chianglaghyn veih my‐chielley.

English: 15 I wil offer to thee the sacrifice of Thankesgiving : and will call upon the Name of the Lord.
Manx: 15 Chebb‐ym hoods yn oural dy hoyrt‐booise: as nee’m geamagh er Ennym y Chiarn.

English: 16 I will pay my vowes unto the Lord, in the sight of all his people : in the courts of the Lords house, even in the mids of thee, O Hierusalem. Praise the Lord.
Manx: 16 Eeck‐ym my vreearaghyn gys y Chiarn, ayns fenish ooilley e phobble: ayns cooyrtyn thie yn Chiarn, dy-jarroo, ayns y vean ayds, O Yerusalem. Moylley‐jee yn Chiarn.

English: Laudate Dominum. Psal. 117.
Manx: Psal. 117. Laudate Dominum.

English: O praise the Lord all yee heathen : praise him, all ye Nations.
Manx: 1 O moylley-jee yn Chiarn, ooilley shiuish ashoonyn: moylley‐jee eh, ooilley shiuish e phobble.

English: 2 For his mercifull kindnesse is ever more and more towards us : and the trueth of the Lord endureth for ever. Praise the Lord.
Manx: 2 Son ta e chenjallys vyghinagh dy-kinjagh ny smoo as ny smoo er ny hoilshaghey orrin: as ta firrinys y Chiarn farraghtyn son dy-bragh. Moylley‐jee yn Chiarn.

English: Confitemini Domino. Psal. 118.
Manx: Psal. 118. Confitemini Domino.

English: O give thanks unto the Lord, for he is gracious : because his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 1 O cur‐jee booise da’n Chiarn, son t’eh graysoil: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 2 Let Israel now confesse, that he is gracious : and that his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 2 Lhig da Israel nish goaill-rish dy vel eh graysoil: as dy vel e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 3 Let the house of Aaron now confesse : that his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 3 Lhig da thie Aaron nish goaill‐rish: dy vel e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 4 Yea, let them now that feare the Lord, confesse : that his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 4 Dy-jarroo, lhig dauesyn ta nish aggle orroo roish y Chiarn, goaill‐rish: dy vel e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 5 I called upon the Lord in trouble : and the Lord heard me at large.
Manx: 5 Deïe mee er y Chiarn ayns my heaghyn: as hug y Chiarn slane clashtyn dou.

English: 6 The Lord is on my side : I will not feare what man doeth unto me.
Manx: 6 Ta’n Chiarn er my lheh’s: cha bee aggle orrym jeh ny oddys dooinney y yannoo rhym.

English: 7 The Lord taketh my part with them that helpe mee: therefore shall I see my desire upon mine enemies.
Manx: 7 Ta’n Chiarn goaill my phaart mâroosyn ta cooney lhiam: shen‐y‐fa hee‐ym my yeearree er my noidyn.

English: 8 It is better to trust in the Lord : then to put any confidence in man.
Manx: 8 Te ny share dy hreishteil ayns y Chiarn: na dy chur barrant erbee gys dooinney.

English: 9 It is better to trust in the Lord : then to put any confidence in princes.
Manx: 9 Te ny share dy hreishteil ayns y Chiarn: na dy chur treishteil erbee ayns prinsyn.

English: 10 All nations compassed mee round about : but in the Name of the Lord will I destroy them.
Manx: 10 Ren dy-chooilley ashoon cheet mygeayrt‐y‐moo’m: agh ayns Ennym y Chiarn nee’m ad y stroie.

English: 11 They kept me in on every side, they kept me in (I say) on every side : but in the Name of the Lord wil I destroy them.
Manx: 11 Ren ad m’y hionney er dy-chooilley cheu, haink ad chione orrym, ta mee gra, er dy-chooilley cheu: agh ayns Ennym y Chiarn stroie‐ym ad.

English: 12 They came about me like Bees, and are extinct even as the fire among the thornes : for in the Name of the Lord I will destroy them.
Manx: 12 Haink ad mygeayrt‐y‐moo’m myr shellanyn, as t’ad er ny vooghey myr aile mastey drineyn: son ayns Ennym y Chiarn nee’m ad y stroie.

English: 13 Thou hast thrust sore at mee, that I might fall : but the Lord was my helpe.
Manx: 13 T’ow er lhie dy-trome orrym dy my lhieggal: agh va’n Chiarn my chooney.

English: 14 The Lord is my strength and my song : and is become my salvation.
Manx: 14 Ta’n Chiarn my niart as my arrane: as t’eh er jeet dy ve my haualtys.

English: 15 The voyce of joy and health is in the dwellings of the righteous : the right hand of the Lord bringeth mightie things to passe.
Manx: 15 Ta coraa boggey as slaynt ayns cummallyn y vooinjer chairagh: ta laue yesh y Chiarn coyrt lesh reddyn yindyssagh gys kione.

English: 16 The right hand of the Lord hath the preeminence : the right hand of the Lord bringeth mightie things to passe.
Manx: 16 Ta laue yesh y Chiarn er-skyn ooilley: ta laue yesh y Chiarn cur lesh reddyn yindyssagh mygeayrt.

English: 17 I wil not die, but live : & declare the works of the Lord.
Manx: 17 Cha voym baase, agh bee’m er my reayll bio; dy hoilshaghey magh obbraghyn y Chiarn.

English: I wil] 1662 I shall
18 The Lord hath chastened and corrected mee : but hee hath not given me over unto death.
Manx: 18 Ta’n Chiarn er my smaghtaghey as er my cherraghey: agh cha vel eh er my livrey harrish gys baase.

English: 19 Open me the gates of righteousnesse : that I may goe into them, and give thankes unto the Lord.
Manx: 19 Foshil‐jee dooys giattyn y chairys: dy voddym goll stiagh orroo, as booise y choyrt da’n Chiarn.

English: 20 This is the gate of the Lord : the righteous shal enter into it.
Manx: 20 Shoh giatt y Chiarn: hed y vooinjer chrauee stiagh ayn.

English: 21 I will thanke thee, for thou hast heard mee : and art become my salvation.
Manx: 21 Ver‐yms booise dhyt, son t’ow er my chlashtyn: as er jeet dy ve my haualtys.

English: 22 The same stone which the builders refused : is become the head stone in the corner.
Manx: 22 Yn chlagh cheddin ren ny masoonee y vee‐lowal: ta er jeet dy ve yn ard chlagh chorneilagh.

English: 23 This is the Lords doing : and it is marveilous in our eyes.
Manx: 23 Shoh jannoo yn Chiarn: as te yindyssagh ayns ny sooillyn ain.

English: 24 This is the day which the Lord hath made : we will rejoyce and be glad in it.
Manx: 24 Shoh’n laa ta’n Chiarn er n’oardaghey: gow‐ee mayd boggey as bee mayd gennal ayn.

English: 25 Helpe mee now, O Lord : O Lord send us now prosperitie.
Manx: 25 Cooin lhiam nish, O Hiarn: O Hiarn, cur dooin nish maynrys.

English: 26 Blessed be he that commeth in the Name of the Lord : we have wished you good lucke, ye that be of the house of the Lord.
Manx: 26 Bannit t’eshyn ta cheet ayns Ennym y Chiarn: ta shin er vannaghey diuish ta jeh thie’n Chiarn.

English: ye that be] 1662 ye that are
27 God is the Lord which hath shewed us light : bind the sacrifice with cords, yea, even unto the hornes of the Altar.
Manx: 27 Jee yn Chiarn t’er chur dooin soilshey: kaingle‐jee yn oural lesh coyrdyn, gys eer eairkyn yn altar.

English: Lord which] 1662 Lord who
Manx: eairkyn] 1765, 1769 eayrkyn

English: 28 Thou art my God, and I will thanke thee : thou art my God, and I will praise thee.
Manx: 28 She uss my Yee, as ver-ym booise dhyt: uss my Yee, as ver‐ym moylley dhyt.

English: 29 O give thankes unto the Lord, for he is gracious: and his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 29 O cur‐jee booise da’n Chiarn, son t’eh graysoil: as ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: The xxiiii. day.
Manx: The 24. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Beati immaculati. Psal. 119.1-8.
Manx: Psal. 119. Beati immaculati.

English: Blessed are those that are undefiled in the way : and walke in the Law of the Lord.
Manx: 1 Bannit t’adsyn ta glen ayns y raad: as ta gimmeeaght ayns leigh yn Chiarn.
glen] 1769 ynric, 1777 ynrick, 1819 glen

English: 2 Blessed are they that keepe his Testimonies : & seek him with their whole heart.
Manx: 2 Bannit t’adsyn ta freayll ny recortyssyn echey: as shirrey er y hon lesh ooilley nyn gree.

English: 3 For they which doe no wickednesse : walke in his wayes.
Manx: 3 Son t’adsyn nagh vel jannoo veg yn olk: gimmeeaght ayns e raaidyn.

English: which] 1662 who
4 Thou hast charged : that we shall diligently keepe thy Commandements.
Manx: 4 T’ow uss er haarey shin: dy-imneagh dy reayll dt’annaghyn.

English: 5 O that my wayes were made so direct : that I might keepe thy Statutes.
Manx: 5 Oh, dy beagh my raaidyn cha jeeragh shen: dy voddin dty ’lattyssyn y reayll!

English: 6 So shall I not bee confounded : while I have respect unto all thy Commandements.
Manx: 6 Myr shen cha bee’m er my choyrt gys nearey: choud as ta mee coyrt tastey da ooilley dty annaghyn.
ooilley] 1765 oilley

English: 7 I will thanke thee with an unfained heart : when I shall have learned the Judgements of thy righteousnes.
Manx: 7 Ver-ym booise dhyt lesh cree firrinagh: tra vee’m er n’ynsaghey briwnyssyn dty chairys.

English: 8 I will keep thy ceremonies : O forsake me not utterly.
Manx: 8 Freill‐ym dty oardaghyn: O ny treig mee dy-bollagh.

English: In quo corriget.
Manx: In quo corriget?

English: Wherewithall shall a yong man cleanse his way : even by ruling himselfe after thy word.
Manx: [9] Cre’n aght nee dooinney aeg e raaidyn y reayll glen: dy-jarroo liorish reill eh hene cordail rish dty ghoo?

English: 10 With my whole heart have I sought thee : O let me not goe wrong out of thy Commandements.
Manx: [10] 2 Lesh ooilley my chree ta mee er hirrey er dty hon: O ny lhig dou goll er‐shaghryn veih dty annaghyn.

English: 11 Thy wordes have I hidde within my heart : that I should not sinne against thee.
Manx: [11] 3 Dty ghoan ta mee er ollaghey cheu‐sthie ayns my chree: nagh jinnin peccah ’yannoo dt’oï.
’yannoo] absent in 1769, 1777, 1819

English: 12 Blessed art thou, O Lord : O teach me thy Statutes.
Manx: [12] 4 Bannit t’ow uss, O Hiarn: O ynsee dou dty ’lattyssyn.

English: 13 With my lips have I bene telling : of all the Judgements of thy mouth.
Manx: [13] 5 Lesh my veillyn ta mee er ny ve ginsh: jeh ooilley briwnyssyn dty veeall.

English: 14 I have had as great delight in the way of thy Testimonies : as in all maner of riches.
Manx: [14] 6 Ta taitnys wheesh er ve aym ayns raad dty leighyn: as ayns dy-chooilley vonney dy verchys.

English: 15 I wil talk of thy Commandements : and have respect unto thy ways.
Manx: [15] 7 Nee’m taggloo jeh dt’annaghyn: as ver-ym geill da dty raaidyn.

English: 16 My delight shall bee in thy Statutes : and I will not forget thy word.
Manx: [16] 8 Bee my haitnys ayns dty ’lattyssyn: as cha jarrood‐ym dty ghoo.

English: Retribue seruo tuo.
Manx: Retribue servo tuo.

English: O doe well unto thy servant : that I may live, and keepe thy word.
Manx: [17] O jean mie da dty harvaant: dy voddym ’ve bio as dty ghoo y reayll.

English: 18 Open thou mine eyes : that I may see the wonderous things of thy Law.
Manx: [18] 2 Foshil uss my hooillyn: dy voddym fakin reddyn yindyssagh dty leigh.

English: 19 I am a stranger upon earth : O hide not thy Commandements from me.
Manx: [19] 3 Ta mee my yoarree er y thalloo: O ny jean uss keiltyn voym dty annaghyn.

English: 20 My soule breaketh out for the very fervent desire : that it hath alway unto thy Judgements.
Manx: [20] 4 Ta m’annym brishey magh son y ghraih feer jeean: t’eck dy-kinjagh gys dt’oardaghyn.

English: 21 Thou hast rebuked the proud : and cursed are they that doe erre from thy Commandements.
Manx: [21] 5 T’ow er choyrt oghsan da ny mooaralee: as cursit t’adsyn ooilley ta goll er‐shaghryn veih dty annaghyn.

English: 22 O turne from mee shame and rebuke : for I have kept thy Testimonies.
Manx: [22] 6 O chyndaa voym’s nearey as oghsan: son ta mee er vreaylley dty recortyssyn.

English: 23 Princes also did sit and speake against mee : but thy servant is occupied in thy Statutes.
Manx: [23] 7 Ren prinsyn myrgeddin soie as loayrt m’oï: agh ta dty harvaant thaaghey eh hene ayns dty ’lattyssyn.

English: 24 For thy testimonies are my delight : & my counsailers.
Manx: [24] 8 Son ta ny recortyssyn ayds my voggey: as my ir‐choyrlee.

English: Adhæsit pauimento.
Manx: Adhæsit pavimento.

English: My soule cleaveth to the dust : O quicken thou mee according to thy word.
Manx: [25] Ta m’annym lhiantyn gys y joan: O jean uss mish y vioghey cordail rish dty ghoo.

English: 26 I have knowledged my wayes, and thou heardest me : O teach me thy Statutes.
Manx: [26] 2 Ta mee er ghoaill‐rish my raaidyn, as t’ow uss er my chlashtyn: O ynsee dou dty ’lattyssyn.

English: knowledged] 1762 acknowledged
27 Make mee to understand the way of thy Commandements : and so shall I talke of thy wonderous workes.
Manx: [27] 3 Cur orrym toiggal raad dt’annaghyn: as myr shen nee’m taggloo jeh dt’obbraghyn yindyssagh.

English: 28 My soule melteth away for very heavinesse : comfort thou me according unto thy word.
Manx: [28] 4 Ta m’annym’s lheïe ersooyl son eer trimshey: jean m’y gherjaghey cordail rish dty ghoo.

English: 29 Take from me the way of lying : and cause thou me to make much of thy Law.
Manx: [29] 5 Scugh foddey voym yn raad dy vreagyn: as cur orrym mooar y yannoo jeh dty leigh.

English: 30 I have chosen the way of trueth : and thy Judgements have I layd before me.
Manx: [30] 6 Ta mee er reih raad ny firrinys: as dty vriwnyssyn ta mee er hoiaghey kiongoyrt rhym.

English: 31 I have sticken unto thy Testimonies : O Lord confound me not.
Manx: [31] 7 Ta mee er lhiantyn gys dty recortyssyn: O Hiarn, ny jean mish y choyrt gys nearey.

English: sticken] 1662 stuck
32 I will runne the way of thy Commandements : when thou hast set my heart at libertie.
Manx: [32] 8 Nee’ms roih ayns raad dty annaghyn: tra t’ow uss er hoiaghey my chree ec reamys.

English: The xxv. day.
Manx: The 25. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Legem pone.
Manx: Legem pone.

English: Teach me, O Lord, the way of thy Statutes : and I shal keepe it unto the end.
Manx: [33] Ynsee dou, O Hiarn, raad dty ’lattyssyn: as freill‐ym eh gys y jerrey.

English: 34 Give me understanding, and I shall keepe thy Lawe : yea, I shal keepe it with my whole heart.
Manx: [34] 2 Cur dou tushtey, as freill‐ym dty leigh: freill‐ym eh dy-jarroo lesh ooilley my chree.

English: 35 Make me to goe in the path of thy Commaundements : for therein is my desire.
Manx: [35] 3 Cur orrym dy immeeaght ayns cassan dt’annaghyn: son shen y raad ta my yeearree.

English: 36 Incline my heart unto thy testimonies : & not to covetousnes.
Manx: [36] 4 Cromm my chree gys dty recortyssyn: as cha nee gys saynt.

English: 37 O turne away mine eyes, lest they behold vanitie : and quicken thou me in thy way.
Manx: [37] 5 O chyndaa ersooyl my hooillyn, nagh der ad geill da fardail: as jean mish y vioghey ayns dty raad.

English: 38 O stablish thy word in thy servant : that I may feare thee.
Manx: [38] 6 O niartee dty ghoo ayns dty harvaant: dy voddyms aggle y ghoaill royd.

English: 39 Take away the rebuke that I am afraide of : for thy Judgements are good.
Manx: [39] 7 Gow ersooyl yn kerraghey ta mee goaill aggle roish: son ta dty vriwnyssyn mie.

English: 40 Beholde, my delight is in thy Commandements : O quicken me in thy righteousnesse.
Manx: [40] 8 Cur‐my‐ner, ta my haitnys ayns dt’annaghyn: O jean mish y vioghey ayns dty chairys.

English: Et veniat super me.
Manx: Et veniat super me.

English: Let thy loving mercie come also unto mee, O Lord : even thy salvation, according unto thy word.
Manx: [41] Lhig da dty vyghin ghraihagh cheet myrgeddin hyms, O Hiarn: dy-jarroo dty haualtys, cordail rish dty ghoo.

English: 42 So shall I make answere unto my blasphemers : for my trust is in thy word.
Manx: [[42] 2 Shen myr verr-ym ansoor da my noidyn: son ta my hreishteil ayns dty ghoo.]
This verse is absent in 1765. Restored here from 1769.

English: 43 O take not the word of thy trueth utterly out of my mouth : for my hope is in thy Judgements.
Manx: [43] 3 O ny gow yn goo dy ynrickys dy-bollagh ass my veeall: son ta my hreishteil ayns dty vriwnyssyn.

English: 44 So shal I alway keepe thy Law : yea, for ever & ever.
Manx: [44] 4 Myr shen freill‐ym dy-kinjagh dty leigh: dy-feer, son dy-bragh as dy-bragh.

English: 45 And I wil walk at libertie : for I seeke thy Commandements.
Manx: [45] 5 As nee’m gimmeeaght ec my reamys: son ta mee shirrey dt’annaghyn.

English: 46 I will speake of thy Testimonies also, even before kings : and will not be ashamed.
Manx: [46] 6 Loayr‐yms jeh dty recortyssyn myrgeddin, dy-jarroo fenish reeaghyn: as cha jean‐ym nearey ’ghoaill.

English: 47 And my delight shal be in thy Commandements : which I have loved.
Manx: [47] 7 As bee my haitnys ayns dt’annaghyn: ta mee er ve graihagh orroo.

English: 48 My handes also will I lift up unto thy Commandements, which I have loved : & my study shal be in thy statutes.
Manx: [48] 8 My laueyn neesht trogg-ym seose gys dt’annaghyn, ta mee er ve graihagh orroo: as bee my smooinaghtyn dowin er dty ’lattyssyn.

English: Memor esto verbi tui
Manx: Memor esto servi tui.

English: verbi] 1662 servi
O thinke upon thy servant, as concerning thy word : wherein thou hast caused me to put my trust.
Manx: [49] O smooinee er dty harvaant cordail rish dty ghoo: ayn t’ow er choyrt orrym dy chur my hreishteil.

English: 50 The same is my comfort in my trouble : for thy word hath quickened me.
Manx: [50] 2 Shoh ta dy my gherjaghey ayns my heaghyn: son ta dty ghoo er my vioghey.

English: 51 The proud have had mee exceedingly in derision : yet have I not shrinked from thy Law.
Manx: [51] 3 Ta mee ec ny mooaralee feer vooar ayns faghid: ny‐yeih cha vel mee er skyrraghtyn veih dty leigh.

English: 52 For I remembered thine everlasting judgements, O Lord : and received comfort.
Manx: [52] 4 Son chooinee mee er dty vriwnyssyn er dyn chenn earish, O Hiarn: as va mee er my gherjaghey.

English: 53 I am horribly afraid : for the ungodly that forsake thy law.
Manx: [53] 5 Ta mee fo aggle atchimagh: er coontey ny mee‐chrauee ta treigeil dty leigh.

English: 54 Thy statutes have bene my songs : in the house of my pilgrimage.
Manx: [54] 6 Ta dty ’lattyssyn er ve my arraneyn: ayns thie my yoarreeaght.

English: 55 I have thought upon thy Name, O Lord, in the night season : and have kept thy Law.
Manx: [55] 7 Ta mee er smooinaghtyn er dt’ Ennyms, O Hiarn, ayns earish ny hoie: as er vreayll dty leigh.

English: 56 This I had : because I kept thy Commandements.
Manx: [56] 8 Shoh va my gherjaghey: er‐y‐fa dy dreill mee dty annaghyn.

English: Portio mea Domine
Manx: Portio mea, Domine.

English: Thou art my portion, O Lord : I have promised to keepe thy Law.
Manx: [57] Uss my eiraght, O Hiarn: ta mee er yialldyn dy reayll dty leigh.

English: 58 I made my humble petition in thy presence with my whole heart : O be mercifull unto me according to thy word.
Manx: [58] 2 Ren mee my accan imlee ayns dt’enish lesh ooilley my chree: O bee myghinagh dou cordail rish dty ghoo.

English: 59 I called mine owne wayes to remembrance : and turned my feet unto thy Testimonies.
Manx: [59] 3 Deïe mee er my raaidyn hene gys cooinaghtyn: as hyndaa mee my chassyn gys dty recortyssyn.

English: 60 I made haste, and prolonged not the time : to keepe thy Commandements.
Manx: [60] 4 Ren mee siyr, as cha lhig mee shiaghey yn traa: dy reayll dty annaghyn.

English: 61 The congregations of the ungodly have robbed me : but I have not forgotten thy Law.
Manx: [61] 5 Ta sheshaghtyn ny mee‐chrauee er my roostey: agh cha vel mish er yarrood dty leigh.

English: 62 At midnight I will rise to give thankes unto thee : because of thy righteous Judgements.
Manx: [62] 6 Ec y vean-oie nee’m girree dy chur booise dhyt: er coontey dty vriwnyssyn cairagh.
