English: 63 I am a companion of all them that feare thee : and keep thy Commandements.
Manx: [63] 7 Ta mee my heshey dauesyn ooilley ta goaill aggle royd: as ta freayll dty annaghyn.

English: 64 The earth, O Lord, is full of thy mercie : O teach mee thy Statutes.
Manx: [64] 7 Ta’n seihll, O Hiarn, laane jeh dty vyghin: O ynsee dou dty ’lattyssyn.

English: Bonitatem fecisti
Manx: Bonitatem fecisti.

English: O Lord, thou hast dealt graciously with thy servant : according unto thy word.
Manx: [65] O Hiarn, t’ow er ghellal dy-graysoil rish dty harvaant: cordail rish dty ghoo.

English: 66 O learne me true understanding and knowledge : for I have beleeved thy Commandements.
Manx: [66] 2 O ynsee dou toiggal as tushtey firrinagh: son ta mee er chredjal dty annaghyn.

English: 67 Before I was troubled, I went wrong : but now have I kept thy word.
Manx: [67] 3 Roish my row mee seaghnit, hie mee er‐shaghryn: agh nish ta mee er vreayll dty ghoo.

English: 68 Thou art good & gracious : O teach me thy Statutes.
Manx: [68] 4 T’ow uss mie as graysoil: O ynsee dou dty ’lattyssyn.

English: 69 The proud have imagined a lie against me : but I will keepe thy Commandements with my whole heart.
Manx: [69] 5 Ta ny mooaralee er droggal breg orrym: agh freill‐yms dt’annaghyn lesh ooilley my chree.

English: 70 Their heart is as fat as brawne : but my delight hath been in thy Law.
Manx: [70] 6 Ta’n cree oc cha roauyr as saill: agh ta my haitnys er ve ayns dty leigh.

English: 71 It is good for me that I have bene in trouble : that I may learne thy Statutes.
Manx: [71] 7 S’mie te er my hon dy row mee ayns seaghyn: dy voddym gynsaghey dty ’lattyssyn.

English: 72 The Law of thy mouth is dearer unto me : then thousands of gold and silver.
Manx: [72] 8 Ta leigh dty veeall ny smoo dy voggey dou: na millaghyn dy airh as argid.
veeall] 1765 veall

English: The xxv. day.
Manx: The 25. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Manus tuæ fecerunt me
Manx: Manus tuæ fecerunt me.

English: Thy hands have made me and fashioned mee : O give mee understanding, that I may learne thy Commandements.
Manx: [73] Ta dty laueyn er my chroo as er my chummey: O cur dou tushtey, dy voddym gynsaghey dt’annaghyn.

English: 74 They that feare thee, will be glad when they see me : because I have put my trust in thy word.
Manx: [74] 2 Bee adsyn ta goaill aggle royd, gennal tra hee ad mee: er‐yn‐oyr dy vel mee er choyrt my hreishteil ayns dty ghoo.

English: 75 I know (O Lord) that thy Judgements are right: and that thou of very faithfulnes hast caused me to be troubled.
Manx: [75] 3 Ta fys aym, O Hiarn, dy vel dty vriwnyssyn cairagh: as dy vel oo ayns eer ynrickys er choyrt seaghyn orrym.

English: 76 O let thy mercifull kindnesse be my comfort : according to thy word unto thy servant.
Manx: [76] 4 O lhig da dty chenjallys vyghinagh ve my gherjagh: cordail rish dty ghoo da dty harvaant.

English: 77 O let thy loving mercies come unto mee, that I may live : for thy Law is my delight.
Manx: [77] 5 O lhig da dty vyghinyn graihagh cheet hyms, dy voddym ve bio: son ta my voggey ayns dty leigh.

English: 78 Let the proud be confounded, for they go wickedly about to destroy me : but I wil be occupied in thy Commandements.
Manx: [78] 6 Lhig da ny mooaralee ve coodit lesh nearey, son t’ad dy-olkyssagh goll mygeayrt dy my stroie: agh nee’ms smooinaghtyn dy-dowin er dt’annaghyn.

English: 79 Let such as feare thee, and have knowen thy Testimonies : be turned unto me.
Manx: [79] 7 Lhig dauesyn ta goaill aggle royd, as t’er hoiggal dty recortyssyn: v’er nyn jyndaa hyms.

English: 80 O let my heart be sound in thy Statutes : that I be not ashamed.
Manx: [80] 8 O lhig da my chree v’er ny hickyraghey ayns dty ’lattyssyn: nagh bee nearey orrym.

English: Defecit anima mea.
Manx: Defecit anima mea.

English: My soule hath longed for thy salvation : and I have a good hope because of thy word.
Manx: [81] Ta m’annym er ghoaill foddeeaght son dty haualtys: as ta my hreishteil mie er graih dty ghoo.

English: 82 Mine eyes long sore for thy word : saying, O when wilt thou comfort me?
Manx: [82] 2 Ta my hooillyn farkiaght dy-jeean son dty ghoo: gra, O cuinn nee oo mish y gherjaghey?

English: 83 For I am become like a bottel in the smoke : yet doe I not forget thy Statutes.
Manx: [83] 3 Son ta mee shymlit myr crackan ayns y jaagh: ny‐yeih cha vel mee jarrood dty ’lattyssyn.

English: 84 How many are the dayes of thy servant : when wilt thou be avenged of them that persecute me?
Manx: [84] 4 Cre whilleen ta laghyn dty harvaant: cuinn nee oo cooilleen y ghoaill orroosyn ta jannoo tranlaase orrym?

English: 85 The proud have digged pits for mee : which are not after thy Law.
Manx: [85] 5 Ta’n sleih moyrnagh er chleiy ooigyn er my hon: nagh vel cordail rish dty leigh.

English: 86 All thy Commandements are true : they persecute mee falsely; O be thou my helpe.
Manx: [86] 6 Ta ooilley dt’annaghyn firrinagh: t’ad jannoo tranlaase orrym dy-aggairagh; O bee uss my niart.

English: 87 They had almost made an ende of me upon earth : but I forsooke not thy Commandements.
Manx: [87] 7 V’ad faggys er n’yannoo kione orrym er y thalloo: agh cha hreig mee dt’annaghyn.

English: 88 O quicken mee after thy loving kindnesse : and so shall I keepe the testimonies of thy mouth.
Manx: [88] 8 O jean mish y vioghey lurg dty chenjallys-ghraihagh: as myr shen freill‐ym recortyssyn dty veeall.

English: In æternum Domine.
Manx: In æternum, Domine.

English: O Lord, thy word : endureth for ever in heaven.
Manx: [89] O Hiarn, ta dty ghoo: farraghtyn son dy-bragh ayns niau.

English: 90 Thy trueth also remaineth from one generation to another : thou hast layd the foundation of the earth, and it abideth.
Manx: [90] 2 Ta dt’irriney myrgeddin farraghtyn veih sheeloghe gys sheeloghe: t’ow er hoiaghey undin ny hooirey, as te er‐mayrn.

English: 91 They continue this day according to thine ordinance : for all things serve thee.
Manx: [91] 3 T’ad tannaghtyn gys y laa t’ayn jiu cordail rish dty oardagh: son ta dy-chooilley nhee dy dty hirveish.

English: 92 If my delight had not bene in thy Lawe : I should have perished in my trouble.
Manx: [92] 4 Er-be dy row my voggey ayns dty leigh: veïn er cherraghtyn ayns my heaghyn.
cherraghtyn] 1777 herraghtyn

English: 93 I will never forget thy Commaundements : for with them thou hast quickened me.
Manx: [93] 5 Cha jarrood‐ym dt’annaghyn dy-bragh: son lioroosyn t’ow er my vioghey.

English: 94 I am thine, O save mee : for I have sought thy Commandements.
Manx: [94] 6 Ta mee lhiats; O saue mee: son ta mee er hirrey lurg dt’annaghyn.

English: 95 The ungodly layde waite for me, to destroy me : but I will consider thy Testimonies.
Manx: [95] 7 Ren ny mee‐chrauee lhie ayns farkiaght er my hon dy my stroie: agh smooinee‐yms er dty recortyssyn.

English: 96 I see that all things come to an end : but thy Commandement is exceeding broad.
Manx: [96] 8 Ta mee fakin dy vel jerrey er dy-chooilley nhee: agh ta dt’annaghyn er-skyn-towse lhean.

English: Quomodo dilexi.
Manx: Quomodo dilexi!

English: Lord, what love have I unto thy Law : all the day long is my studie in it.
Manx: [97] Hiarn, cre’n ghraih t’ayms er dty leigh: fey‐ny‐laa ta mee smooinaghtyn er dy-dowin.

English: 98 Thou through thy Commandements hast made me wiser then mine enemies : for they are ever with me.
Manx: [98] 2 T’ow uss trooid dt’annaghyn er my yannoo ny s’creeney na my noidyn: son t’ad dy-kinjagh mârym.

English: 99 I have more understanding then my teachers : for thy Testimonies are my studie.
Manx: [99] 3 Ta ny smoo dy hushtey aym na t’ec my ir‐ynsee: son ayns dty recortyssyn ta mee baarail my smooinaghtyn.

English: 100 I am wiser then the aged : because I keepe thy Commandements.
Manx: [100] 4 Ta mee ny s’creeney n’yn chenndeeaght: er‐yn‐oyr dy vel mee freayll dt’annaghyn.

English: 101 I have refrained my feete from every evill way : that I may keepe thy word.
Manx: [101] 5 Ta mee er chummal my chassyn veih dy-chooilley ghrogh raad: dy voddin freayll dty ghoo.

English: 102 I have not shrunke from thy Judgements : for thou teachest me.
Manx: [102] 6 Cha vel mee er skyrraghtyn veih dty vriwnyssyn: son t’ow dy my ynsaghey.

English: 103 O how sweete are thy wordes unto my throat : yea, sweeter then honie unto my mouth.
Manx: [103] 7 O cre cha millish ta dty ghoan gys my vlass: dy-jarroo, ny s’miljey na mill da my veeall!

English: 104 Through thy Commaundements I get understanding : therefore I hate all wicked wayes.
Manx: [104] 8 Trooid dt’annaghyn ta mee geddyn tushtey: shen‐y‐fa ta dwoaie aym er dy-chooilley ghrogh raad.

English: wicked] 1662 evill
The xxvi. day.
Manx: The 26. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Lucerna pedibus meis.
Manx: Lucerna pedibus meis.

English: Thy word is a lanterne unto my feete : and a light unto my paths.
Manx: [105] Ta dty ghoo londeyr da my chassyn: as soilshey da my chesmadyn.

English: 106 I have sworne, and am stedfastly purposed : to keepe thy righteous Judgements.
Manx: [106] 2 Ta mee er vreearrey, as ta mee dy-shickyr kiarit: dy reayll dty vriwnyssyn.

English: 107 I am troubled above measure : quicken mee (O Lord) according to thy word.
Manx: [107] 3 Ta mee seaghnit er-skyn towse: jean mish y vioghey, O Hiarn, cordail rish dty ghoo.

English: 108 Let the free will offerings of my mouth please thee, O Lord : and teach me thy Judgements.
Manx: [108] 4 Lhig da ourallyn-arryltagh my veeall uss y wooiys, O Hiarn: as ynsee dou dty vriwnyssyn.

English: 109 My soule is alway in my hand : yet do I not forget thy Law.
Manx: [109] 5 Ta m’annym dy-kinjagh ayns my laue: ny‐yeih cha vel mee jarrood dty leigh.

English: 110 The ungodly have laid a snare for me : but yet I swarved not from thy Commandements.
Manx: [110] 6 Ta ny mee‐chrauee er hoiaghey ribbeh er my hon: agh ny‐yeih cha jagh mee er‐shaghryn veih dty annaghyn.

English: 111 Thy testimonies have I claimed as mine heritage for ever : and why? they are the very joy of my heart.
Manx: [111] 7 Dty recortyssyn ta mee er hirrey myr m’eiraght son dy-bragh: as cre’n‐fa? t’ad eer boggey my chree.

English: 112 I have applied my heart to fulfil thy Statutes alway : even unto the end.
Manx: [112] 8 Ta mee er chrommey my chree dy chooilleeney dty ’lattyssyn dy-kinjagh: dy-jarroo gys y jerrey.

English: Iniquos odio habui.
Manx: Iniquos odio habui.

English: I hate them that imagine evill things : but thy Law doe I love.
Manx: [113] Ta dwoaie aym orroosyn ta smooinaghtyn er yn olk: agh shynney lhiam dty leigh.

English: 114 Thou art my defence and shielde : and my trust is in thy word.
Manx: [114] 2 T’ow uss my endeilagh as my choadey: as ta my hreishteil ayns dty ghoo.

English: 115 Away from me ye wicked : I wil keepe the Commandements of my God.
Manx: [115] 3 Ass my enish, shiuish ghrogh‐yantee: freill‐yms annaghyn my Yee.

English: 116 O stablish me according to thy word, that I may live : and let me not be disappointed of my hope.
Manx: [116] 4 O niartee mee cordail rish dty ghoo, dy voddym ’ve beayn: as ny lhig dou tuittym giare jeh my hreishteil.

English: 117 Hold thou mee up, and I shall be safe : yea, my delight shall be ever in thy Statutes.
Manx: [117] 5 Jean uss mish y chummal seose, as bee’m sauchey: bee my haitnys dy-jarroo ayns dty ’lattyssyn.

English: 118 Thou hast troden downe all them that depart from thy Statutes : for they imagine but deceit.
Manx: [118] 6 T’ow uss er choyrt fo-chosh adsyn ooilley ta cur cooyl rish dty ’lattyssyn: son cha vel ad smooinaghtyn agh er molteyraght.

English: 119 Thou puttest away all the ungodly of the earth like drosse : therefore I love thy Testimonies.
Manx: [119] 7 T’ow sheebey ersooyl ooilley mee‐chrauee yn thallooin myr kesh: shen‐y‐fa shynney lhiam dty recortyssyn.

English: 120 My flesh trembleth for feare of thee : and I am afraid of thy Judgements.
Manx: [120] 8 Ta my eill er‐creau son aggle jeeds: as ta mee fo atchim dty vriwnyssyn.

English: Feci iudicium.
Manx: Feci judicium.

English: I deale with the thing that is lawfull and right : O give me not over unto mine oppressors.
Manx: [121] Ta mee dellal ayns y chooish ta lowal as jeeragh: O ny faag mee fo pooar my hranlaasee.

English: 122 Make thou thy servant to delight in that which is good : that the proud do me no wrong.
Manx: [122] 2 Cur er dty harvaant dy ghoaill taitnys ayns shen ny ta mie: nagh jean ny mooaralee veg yn aggair dou.

English: 123 Mine eyes are wasted away with looking for thy health : and for the word of thy righteousnesse.
Manx: [123] 3 Ta my hoilshey er vailleil lesh jeeaghyn son dty lhaynt: as son goo dty chairys.

English: 124 O deale with thy servant according unto thy loving mercie : and teach me thy Statutes.
Manx: [124] 4 O dell rish dty harvaant cordail rish dty vyghin ghraihagh: as ynsee dou dty ’lattyssyn.

English: 125 I am thy servant, O grant me understanding : that I may know thy testimonies.
Manx: [125] 5 Ta mish dty harvaant; O cur dou tushtey: dy voddym toiggal dty ’lattyssyn.

English: 126 It is time for thee Lord to lay to thine hand : for they have destroyed thy Law.
Manx: [126] 6 Te traa dhyt, Hiarn, dy hroggal dty laue: son t’ad er choyrt naardey dty leigh.

English: 127 For I love thy Commandements : above golde and precious stone.
Manx: [127] 7 Son shynney lhiam dty annaghyn: er-skyn airh as claghyn costal.

English: 128 Therefore hold I streight all thy Commandements : and all false wayes I utterly abhorre.
Manx: [128] 8 Shen‐y‐fa ta mee cummal jeeragh ayns ooilley dty annaghyn: agh son raaidyn cammey ta slane dwoaie aym orroo ooilley.

English: Mirabilia.
Manx: Mirabilia.

English: Thy testimonies are wonderfull : therefore doeth my soule keepe them.
Manx: [129] Ta dty recortyssyn yindyssagh: shen‐y‐fa ta m’annym dy reayll ad.

English: 130 When thy word goeth forth : it giveth light and understanding unto the simple.
Manx: [130] 2 Tra ta dty ghoo goll magh: te coyrt soilshey as creenaght da’n vooinjer ôney.

English: 131 I opened my mouth, and drew in my breath : for my delight was in thy Commandements.
Manx: [131] 3 Doshil mee my veeall, as ghow mee ennal: son ta my haitnys ayns dt’annaghyn.
veeall] 1765 veall

English: 132 O looke thou upon me, and be mercifull unto mee : as thou usest to doe unto those that love thy Name.
Manx: [132] 4 O jeeagh orrym, as bee myghinagh dou: myr b’oallagh oo jannoo roosyn ta graihagh er dt’ Ennym.

English: 133 Order my steps in thy word : and so shall no wickednesse have dominion over me.
Manx: [133] 5 Jean my chesmadyn y leeideil ayns dty ghoo: as myr shen cha vow mee‐chraueeaght erbee barriaght orrym.

English: 134 O deliver me from the wrongfull dealings of men : and so shall I keep thy Commandements.
Manx: [134] 6 O livrey mee veih tranlaase drogh gheiney: as myr shen freill‐ym dt’annaghyn.

English: 135 Shew the light of thy countenance upon thy servant : and teach me thy Statutes.
Manx: [135] 7 Lhig da dt’eddin soilshean er dty harvaant: as ynsee dou dty ’lattyssyn.

English: 136 Mine eyes gush out with water : because men keep not thy Law.
Manx: [136] 8 Ta my hooillyn shilley lesh jeïr: er‐yn‐oyr nagh vel deiney freayll dty leigh.

English: Iustus es Domine.
Manx: Justus es, Domine.

English: Righteous art thou, O Lord : and true is thy judgement.
Manx: [137] T’ow uss cairagh, O Hiarn: as ynrick ta dty vriwnyssyn.

English: 138 The Testimonies that thou hast commanded : are exceeding righteous and true.
Manx: [138] 2 Ny recortyssyn t’ow uss er n’oardaghey: t’ad er-skyn-towse cairagh as firrinagh.

English: 139 My zeale hath even consumed mee : because mine enemies have forgotten thy words.
Manx: [139] 3 Ta my ghraih’s jeean er my choyrt eer naardey: son dy vel my noidyn er yarrood dty ghoan.

English: 140 Thy word is tried to the uttermost : and thy servant loveth it.
Manx: [140] 4 Ta dty ghoo’s er ny phrowal gys y chooid sodjey: as ta graih ec dty harvaant er.

English: 141 I am small, and of no reputation : yet do I not forget thy Commandements.
Manx: [141] 5 Ta mee fardalagh, as beg er ny hoiaghey jee’m: ny‐yeih cha vel mee jarrood dt’annaghyn.

English: 142 Thy righteousnesse is an everlasting righteousnesse : and thy Law is the trueth.
Manx: [142] 6 Ta’n chairys ayds cairys dy-bragh farraghtyn: as dty leigh yn irriney.

English: 143 Trouble and heavinesse have taken hold upon me : yet is my delight in thy Commandements.
Manx: [143] 7 Ta seaghyn as trimshey er ghoaill greme orrym: ny‐yeih ta my haitnys ayns dt’annaghyn.

English: 144 The righteousnesse of thy Testimonies is everlasting : O grant me understanding, and I shall live.
Manx: [144] 8 Ta cairys dty recortyssyn dy-bragh farraghtyn: O giall dou tushtey, as bee’m bio.

English: The xxvi. day.
Manx: The 26. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Clamaui in toto corde meo
Manx: Clamavi in toto corde meo.

English: I call with my whole heart : heare me, O Lord, I will keepe thy Statutes.
Manx: [145] Ta mee geamagh lesh ooilley my chree: eaisht rhym, O Hiarn, freill‐ym dty ’lattyssyn.

English: 146 Yea, even unto thee doe I call : helpe me, and I shall keepe thy Testimonies.
Manx: [146] 2 Hoods, dy-feer, ta mee geamagh: cooin lhiam, as freill‐ym dty recortyssyn.

English: 147 Earely in the morning doe I cry unto thee : for in thy word is my trust.
Manx: [147] 3 Ec brishey’n laa ta mee geamagh hoods: son ayns dty ghoo ta my hreishteil.

English: 148 Mine eyes prevent the night watches : that I might be occupied in thy words.
Manx: [148] 4 Ta my hooillyn dooisht roish arrey ny hoie: dy voddym my hraa ’vaarail ayns dty ghoan.

English: 149 Hear my voyce (O Lord) according unto thy loving kindnesse : quicken me, according as thou art wont.
Manx: [149] 5 Clasht rish my choraa, O Hiarn, cordail rish dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh: cur bree ayn-ym myr b’oallagh oo.

English: 150 They draw nigh that of malice persecute mee : and are farre from thy Law.
Manx: [150] 6 T’ad tayrn er‐gerrey ta dy-goanlyssagh jannoo tranlaase orrym: as t’ad foddey veih dty leigh.

English: 151 Be thou nigh at hand, O Lord : for all thy Commandements are true.
Manx: [151] 7 Bee uss er‐gerrey ec laue, O Hiarn: son ta ooilley dty annaghyn firrinagh.

English: 152 As concerning thy Testimonies, I have knowen long since : that thou hast grounded them for ever.
Manx: [152] 8 Mychione dt’annaghyn, ta fys aym foddey er dy henney: dy vel oo er hoiaghey ad er undin shickyr son dy-bragh.

English: Vide humilitatem
Manx: Vide humilitatem.

English: O consider mine adversitie, and deliver me: for I doe not forget thy Law.
Manx: [153] O smooinee er my arkys, as livrey mee: son cha vel mee jarrood dty leigh.

English: 154 Avenge thou my cause, and deliver mee : quicken me according to thy word.
Manx: [154] 2 Gow my chooish ayns laue as livrey mee: jean mee y vioghey cordail rish dty ghoo.

English: 155 Health is farre from the ungodly : for they regard not thy Statutes.
Manx: [155] 3 Ta slaynt foddey voish ny mee‐chrauee: son cha vel ad cur geill da dty ’lattyssyn.

English: 156 Great is thy mercie, O Lord : quicken me, as thou art wont.
Manx: [156] 4 S’mooar ta dty vyghin, O Hiarn: jean mee y vioghey myr b’oallagh oo.

English: 157 Many there are that trouble me, and persecute me : yet doe I not swarve from thy Testimonies.
Manx: [157] 5 Shimmey adsyn ta dy my voirey as jannoo tranlaase orrym: ny‐yeih cha vel mish goll dy-lhiattee voish dty recortyssyn.

English: 158 It grieveth mee when I see the transgressours : because they keepe not thy Law.
Manx: [158] 6 Te trimshey dou dy akin ny drogh‐yantee: son nagh vel ad freayll dty leigh.

English: 159 Consider, O Lord, how I love thy Commandements : O quicken me according to thy loving kindnesse.
Manx: [159] 7 Smooinee, O Hiarn, kys shynney lhiam dty annaghyn: O jean mish y vioghey cordail rish dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh.

English: 160 Thy word is true from everlasting : all the Judgements of thy righteousnesse endure for evermore.
Manx: [160] 8 Ta dty ghoo’s firrinagh er dy rieau: ta ooilley briwnyssyn dty chairys farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: Principes persecuti sunt
Manx: Principes persecuti sunt.

English: Princes have persecuted me without a cause: but my heart standeth in awe of thy words.
Manx: [161] Ta prinsyn er n’yannoo tranlaase orrym gyn oyr: agh ta my chree shassoo ayns aggle jeh dty ghoo.

English: thy words.] 1662 thy word.
162 I am as glad of thy Word : as one that findeth great spoyles.
Manx: [162] 2 Ta wheesh dy voggey aym jeh dty ghoo: as t’ec fer ta cosney mooarane spooilley.

English: 163 As for lies, I hate and abhorre them : but thy Law doe I love.
Manx: [163] 3 Er son breagyn, ta feoh as dwoaie aym orroo: agh shynney lhiam dty leigh.

English: 164 Seven times a day doe I praise thee : because of thy righteous Judgements.
Manx: [164] 4 Shiaght keayrtyn ’sy laa ta mee dy dty voylley: er graih dty vriwnyssyn cairagh.

English: 165 Great is the peace that they have which love thy Law : and they are not offended at it.
Manx: [165] 5 S’mooar ta’n shee t’ocsyn ta graihagh er dty leigh: as cha der nhee erbee orroo eh y hreigeil.

English: which] 1662 who
166 Lord, I have looked for thy saving health : and done after thy Commandements.
Manx: [166] 6 Hiarn, ta mee er yeeaghyn son dty haualtys slayntoil: as er n’yannoo lurg dty annaghyn.

English: 167 My soule hath kept thy Testimonies : and loved them exceedingly.
Manx: [167] 7 Ta m’annym er vreayll dty recortyssyn: as er choyrt graih er-skyn-towse daue.

English: 168 I have kept thy Commandements and Testimonies : for all my wayes are before thee.
Manx: [168] 8 Ta mee er vreayll dt’annaghyn as dty recortyssyn: son ta ooilley my raaidyn kiongoyrt rhyt.

English: Appropinquet deprecatio
Manx: Appropinquet deprecatio.

English: Let my complaint come before thee, O Lord : give me understanding according to thy word.
Manx: [169] Lhig da my accan cheet kiongoyrt rhyt, O Hiarn: cur dou tushtey cordail rish dty ghoo.

English: 170 Let my supplication come before thee : deliver me according to thy word.
Manx: [170] 2 Lhig da my aghin cheet gys dt’enish: livrey mee cordail rish dty ghoo.

English: 171 My lippes shall speake of thy praise : when thou hast taught me thy Statutes.
Manx: [171] 3 Nee my veillyn fockley magh dty voylley: tra t’ow er m’ynsaghey ayns dty ’lattyssyn;

English: 172 Yea, my tongue shall sing of thy word : for all thy Commandements are righteous.
Manx: [172] 4 Dy-jarroo nee my hengey’s arrane y ghoaill jeh dty ghoo: son ta ooilley dt’annaghyn cairagh.

English: 173 Let thine hand helpe me : for I have chosen thy Commandements.
Manx: [173] 5 Lhig da dty laue cooney lhiam: son ta mee er ghoaill dty annaghyn myr reih.

English: 174 I have longed for thy saving health, O Lord : and in thy Law is my delight.
Manx: [174] 6 Ghow mee foddeeaght son dty haualtys slayntoil, O Hiarn: as ayns dty leigh ta my haitnys.

English: 175 O let my soule live, and it shall praise thee : and thy Judgements shall helpe me.
Manx: [175] 7 O lhig da m’annym ’ve bio, as nee eh uss y voylley: as nee dty vriwnyssyn cooney lhiam.

English: 176 I have gone astray like a sheepe that is lost : Oh seeke thy servant, for I doe not forget thy Commandements.
Manx: [176] 8 Ta mee er n’gholl er‐shaghryn myr keyrrey chailjey: O cur lhiat thie dty harvaant; son cha vel mee jarrood dty annaghyn.

English: The xxvii. day.
Manx: The 27. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Ad Dominum. Psal. 120
Manx: Psal. 120. Ad Dominum.

English: When I was in trouble I called upon the Lord : and he heard me.
Manx: 1 Tra va mee ayns seaghyn deïe mee gys y Chiarn: as ren eh m’y chlashtyn.

English: 2 Deliver my soule, O Lord, from lying lips : and from a deceitful tongue.
Manx: 2 Livrey m’annym’s, O Hiarn, veih meillyn breagagh: as veih chengey molteyragh.

English: 3 What reward shall bee given or done unto thee thou false tongue : even mighty and sharpe arrowes, with hote burning coales.
Manx: 3 Cre’n leagh vees er ny choyrt ny er ny yannoo dhyts, O hengey oalsey: dy-jarroo sideyn lajer as gear, lesh smaraagyn jiarg loshtee.

English: 4 Woe is mee, that I am constrained to dwell with Mesech : and to have my habitation among the tents of Cedar.
Manx: 4 Smerg dou dy vel mee êginit dy chummal marish Mesech: as dy vel my ynnyd‐vaghee mastey cabbaneyn Kedar!

English: 5 My soule hath long dwelt among them : that bee enemies unto peace.
Manx: 5 Ta m’annym’s er chummal foddey ny‐vud ocsyn: ta nyn noidyn da shee.

English: that bee] 1662 that are
6 I labour for peace, but when I speake unto them thereof : they make them ready to battell.
Manx: 6 Ta mee strieu son shee, agh cha vel mee ny‐sleaih loayrt roosyn jeh shen: nagh vel ad jannoo ad hene aarloo gys caggey.

English: Leuaui oculos. Psal. 121.
Manx: Psal. 121. Levavi oculos.

English: I will lift up mine eyes unto the hilles : from whence commeth my helpe.
Manx: 1 Trogg‐ym seose my hooillyn gys ny croink: vouesyn ta my chooney cheet.

English: 2 My helpe commeth even from the Lord : which hath made heaven and earth.
Manx: 2 Ta my chooney cheet dy-feer veih’n Chiarn: t’er chroo niau as thalloo.

English: which] 1662 who
3 He wil not suffer thy foote to be mooved : and hee that keepeth thee, will not sleepe.
Manx: 3 Cha lhig eh da dty chass dy v’er ny scughey: as cha jean eshyn cadley ta dt’endeil.

English: 4 Behold, he that keepeth Israel : shall neither slumber nor sleepe.
Manx: 4 Cur‐my‐ner, cha jean eshyn ta freayll Israel: saveenagh ny cadley.

English: 5 The Lord himselfe is thy keeper : the Lord is thy defence upon thy right hand;
Manx: 5 Ta’n Chiarn hene dt’endeilagh: ta’n Chiarn dty niart er dty laue yesh;

English: 6 So that the Sunne shall not burne thee by day : neither the Moone by night.
Manx: 6 Myr shen nagh jean chiass ny greïney oo y lostey ’sy laa: n’yn eayst ’syn oie.

English: 7 The Lord shall preserve thee from all evill : yea, it is even he that shall keepe thy soule.
Manx: 7 Nee’n Chiarn uss y choadey veih dy-chooilley olk: dy-jarroo eshyn eh nee dt’annym y reayll.

English: 8 The Lord shall preserve thy going out and thy coming in : from this time foorth for evermore.
Manx: 8 Freill‐ee yn Chiarn dty gholl magh as dty heet stiagh: veih’n traa shoh magh er son dy-bragh.

English: Lætatus sum. Psal. 122.
Manx: Psal. 122. Lætatus sum.

English: I was glad when they said unto me : Wee will goe into the house of the Lord.
Manx: 1 S’mooar va my voggey tra dooyrt ad rhym: Nee mayd goll gys thie’n Chiarn.

English: 2 Our feet shal stand in thy gates : O Hierusalem.
Manx: 2 Shassee ny cassyn ainyn ayns dty yiattyn: O Yerusalem.

English: 3 Hierusalem is built as a Citie : that is at unitie in it selfe.
Manx: 3 Ta Jerusalem troggit myr ard‐valley: ta ec unnaneys ayn hene.

English: 4 For thither the Tribes goe up, even the Tribes of the Lord : to testifie unto Israel, to give thanks unto the Name of the Lord.
Manx: 4 Son gys shen ta ny kynneeyn goll seose, dy-jarroo kynneeyn y Chiarn: dy ymmyrkey feanish da Israel, dy choyrt booise da Ennym y Chiarn.

English: 5 For there is the seat of Judgement : even the seat of the house of David.
Manx: 5 Son shen y raad ta stoyl y vriwnys: dy-jarroo stoyl‐reeoil lught‐thie Ghavid.

English: 6 O pray for the peace of Jerusalem : they shall prosper that love thee.
Manx: 6 O guee‐jee son shee Yerusalem: nee adsyn bishaghey ta graihagh ort.

English: that] 1605 tha
7 Peace be within thy walles : and plenteousnesse within thy palaces.
Manx: 7 Shee dy row cheu‐sthie jeh dty voallaghyn: as sonnys cheu‐sthie jeh dty chooyrtyn.

English: 8 For my brethren and companions sakes : I will wish thee prosperitie.
Manx: 8 Er graih my vraaraghyn as my heshaghyn dooie: guee‐ym son dty vaynrys.

English: 9 Yea, because of the house of the Lord our God : I will seeke to doe thee good.
Manx: 9 Dy-jarroo, son graih chiamble y Chiarn nyn Yee: shirr‐ym dy choyrt dty vie er y hoshiaght.

English: Ad te leuaui oculos meos. Psal. 123.
Manx: Psal. 123. Ad te levavi oculos.

English: Unto thee lift I up mine eyes : O thou that dwellest in the heavens.
Manx: 1 Hoods ta mee troggal seose my hooillyn: O uss ta cummal ayns ny niaughyn.

English: 2 Beholde, even as the eyes of servants looke unto the hand of their masters, and as the eyes of a mayden unto the hand of her mystresse : even so our eyes waite upon the Lord our God, untill he have mercy upon us.
Manx: 2 Cur‐my‐ner, myr ta sooillyn ny fir‐vooinjerey jeeaghyn gys laue nyn mainshtyr, as myr ta sooillyn yn inney‐veyl gys laue e ben-’ainshtyr: dy-jarroo myr shen ta ny sooillyn ainyn farkiaght er y Chiarn nyn Yee, derrey nee eh myghin orrin.

English: 3 Have mercie upon us, O Lord, have mercie upon us : for we are utterly despised.
Manx: 3 Jean myghin orrin, O Hiarn, jean myghin orrin: son cha vel veg eddyr dy hoiaghey j’in.

English: 4 Our soule is filled with the scornefull reproofe of the wealthy : and with the despitefulnesse of the proud.
Manx: 4 Ta nyn annym lhieent lesh oltooan craidoilagh ny berchee: as lesh goanlys ny mooaralee.

English: Nisi quia Dominus. Psal. 124.
Manx: Psal. 124. Nisi quia Dominus.

English: If the Lord himselfe had not bene on our side (now may Israel say :) if the Lord himselfe had not bene on our side, when men rose up against us;
Manx: 1 Er‐be dy row yn Chiarn hene er nyn lieh, foddee Israel nish gra: er‐be dy row yn Chiarn hene er nyn lieh, tra dirree sleih seose nyn ’oï;

English: 2 They had swallowed us up quicke : when they were so wrathfully displeased at us.
Manx: 2 Veagh ad er nyn sluggey sheese bio: tra v’ad cha eulyssagh ayns corree rooin.

English: 3 Yea, the waters had drowned us : and the streame had gone over our soule.
Manx: 3 Veagh ny hushtaghyn, dy-feer, er vaih shin: as veagh y thooilley er n’gholl harrish nyn annym.

English: 4 The deepe waters of the proude : had gone even over our soule.
Manx: 4 Veagh ushtaghyn dowin ny mooaralee: er n’gholl eer harrish nyn anmeenyn.

English: 5 But praised be the Lord : which hath not given us over for a pray unto their teeth.
Manx: 5 Agh moylley dy row gys y Chiarn: nagh vel er livrey shin seose son spooilley da ny feeacklyn oc.

English: which] 1662 who
6 Our soule is escaped, even as a birde out of the snare of the fouler : the snare is broken, and we are delivered.
Manx: 6 Ta’n annym ain er scapail, dy-jarroo myr ushag ass ribbeh yn shelgeyr: ta’n ribbeh er ny vrishey, as ta shin er nyn livrey.
ushag] 1765, 1769 ushagh

English: 7 Our helpe standeth in the Name of the Lord : which hath made heaven and earth.
Manx: 7 Ta’n cooney ainyn shassoo ayns Ennym y Chiarn: ta er chroo niau as thalloo.

English: which] 1662 who
Qui confidunt. Psal. 125.
Manx: Psal. 125. Qui confidunt.

English: They that put their trust in the Lord, shall be even as the mount Sion : which may not be remooved, but standeth fast for ever.
Manx: 1 Bee adsyn ta coyrt nyn dreishteil ayns y Chiarn, dy-jarroo myr cronk Sion: nagh vod v’er ny scughey, agh ta shassoo shickyr er son dy-bragh.

English: 2 The hilles stand about Hierusalem : even so standeth the Lord round about his people, from this time foorth for evermore.
Manx: 2 Myr ta ny croink soit dy-cruinn mygeayrt Jerusalem: dy-jarroo myr shen ta’n Chiarn mygeayrt e phobble, veih’n traa shoh magh er son dy-bragh.

English: 3 For the rod of the ungodly commeth not into the lot of the righteous : lest the righteous put their hand unto wickednesse.
Manx: 3 Son cha jig lorg ny mee‐chrauee er cronney yn vooinjer chairal: son nagh der y sleih cairal nyn laue gys olkys.

English: 4 Doe well, O Lord : unto those that bee good and true of heart.
Manx: 4 Jean mie, O Hiarn: dauesyn ta mie as firrinagh ayns cree.

English: bee] 1662 are
5 As for such as turne backe unto their owne wickednes : the Lord shal leade them forth with the evil doers; but peace shal be upon Israel.
Manx: 5 Er son nyn lheid as ta chyndaa reesht gys yn olkys oc hene: leeid-ee yn Chiarn ad magh marish ny drogh‐yantee; agh bee shee er Israel.

English: The xxvii. day.
Manx: The 27. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: In conuertendo. Psal. 126.
Manx: Psal. 126. In convertendo.

English: When the Lord turned againe the captivitie of Sion : then were we like unto them that dreame.
Manx: 1 Tra hug y Chiarn chyndaa da cappeeys Sion: eisht va shin goll-rish sleih va dreamal.

English: 2 Then was our mouth filled with laughter : and our tongue with joy.
Manx: 2 Eisht va nyn meeall lhieent lesh gennallys: as y chengey ain lesh boggey.

English: 3 Then saide they among the Heathen : The Lord hath done great things for them.
Manx: 3 Shen y traa dooyrt ad mastey ny ashoonee: Ta’n Chiarn er n’yannoo reddyn mooarey er ny son oc.

English: 4 Yea, the Lord hath done great things for us already : whereof we rejoyce.
Manx: 4 Ta’n Chiarn, dy-feer, er n’yannoo hannah reddyn yindyssagh er nyn son: jeu ta shin goaill boggey.

English: 5 Turne our captivitie, O Lord : as the rivers in the South.
Manx: 5 Cur chyndaa da’n chappeeys ain, O Hiarn: myr da ny awinyn ayns y jiass.

English: 6 They that sow in teares : shall reape in joy.
Manx: 6 Adsyn ta cuirr ayns jeïr: nee ad buinn ayns boggey.

English: 7 Hee that now goeth on his way weeping, and beareth foorth good seed : shall doubtlesse come againe with joy, and bring his sheaves with him.
Manx: 7 Eshyn ta nish goll er e hoshiaght keayney, as ta cuirr rass mie: hig eh reesht dyn dooyt lesh gennallys, as ver eh lesh e vunneeyn mârish.

English: Nisi Dominus. Psal. 127.
Manx: Psal. 127. Nisi Dominus.

English: Except the Lord builde the house : their labour is but lost that build it.
Manx: 1 Mannagh vel y Chiarn troggal y thie: ta’n obbyr oc ayns fardail ta dy hroggal eh.

English: 2 Except the Lord keepe the Citie : the watchman waketh but in vaine.
Manx: 2 Mannagh vel y Chiarn freayll yn ard‐valley: ta’n arreyder dooisht ayns fardail.

English: 3 It is but lost labour that ye haste to rise up earely, and so late take rest, and eate the bread of carefulnesse : for so he giveth his beloved sleepe.
Manx: 3 Cha vel eh agh obbyr callit dy vel shiu ayns siyr dy irree dy-moghey, as cha anmagh goaill fea, as gee yn arran dy imnea: son shen myr t’eh coyrt cadley dauesyn shynney lesh.

English: 4 Loe, children and the fruit of the wombe : are an heritage and gift that commeth of the Lord.
Manx: 4 Cur‐jee my‐ner, cloan as mess y vrein: t’ad eiraght as gioot ta cheet veih’n Chiarn.

English: 5 Like as the arrowes in the hand of the Giant : even so are the yong children.
Manx: 5 Myr ta ny sideyn ayns laue yn dooinney lajer: eer myr shen ta’n chloan aegey.
ny sideyn] 1819 sideyn

English: 6 Happy is the man that hath his quiver full of them : they shall not bee ashamed when they speake with their enemies in the gate.
Manx: 6 S’maynrey yn dooinney ta’n quhiver echey laane jeu: cha bee nearey orroo tra t’ad coyrt eddin da nyn noidyn ayns y yiatt.

English: Beati omnes. Psal. 128.
Manx: Psal. 128. Beati omnes.

English: Blessed are all they that feare the Lord : and walke in his wayes.
Manx: 1 Bannit t’adsyn ooilley ta goaill aggle roish y Chiarn: as ta gimmeeaght ayns e raaidyn.

English: 2 For thou shalt eate the labours of thine handes : O well is thee, and happy shalt thou be.
Manx: 2 Son nee oo gee jeh laboraght dty laueyn: O s’mie t’ow, as s’maynrey vees oo.

English: 3 Thy wife shal be as the fruitfull Vine : upon the walls of thine house.
Manx: 3 Bee dty ven myr y billey‐feeyney messoil, er voallaghyn dty hie;

English: 4 Thy children like the Olive branches : round about thy table.
Manx: 4 Dty chloan goll‐rish ny banglaneyn‐olive: mygeayrt‐y‐mysh dty voayrd.

English: 5 Loe, thus shall the man bee blessed : that feareth the Lord.
Manx: 5 Cur‐my‐ner, myr shoh vees y dooinney bannit: ta goaill aggle roish y Chiarn.

English: 6 The Lord from out of Sion shall so blesse thee : that thou shalt see Hierusalem in prosperitie all thy life long.
Manx: 6 Nee yn Chiarn magh ass Sion myr shen oo y vannaghey: dy vaik oo Jerusalem ayns maynrys ooilley laghyn dty vea;

English: 7 Yea, that thou shalt see thy childrens children: and peace upon Israel.
Manx: 7 Dy-jarroo, dy vaik oo cloan dty chlienney: as shee er Israel.

English: Sæpe expugnauerunt. Psal. 129.
Manx: Psal. 129. Sæpe expugnaverunt.

English: Many a time have they fought against me from my youth up : (may Israel now say.)
Manx: 1 Shimmey keayrt t’ad er chaggey m’oï veih my aegid: foddee Israel nish gra;

English: 2 Yea, many a time have they vexed me from my youth up : but they have not prevailed against me.
Manx: 2 Dy-jarroo, shimmey keayrt t’ad er n’yannoo tranlaase orrym veih m’aegid derrey nish: agh cha vel ad er chosney orrym.

English: 3 The plowers plowed upon my backe : and made long furrowes.
Manx: 3 Ta ny errooyn er chreaue er my ghreeym: as er n’yannoo creaghyn liauyrey;
chreaue] 1777 hraaue

English: 4 But the righteous Lord : hath hewen the snares of the ungodly in pieces.
Manx: 4 Agh ta’n Chiarn cairagh: er vrishey ribbaghyn ny mee‐chrauee dy peeishyn.

English: 5 Let them bee confounded and turned backward: as many as have evill will at Sion.
Manx: 5 Lhig dauesyn v’er nyn goyrt gys nearey as er nyn gastey: whilleen as t’ayns drogh-aigney gys Sion.
goyrt] 1765, 1769 ghoyrt

English: 6 Let them bee even as the grasse growing upon the house tops : which withereth afore it be plucked up;
Manx: 6 Dy-jarroo, lhig daue ’ve myr y faiyr gaase er mullagh y thie: ta fioghey roish my te slane er n’aase;

English: 7 Whereof the mower filleth not his hand : neither hee that bindeth up the sheaves, his bosome.
Manx: 7 Lesh cha vel y beaynnee lhieeney e laue: ny eshyn ta kiangley ny bunneeyn e oghrish;

English: 8 So that they who go by, say not so much as, The Lord prosper you : we wish you good lucke in the Name of the Lord.
Manx: 8 Myr shen nagh vel adsyn ta goll shiaghey wheesh as gra, Dy vannee yn Chiarn diu: aiyh mie diu ayns Ennym y Chiarn.
aiyh] 1819 aïgh

English: PSALM 130.
Manx: PSAL. 130.

English: De profundis. Psal. 130.
Manx: Psal. 130. De profundis.

English: Out of the deepe have I called unto thee (O Lord :) Lord heare my voyce.
Manx: 1 Veih’n diunid ta mee er n’eamagh hoods, O Hiarn: Hiarn, clasht rish my choraa.

English: 2 Oh let thine eares consider well : the voyce of my complaint.
Manx: 2 O lhig da dty chleayshyn geill y choyrt: da coraa m’accan.

English: 3 If thou Lord wilt bee extreme to marke what is done amisse : O Lord, who may abide it?
Manx: 3 My vees uss, Hiarn, gyere dy ghoaill tastey jeh nyn shaghrynys: O Hiarn, quoi oddys shassoo fo?

English: 4 For there is mercy with thee : therefore shalt thou be feared.
Manx: 4 Agh mârts ta myghin: shen‐y‐fa bee aggle er ny ghoaill royd.

English: 5 I looke for the Lord; my soule doeth waite for him : in his word is my trust.
Manx: 5 Ta mee jeeaghyn son y Chiarn, ta m’annym farkiaght er y hon: ayns e ghoo ta my hreishteil.

English: 6 My soule fleeth unto the Lord : before the morning watch, I say, before the morning watch.
Manx: 6 Ta my chree chea gys y Chiarn: roish arrey yn voghrey, ta mee gra, roish arrey yn voghrey.

English: 7 O Israel, trust in the Lord, for with the Lord there is mercy : and with him is plenteous redemption.
Manx: 7 O Israel, cur dty hreishteil ayns y Chiarn, son marish y Chiarn ta myghin: as mârishyn ta livrey‐ys niartal.

English: 8 And he shall redeeme Israel : from all his sinnes.
Manx: 8 As livrey‐ee eh Israel: veih ooilley e pheccaghyn.

English: Domine, non est. Psal. 131.
Manx: Psal. 131. Domine, non est.

English: Lord, I am not high minded : I have no proud lookes.
Manx: 1 Hiarn, cha vel mee ard-aignagh: cha vel aym shilley mooaralagh.

English: 2 I doe not exercise my selfe in great matters : which are to high for me.
Manx: 2 Cha vel mee goaill orrym dy loayrt jeh cooishyn mooarey: ta er-skyn roshtyn my hushtey.

English: 3 But I refraine my soule, and keepe it low, like as a childe that is weaned from his mother : yea, my soule is even as a weaned childe.
Manx: 3 Agh ta mee ginjillaghey m’annym, as freayll eh fo smaght, myr lhiannoo t’er ny harbaa veih e voir: dy-jarroo ta my annym myr lhiannoo charbaait.

English: 4 O Israel trust in the Lord : from this time foorth for evermore.
Manx: 4 O Israel, cur dty hreisht ayns y Chiarn: veih’n traa shoh magh er son dy-bragh.

English: The xxviii. day.
Manx: The 28. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Memento Domine. Psal. 132.
Manx: Psal. 132. Memento, Domine.

English: Lord, remember David : and all his trouble;
Manx: 1 Hiarn, cooinee er David: as ooilley e heaghyn.

English: 2 How he sware unto the Lord : and vowed a vowe unto the Almightie God of Jacob;
Manx: 2 Kys ren eh breearrey gys y Chiarn: as gialdyn casherick y yannoo da Jee Ooilley‐niartal Yacob.

English: 3 I will not come within the tabernacle of mine house : nor clime up into my bed;
Manx: 3 Cha jig‐yms fo clea my hie: cha-moo hem seose gys my lhiabbee;

English: 4 I will not suffer mine eyes to sleepe, nor mine eye lids to slumber : neither the temples of my head to take any rest;
Manx: 4 Cha der-ym cadley da my hooillyn, ny saveenagh da ferrooghyn my hooill: ny cuishlinyn my khing dy ghoaill veg y fea;

English: 5 Untill I finde out a place for the Temple of the Lord : an habitation for the mightie God of Jacob.
Manx: 5 Derrey yioym magh boayll son chiamble y Chiarn: ynnyd‐vaghee son Jee niartal Yacob.

English: 6 Loe, we heard of the same at Ephrata : and found it in the wood.
Manx: 6 Cur‐my‐ner, cheayll shin jeh ec Ephrata: as hooar shin eh ayns y cheyll.

English: 7 We will goe into his Tabernacle : and fall low on our knees before his footestoole.
Manx: 7 Hem mayd stiagh ayns y chabbane‐agglish echeysyn: as tuitt-ee mayd injil er nyn ghlioonyn kiongoyrt rish stoyl e choshey.
choshey] 1765, 1769 chosshey

English: 8 Arise, O Lord, into thy resting place : thou, and the Arke of thy strength.
Manx: 8 Trogg ort, O Hiarn, gys ynnyd dt’ea: uss, as arg dty niart.

English: 9 Let thy Priests bee clothed with righteousnesse : and let thy Saints sing with joyfulnesse.
Manx: 9 Lhig da dty haggyrtyn ’ve coamrit lesh cairys: as lhig da dty nooghyn kiaulleeaght ’yannoo lesh boggey.

English: 10 For thy servant Davids sake : turne not away the presence of thine Anointed.
Manx: 10 Er graih dty harvaant Ghavid: ny chyndaa ersooyl eddin dt’ Er-ooïllit.

English: 11 The Lord hath made a faithfull othe unto David : and he shall not shrinke from it;
Manx: 11 Ta’n Chiarn er n’yannoo breearrey firrinagh da David: as cha jed eh n’oi;

English: 12 Of the fruit of thy body : shall I set upon thy seate.
Manx: 12 Jeh mess dty chorp: nee’ms soiaghey er dty stoyl‐reeoil.

English: 13 If thy children will keepe my Covenant, and my Testimonies that I shall learne them : their children also shall sit upon thy seat for evermore.
Manx: 13 My nee dty chloan freayll my chonaant as my recortyssyn nee’ms gynsaghey daue: nee’n chloan ocsyn myrgeddin soie er dty stoyl‐reeoil er son dy-bragh.

English: 14 For the Lord hath chosen Sion to bee an habitation for himselfe : he hath longed for her.
Manx: 14 Son ta’n Chiarn er ghoaill Sion myr reih dy ve ynnyd‐vaghee da hene: t’eh er ghoaill taitnys ayn-jee.

English: 15 This shall be my rest for ever : here wil I dwell, for I have a delight therein.
Manx: 15 Shoh’n raad vee’m ec fea son dy-bragh: ayns shoh nee’m cummal, son ta mee goaill boggey ayn.

English: 16 I will blesse her vitailes with increase : and wil satisfie her poore with bread.
Manx: 16 Nee’m yn beaghey eck y vannaghey lesh bishagh: as nee’m ny boghtyn eck y yannoo magh lesh arran.

English: 17 I will decke her Priests with health : and her Saints shall rejoyce and sing.
Manx: 17 Ny saggyrtyn eck nee’m y chomm’rey lesh slaynt: as gow-ee ny nooghyn eck boggey lesh arraneyn‐moyllee.

English: 18 There shall I make the horne of David to flourish : I have ordeined a lanterne for mine anoynted.
Manx: 18 Shen y raad ver-ym er niart Ghavid dy vlaaghey: ta mee er n’oardaghey londeyr son my Er‐ooïllit.

English: 19 As for his enemies, I shall clothe them with shame : but upon himselfe shall his Crowne flourish.
Manx: 19 Er son e noidyn, nee’m adsyn y choodaghey lesh nearey: agh er hene nee’n attey echey cur magh blaa.

English: Ecce quàm bonum. Psal. 133.
Manx: Psal. 133.Ecce quam bonum!

English: Behold how good and joyful a thing it is : brethren to dwel together in unitie.
Manx: 1 Cur‐jee my‐ner, cre cha mie as eunyssagh te: vraaraghyn, dy vaghey cooidjagh ayns unnaneys.

English: 2 It is like the precious oyntment upon the head, that ranne downe unto the beard : even unto Aarons beard, and went downe to the skirts of his clothing.
Manx: 2 Te goll‐rish yn ooïll millish er y chione, roih sheese er yn aasaag: dy-jarroo er faasaag Aaron, as ren shilley sheese gys rumbyllyn e choamrey.
faasaag] 1765, 1769 phaasaag

English: 3 Like as the dew of Hermon : which fel upon the hil of Sion.
Manx: 3 Casley rish druight Hermon: huitt sheese er cronk Sion.

English: 4 For there the Lord promised his blessing : and life for evermore.
Manx: 4 Son ayns shen yiall y Chiarn e vannaght: as bea er son dy-bragh.

English: Ecce nunc. Psal. 134.
Manx: Psal. 134. Ecce nunc.

English: Behold (now) praise the Lord : all ye servants of the Lord;
Manx: 1 Cur‐jee my‐ner nish, moylley‐jee yn Chiarn: ooilley shiuish sharvaantyn y Chiarn;

English: 2 Ye that by night stand in the house of the Lord: even in the Courts of the house of our God.
Manx: 2 Shiuish ta ’syn oie shassoo [shirveish] ayns thie yn Chiarn: dy-jarroo ayns cooyrtyn thie yn Jee ain.

English: 3 Lift up your handes in the Sanctuary : and praise the Lord.
Manx: 3 Trogg‐jee seose nyn laueyn ayns yn ynnyd-casherick: as cur‐jee moylley da’n Chiarn.

English: 4 The Lord that made heaven and earth : give thee blessing out of Sion.
Manx: 4 Dy jean y Chiarn chroo niau as thalloo: bannaght y choyrt dhyts veih Sion.

English: Laudate Nomen. Psal. 135.
Manx: Psal. 135. Laudate nomen.

English: O praise the Lord, laude ye the Name of the Lord : praise it, O ye servants of the Lord;
Manx: 1 O moylley‐jee yn Chiarn, cur‐jee ard‐voylley da Ennym y Chiarn: jean‐jee eh y voylley, O shiuish shirveishee yn Chiarn;

English: 2 Ye that stand in the house of the Lord : in the Courts of the house of our God.
Manx: 2 Shiuish ta shassoo ayns thie yn Chiarn: ayns cooyrtyn thie yn Jee ain.

English: 3 O praise the Lord, for the Lord is gracious : O sing praises unto his Name, for it is lovely.
Manx: 3 O moylley‐jee yn Chiarn, son ta’n Chiarn graysoil: O trogg‐jee arraneyn‐moyllee gys yn Ennym echey, son te eunyssagh.

English: 4 For why? the Lord hath chosen Jacob unto himselfe : and Israel for his owne possession.
Manx: 4 As cre’n‐oyr? ta’n Chiarn er reih Jacob da hene: as Israel son e eiraght hene.

English: 5 For I know that the Lord is great : and that our Lord is above all gods.
Manx: 5 Son ta fys aym dy vel y Chiarn mooar: as dy vel y Chiarn ainyn er-skyn dy-chooilley yee.

English: 6 Whatsoever the Lord pleased, that did hee in heaven and in earth : and in the sea, and in all deepe places.
Manx: 6 Cre-erbee s’gooidsave lesh y Chiarn, shen ren eh ayns niau, as er y thalloo: ayns yn aarkey, as ayns ooilley ny diunidyn mooarey.

English: 7 Hee bringeth foorth the cloudes from the endes of the world : and sendeth foorth lightnings with the raine, bringing the winds out of his treasures.
Manx: 7 T’eh cur magh ny bodjallyn veih ardjyn sodjey magh y theihll: as cur magh ny tendeilyn-taarnee lesh y fliaghey, tayrn ny geayghyn magh ass e hashtaghyn.

English: 8 He smote the first borne of Egypt : both of man & beast.
Manx: 8 Woaill eh yn chied er-ny-ruggey ayns cheer Egypt: chammah dy gheiney as maase.

English: 9 Hee hath sent tokens & wonders into the mids of thee, O thou land of Egypt : upon Pharao and all his servants.
Manx: 9 T’eh er hoilshaghey cowraghyn as yindyssyn ayns y vean ayds, O heer Egypt: er Pharaoh as ooilley e vooinjer.

English: 10 He smote divers nations : and slew mighty Kings;
Manx: 10 Woaill eh ymmodee ashoonyn: as stroie eh reeaghyn niartal;
Woaill] 1777 Woaillee, 1819 Woaill

English: 11 Sehon king of the Amorites, and Og the king of Basan : and all the kingdomes of Chanaan;
Manx: 11 Sehon ree ny Amoriteyn, as Og ree Vasan: as ooilley reeriaghtyn Chanaan;

English: 12 And gave their land to be an heritage : even an heritage unto Israel his people.
Manx: 12 As hug eh yn cheer oc dy ve son eiraght: dy-jarroo son eiraght da Israel e phobble.

English: 13 Thy Name, O Lord, endureth for ever : so doeth thy memoriall, O Lord, from one generation to another.
Manx: 13 Ta dt’ Ennym, O Hiarn, farraghtyn son dy-bragh: as dty imraa myrgeddin, O Hiarn, veih sheeloghe gys sheeloghe.

English: 14 For the Lord will avenge his people : and be gracious unto his servants.
Manx: 14 Son gow-ee yn Chiarn cooilleeney son e phobble: as bee eh graysoil da e harvaantyn.

English: 15 As for the images of the heathen, they are but silver and gold : the worke of mens hands.
Manx: 15 Er son jallooyn ny ashoonyn, cha vel ad agh argid as airh: obbyr laueyn deiney;
ashoonyn] 1765, 1769 ashooyn

English: 16 They have mouthes, and speake not : eyes have they, but they see not.
Manx: 16 Ta beïll oc, as cha vel ad loayrt: ta sooillyn oc, agh cha vel ad fakin;

English: 17 They have eares, and yet they heare not : neither is there any breath in their mouthes.
Manx: 17 Ta cleayshyn oc, agh cha vel ad clashtyn: cha-moo ta veg yn ennal ayns nyn meeall.

English: 18 They that make them are like unto them : and so are all they that put their trust in them.
Manx: 18 T’adsyn ta jannoo ad casley roo: as myr shen t’adsyn ooilley ta cur nyn dreishteil ayndoo.

English: 19 Praise the Lord ye house of Israel : praise the Lord ye house of Aaron.
Manx: 19 Moylley‐jee yn Chiarn, shiuish hie Israel: moylley‐jee yn Chiarn, shiuish hie Aaron.

English: 20 Praise the Lord yee house of Levi : yee that feare the Lord, praise the Lord.
Manx: 20 Moylley‐jee yn Chiarn, shiuish hie Levi; shiuish ta goaill aggle roish y Chiarn, bannee‐jee yn Chiarn.

English: 21 Praised bee the Lord out of Sion : which dwelleth at Hierusalem.
Manx: 21 Bannit dy row yn Chiarn veih Sion: ta vaghey ec Jerusalem.

English: which] 1662 who
Manx: vaghey] 1769, 1777 cummal, 1819 baghey

English: The xxviii. day.
Manx: The 28. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Confitemini. Psal. 136.
Manx: Psal. 136. Confitemini.

English: O give thanks unto the Lord, for he is gracious : and his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 1 O cur‐jee booise da’n Chiarn, son t’eh graysoil: as ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 2 O give thanks unto the God of all gods : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 2 O cur‐jee booise da Jee dy-chooilley Yee: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 3 O thanke the Lord of all lords : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 3 O cur‐jee booise da Chiarn dy-chooilley Hiarn: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 4 Who onely doeth great wonders : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 4 Ta ny-lomarcan jannoo yindyssyn mooarey: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: Which] 1662 Who
5 Which by his excellent wisedome made the heavens : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 5 Ta liorish e chreenaght er-skyn‐earroo er chroo ny niaughyn: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: Which] 1662 Who
6 Which layde out the earth above the waters : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 6 Ren sheeyney magh yn thalloo er-skyn ny hushtaghyn: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: Which] 1662 Who
7 Which hath made great lights : for his mercy endureth for ever;
Manx: 7 Ren soilshaghyn mooarey y chroo: son ta e vyghyn farraghtyn son dy-bragh;

English: Which] 1662 Who
8 The Sunne to rule the day : for his mercy endureth for ever;
Manx: 8 Yn ghrian dy reill y laa: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh;

English: 9 The Moone and the starres to governe the night : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 9 Yn eayst as ny rollaagyn dy reill yn oie: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 10 Which smote Egypt with their first borne : for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 10 Ren Egypt as yn chied er-ny-ruggey oc y woalley: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh;

English: Which] 1662 Who
11 And brought out Israel from among them : for his mercy endureth for ever;
Manx: 11 As hug lesh Israel magh veih ny mast’ oc: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh;

English: 12 With a mighty hand, and stretched out arme : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 12 Lesh laue niartal as roih sheeynit magh: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 13 Which divided the red Sea in two parts : for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 13 Ren y faarkey Jiarg y rheynn ayns daa ayrn: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh;

English: Which] 1662 Who
14 And made Israel to goe thorow the middest of it: for his mercy endureth for ever.
Manx: 14 As ren Israel y leeideil trooid y vean echey: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 15 But as for Pharao and his hoste, he overthrew them in the red Sea : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 15 Agh er son Pharaoh as e heshaght‐caggee, ren eh adsyn y stroie ayns yn aarkey Jiarg: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 16 Which ledde his people thorow the wildernesse : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 16 Ren e phobble hene y leeideil trooid yn aasagh: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: Which] 1662 Who
17 Which smote great Kings : for his mercy endureth for ever;
Manx: 17 Ren reeaghyn pooaral y woalley: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh;

English: Which] 1662 Who
18 Yea, and slew mightie Kings : for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 18 As ren stroie reeaghyn niartal: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh;

English: 19 Sehon King of the Amorites : for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 19 Sehon ree ny Amoriteyn: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 20 And Og the King of Basan : for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 20 As Og ree Vasan: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh;

English: 21 And gave away their land for an heritage : for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 21 As hug ersooyl yn cheer oc son eiraght: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh;

English: 22 Even for an heritage unto Israel his servant : for his mercy endureth for ever.
Manx: 22 Dy-jarroo son eiraght da Israel e harvaant: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 23 Which remembred us when wee were in trouble: for his mercie endureth for ever;
Manx: 23 Ren cooinaghtyn orrin tra va shin ayns seaghyn: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: Which] 1662 Who
24 And hath delivered us from our enemies : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 24 As ta er livrey shin veih nyn noidyn: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 25 Which giveth food to all flesh : for his mercy endureth for ever.
Manx: 25 Ta coyrt beaghey da dy-chooilley eill: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: Which] 1662 Who
26 O give thankes unto the God of heaven : for his mercy endureth for ever.
Manx: 26 O cur‐jee booise da Jee ny niaughyn: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: 27 O give thankes unto the Lord of lords : for his mercie endureth for ever.
Manx: 27 O cur‐jee booise da’n Chiarn dy hiarnyn: son ta e vyghin farraghtyn son dy-bragh.

English: Super flumina. Psal. 137.
Manx: Psal. 137. Super flumina.

English: By the waters of Babylon wee sate downe & wept : when we remembered (thee) O Sion.
Manx: 1 Liorish awinyn Vabylon hoie shin sheese as cheayn shin: tra ren shin smooinaghtyn orts, O Sion.

English: 2 As for our harpes, wee hanged them up : upon the trees that are therein.
Manx: 2 Er son ny claasaghyn ain, chrogh shin ad seose: er ny biljyn ta ayns shen.

English: 3 For they that led us away captive, required of us then a song and melodie in our heavinesse : Sing us one of the songs of Sion.
Manx: 3 Son adsyn ren shin y leeideil ayns cappeeys, hirr ad orrin arrane, as bingys ayns nyn drimshey: Gow‐jee dooin unnane dy arraneyn Sion.

English: 4 How shall we sing the Lords song : in a strange lande?
Manx: 4 Kys oddys mayd arrane y Chiarn y ghoaill: ayns cheer yoarree?

English: 5 If I forget thee, O Hierusalem : let my right hand forget her cunning.
Manx: 5 My yarrood‐yms uss O Yerusalem: lhig da my laue yesh jarrood e slheïe.

English: 6 If I do not remember thee, let my tongue cleave to the roofe of my mouth : yea, if I preferre not Hierusalem in my mirth.
Manx: 6 Mannagh gooin‐yms orts, lhig da my hengey lhiantyn gys clea my veeall: dy-jarroo, mannagh vel mee soiaghey jeh Jerusalem er-skyn dy-chooilley voggey elley.
clea] 1769, 1777 druntyn

English: 7 Remember the children of Edom, O Lord, in the day of Hierusalem : how they said, Downe with it, downe with it, even to the ground.
Manx: 7 Cooinee er cloan Edom, O Hiarn, ayns laa Yerusalem: kys dooyrt ad, Sheese lesh, sheese lesh, corrym rish y thalloo.
ad, Sheese] 1765, 1769 ad, Sheesh

English: 8 O daughter of Babylon, wasted with misery : yea, happie shall he be that rewardeth thee as thou hast served us.
Manx: 8 O inneen Vabylon, kiarit son toyrt‐mow: s’maynrey vees y dooinney nee uss y chooilleeney myr t’ow er hirveish shinyn.

English: 9 Blessed shall he be that taketh thy children : and throweth them against the stones.
Manx: 9 Bannit vees eshyn ghoys dty chloan: as hilgys ad noi ny claghyn.

English: Confitebor tibi. Psal. 138.
Manx: Psal. 138. Confitebor tibi.

English: I wil give thanks unto thee, O Lord, with my whole heart : even before the gods will I sing praise unto thee.
Manx: 1 Ver-ym booise dhyt, O Hiarn, lesh ooilley my chree: dy-jarroo fenish ny ainleyn goym arraneyn‐moyllee hoods.

English: 2 I wil worship toward thy holy Temple, & praise thy Name, because of thy loving kindnesse and trueth : for thou hast magnified thy Name and thy word above all things.
Manx: 2 Nee’m ooashley ’choyrt kiongoyrt rish dty hiamble casherick, as dt’ Ennym y voylley, er coontey dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh as dt’ynrickys: son t’ow er ghloyraghey dt’ Ennym as dty Ghoo er-skyn dy-chooilley nhee.

English: 3 When I called upon thee, thou heardest mee : and enduedst my soule with much strength.
Manx: 3 Tra deïe mee ort, ren oo m’y chlashtyn: as m’annym y chomm’rey lesh mooarane niart.

English: 4 All the Kings of the earth shall praise thee, O Lord : for they have heard the words of thy mouth.
Manx: 4 Nee ooilley reeaghyn y thallooin uss y voylley, O Hiarn: son t’ad er chlashtyn goan dty veeall;

English: 5 Yea, they shall sing in the wayes of the Lord : that great is the glory of the Lord.
Manx: 5 Dy-jarroo, gow‐ee ad arraneyn ayns raaidyn y Chiarn: Dy vel gloyr y Chiarn mooar.

English: 6 For though the Lord be high, yet hath he respect unto the lowly : as for the proud, he beholdeth them afarre off.
Manx: 6 Son ga dy vel y Chiarn ard, ny‐yeih t’eh coyrt tastey da’n sleih imlee: agh er son ny mooaralee t’eh jeeaghyn orroo foddey veih.

English: 7 Though I walke in the mids of trouble, yet shalt thou refresh me : thou shalt stretch foorth thy hand upon the furiousnesse of mine enemies, and thy right hand shall save mee.
Manx: 7 Ga dy vel mee shooyll ayns mean seaghyn, ny‐yeih nee oo m’y ooraghey: sheeyn‐ee oo magh dty laue er eulys my noidyn, as nee dty laue yesh mish y hauail.

English: 8 The Lord shal make good his loving-kindnes toward me : yea, thy mercie, O Lord, endureth for ever; despise not then the workes of thine owne hands.
Manx: 8 Nee’n Chiarn e chenjallys‐ghraihagh y yannoo mie dooys: ta dty vyghin, O Hiarn, farraghtyn son dy-bragh; ny jean beg y hoiaghey eisht jeh obbyr dty laueyn hene.

English: The xxix. day.
Manx: The 29. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Domine probasti. Psal. 139.
Manx: Psal. 139. Domine, probâsti.

English: O Lord, thou hast searched mee out, and knowen me : thou knowest my downe sitting and mine uprising, thou understandest my thoughts long before.
Manx: 1 O Hiarn, t’ow er my ronsaghey magh, as er my hoiggal: shione dhyts my hoie‐sheese, as my irree‐seose; t’ow toiggal my smooinaghtyn foddey ro‐laue.

English: 2 Thou art about my path, and about my bedde : and spiest out all my wayes.
Manx: 2 T’ow uss mygeayrt my chassan, as mygeayrt my lhiabbee: as fakin ooilley my raaidyn.

English: 3 For loe, there is not a word in my tongue : but thou, O Lord, knowest it altogether.
Manx: 3 Son cur‐my‐ner, cha vel fockle er my hengey: nagh vel uss, O Hiarn, dy-slane toiggal.

English: 4 Thou hast fashioned me behinde and before : and layd thine hand upon me.
Manx: 4 T’ow uss er my chummey cheu-chooylloo, as cheu-veealloo: as er choyrt dty laue orrym.

English: 5 Such knowledge is too wonderfull and excellent for me : I cannot attaine unto it.
Manx: 5 Dy hoiggal shoh, te ro yindyssagh as ro ard er my hon: cha voddym roshtyn huggey.

English: 6 Whither shal I goe then from thy Spirit : or whither shall I goe then from thy presence?
Manx: 6 C’raad eisht nee’m chea veih dty Spyrryd: ny c’raad nee’m cosney veih dt’enish?

English: 7 If I clime up into heaven, thou art there : if I goe downe to hell, thou art there also.
Manx: 7 My hem seose gys niau, t’ow ayns shen: my hem sheese gys niurin, t’ow ayns shen myrgeddin.

English: 8 If I take the wings of the morning : and remaine in the uttermost parts of the Sea;
Manx: 8 My ghoym skainyn y voghrey: as tannaghtyn ayns ny ardjyn sodjey magh d’yn aarkey;

English: 9 Even there also shall thy hand leade me : and thy right hand shall hold me.
Manx: 9 Dy-jarroo ayns shen myrgeddin nee dty laue m’y leeideil: as nee dty laue yesh m’y niartaghey.

English: 10 If I say, Peradventure the darknesse shall cover me : then shall my night be turned to day.
Manx: 10 My jirr-ym, Foddee dy jean y dorraghys m’y choodaghey: eisht bee m’oie er ny hyndaa gys soilshey yn laa.

English: 11 Yea, the darkenesse is no darkenesse with thee, but the night is as cleare as the day : the darknesse and light (to thee) are both alike.
Manx: 11 Dy-jarroo, cha vel y dorraghys dorraghey mârts, agh ta’n oie cha sollys as y laa: ta’n dorraghys as y soilshey dhyts co‐laik.

English: 12 For my reines are thine : thou hast covered mee in my mothers wombe.
Manx: 12 Son lhiats my challin: t’ow er my choodaghey ayns breïn my vayrey.

English: 13 I will give thankes unto thee, for I am fearefully and wonderfully made : marveilous are thy works, and that my soule knoweth right well.
Manx: 13 Ver-ym booise dhyt, son ta mee dy-atchimagh as dy-yindyssagh er my chroo: mirrillagh ta dt’obbraghyn, as s’mie ta m’annym’s dy hoiggal shen.

English: 14 My bones are not hid from thee : though I bee made secretly, and fashioned beneath in the earth.
Manx: 14 Cha vel my chraueyn er ny cheiltyn voïds: ga dy row mee jeant dy-follit, as er my chummey heese er y thalloo.

English: 15 Thine eyes did see my substance, yet being unperfect : and in thy booke were all my members written;
Manx: 15 Honnick dty hooillyn yn stoo ayms, tra ve foast gyn cummey: as ayns dty lioar va ooilley my oltyn scruit;

English: 16 Which day by day were fashioned : when as yet there was none of them.
Manx: 16 Va laa lurg laa er nyn gummey: tra nagh row ad foast er jeet rish.

English: 17 How deare are thy counsels unto me, O God : O how great is the summe of them!
Manx: 17 O cre cha deyr ta dty choyrlyn dooys, O Yee: O cre wheesh ta’n symm oc!

English: 18 If I tell them, they are moe in number then the sand : when I wake up, I am present with thee.
Manx: 18 My hem dy choontey ad, t’ad ny smoo ayns earroo n’yn gheinnagh: tra ta mee doostey ass my chadley, ta mee ayns dt’enish.

English: 19 Wilt thou not slay the wicked, O God : depart from me, ye bloodthirstie men.
Manx: 19 Nagh jean oo stroie ny drogh‐yantee, O Yee: immee‐jee ass m’enish, shiuish gheiney foalley.
foalley] 1769, 1777 fuilltagh

English: 20 For they speake unrighteously against thee : and thine enemies take thy Name in vaine.
Manx: 20 Son t’ad loayrt dy-mee‐chairagh dt’oï: as ta dty noidyn goaill dt’ Ennym ayns fardail.

English: 21 Doe not I hate them, O Lord, that hate thee : and am not I grieved with those that rise up against thee?
Manx: 21 Nagh vel dwoaie aym orroosyn, O Hiarn, ta dwoaie oc orts: as nagh vel mee corree roosyn ta girree magh dt’oï?

English: 22 Yea, I hate them right sore : even as though they were mine enemies.
Manx: 22 Dy-jarroo ta slane dwoaie aym orroo: myr dy beagh ad my eer noidyn.

English: 23 Trie me, O God, and seeke the ground of my heart : prove me, and examine my thoughts.
Manx: 23 Prow mee, O Yee, as ronsee grunt my chree: jean m’y hirrey magh, as feysht my smooinaghtyn.

English: 24 Looke well if there be any way of wickednesse in me : and leade me in the way everlasting.
Manx: 24 Jeeagh my ta mee ayns raad erbee dy olkys: as leeid mee gys raad yn vea dy-bragh farraghtyn.

English: Eripe me, Domine. Psal. 140.
Manx: Psal. 140. Eripe me, Domine.

English: Deliver me, O Lord, from the evil man : and preserve me from the wicked man;
Manx: 1 Livrey mee, O Hiarn, veih’n drogh ghooinney: as freill mee veih’n dooinney dewil;

English: wicked man] 1599 wicked men
2 Which imagine mischiefe in their hearts : and stirre up strife all the day long.
Manx: 2 Ta smooinaghtyn er olk ayns nyn greeaghyn: as dy-kinjagh greesaghey seose anvea.

English: Which] 1662 Who
3 They have sharpened their tongues like a serpent : adders poison is under their lips.
Manx: 3 T’ad er slhieu nyn jengaghyn myr ard‐nieu: ta pyshoon yn adder fo nyn meillyn.

English: 4 Keepe me, O Lord, from the handes of the ungodly : preserve mee from the wicked men, which are purposed to overthrow my goings.
Manx: 4 Freill mee, O Hiarn, veih laueyn ny mee‐chrauee: jean m’y choadey veih ny tranlaasee, ta kiarit dy my hilgey harrish ayns my raaidyn.

English: which] 1662 who
5 The proud have layd a snare for mee, and spread a net abroad with cords : yea, and set traps in my way.
Manx: 5 Ta ny mooaralee er hoiaghey ribbeh er my hon, as er skeayley magh lieen dy-lhean lesh coyrdyn: dy-jarroo t’ad er hoiaghey trappyn ayns my raad.

English: 6 I saide unto the Lord, Thou art my God : heare the voyce of my prayers, O Lord.
Manx: 6 Dooyrt mee rish y Chiarn, She uss my Yee: eaisht rish coraa my phadjeryn, O Hiarn.

English: 7 O Lord God, thou strength of my health : thou hast covered my head in the day of battell.
Manx: 7 O Hiarn Yee, uss niart my ’lhaynt: t’ow er choodaghey my chione ayns laa yn chaggey.

English: 8 Let not the ungodly have his desire, O Lord : let not his mischievous imagination prosper, lest they be too proude.
Manx: 8 Ny lhig da’n dooinney mee‐chrauee cooilleen‐aigney ’gheddyn orrym, O Hiarn: ny lhig da ny saaseyn aggairagh echey goaill toshiaght, nagh bee ad ro voyrnagh.

English: 9 Let the mischiefe of their owne lips fall upon the head of them : that compasse me about.
Manx: 9 Lhig da olkys nyn meillyn hene tuittym er y chione ocsyn: ta dy my hionney stiagh er dy-chooilley cheu.

English: 10 Let hot burning coales fal upon them : let them be cast into the fire and into the pit, that they never rise up againe.
Manx: 10 Lhig da smaraagyn jiarg losht tuittym orroo: lhig daue ve tilgit ayns yn aile, as ayns ny ooigyn dowiney, nagh nirree ad reesht dy-bragh.

English: 11 A man full of wordes shall not prosper upon the earth : evill shall hunt the wicked person to overthrow him.
Manx: 11 Cha jig y feanish foalsey er y hoshiaght er y thalloo: nee olk yn dooinney tranlaasagh y helg gys e hoyrt‐mow.

English: 12 Sure I am that the Lord will avenge the poore : and maintaine the cause of the helplesse.
Manx: 12 Shickyr ta mee dy jean y Chiarn cooilleeney ’ghoaill ayns lieh’n voght: as dy gum eh seose cooish yn ymmyrchagh.

English: 13 The righteous also shall give thanks unto thy Name : and the just shall continue in thy sight.
Manx: 13 Ver y dooinney ynrick myrgeddin booise da dt’ Ennym: as nee’n er‐cairagh tannaghtyn ayns dty hilley.

English: Domine, clamaui. Psal. 141.
Manx: Psal. 141. Domine, clamavi.

English: Lord, I call upon thee, haste thee unto me : and consider my voyce, when I cry unto thee.
Manx: 1 Hiarn, ta mee geamagh ort, jean siyr hym: as cur geill da my choraa, tra ta mee jannoo m’accan hood.

English: 2 Let my prayer be set forth in thy sight as the Incense : and let the lifting up of my hands be an evening sacrifice.
Manx: 2 Lhig da my phadjer v’er ny hebbal ayns dt’enish myr yn incense: as lhig da troggal seose my laueyn ’ve myr oural yn astyr.

English: 3 Set a watch, O Lord, before my mouth : and keep the doore of my lips.
Manx: 3 Soie arrey, O Hiarn, roish my veeall: as freill dorrys my veillyn.

English: 4 O let not mine heart be inclined to any evill thing : let mee not bee occupied in ungodly workes, with the men that worke wickednes, lest I eat of such things as please them.
Manx: 4 O ny lhig da my chree ve er ny loobey gys drogh obbyr erbee: ny lhig dou raad y choyrt dou hene ayns cliaghtaghyn mee‐chrauee, mâroosyn ta gobbraghey olk; er aggle dy goym commee jeh ny t’ad goaill taitnys ayn.

English: 5 Let the righteous rather smite mee friendly : and reprove me.
Manx: 5 Ny-sleaie lhig da deiney mie m’y cherraghey ayns aigney mie: as oghsan y choyrt dou.

English: 6 But let not their precious balmes breake my head: yea, I will pray yet against their wickednesse.
Manx: 6 As bee shoh myr ooïll slayntoil, nagh brish my chione: nee’m padjer foast y ghoaill noi’n olkys oc.

English: 7 Let their Judges bee overthrowen in stonie places: that they may heare my words, for they are sweete.
Manx: 7 Lhig da ny briwnyn oc cherraghtyn ayns ynnydyn claghagh: dy vod ad clashtyn my ghoan, son t’ad millish.

English: 8 Our bones lie scattered before the pit : like as when one breaketh and heweth wood upon the earth.[276]
Manx: 8 Ta ny craueyn ain ny lhie skeaylt er beeall yn oaie: ’naght myr ta fer brishey as scoltey feiyh er y thalloo.
feiyh] 1777 fuygh

English: 9 But mine eyes looke unto thee, O Lord God : in thee is my trust, O cast not out my soule.
Manx: 9 Agh ta my hooillyn jeeaghyn hoods, O Hiarn Yee: ayn-yds ta my hreishteil, O ny jean m’annym y hreigeil.

English: 10 Keepe mee from the snare that they have laid for mee : and from the traps of the wicked doers.
Manx: 10 Freill mee veih’n ribbeh t’ad er hoiaghey er my hon: as voish geulaghyn ny drogh‐yantee.

English: 11 Let the ungodly fall into their owne nets together : and let me ever escape them.
Manx: 11 Lhig da ny mee‐chrauee tuittym lesh‐y‐chielley ayns ny ribbaghyn oc hene: as lhig dooys dy-bragh ad y haghney.

English: The xxix. day.
Manx: The 29. day.

English: Evening prayer.
Manx: EVENING PRAYER.

English: Voce mea ad Dominum. Psal. 142.
Manx: Psal. 142. Voce mea ad Dominum.

English: I cryed unto the Lord with my voice : yea, even unto the Lord did I make my supplication.
Manx: 1 Hrogg mee seose my choraa gys y Chiarn: dy-jarroo, gys y Chiarn ren mee my aghin.

English: 2 I powred out my complaints before him : and shewed him of my trouble.
Manx: 2 Gheayrt mee magh my accan kiongoyrt rish: as hoilshee mee da my heaghyn.

English: 3 When my spirit was in heavinesse, thou knewest my path : in the way wherein I walked, have they privily laid a snare for me.
Manx: 3 Tra va my spyrryd ayns trimshey, va sooill ayd er my chassan: ayns y raad va mee shooyll t’ad dy-follit er hoiaghey ribbeh er my hon.

English: 4 I looked also upon my right hand : and saw there was no man that would know me.
Manx: 4 Yeeagh mee myrgeddin er my laue yesh: as honnick mee nagh row fer erbee yinnagh goaill rhym.

English: 5 I had no place to flee unto : and no man cared for my soule.
Manx: 5 Cha row ynnyd erbee aym dy chea huggey son sauchys: as cha row dooinney erbee ren scansh jeh my vioys.

English: 6 I cried unto thee, O Lord, and said : Thou art my hope and my portion in the land of the living.
Manx: 6 Deïe mee hoods, O Hiarn, as dooyrt mee: Uss my hreishteil as my eiraght ayns cheer y sleih bio.

English: 7 Consider my complaint : for I am brought very lowe.
Manx: 7 Cur geill da m’accan: son dy-injil ta mee er duittym.

English: 8 O deliver mee from my persecutors : for they are too strong for me.
Manx: 8 O livrey mee veih my hranlaasee: son t’ad ro lajer er my hon.

English: 9 Bring my soule out of prison, that I may give thanks unto thy Name : which thing if thou wilt graunt me, then shall the righteous resort unto my companie.
Manx: 9 Livrey m’annym ass pryssoon, dy voddym booise y choyrt da dt’ Ennym: as shoh my ver oo dou, eisht nee deiney crauee thaaghey my heshaght.

English: Domine exaudi. Psal. 143.
Manx: Psal. 143. Domine, exaudi.

English: Heare my prayer, O Lord, and consider my desire : hearken unto me for thy trueth and righteousnesse sake.
Manx: 1 Eaisht rish my phadjer, O Hiarn, as cur geill da my yeearree: cur clashtyn dou er graih dty ynrickys as dty chairys;

English: 2 And enter not into judgement with thy servant: for in thy sight shall no man living be justified.
Manx: 2 As ny gow er dty hoshiaght gys briwnys rish dty harvaant: son ayns dty hilley’s cha bee dooinney erbee bio er ny heyrey.

English: 3 For the enemie hath persecuted my soule; hee hath smitten my life downe to the ground : hee hath layd me in the darkenesse, as the men that have bene long dead.
Manx: 3 Son ta’n noid er n’yannoo tranlaase er m’annym; t’eh er woalley sheese my vioys gys y thalloo: t’eh er m’eiyrt gys y dorraghys, goll roosyn ta er ve foddey marroo.

English: 4 Therefore is my spirit vexed within mee : and my heart within me is desolate.
Manx: 4 Shen‐y‐fa ta my spyrryd seaghnit ayn-ym: as ta my chree brisht cheu‐sthie jee’m.

English: 5 Yet doe I remember the time past; I muse upon all thy workes : yea, I exercise my selfe in the workes of thy hands.
Manx: 5 Agh foast ta mee cooinaghtyn er y traa t’er n’gholl shiaghey; ta mee smooinaghtyn dy-dowin er ooilley dty obbraghyn: ta mee dy-jarroo baarail mee hene ayns obbraghyn dty laueyn.

English: 6 I stretch foorth my hands unto thee : my soule gaspeth unto thee as a thirstie land.
Manx: 6 Ta mee sheeyney magh my laueyn hoods: ta m’annym mennuigh er dty hon myr thalloo sponkit.
mennuigh] 1769, 1777 paagh; sponkit] 1769, 1777 chirrym

English: 7 Heare me, O Lorde, and that soone, for my spirite waxeth faint : hide not thy face from mee, least I bee like unto them that goe downe into the pit.
Manx: 7 Eaisht rhym, O Hiarn, as shen dy-leah, son ta my spyrryd gannooinaghey: ny follee voym dt’eddin, nagh bee’m casley roosyn ta goll sheese ayns yn oaie.

English: 8 O let mee heare thy loving kindnesse betimes in the morning, for in thee is my trust : shewe thou mee the way that I should walke in, for I lift up my soule unto thee.
Manx: 8 O lhig dou clashtyn dty chenjallys‐ghraihagh leah ’sy voghrey, son ayn-yds ta my hreishteil: jeeagh dou yn raad ayn lhisin gimmeeaght, son hoods ta mee troggal seose m’annym.

English: 9 Deliver me, O Lord, from mine enemies : for I flee unto thee to hide me.
Manx: 9 Livrey mee, O Hiarn, veih my noidyn: son hoods ta mee chea dy my choadey.

English: 10 Teache me to doe the thing that pleaseth thee, for thou art my God : let thy loving Spirit leade me foorth into the land of righteousnesse.
Manx: 10 Ynsee dou dy yannoo dtˈaigney, son she uss my Yee: lhig da dty Spyrryd graihagh mish y leeideil gys y cheer dy chairys.

English: 11 Quicken me, O Lorde, for thy Names sake : and for thy righteousnesse sake, bring my soule out of trouble.
Manx: 11 Niartee lhiam, O Hiarn, er graih dt’ Ennym: as er graih dty ynrickys, jean m’annym y reaghey ass seaghyn.
lhiam] 1769, 1777 mee

English: 12 And of thy goodnesse slay mine enemies : and destroy all them that vexe my soule; for I am thy servant.
Manx: 12 As jeh dty vieys giare sheese my noidyn: as stroie adsyn ooilley ta jannoo tranlaase er m’annym, son mish dty harvaant.

English: The xxx. day.
Manx: The 30. day.

English: Morning prayer.
Manx: MORNING PRAYER.

English: Benedictus Dominus. Psal. 144.
Manx: Psal. 144. Benedictus Dominus.

English: Blessed be the Lord my strength : which teacheth my handes to warre, and my fingers to fight;
Manx: 1 Bannit dy row yn Chiarn my niart: ta gynsaghey my laueyn dy chaggey, as my veïr dy ghleck;

English: which] 1662 who
2 My hope and my fortresse, my castle and deliverer, my defender, in whom I trust : which subdueth my people that is under me.
Manx: 2 My varrant as my hoor lajer, my chashtal as m’er-livreyee, my endeilagh ayn ta mee treishteil: ta smaghtaghey yn pobble ta fo my reill.

English: which] 1662 who
3 Lorde, what is man, that thou hast such respect unto him : or the sonne of man, that thou so regardest him?
Manx: 3 Hiarn, cre ta dooinney, dy vel oo coyrt lheid y gheill da: ny mac dooinney, dy vel oo jannoo wheesh jeh?

English: 4 Man is like a thing of nought : his time passeth away like a shadow.
Manx: 4 Cha vel dooinney agh myr red gyn veg: ta e hraa goll shiaghey myr y scaadoo.

English: 5 Bowe the heavens, O Lord, and come downe : touche the mountaines, and they shall smoke.
Manx: 5 Cromm dty niaughyn, O Hiarn, as tarr neose: benn rish ny sleïtyn, as bee ad ayns jaagh.

English: the heavens] 1662 thy heavens
6 Cast foorth thy lightning, and teare them : shoote out thine arrowes, and consume them.
Manx: 6 Tilg magh dty hendeilyn as skeayll ad: lhig magh dty hideyn, as stroie ad.

English: 7 Send downe thine hand from above : deliver me, and take me out of the great waters, from the hand of strange children;
Manx: 7 Sheeyn magh dty laue veih’n yrjid: livrey mee, as saue mee veih ny hushtaghyn mooarey, veih laue cloan yoarree;

English: 8 Whose mouth talketh of vanitie : and their right hand is a right hand of wickednesse.
Manx: 8 Yn beeall oc ta loayrt dy-foalsey: as ta’n laue yesh oc laue yesh dy volteyrys.

English: 9 I wil sing a new song unto thee, O God : and sing praises unto thee upon a ten stringed Lute.
Manx: 9 Goyms arrane‐moyllee noa hoods, O Yee: as hoods nee’m kiaulleeaght er lute dy yeih strengyn.

English: 10 Thou hast given victorie unto Kings : and hast delivered David thy servant from the peril of the sword.
Manx: 10 T’ow uss er choyrt barriaght da reeaghyn: as er livrey David dty harvaant veih gaue yn chliwe.

English: 11 Save me, and deliver me from the hand of strange children : whose mouth talketh of vanitie, and their right hand is a right hand of iniquitie.
Manx: 11 Saue as livrey mee veih laue cloan yoarree: yn beeall oc ta loayrt dy-foalsey, as ta’n laue yesh oc laue yesh dy volteyrys.

English: 12 That our sonnes may growe up as the yong plants : and that our daughters may bee as the polished corners of the Temple.
Manx: 12 Dy vod ny mec ainyn gaase seose myr ny biljyn aegey: as dy vod ny inneenyn ain ’ve myr corneilyn aalin y chiamble;

English: 13 That our garners may bee full and plenteous with all manner of store : that our sheepe may bring foorth thousands and ten thousands in our streets.
Manx: 13 Dy vod ny thieyn‐tashtee ain ’ve laane, as jeant magh dy-palchey lesh dy-chooilley sorch dy stoyr: dy vod ny kirree ain bishaghey gys thousaneyn as jeih thousaneyn ayns nyn oayll;

English: 14 That our oxen may be strong to labour, that there bee no decay : no leading into captivitie, and no complayning in our streets.
Manx: 14 Dy vod ny dew ain ’ve lajer son obbyr, nagh bee assee erbee: ny veg y chappeeys, ny oyr gaccan ayns nyn straaidyn.

English: 15 Happie are the people that be in such a case : yea, blessed are the people which have the Lord for their God.
Manx: 15 S’maynrey yn pobble ta ’sy stayd shoh: dy-jarroo, bannit ta’n pobble ta’n Chiarn oc son nyn Yee.

English: people that be] 1662 people that are; people which] 1662 people who
Exaltabo te Deus. Psal. 145.
Manx: Psal. 145. Exaltabo te, Deus.

English: I will magnifie thee, O God, my King : and I wil praise thy Name for ever and ever.
Manx: 1 Ver-yms ard‐voylley dhyt, O Yee my Ree: as nee’ms dty Ennym y vannaghey son dy-bragh as dy-bragh.

English: 2 Every day will I give thankes unto thee : and praise thy Name for ever and ever.
Manx: 2 Dy-chooilley laa ver-ym booise dhyt: as dt’ Ennym y ghloyraghey son dy-bragh as dy-bragh.
